fields.headline: FA top brass back Crozier
fields.trailText: Top Football Association officials yesterday threw their weight behind Adam Crozier after a week of controversy involving the chief executive.
fields.body:
Top Football Association officials yesterday threw their weight behind Adam Crozier after a week of controversy involving the chief executive.

Crozier has been heavily criticied for his role in the Wembley stadium crisis, in which the FA pulled out of underwriting the cost of the £700m project. Particularly controversial was his letter to the government asking for money towards rebuilding the stadium and suggesting that such assistance could be kept "under wraps" until after the general election on June 7.

This, and reports of an after-dinner speech where he branded the former FA management "a shambles", were followed by revelations yesterday that he had been given a £100,000 pay rise, taking his salary to £400,000 a year, plus a £100,000 bonus.

In a statement yesterday the FA's chairman Geoff Thompson said: "A remuneration subcommittee had the responsibility of deciding the chief executive's salary and did so. Their decision was presented to the FA board on February 15, where the report was received and noted."

The FA also moved to deny that Frank Pattison, who with David Dein is one of the two vice-chairmen responsible for Crozier's salary, had been "appalled" at the rise, and that the Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore was originally first choice to replace Graham Kelly as chief executive.

Pattison said: "I was fully consulted on the issue of the chief executive's salary in line with the requirements of the board. I personally presented the recommendation to the board. I am deeply dismayed that a newspaper should infer there was any dissent."

The FA insisted Scudamore was never shortlisted. Thompson insisted: "Adam Crozier was our first choice."

Thompson also denied that there was anything wrong with Crozier's letter to the government regarding Wembley. "To suggest the FA's chief executive had somehow done something underhand is outrageous and untrue."

Fifa has refused to reschedule the Scotland captain Colin Hendry's appeal against a six-match international ban to enable him to be free to play for Bolton in a play-off game. His case will be heard a week tomorrow, the day Bolton play their second leg against West Bromwich.

The 35-year-old Scottish defender has said he will travel to Switzerland to make a personal plea to the disciplinary committee. But Fifa confirmed the clash of dates. A spokesman said: "We have several cases to deal with, not just Colin Hendry's. It is up to him to decide whether he wants to play or attend."

fields.headline: Allison admits alcoholism
fields.trailText: Malcolm Allison has been admitted to hospital suffering from a broken collarbone and alcoholism.
fields.body:
Malcolm Allison watched Manchester City drop out of the Premiership from a hospital bed. He is in Wythenshawe Hospital suffering from a broken collarbone and alcoholism.

"Just tell people I'm in a bad way," he said yesterday. "But I hope to be out of here sooner rather than later."

The 73-year-old former Manchester City manager was taken to hospital after a fall near his warden-controlled home at Hale, Cheshire.

"He is very ill but he has accepted for the first time he is an alcoholic," his son Mark told the Manchester Evening News. "Previously he's been to AA and has been in the Priory, But he has never actually accepted what his biggest problem is. Now he hopes the doctors can arrange for him to be admitted to a clinic."

Allison took a turn for the worse after breaking up with his long-term partner Lynn. This month he admitted that he had contemplated suicide.

According to the Evening News, he had spent part of the evening before his fall in a pub with his girlfriend Diane. "He has his off days and is in a lot of pain," she said. "I couldn't believe it when I found out he was back in hospital."

Allison, a former West Ham defender who retired early with an ankle injury that still bothers him, joined City in 1965 after impressing their manager Joe Mercer while on a course at Lilleshall. He was City's coach when they won the league championship in 1968, the FA Cup in 1969 and the European Cup Winners' Cup in 1970, then had two spells as their manager, both more or less calamitous.

In his second spell, in 1979-80, he brought in a Dutch style, a Yugoslav captain who could not speak English and a series of players who proved unworthy of their huge transfer fees.

He also managed Crystal Palace twice, Plymouth Argyle twice and Middlesbrough, maintaining a high profile for more than 20 years with his flair for publicity, flamboyant lifestyle and trenchant opinions, many of which were unflattering to English football and footballers.

He now co-hosts a Saturday afternoon phone-in on local radio with the former Manchester United manager Tommy Docherty.

"He can't do anything on the after-dinner speaking circuit because they are drink-associated," Mark Allison said.

"He still has a lot to offer soccer but he does suffer from loneliness. If he goes into a pub someone there will buy him a drink and then they get one of his great stories."

fields.headline: Reds suffer bout of the Blues
fields.trailText: Liverpool missed the chance to secure a Champions League while Chelsea did little to improve their hopes of gaining a Uefa Cup place.
fields.body:
The road to Europe led Liverpool down a cul-de-sac and Chelsea towards no-man's-land last night. While Gérard Houllier's side will reflect on a missed opportunity to secure Champions League status, Claudio Ranieri's improving team must be consumed by the fear that a place in next season's Uefa Cup could be snatched from their grasp.

So near, and yet so far. It was an absorbing night on Merseyside, tense and exhilarating stuff, but there could be no disguising the anticlimax blanketing Anfield after a result that means both sides face an uneasy finale to their campaigns. Liverpool, in particular, will feel rueful after twice taking the lead through Michael Owen and squandering the chance to see off Leeds and Ipswich in the pursuit of a Champions League place.

If they are to be elevated to Europe's most demanding arena, however, they will have to toughen up. Their glass jaw was exposed by Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink with a predatory double of his own as Chelsea, displaying a confidence rarely evident on their travels this season, strove for the victory that would have ensured a Uefa Cup berth.

It was not to be, which means Liverpool must win at Charlton to quell any lingering fears of a late collapse, while Chelsea will need a draw to confirm sixth position ahead of Sunderland. The good news, for them, is that they will be at Manchester City.

Ranieri, a man who attends post-match press conferences only when his side have lost, has been conspicuous by his absence of late. His side have lost only four of their last 19 Premiership fixtures and, judging by the way they twice fought back, durability is an ingredient he has brought to the pot.

There is undoubtedly a new sense of togetherness about Chelsea but they were behind to a beautifully manoeuvred goal after only eight minutes. The opening was instigated by Patrik Berger's reverse pass and Gary McAllister's clever dummy split the visiting defence, allowing Owen to scamper into the penalty area before dinking the ball over the exposed Carlo Cudicini.

Such a setback would, not so long ago, have been the catalyst for a Chelsea capitulation but within five minutes they were level. There did not seem much on when Marcel Desailly picked out Hasselbaink but the Dutchman is not the Premiership's leading scorer by fluke and, allowed to run at the home defence, his dipping right-foot drive had the power and precision to beat Sander Westerveld from 35 yards. The Liverpool goalkeeper will reflect, like his defensive colleagues, that he could have done better.

Chelsea's commitment to attack was commendable even if it did leave them susceptible in defence. Owen, in particular, looked hell-bent on punishing them but Cudicini superbly kept out two more first-half efforts from the England striker and, in between, saved brilliantly at Emile Heskey's feet.

On a full-blooded, occasionally fractious night Owen's selection could have been construed as a gamble ahead of Saturday's FA Cup final against Arsenal and the Uefa Cup final against Alaves next Wednesday. But fresh from scoring a hat-trick against Newcastle on Sunday, he was clearly intent on continuing where he had left off.

On the hour his 21st goal of the season came courtesy of a fierce volley from six yards, lashing the ball past Cuducini from a Sami Hyypia assist, in the midst of a goalmouth scramble in front of the Italian goalkeeper.

Once more, however, Liverpool's exaltation was short-lived. On 66 minutes Hasselbaink broke clear again before unleashing a venomous drive past Westerveld for his 25th of the season.

webTitle: Steve Coppell is new Brentford manager

fields.headline: Coppell renews link with Noades to become Brentford's manager
fields.trailText: Steve Coppell has been named as the manager of Second Division Brentford.
fields.body:
Steve Coppell, formerly in charge of Crystal Palace, has been named as the manager of Second Division Brentford. He had been linked with a move to join Gianluca Vialli at Watford.

Brentford's chairman Ron Noades said: "Steve comes to Brentford with a wealth of experience at high level and his professionalism and integrity should be invaluable to both Brentford Football Club players and supporters alike."

Coppell agreed to take over from Watford-bound Ray Lewington at Griffin Park and will once again link up with Noades after the pair worked together at Selhurst Park.

Queens Park Rangers have ditched plans to merge with Wimbledon because of supporters' overwhelming opposition to the scheme. It emerged last week that the two London clubs had been in talks about a possible union, but fans of both sides immediately objected.

A QPR statement read: "After serious consideration and talks with supporters, the boards of Loftus Road and Queens Park Rangers have decided not to take discussions with Wimbledon regarding a possible merger any further."

On Sunday the Wimbledon chairman Charles Koppel assured supporters after the Dons' match against Norwich that there would be no merger.

The Blackburn manager Graeme Souness has ruled out the possibility of signing top foreign players after accusing them of bailing out when the going gets tough.

"There are going to be periods next season where our backs are going to be firmly against the wall and I think it's easier for foreigners to take less responsibility," said Souness.

"I can't rule out foreigners," he added, "but my basic thinking is that we are in east Lancashire, we come from the heart of England and I want us to be a real workmanlike team like we have been this year."

The Derby County manager Jim Smith has confirmed he will not offer the Nigerian defender Taribo West a contract for next season.

"He's done really well for us and we're grateful for his efforts," said Smith. "But his international commitments with Nigeria mean we cannot get the continuity of appearances from him we need, especially at the level of wages we've been paying him."

Mark Wright has emerged as favourite to take charge of his former club Oxford United after his decision to quit as manager of the Conference club Southport at the weekend.

Wycombe's FA Cup hero Roy Essandoh is one of eight out-of-contract players the club have released.

fields.headline: Harvey Wainapel
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Everything about Harvey Wainapel, the pure-toned American saxophonist, is fastidious. His sound, on tenor or soprano, exhibits hardly any of the bell-note honks, grainy harmonics or white-knuckle helldriving of post-Coltrane sax playing. It often takes on the warmer, fruitier sound of the clarinet (which he also plays) or even the smoothness of articulation of a viola.

A neat, dapper, bespectacled man, Wainapel also likes the smallest element of a performance, from a single note to the namecheck for his sidemen, to be given its proper weight. The gifted young British drummer Seb Rochford was solemnly introduced as "Sebastian", and Wainapel carefully told the audience that his name is pronounced "wine-apple".

Considering that this reviewer, with a head full of the sad death of the drummer Billy Higgins last weekend, is composing this piece in a hair shirt for attaching Higgins's name to the feverishly alive Billy Jenkins in yesterday's Cheltenham festival round-up, Wainapel's care in these matters seems like a better lesson than usual. But it is also a reflection of a particular kind of detailed, patient lyricism in jazz improvisation that's rare among today's performers. Wainapel played with a variety of mainstream-to-soft-bop pieces from his recent CDs The Hang and Ambrosia. And even though the music was often as quiet as a whisper, his class was always audible.

Wainapel transforms the sometimes anguished sound of the soprano saxophone to a honey-smooth purr. Rochford confirmed his growing reputation with a soft, pattering, subtly appropriate accompaniment on brushes. In Latin mode (Wainapel likes bossa novas, but plays them as if they were ballads), the music remained a careful unfurling of tone and nuance rather than an invitation to dance. This is reserved, urbane, orthodox, supper-club jazz - but high in the premier league for all that.

fields.headline: Ministers in EU utilities war
fields.standfirst:
Britain threatens to block foreign takeovers in European power play

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The government is planning to block or hold up foreign takeovers of British energy companies in retaliation for Europe's failure to open up gas and electricity markets.
fields.body:
The government is planning to block or hold up foreign takeovers of British energy companies in retaliation for Europe's failure to open up gas and electricity markets.

Among the first casualties could be the £10bn takeover of PowerGen by E.ON, the German multi-utility, which the government will refer to the European Union competition authorities for investigation.

Electricité de France, the state-owned group which already owns London Electricity and the supply business of South West Electricity, would face a similar block or even veto if it makes its long-expected bid for electricity supplier Seeboard.

Senior government officials said yesterday: "We are looking at ways of holding up European forays into the UK market. It may not be possible but, at the very least, we would force Brussels to intervene and impose an investigation on competition grounds, holding up the process."

This emerged as the European commission referred France to the European court of justice for failing to legally open up its gas market to competition in line with a 1998 directive which requires 20% of that business to be liberalised.

Ministers' outrage at the ease with which big French and German players can buy into Britain's energy sector while there is no reciprocity in their own markets has risen since the failure of the March Stockholm summit to bring further deregulation.

France and Germany, which fell out at the Nice summit over EU institutional reform, combined to block progress on a new directive that would see Europe's market wholly competitive by 2005 at the latest.

Many leading UK groups, including Centrica, the dominant player, have become increasingly exasperated and frustrated at their exclusion from an EU market worth billions of pounds potentially.

Reflecting this, Peter Hain, trade and industry minister, said: "We want to see rapid liberalisation of the energy market in Europe and so do the vast majority of EU members . . .We are pressing the commission to bring forward this new directive."

Welcoming yesterday's "encouraging decisive action", he said: "We feel especially aggrieved when EdF is pursuing takeover negotiations with British companies, including Seeboard, but our own companies are blocked from reciprocal ventures."

Whitehall sources indicated that the new directive should be reactivated by the Belgians who take over the EU presidency on July 1 but no genuine movement is expected until after next year's French presidential election.

Even then, it is thought that the Germans, whose utilities enjoy substantial political support, are the most reluctant to see full-scale competition.

EdF, which paid £2.4bn for its two UK electricity businesses, also owns two British power stations. It claims to have just 5% of the generation market and, with 3m domestic customers, to be the fifth largest in energy supply.

Sources refused to comment on any move for Seeboard which is owned by US group AEP which would want £1.5bn for the business. But they made no secret of the French group's interest in acquiring Seeboard's 2m customers to give it critical mass in the UK.

Mr Hain yesterday approved £25m in state aid to four British pits under a scheme to help the coal industry through short-term energy market problems and low world prices.

webTitle: World music: Arto Lindsay and guests

fields.headline: Boos and cheers at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
Arto Lindsay and guests
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Arto Lindsay and guests
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It is nice to see a Barbican crowd get its knickers in a twist - they cheered, they booed, they walked out, they demanded encores. New York, the second city to be featured in the Barbican's Urban Beats series, at least lived up to its promotion as "uneasy listening".

Composer/guitarist Jonathan Bepler's opening stutterings were taken through a laptop and layered up, combined with machine-like waves of city noise. It was too predictably structured, but the initial build-up and the final forlorn ending were particularly effective.

Then, in stark contrast, came the sweet bossa nova of Vinicius Cantuaria. It is difficult to imagine a band being more laidback without being under general anaesthetic. Not that the music lacked life. Cantuaria's approach - which goes for the whole band - is minimal, sexy, with a beautiful concentration on quality of sound over showy pyrotechnics.

Larry 7 opened the second half creating snaps, crackles and pops by shining torches on light-sensitive electronics. Difficult sounds don't have to mean difficult listening, but they rely on shape and structure. Without either, the crowd was soon indulging in ironic clapping and cheering.

Arto Lindsay came on to an atmosphere of make or break. He is spellbinding to watch. Wiry, loose-jointed and dressed like an office worker who has just slackened off in the pub, he struts and prowls. Then, as if a bolt of electricity has travelled up his arm, he spasms, attacking the guitar: twang, scrape, distort. Then he's relaxed again, singing gently in that seductive Brazilian voice. Lindsay stirred a melting pot of bossa, noise, electronics, surround sound ("driven" by Ben Rubin) and heavy funk. As guest guitarist Cantuaria held the more traditional guitar parts in place, Lindsay flew off into noisy fantasies. But while he barely played a single pitched note, his gestures were full of musicality: placed and phrased, full of feeling, sometimes intense, sometimes jokey.

What had looked like wayward programming was clarified. Lindsay took the sound elements of the evening and made sense of them all.

fields.headline: HBOS attack could cost rivals $1.5bn
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: A £1.5bn hole could be knocked out of the profits of high street banks following the £30bn merger between Halifax and Bank of Scotland, analysts say.
fields.body:
A £1.5bn hole could be knocked out of the profits of high street banks following the £30bn merger between Halifax and Bank of Scotland, analysts say.

It would be the result of any decision by the big four banks - Lloyds TBS, HSBC, Barclays and NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland - to start paying interest on current accounts. The profits blow is the equivalent of more than 5% of the entire sector's profitability.

Halifax is already paying 4% interest on balances - compared with a 0.1% rate paid by most of the big banks - and is expected to introduce the higher interest payment for Bank of Scotland customers.

Announcing their planned merger to create HBOS last week, the two declared war on the "big four" and warned they had set aside a sum with which to woo customers. The City believes it likely to focus first on the big four's 70% market share of current accounts.

While the combined bank would still have just a 5% of current accounts, analysts believe it might force Royal Bank of Scotland to follow suit quickly because of the fierce battle for customers in Scotland where BoS has a 26% market share.

The analysts at investment bank Fox-Pitt Kelton believe that matching Halifax's offer to pay a 4% interest rate on current accounts and reduce overdraft rates to 10% - compared with the 18% charged by the big four - would blow a £1.5bn hole in the banking sector.

"This 4% is the maximum the banks can offer and break even," Jon Kirk, analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton said.

Traditionally, the current account market is seen as one dominated by inertia. Royal Bank said: "Our research shows that interest rates are not the leading factor for current accounts."

fields.headline: Flying colours for the wild men of dance
fields.standfirst:
First Class Air Male
Clore Studio, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
First Class Air Male
Clore Studio, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Dance's most charismatic soloists have historically been women - Isadora Duncan, Mary Wigman, Loie Fuller - but the rush on tickets for Monday night's First Class Air Male suggests that single men are in vogue.

Of the four male soloists on show, Akram Khan is the only one performing his own choreography, his acclaimed piece Loose in Flight. Here Khan works within the modular phrases of his native Kathak style and blows them open with the blunter, wilder moves of modern dance. In concentrated riffs he moves from radiant stillness to ferocious bursts of speed, changing drastic gear from tiny classical detail to raging, ragged leaps. The beauty of his dancing, the absoluteness of his control hold the theatre breathless.

Adam Cooper is Khan's equal at dominating the stage, simply by virtue of his personal glamour. But in Jan De Schynkel's Can't Bark he reminds us of the dangerous intensity of his imagination. In this funny, disturbing study of conflicting desire Cooper is half man, half dog, an angry, rude, comic, disgusting beast. He clutches on to his own lead, rubs at his outrageously phallic tail, dances himself frantic and glowers passionately at the audience. It is a wonderfully bizarre piece.

Wayne McGregor's Codex is performed by the excellent Ben Ash, whose square, terrier body gives an intriguing physical slant to the long, flickering lines of McGregor's choreography, hardening its limbs, and building solid texture through its sudden kinks and changes of pace. Ash, like the other two, is a virtuoso in his own style - which leaves the last of the four, Frédéric Seguette, looking a little like a wallflower.

The wit of Jérme Bel's Shirtologie emerges too slowly and too intermittently as Seguette simply stands centre stage and peels off a series of T-shirts, each one emblazoned with the logos of 21st-century capitalism. Seguette does, however, have an enchanting way of looking crushed and bemused by the weight of information he's carrying on his chest, and his mournful humour adds to a showcase for male performance and choreography that deserves much wider showing.

fields.headline: Mark and Lard take to the stage
fields.standfirst:
The Shirehorses
Garage, Glasgow
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Shirehorses
Garage, Glasgow
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Radio 1 DJs are not renowned for making great music. The recorded output of Tony Blackburn, Dave Lee Travis and Kenny Everett may be memorable, but for all the wrong reasons. So why should The Shirehorses, aka Radio 1's drivetime jocks Mark Radcliffe and Marc "Lard" Riley, prove any different?

In their favour, the boys certainly have an enthusiastic crowd behind them. With seemingly every male student in west-central Scotland crammed into the venue, tonight's act could hardly get a warmer reception. Just as repetition of each radio catchphrase is greeted with hoots of approval, so too are Mark and Lard's spoof covers of recent indie hits.

Sorry, did I say "spoof"? According to Radcliffe, the Shirehorses have been the victims of plagiarism at the hands of almost every British guitar band. Blur's Country House is, apparently, just a rip-off of their own song about being trapped in the sticks with a corpulent wife: "I live with my spouse, my very big spouse in the country." Travis's Why Does It Always Rain on Me?, we learn, was lifted from Mark and Lard's paean to having to endure inappropriate cheese backstage, Why Is It Always Dairylea? And, to the delight of the undergraduates in the audience, we discover that the Manic Street Preachers' Spanish civil war opus borrows heavily from the Shirehorses' assault on substandard lager in student unions, If You Tolerate This Piss Your Bitter Will Be Next.

If this comes across as lewd, juvenile and unsubtle on paper, that's because it is exactly the same live. However, Mark and Lard's easygoing Mancunian charm helps them carry it off. As frustrated musicians themselves - Riley, amazingly, survived a stint in the Fall - you can tell they are genuinely passionate about the form. And if the singing is hardly note-perfect, then a spirited delivery helps the pair bluff their way through.

Of course, there's a highly laddish flavour to tonight's show. Mark and Lard play in front of a reconstructed pub, cheer when told that Manchester City have just scored, and cast aspersions on each other's heterosexuality. Sometimes the banter can grate, but it is never anything other than good-humoured.

The Shirehorses don't leave you wanting more: each parody is as disposable as your average radio sketch. However, it's no less enjoyable for that. If nothing else, Mark and Lard's take on indie rock lends some laughs to a genre notorious for taking itself overseriously.

 At the Astoria, London WC2 (020-7434 9592), on Thursday, then tours.

fields.headline: A right royal rental
fields.standfirst: Lisa Bachelor looks at what a right royal couple pays in rent each week and what this equates to in the real world
fields.trailText: Lisa Bachelor looks at what a right royal couple pays in rent each week and what this equates to in the real world.
fields.body:
For most of us, the idea of living in a palace for the price of a council house is only a dream. But for Prince and Princess Michael of Kent, this is a daily reality - and one they may soon have to face leaving.

Buckingham Palace confirmed at the weekend that the couple pay only £3,500 a year toward the upkeep of their seven-bedroom, nine-reception room grace and favour apartment at Kensington Palace - the equivalent of a weekly rent of £67.30.

The confirmation from the palace came amid reports that the couple face losing the apartment in a review of what members of the royal family can and cannot do.

Although the couple are not exactly going to be out of pocket - they own an eight-bedroom country mansion in Gloucestershire worth an estimated £1.6m - Guardian Money set out to see what the couple could expect to get elsewhere in the country for £67 a week, should they face eviction.

Recent house price rises across the country make the prospect of finding something in this price bracket pretty grim.

Nationwide Building Society revealed this week that over the past 50 years the average price of a UK home has risen by a staggering 4,500% - from £1,900 in 1952 to today's typical price tag of £86,244.

While this might be good news for homeowners, its not so great for those renting property - and landlords can afford to be increasingly picky about their tenants.

Landlords in general are very choosy and they want to see people in gainful employment, says Dave Ward, spokesperson for fish4.co.uk

They will be looking for people with a regular income and will also be very picky about allowing pets into the property. Theyre also not going to allow too much storage - so large collections of Russian literature and ballgowns are out. Finally, they will require references to ensure the tenant is a respectable and trustworthy person to let the property to.

So what can you rent for £67 a week get in the UK? I have tried my best to search the thousands of properties in London we have at Fish4 to find a suitable rental abode for the Kents. I am afraid that although we have the largest UK online rental directory for rental properties, it is, not surprisingly, impossible to find a similar standard of accommodation for £67 per week, says Mr. Ward.

At Fish4 we suggest increasing their budget to £75 per week and to first look at shared accommodation from zone three onwards or to perhaps look beyond London to the countryside but not, Im afraid, the south-east.

In London, the royal couple would have to be prepared to move well away from lush Kensington. Instead, they would get a single bedsit with shared kitchen and bathroom in Kingsbury, W10, for £75 a week or a single room in Stepney, East London with shared bathroom and kitchen for the same price. And in nearby North Kensington, they would have to cough up about £135 a week for a studio flat with barely enough room to swing a cat.

Wales is a more affordable option. Although prices have started rising again after a fall-off late last year, according to the Halifax, the average house price in Wales is now £65,678 compared to the greater London average of £157,691. There, the royals could rent a one-bedroom part- furnished flat in Cardiff city centre for £60 a week.

In Liverpool, adding a bit to the budget, would get them a one-bedroom fully furnished townhouse with satellite television for £300 a month. For a bit of sea air, the Scottish town of Saltcoats would also be affordable at a stretch. For £300 a month - leaving any pets behind - the Kents could rent an ex-council flat with a lounge/kitchen and double glazing.

If the Royal couple are planning to stick to budget and move, they better do it soon. Halifax analysts are forecasting a further rise in house prices this year and next. However, it definitely sounds like theyre better off staying put. According to London estate agents Ironside, their £67 a week rent is allowing them to stay at accommodation that would normally be rented for about £10,000 a week.

fields.headline: Bank faces more hurdles
fields.standfirst: Despite winning £180m financial backing from Britain's high street banks, the controversial universal bank still faces hurdles that may halt the project
fields.trailText: Despite winning £180m financial backing from Britain's high street banks, the controversial universal bank still faces hurdles that may halt the project.
fields.body:
Britain's high street banks yesterday finally agreed to contribute £180m to help set up and run the controversial post office-based universal bank. But industry sources said the scheme still faced hurdles that could halt the project.

Announcing the deal to provide bank accounts for social security claimants, Alan Johnson, the industry minister, also revealed the urgent need to throw a lifeline to the 18,000-strong post office network.

A record 547 post offices closed in the last financial year, an increase of 311 over the previous 12 months, he said yesterday. He insisted, that the deal with the banks offered small post offices the chance of a more secure future because customers doing their banking in post offices would also be enticed to make other transactions.

The banks have agreed to make basic accounts, which do not allow customers to get overdrawn, available in post offices as well as contributing a combined £180m over five years to run a new post office-based card account.

The need for banking facilities is most pressing for some 4m benefits claimants who will need an account when the social security system is computerised in 2003. The Post Office also needs to find a way to plug £400m in lost revenues following the process.

The fact the banks had agreed to pay £36m a year for five years prompted some bankers to question whether the Treasury would be left to foot a large bill.

Senior bankers also warned that the project might yet be halted because of an agreement the 11 retail banks secured with the Department of Trade and Industry over the number of bank accounts they should be required to open.

One banker said: "If there are any parties who want to tip it out of bed then it can still be done. There is an area still open for negotiation which is the whole issue of allocating account openings between the banks".

The memorandum of understanding sent to the banks gives them the opportunity to develop "appropriate arrangements to guard against the risk of individual institutions picking up disproportionately excessive numbers of basic bank accounts through post offices".

This relates to the agreement by the banks to make so-called basic accounts available through the post office. The banks have already secured agreement that potential customers should not be able to open these basic accounts directly in post offices.

Mr Johnson said that 99% of the new account applicants would not need to be interviewed by a bank. Sub-post office managers will help in the process of identification.

The new post office-based account will be very basic, allowing only one cash withdrawal a week. The account will not have facilities for direct debits and it will still be necessary to queue at the post office.

This has already led to claims that the post office-based account does not even match the requirements imposed by the Treasury on the banks to make direct debits available in their basic bank accounts.

Ian Mullen, chief executive of the British Bankers' Association, said: "The agreement to pay £180m towards the running costs of the Post Office card account represents a significant commitment which shows that banks take seriously their social responsibilities

fields.headline: BBCPO/ Tortelier
fields.standfirst:
BBCPO/ Tortelier
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
BBCPO/ Tortelier
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The second orchestral concert in this year's Royal Northern College of Music cello festival included one acknowledged masterpiece - Dvorak's concerto - and devoted the remaining time to rarely heard works. Samuel Barber's 1945 concerto, played by the young cellist Liwei Qin, is a work of modest dimensions. Apart from a formidable first movement cadenza, it shuns virtuosity and passionate intensity. Qin was sensitive to its gentle eloquence and to the finely balanced interplay between soloist and orchestra. If the result was slightly bland, it was only because the concerto itself never quite manages to inspire.

Ernest Bloch's "Hebraic rhapsody" Schelomo has not dated well. But cellists like to play it, and when the cellist is Ralph Kirshbaum it seems ungrateful to focus on the work's weaknesses. The music was outclassed by Kirshbaum's playing: his wonderful sensitivity to colour made Schelomo worth hearing, for once.

The American composer Aaron Jay Kernis originally wrote Air for Joshua Bell; his transcription for cello received its European premiere in Saturday's concert. As a work for cello, Air is vaguely in the mode of John Tavener's Protecting Veil: long-breathed and harmonically very simple, with string and harp textures straight out of Mahler's Fifth Symphony.

As the soundtrack to a romantic film, it would be just great. But, in spite of all the loving care lavished on it by Truls Mork, as a concert piece it is tedious.

Dvorak's concerto does not often receive the kind of treatment meted out to it by Natalia Gutman. The sheer depth and breadth of her sound, combined with a slight roughness, is unique, and she is an outstanding interpreter of Russian music. Her Dvorak was stormy and passionate, with a finale that whirled along at astonishing speed. Her choice of encore, however - the first Bourrée from Bach's C major Cello Suite - was played with exquisite delicacy.
fields.bodyText: The second orchestral concert in this year's Royal Northern College of Music cello festival included one acknowledged masterpiece - Dvorak's concerto - and devoted the remaining time to rarely heard works. Samuel Barber's 1945 concerto, played by the young cellist Liwei Qin, is a work of modest dimensions. Apart from a formidable first movement cadenza, it shuns virtuosity and passionate intensity. Qin was sensitive to its gentle eloquence and to the finely balanced interplay between soloist and orchestra. If the result was slightly bland, it was only because the concerto itself never quite manages to inspire. Ernest Bloch's "Hebraic rhapsody" Schelomo has not dated well. But cellists like to play it, and when the cellist is Ralph Kirshbaum it seems ungrateful to focus on the work's weaknesses. The music was outclassed by Kirshbaum's playing: his wonderful sensitivity to colour made Schelomo worth hearing, for once. The American composer Aaron Jay Kernis originally wrote Air for Joshua Bell; his transcription for cello received its European premiere in Saturday's concert. As a work for cello, Air is vaguely in the mode of John Tavener's Protecting Veil: long-breathed and harmonically very simple, with string and harp textures straight out of Mahler's Fifth Symphony. As the soundtrack to a romantic film, it would be just great. But, in spite of all the loving care lavished on it by Truls Mork, as a concert piece it is tedious. Dvorak's concerto does not often receive the kind of treatment meted out to it by Natalia Gutman. The sheer depth and breadth of her sound, combined with a slight roughness, is unique, and she is an outstanding interpreter of Russian music. Her Dvorak was stormy and passionate, with a finale that whirled along at astonishing speed. Her choice of encore, however - the first Bourrée from Bach's C major Cello Suite - was played with exquisite delicacy.

fields.headline: Pipilotti Rist
fields.standfirst:
Tramway, Glasgow
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Tramway, Glasgow
Rating: *****
fields.body:
For Show a Leg, her first solo exhibition in the UK since 1996, Swiss video artist Pipilotti Rist has thoroughly feminised the brooding postindustrial gloom of Tramway. The ways in which she has done this may be familiar to those who know her work - gorgeous visuals featuring startling, edgy women behaving badly, accompanied by equally luscious soundscapes - but there is a surprise even for her dedicated followers.

Rist, whose work has been compared to MTV by fans and critics alike, has filled Tramway's vast main space with net curtains. They lose their traditional function as markers of suburban respectability here, not least because this is a room without windows. Rist uses the huge panels of net, hung high and low, as flimsy, diaphanous projection screens. They break up the space - this is Rist's largest ever installation - without sacrificing its imposing sense of size. It retains its potential as a place you can lose yourself in.

On to the walls and curtains Rist beams fragments and scraps of three colour video pieces, set in a domestic interior, a city street and a doctor's surgery. On the street, two women pose and saunter in 1950s-style sundresses and high heels; at home, a woman jumps across her bedroom, naked save for some funky boots; in the surgery, a naked woman silently curls and unfurls her body on the floor.

Rist continually plays with traditional representations of women. In Show a Leg, she utilises archetypes - woman as naked figure in art; the glamorous pin-up look; the mad woman in a medical context - but departs radically from them by never revealing these women's stories, their secrets, their motivations. Just as you think you're tracing a narrative, the image dissolves and moves on. Rist disperses her images through the space - they pop up before you and eerily follow you through the gauzy maze of nets. To this she adds a dreamy, ambient soundscape: bursts of girls' laughter, percussive rhythms, snatches of melody. This too swirls through the gallery.

The effect is ravishingly kaleidoscopic and gently psychedelic. Poetic and political at the same time, this is a sensual treat that nudges us to think about the gap between how women live and how they are shown to exist in the mass media.

When you step out from behind the curtains, blinking to adjust to light, the bigger ideas that shape the work present themselves. As you wander through, though, the pleasure is magical, sensual, childish, and yet profound.

 Until June 10. Details: 0141-287 3900.

fields.headline: Cruyff slates 'boring' Liverpool tactics
fields.trailText: The former Manchester United midfielder Jordi Cruyff reckons that Liverpool's defence will make this season's Uefa Cup final the most boring ever.
fields.body:
The former Manchester United midfielder Jordi Cruyff has criticised Liverpool's defensive European displays and predicted that tomorrow week's Uefa Cup final, which also features Cruyff's current club Alaves, will be the most boring in the competition's history.

Liverpool beat Barcelona 1-0 in the semi-finals thanks to a stubborn defensive display in the away leg, while Alaves thrilled in beating Kaiserslautern 9-2, but the Spanish club are planning a more considered approach to the final.

"If Liverpool defend with nine men behind the ball they'll find we have 10 men back," said Cruyff. "It could be one of the most boring finals in history. It's up to Liverpool to take the initiative and their fans won't stand for them playing the same sort of defensive game."

Last month Cruyff's father, the three-times European Player of the Year Johan, called Liverpool "horrible", claiming they are "incapable of putting three passes together". But the Alaves coach Jose Manuel Esnal said: "In European finals you don't often see a lot of great football but any way of playing that gives you victory is great football."

Brentford yesterday confirmed the departure of their manager Ray Lewington, who is to join Gianluca Vialli and Ray Wilkins at Watford. But their chairman Ron Noades denied that Steve Coppell has been lined up as a replacement.

The Wolves chairman Sir Jack Hayward, who decided three years ago to stop bankrolling the club's attempts at promotion, has changed his mind and pledged £15m towards Dave Jones's rebuilding of the team. "I'm 77 years old now and it's my last roll of the dice, so I'm going to make my money available," he said.

Bobby Robson has attacked the Newcastle defender Marcelino, who was quoted in his native Spain at the weekend as being upset at his treatment by the club and desperate to leave. "How dare he say what he has?" he said. "I am surprised and I'm really angry."

 Iranian officials yesterday began an investigation into the collapse of a roof at an overcrowded stadium at the weekend that left two fans dead and hundreds injured. Asghar Samarbakhsh, the deputy sports director for Mazandaran province, said: "The police are to blame for not preventing people without tickets from entering the stadium. All those who were on the roof had come into the stadium without tickets."

fields.headline: Kluivert threatens to leave Barcelona
fields.trailText: Patrick Kluivert has warned Barcelona that, if they do not agree to his terms for a new contract, he will seek a new club.
fields.body:
Patrick Kluivert has warned Barcelona that, if they do not agree to his terms for a new contract, he will seek a new club.

"I will negotiate with Barcelona first but, if we do not reach agreement, I will talk to other teams," said the 24-year-old Holland striker, who would cost about £30m.

Kluivert's contract expires in at the end of June next year and there has been speculation that he will follow Luis Figo in defecting to Real Madrid if negotiations with Barcelona break down.

"Would I ever play at Real Madrid? I am not sure," Kluivert replied when asked about the possibility of going to Real. But he denied he had already signed an agreement to join Real. "That isn't true. I am not that sort of person. I have great respect for my club and my present contract."

Juventus' president Vittorio Chiusano has criticised the late-season decision to relax Italy's non-EU player limit per game as "ill-timed" after his club's 2-2 draw with the leaders Roma.

Roma were the only club to exploit fully last week's rule change, ending Sunday's game with five non-EU players - the new limit - on the pitch. One of them, the Japanese substitute Hidetoshi Nakata, scored and set up the late equaliser.

The Bundesliga is set to return to a crowded Saturday afternoon schedule, dropping Friday and Saturday night matches, after mass protests by German fans. The standard two Sunday afternoon games will probably remain.

fields.headline: Big Brother uncovers Sun impostor
fields.trailText: 4pm: Big Brother producers have foiled an attempt by the Sun to get a journalist into the house as a contestant for the second series. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Big Brother producers have foiled an attempt by the Sun to get a journalist into the house as a contestant for the second series.

Giovanna Iozzi, who writes TV features for the paper, got through to the last 70 applicants who were called for face-to-face interviews with Big Brother's executive producer Conrad Green and series producer Jeremy Phillips about a month ago.

"We were already suspicious when she came for the interview and had assumed she was a journalist," Mr Phillips said.

"Some of the things she'd put on the application form, like her name and age, didn't add up. She also said she had worked in a massage parlour and thought the show should have more sex in it."

Then during the interview Mr Phillips said Ms Iozzi said she had a sister who worked as a secretary in an office, when on her form she said she was a teacher.

He added that he had gone outside the building where the interview was being held and discovered a Sun photographer in a car, who tried to cover up his camera as Mr Phillips approached.

After the interview a Channel 4 press officer rang Ms Iozzi to confirm the attempted deception.

"We go to talk to family and friends - if there's an impostor we will find them," Mr Phillips said, adding that Ms Iozzi's interview had been taped.

But the Sun writer did well to get through to this stage.

More than 50,000 people requested application forms and around 5,000 submitted videos - compared to just 700 last time.

Channel 4 is not planning to unveil the names of the 10 selected to take part in Big Brother 2 until they actually go into the house later this month.

webTitle: Women's FA Cup final: Arsenal 1 - 0 Fulham

fields.headline: Banks keeps Arsenal on treble trail
fields.trailText: Arsenal's amateurs kept themselves in line for the treble with a victory over the professionals of Fulham in front of a record crowd for a women's match in this country.
fields.body:
The women's game got its dream FA Cup final in the end - but it had to wait until an exciting second half after a disappointing opening 45 minutes. A crowd of 13,824, nearly double the previous record attendance for any women's match in this country, including internationals, crowned Arsenal popular victors.

Never mind the Cup custom of making lower league sides the neutral's choice, nor the fact that Arsenal, with the League Cup already in their possession, are likely to clinch the treble at Tranmere on Thursday night by taking the Premier Division title. For the women's game, and the all-amateur Premiership in particular, the consequences of a triumph for Fulham's professionals would perhaps have been too great to contemplate.

"I am pleased for the national league," Arsenal's manager Vic Akers said. "It just goes to prove throwing money at it is not the be-all and end-all."

Two divisions separate Arsenal and Fulham, but yesterday that disparity did not equate to a notable difference in class. Both started nervously in a game that provided each side with their sternest test of the season. In midfield, the battles between Jayne Ludlow and Katie Chapman, and Sian Williams and Margunn Haugenes were competitive without being fruitful.

Reaching the interval goaless, after Fulham's Sanchia Duncan had had a goal disallowed for offside, must have been a novelty, too, given both sides' habit of scoring in double figures.

The game swung on three minutes in the second half. First Fulham's Marianne Pettersen was brought down by Carol Harwood and her Norwegian international team-mate Haugenes stepped up to take the penalty. But Arsenal's goalkeeper Emma Byrne guessed right to save her soft shot and within moments Angela Banks had scored the winner on the rebound after Marieanne Spacey had hit the bar.

For Fulham, there were final tears. "This was the pinnacle of what we were hoping to achieve but we'll get over it," said manager Frank McMorrow. They will have a chance to do so next Sunday when they face Hampton in the South-East Combination League.

Woman of the match: Angela Banks (Arsenal).

Arsenal (3-5-2): Byrne; Stoney, Harwood, White; Pealling, Ludlow, Williams, Grant, Wheatley; Spacey (Maggs, 84min), Banks.

Fulham ( 4-4-2): Bowry; Gibbons, Petersen, Phillip, Jerray-Silver; Duncan (Mork, 78), McArthur (Rahman, 83), Chapman, Yankey; Haugenes, Pettersen.

Referee: T Parkes.

fields.headline: At 42, is Barbie past it?
fields.standfirst: As sales of the international superstar slump,  Joanna Moorhead wonders whether we're falling out of love with the world's bestselling doll
fields.trailText: As sales of the international superstar slump, Joanna Moorhead wonders whether we're falling out of love with the world's bestselling doll.
fields.body:
Hold the obituary: Barbie sales might have dipped but the world's most perfect blonde is a long way from bowing out. What, after all, is a spunky 42-year-old to do if her popularity seems slightly on the wane? Her manufacturers Mattel used to boast that three Barbies were bought somewhere in the world every second, but they have recently reported losses of more than £20m in the first quarter of the year, blaming slumping sales of Barbie dolls. Now all the talk is of an autumn offensive which is going to push Barbie right back where her boobs have always been - way out in front.

Each year sees the release of 150 Barbies worldwide, many launching her on a whole new career path. She isn't exactly what you'd call a sticker in job terms. So what if she looked radiant as an air stewardess - that was before her favourite magazine offered her a post as its fashion editor. She even took on George Bush for the US presidency (if her name had been on the Florida nomination papers, she'd probably have won).

But now the chips are down and so Barbie is retreating to her least controversial and biggest selling role, as a fairy-tale heroine. She'll make her professional ballet debut as Clara in the Nutcracker and accompanying the new-look doll comes a feature film, so Mattel can really hammer home the romance and crank up the merchandising.

It is music to the ears of die-hard Barbie fans such as toyshop owner Val Stedham, who believes wholeheartedly in the world's single bestselling toy. "Barbie is a dream to sell," says Stedham, who runs Moon's Toymaster in Newmarket. "She's a complete classic - everyone's going to want the Nutcracker doll for Christmas."

Everyone might be a bit of an exaggeration, but it's safe to say that the queue will include 10-year-old Stephanie Oliver of Chingford in east London, whose 104-strong Barbie collection is one of the largest in Britain. Stephanie got her first Barbie when she was three - she can't remember her name, but she came with a big tube and you could blow bubbles around her.

At the moment, with her Sats coming up in a couple of weeks, schoolwork is keeping her from her beloved dolls more than she would like - but she still manages to find time to fix their hairstyles and, occasionally, to play her favourite game. "I set up a big shop with loads of Barbie shoes and outfits, then I get all my Barbies to choose new outfits for themselves," she says. "As well as my Barbies, I get the others to come along, all her sisters, like Kelly and Skipper and Stacie. I've even got a Krissy - she's Barbie's baby sister."

Fifteen years ago, Stephanie would have been a typical Barbie fan, but in the current market she's a bit of an anachronism. Today's girls are older, younger, and the effect of that has been to put Barbie on the two- and three-year-olds' wish lists. Stephanie says that, though many of her friends have the odd Barbie or two at the back of a drawer, few play with them or acquire new ones.

This, in fact, is the nub of Mattel's problem and the reason why, although it's the Barbies in frilly pink numbers with big hair who sell best, the design team works flat out to capture the imaginations of girls of eight, nine and 10, who just might go for an astronaut Barbie but wouldn't be seen dead with a Snow White.

Today's Barbie "dream market" is the likes of Daisy Chitnis, almost five and the proud owner of a sizeable Barbie collection. Jane, Daisy's mum, takes the usual post-feminist line on her daughter's obsession of the moment: Barbie might be ridiculous in terms of body shape, but it doesn't matter because it isn't what Daisy and her friends are aware of as they decide whether to slide her into the pink chiffon, the print sundress or the full-skirted ballgown.

In fact, Jane says, Barbie's looks belie a life of unparalleled tedium. "In Daisy's games, they're always going to the supermarket, doing the cleaning or looking after the younger children," she says. "They may be a little overdressed for the dull life they lead, but it doesn't seem to bother them - and it certainly doesn't bother Daisy."

Far from moulding the lifestyle to fit the doll, today's young Barbie-owners mould the doll to fit the lifestyle they see around them. So while she might be dressed to the nines and tottering around on absurd heels, chances are, in the world of make-believe, Barbie will be hanging out at the supermarket and the school gates just like the real women Daisy and her friends see around them.

Most Barbie fans trace their interest back to the excitement of being given their first doll for a birthday or Christmas present, but at 58, toyshop owner Val Stedham is older than her favourite toy. She was hooked on the Barbie dream when she saw how enthusiastically her daughter Claire, now 28, played with the doll - in fact, she says, it was seeing Claire playing with her Barbies that convinced her to take up running a toyshop and she now feels "passionate" about giving parents advice on good toys that are well-made and spur imaginative play.

Not everyone shares her enthusiasm, however. Dr Elizabeth Mapstone, a chartered psychologist who writes on sexual stereotyping, says she wouldn't have dreamed of giving the glitzy doll to her daughters, now in their 30s. "But when they were old enough to have pocket money, they did go out and buy them themselves and in my opinion it didn't do either of them any good. The trouble is, Barbie's figure is nothing like normal - it's distorted to the extent that any woman who looked like her would have something seriously wrong with her and whatever people might like to think, that image does affect a young person.

"Barbie isn't the worst thing in the world, but it's not a good thing for any girl, at any stage of her development, to get the notion that the ideal female figure is this ultra-slim, etiolated form. I think buying her is a mistake. If you don't want your child to be affected by this image of the female body, then don't let her have a Barbie, it's as simple as that."

Cassidy Park, vice president of Barbie design and development in the US, counters that, far from being a brainless glamour-girl, Barbie is a young woman of her times, a role model making today's girls aware of the vast number of careers available. "There aren't any limits to what Barbie can become," Park says, though she does admit, in the next breath, that it's the romantic, big-dress Barbies that sell in droves and the astronauts, dentists and vets who get dusty on the toyshop shelves.

Just five years younger than her star product, Park shares Barbie's love of all things pretty and pink. She trained as a fashion designer and chanced upon a job at Mattel when she started freelancing after having her daughter, Turner, eight years ago. "I just came in temporarily to work on Barbie and straight away I absolutely loved it," she says. "It seemed an amazingly natural thing for me to do. As a child I'd always played with Barbie, though I wouldn't say I was a diehard fan. I am now, of course - I live and breathe her, and I spend my life deciding where she's going to go next and what she's going to do."

Back in Newmarket, there is no doubting who's come to town when the pink Barbie-mobile rides down the main street for the great lady's occasional promotional visits to Val Stedham's toyshop. "I only have to put up one notice saying she's coming and we get a queue out the door all day long," Stedham says. "She signs their autographs, chats with them, talks about her life. It's good to see how happy the little girls are to see her. It's so simple ... and so appealing."

She'll make her professional ballet debut as Clara in the Nutcracker and accompanying the new-look doll comes a feature film, so Mattel can really hammer home the romance and crank up the merchandising. It is music to the ears of die-hard Barbie fans such as toyshop owner Val Stedham, who believes wholeheartedly in the world's single bestselling toy. "Barbie is a dream to sell," says Stedham, who runs Moon's Toymaster in Newmarket. "She's a complete classic - everyone's going to want the Nutcracker doll for Christmas." Everyone might be a bit of an exaggeration, but it's safe to say that the queue will include 10-year-old Stephanie Oliver of Chingford in east London, whose 104-strong Barbie collection is one of the largest in Britain. Stephanie got her first Barbie when she was three - she can't remember her name, but she came with a big tube and you could blow bubbles around her. At the moment, with her Sats coming up in a couple of weeks, schoolwork is keeping her from her beloved dolls more than she would like - but she still manages to find time to fix their hairstyles and, occasionally, to play her favourite game. "I set up a big shop with loads of Barbie shoes and outfits, then I get all my Barbies to choose new outfits for themselves," she says. "As well as my Barbies, I get the others to come along, all her sisters, like Kelly and Skipper and Stacie. I've even got a Krissy - she's Barbie's baby sister." Fifteen years ago, Stephanie would have been a typical Barbie fan, but in the current market she's a bit of an anachronism. Today's girls are older, younger, and the effect of that has been to put Barbie on the two- and three-year-olds' wish lists. Stephanie says that, though many of her friends have the odd Barbie or two at the back of a drawer, few play with them or acquire new ones. This, in fact, is the nub of Mattel's problem and the reason why, although it's the Barbies in frilly pink numbers with big hair who sell best, the design team works flat out to capture the imaginations of girls of eight, nine and 10, who just might go for an astronaut Barbie but wouldn't be seen dead with a Snow White. Today's Barbie "dream market" is the likes of Daisy Chitnis, almost five and the proud owner of a sizeable Barbie collection. Jane, Daisy's mum, takes the usual post-feminist line on her daughter's obsession of the moment: Barbie might be ridiculous in terms of body shape, but it doesn't matter because it isn't what Daisy and her friends are aware of as they decide whether to slide her into the pink chiffon, the print sundress or the full-skirted ballgown. In fact, Jane says, Barbie's looks belie a life of unparalleled tedium. "In Daisy's games, they're always going to the supermarket, doing the cleaning or looking after the younger children," she says. "They may be a little overdressed for the dull life they lead, but it doesn't seem to bother them - and it certainly doesn't bother Daisy." Far from moulding the lifestyle to fit the doll, today's young Barbie-owners mould the doll to fit the lifestyle they see around them. So while she might be dressed to the nines and tottering around on absurd heels, chances are, in the world of make-believe, Barbie will be hanging out at the supermarket and the school gates just like the real women Daisy and her friends see around them. Most Barbie fans trace their interest back to the excitement of being given their first doll for a birthday or Christmas present, but at 58, toyshop owner Val Stedham is older than her favourite toy. She was hooked on the Barbie dream when she saw how enthusiastically her daughter Claire, now 28, played with the doll - in fact, she says, it was seeing Claire playing with her Barbies that convinced her to take up running a toyshop and she now feels "passionate" about giving parents advice on good toys that are well-made and spur imaginative play. Not everyone shares her enthusiasm, however. Dr Elizabeth Mapstone, a chartered psychologist who writes on sexual stereotyping, says she wouldn't have dreamed of giving the glitzy doll to her daughters, now in their 30s. "But when they were old enough to have pocket money, they did go out and buy them themselves and in my opinion it didn't do either of them any good. The trouble is, Barbie's figure is nothing like normal - it's distorted to the extent that any woman who looked like her would have something seriously wrong with her and whatever people might like to think, that image does affect a young person. "Barbie isn't the worst thing in the world, but it's not a good thing for any girl, at any stage of her development, to get the notion that the ideal female figure is this ultra-slim, etiolated form. I think buying her is a mistake. If you don't want your child to be affected by this image of the female body, then don't let her have a Barbie, it's as simple as that." Cassidy Park, vice president of Barbie design and development in the US, counters that, far from being a brainless glamour-girl, Barbie is a young woman of her times, a role model making today's girls aware of the vast number of careers available. "There aren't any limits to what Barbie can become," Park says, though she does admit, in the next breath, that it's the romantic, big-dress Barbies that sell in droves and the astronauts, dentists and vets who get dusty on the toyshop shelves. Just five years younger than her star product, Park shares Barbie's love of all things pretty and pink. She trained as a fashion designer and chanced upon a job at Mattel when she started freelancing after having her daughter, Turner, eight years ago. "I just came in temporarily to work on Barbie and straight away I absolutely loved it," she says. "It seemed an amazingly natural thing for me to do. As a child I'd always played with Barbie, though I wouldn't say I was a diehard fan. I am now, of course - I live and breathe her, and I spend my life deciding where she's going to go next and what she's going to do." Back in Newmarket, there is no doubting who's come to town when the pink Barbie-mobile rides down the main street for the great lady's occasional promotional visits to Val Stedham's toyshop. "I only have to put up one notice saying she's coming and we get a queue out the door all day long," Stedham says. "She signs their autographs, chats with them, talks about her life. It's good to see how happy the little girls are to see her. It's so simple ... and so appealing."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: Alex
fields.trailText: I was reminded by your comment "My fear is almost that I will have grown but my life will not, that I will just slot back in and soon it will be as if this wonderful adventure never happened. Does that make sense?" of my own feelings when I returned from a year out (sadly 10 years ago now!).
fields.body:
I was reminded by your comment "My fear is almost that I will have grown but my life will not, that I will just slot back in and soon it will be as if this wonderful adventure never happened. Does that make sense?" of my own feelings when I returned from a year out (sadly 10 years ago now!).

Don't worry. Life at home may well feel a bit restricted and, yes, it'll take time to adjust (I reckon coming home is much tougher than leaving), but if you're anything like me then it will never feel like it never happened. I guess the reason I have avidly followed the Netjetters over the past five months is because I still relate to travelling. In fact, I still travel as often as I can - currently I am planning a trip to South America for a couple of years from now.

There's plenty more of the world to see, and youll have plenty more opportunities to see it. "Traveller" is a state of mind, and nothing can take that away from you. Good luck with the last few weeks

fields.headline: Chilling in Chile
fields.standfirst: Sue takes a breather in Santiago to prepare for more adventures ahead
fields.trailText: I have been a bit stuck this week - stuck in Santiago. It is my own fault as I decided to book a tour for Peru and Machu Picchu. That meant sending out lots of emails, waiting for replies, making decisions and more waiting. I should have done it all weeks ago.
fields.body:
I have been a bit stuck this week - stuck in Santiago. It is my own fault as I decided to book a tour for Peru and Machu Picchu. That meant sending out lots of emails, waiting for replies, making decisions and more waiting. I should have done it all weeks ago.

Santiago is not a bad place to be stuck. It is a pleasant city, roomier and less cosmopolitan than Buenos Aries, more Spanish. There is the same shiny shoe obsession and lots of coffee shops, although in some of them there are no tables and chairs, you just stand round a high counter. The Chileans obviously love their ice cream, as these places abound, vying to produce the biggest most elaborate ones.

I had another attack of deja vu as I arrived on Sunday and everything was shut. My accommodation was in a lovely hostel with charming hosts, but it was too much to pay for a room with no windows and a dribble of a shower. So again I moved on next day to a place half the price, new and clean if somewhat soulless.

Monday I must have walked miles exploring the city. I walked up Cerro Santa Lucia, a huge rock in the middle of the city which gives lovely views over Santiago with the Andes in the background.

Tuesday was going to be bank and shopping day in a different area of the city. (Sadly I have managed to lose my sleeping bag somewhere in Argentina. I must have left it in one of the hotels before I went to Iguazu.) I ventured onto the underground pleasantly surprised at how quiet it was. The totally shuttered shopping centre made me check my little calendar to then realise it was May 1 - a holiday here too.

Instead, I went to the even bigger hill of San Cristobel which forms the Parque Metropolitano. A funicular takes you up almost vertically and you come down by cable car. At the very top is a huge statue of the virgin Mary, nearly as big as all the satellite masts that surround it.

Wednesday was doing all the things I meant to do Tuesday. I even managed to get a bit of a trim of my straggles in a hairdressers. Risky with no Spanish but it turned out OK. Thanks to Simon for the info on Buenos Aires and Paul on Santiago- I never managed to find the fish market or the restaurant he recommended.

Replies to my emails were now starting to come in and I had an offer from Exodus to go on a trip walking the Inca Trail. I agonised whether to do it. The aches in my legs after 3 days of walking round a flat city convinced me that maybe at this point I am just too tired. I think I would have gone for it a couple of months ago. I hope I do not regret the decision when I am back home and rested.

With only 4 weeks to go my thoughts inevitably begin to turn to home more often. I am looking forward to seeing my children (I am hoping to go and see Ben in Japan in the summer), all my friends, my lovely little house if it is still standing, my 2 cats and to sleeping in my own bed. The thing I have most craved is a pint of warm flat English beer - IPA to be exact. Someone line one up for me please. I am a little worried about how I will settle back down. My fear is almost that I will have grown but my life will not, that I will just slot back in and soon it will be as if this wonderful adventure never happened. Does that make sense?

Still, 4 weeks left to enjoy. I am fixed up now to join a Tucan tour. I have hardly spoken to anybody so far in South America so, despite what I said in Australia, it will be good to be in a group for a couple of weeks. I spent most of today arranging to fly up to the desert at San Pedro de Atacama (with a lot of help from the very patient Claudia at PassTours). I have been trying to work out how to then get to Lima on Monday, when the tour starts. Apparently there are buses but it all has to be booked from up there - rather a tight schedule but I am sure it will work out. Ever the optimist.

I thought I had better write this today as I do not know if they have the internet in the desert. This has been a bit of a rambling report and for once without any superlatives - a welcome rest perhaps!

Happy birthday to my son Sam. Peru next week

Sue

fields.headline: Election press roundup
fields.trailText:
The Guardian
Blair warns of bruising poll battle
Tony Blair braced his party for bruising setbacks in the run up to the general election, admitting the Labour government had "not done everything people want" and must fight for every vote.
fields.body:
The Guardian
Blair warns of bruising poll battle
Tony Blair braced his party for bruising setbacks in the run up to the general election, admitting the Labour government had "not done everything people want" and must fight for every vote.

William Hague used the launch of the Conservatives' manifesto for the local election to argue that Labour has "the same record of incompetence, arrogance, mismanagement and inefficiency in local government" as at national level.

Hague pledges hard line on unwed mothers and travellers
William Hague unveiled a series of hardline policies for the local election. The section of the manifesto, entitled Helping Teenage Mothers and Families, said: "The first question when an unwed teenager is pregnant should not be whether there is a council flat for her, but whether her parents can support her and her child when she finishes school or looks for work."

The Times
Blair heads for second term today
Tony Blair will today announce June 7 as the election date, after telling his party to show hunger and humility as it seeks re-election. He told his cabinet yesterday: "The Conservatives will run a campaign based on apathy, cynicism and short-term tax cuts. We have to go out and win the case for long-term reform and change."

Back Blair for sake of Europe, Schröder urges
The German chancellor Gerhard Schröder yesterday called for a Labour victory so that Britain "could work in Europe for Europe."

Hague hopes Womble will hit right note
Lisa Verrico reviews the parties' battle anthems. The Tories' Heartlands is like the theme from Titanic, whereas Labour's Lifted by the Lighthouse Family makes Blair remind her of "an embarassing uncle who thinks he's still up to date with the hit parade".

Financial Times
Hague commits Tories to rolling tax cuts
A rolling programme of tax cuts, including sharp reductions in capital gains tax, will be promised by William Hague as part of a long-term Conservative drive to shrink the size of the state.

In an interview with the paper, Hague says the £8bn cut in annual taxes promised by year three of the next parliament was the first step in "very clear and radical plans for tax reduction" to be set out during the campaign.

The Daily Telegraph
Phoney war over as Blair fires the gun
Blair admits New Labour hasn't lived up to all its ambitious promises which secured his landslide majority. The Tories, meanwhile, had kicked off their own campaign by launching their manifesto for local elections.

Tory theme tune throws a wobbly
The Tories unveiled their theme tune and things went wrong. Homelands, or "Wobble on a Womble" as it is now known, made its debut in a London basement with bad acoustics.

Composer Mike Batt, who brought us the Wombles theme tune, said: "I wanted the music to have gravitas and strength of purpose."

Flying start to campaign for Lib Dems
Charles Kennedy to take 2,000-mile, three-day tour of 11 media events throughout England, Scotland and Wales.

The Independent
Blair orders ministers to be "humble and hungry"
He has told ministers to forget opinion polls which point to a landslide victory and to earn every vote. "We have to show a sense of humility," he told the 75-minute special Downing Street session yesterday.

Tories start battle as the weakest-ever opposition Polls say William Hague is the most unpopular opposition leader of all time. Neil Kinnock, James Callaghan, Sir Alex Douglas-Home, Michael Foot and Edward Heath are named as other leaders who "let the side down".

Daily Mail
Labour: We failed to deliver
Blair plays it humble as election race begins. Tony Blair begins the battle for a historic second term in office today by admitting he has failed to deliver all he has promised in the first.

The prime minister pledged to fight with "honesty and humility" and urged colleagues to "show we are hungry for this, not just because we want to remain in power but because we have a purpose."

From the local campaign trail, Hague gets in the first shots. An "upbeat" William Hague launched his manifesto for the only poll yet confirmed for June 7: the local council elections.

The Sun
Let's Go: June 7 election to be called by Blair today
Tony Blair will visit Buckingham Palace today to ask the Queen to dissolve parliament. (The Ronnie Biggs story pushes this announcment back to p10.)

A source is quoted saying: "Tony's had his mind on June 7 for over a month and nothing has happened in that time to dissuade him. But he wanted to consult his Cabinet colleagues first - and they all gave him the nod."

Hague Theme is by Mr Womble
Wombles theme-tune composer Mike Batt has composed a melody called Heartlands for the Tories' election broadcasts and rallies.

The Mirror
We're Off! Blair to call June 7 General Election today. The election will be a one-horse race, says another story, but Blair must make sure Labour's hug majority is not dented by voter apathy.

The contest will be the first fought on the internet, with e-mails and text messages set to form a key part of the media used. Labour will offer SMS messages like "X 4 LBR IF UR UP 4 IT".

Daily Star
Blair Readies MPs For Fight
Tony Blair ordered a Bank Holiday cabinet meeting as he readied to fire the starting pistol for the June 7 General Election.

The prime minister told colleagues: "In 1997 people were desperate to get rid of the Tories, but this time we don't have that advantage."

fields.headline: Scientists criticise government funding
fields.trailText: Two of the UK's leading scientific figures have publicly criticised government funding of science.
fields.body:
Two of the UK's leading scientific figures have publicly criticised government funding of science.

Professor David King, the government's chief scientific advisor, told the House of Commons' science and technology select committee last week that he was not confident about civil servants' capabilities as too much governmental funding was now being outsourced.

He said that the loss of research expertise within government meant ministers no longer knew what questions they could ask of scientists.

Other senior academics agree that something is wrong, and not just with the funding of research within government.

The chief executive and deputy chairman of the Natural Environment Research Council (NERC), Professor John Lawton, says that while research councils' budgets have increased significantly in real terms over the last ten years, the opposite has been the case in government research.

And even though he has been a beneficiary of the changes, the loss of government research facilities has affected everyone. He also questions whether the increases have been large enough for Britain to stay at the forefront of scientific research. Scientific budgets are not increasing fast enough to cope with a doubling of scientific knowledge every ten years, he said.

But the bigger problem may be that some areas of research have missed out on funding, even though research councils are using their discretionary budgets to fund long term research. Although he agrees that governments have to set priorities, Professor Lawton thinks we may come to regret some of the losses.

For example, "We are losing taxonomists. You just have to speak to Kew Gardens or the Natural History Museum to see they are losing staff and are not able to train new ones. Which is fine - until you need to identify if a particular insect is a disease vector," he said.

But some of his colleagues think that long term studies are being jettisoned in favour of short term priorities.

Professor Judith Petts, deputy director of Manchester University's centre for environmental research and training, said, "The councils need more flexibility to decide where to spend their money. Already the medical sciences are being given more priority than issues like global warming, although there is a lot of good work going on."

fields.headline: Cornwall to get first university
fields.trailText: Cornwall is to get its first university as part of a £54m drive to keep local talent in the county, it was announced this week.
fields.body:
Cornwall is to get its first university as part of a £54m drive to keep local talent in the county, it was announced this week.

At present, approximately 90% of young people in Cornwall who take up places in higher education leave the county and do not return.

But it is hoped that the brand new, purpose-built university will encourage youngsters to stay in the county. As well as offering the chance to study for degrees and other professional qualifications, it will also provide internet-style "lifelong learning" for older students who want to improve their skills. The so-called Combined Universities of Cornwall in Falmouth will join forces with the region's further education colleges, and will be the hub of post-16 learning in the area. A site in Falmouth will be the base for degree level study and research. It will aim to provide the region with a highly skilled young workforce to aid business growth, Education Secretary David Blunkett said earlier this week.
