webTitle: The seven ages of an academic

fields.headline: The seven ages of an academic
fields.trailText: Professor Mike Rennie introduces the seven ages of an academic. From the PhD student to the research postdoc to the head of department, our careers page will offer advice and information for each stage of the academic career.
fields.body:
Shakespeare's Seven Ages describes the entire life of a man, from the mewling, puking infant to the lean and slipper'd pantaloon - who, of course, ends the last scene "sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything". It is, of course, easy to see some parallels between Shakespeare's Seven Ages and the seven ages of an academic.

I imagine many supervisors have regarded their PhD students as mewling and puking, but PhD students are hardly infants. And although I am sure many junior academics can recognise their professors as being "full of strange oaths, jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel, seeking the bubble of reputation", all of an academic's ages have to be fitted in to the short period between the early 20s and middle 60s - just over 40 years for most people.

We can identify our seven ages of an academic as: PhD studentship; postdoctoral fellowships (one or more); first lectureship (for those brave enough to venture into a career with few material rewards); the leadership of a research group and then, at last, the glittering prizes: a personal chair or, even better, an established professorship.

Then, unless one is a particularly well-balanced (and well supported) professor, things arguably start to go downhill, as administrative loads are rapidly and endlessly added. It is pay-back time as far as the university is concerned, and becoming Head of Department and possibly Dean are often unavoidable, either by coercion or choice. Some academics do make a difference to their department, the best developing their staff, enhancing their physical surroundings and increasing the quality of teaching and research.

But what about the halcyon days many academics dream of, when they will be released from the responsibilities of supervising students, setting budgets and suffering the agonies of promotion boards? It seems to me that some of the best teachers and researchers I know have indeed not recognised any bar to intellectual sprightliness at the age of 65 or more. There are many examples of Emeritus professors who continue to be productive as researchers. Alternatively, they eschew the pleasures of writing grants and papers and instead spend their time making up for the deficiencies of their younger colleagues' teaching.

Given the right attitudes, a huge tolerance for overwork and underpay and like-minded colleagues and students, the personal rewards of academia remain great. Whether this balance remains positive in the face of the government's current policies I cannot say, but if I were in my 20s again I would probably still take the risk, if only for the independence of thought and action that a career in academia brings.

 Mike Rennie is Symers Professor of Physiology at the University of Dundee.

webTitle: Nero's folly crumbles after heavy rain in Rome

fields.headline: Nero's folly crumbles after heavy rain in Rome
fields.trailText: Part of the ceiling of Nero's Golden House, a palace so sumptuous it scandalised even the ancient Romans, has collapsed after torrential rain. Bricks and plaster crashed into a gallery next to the octagonal chamber early on Sunday morning, hours before tourists were due to visit the site, also known as the Domus Aurea.
fields.body:
Part of the ceiling of Nero's Golden House, a palace so sumptuous it scandalised even the ancient Romans, has collapsed after torrential rain. Bricks and plaster crashed into a gallery next to the octagonal chamber early on Sunday morning, hours before tourists were due to visit the site, also known as the Domus Aurea.

Yesterday a gap 80cm square yawned beside the oculus, a hole at the top of the ceiling, which sheltered frescoes on the walls below. Archaeologists and restorers, wearing hard hats, emerged from an inspection to say that the palace would be partially reopened tomorrow.

Further collapses were not ruled out, however, as rainwater had infiltrated cavities despite an 18-year restoration, which culminated in a triumphant re-opening in 1999.

The collapse is certain to fuel fears about the safety of other imperial remnants in Rome. Potentially destructive water infiltration has been detected in the sprawling complex of ruins known as the Forum, which symbolised Roman power since the eighth century BC with temples, basilicas and arches.

Maintenance has been held up for decades by lack of funds. A spurt of money for last year's jubilee, or holy year, has now evaporated.

Conservationists are also concerned about threats to the Colosseum from underground water and vegetation. Some corridors where gladiators once waited to fight are overgrown with plants. Exotic species from Africa date back to seeds dropped from the hooves and paws of imported animals.

In January, the Vatican closed the tomb of St Peter to tourists and scholars because of humidity damage, which had allowed the growth of saline encrustations and microbiological phenomena.

Emperor Nero took advantage of the great fire of AD 64, which historians say he did not start, to clear swaths of central Rome for a new palace.

Built on the Oppian Hill, a ridge on Monte Esquilino, the architects Severo and Celere created a pastoral idyll by ringing the structure with gardens and an artificial lake. Gold, silver, pearl, ivory, marble and frescoes from the peak period in Roman art adorned more than 1,000 rooms, taking up more than 30,000 sq metres in an attempt to surpass oriental and Egyptian monarchs.

Romans denounced such megalomania - "All Rome has become a villa" - and Nero's successors were quick to demolish it. The lake was drained to become the site of the Colosseum and the palace was turned into public baths.

During the Renaissance, Raphael and other artists clambered among its ruins to study the frescoes. The octagonal chamber was one of 32 rooms which survived to be excavated and restored. Hundreds of people visit daily.

Silvana Rizzo, director of the Imperial Forum, said that recent deluges, after one of the wettest Aprils on record, combined with humidity, put stress on ancient structures: "In the last few days I have examined the situation in the Forum and even there there are serious problems with disposal of water."

It was thought likely that Nero's palace had been further weakened by roots from trees at a nearby park.

webTitle: Academics given guide to the web

fields.headline: Academics given guide to the web
fields.trailText: A £300,000 initiative launched today by 30 universities will provide free courses guiding students and academics towards the best web resources on their subject.
fields.body:
A £300,000 initiative launched today by 30 universities aims to allow every student and academic to get the best out of the web.

The Resource Discovery Network (RDN) Virtual Training Suite, launched today by the parliamentary under-secretary of state for education and technology, Michael Wills, will provide 40 free courses intended to guide an individual towards the best resources in their subject.

Over the last year, a host of schemes have sought to make university courses adopt new technology into their design. But these efforts will be useless if academics do not have the technological literacy to make use of them.

"Lecturers and some students are extremely good at using traditional research tools, but there's a huge variation in skills levels in using the internet. These tutorials allow people to learn quickly, quietly and in the corner," said Emma Price, project manager for the new scheme.

The ability to complete the tutorials privately is one of the scheme's aims, as it allows those shy about technology to get over their phobia without having to own up to it.

The training suite was funded by the government's joint information systems committee and is still under construction. Users approach the tutorials through "hubs" for each of the different subject areas, including social sciences, humanities or physical sciences.

The vice-chancellor of Bristol University, Sir John Kingman, said: "The ability to locate, evaluate and use information on the internet is becoming an essential skill. This new educational resource will help people in all subject disciplines to learn more."

fields.headline: Debt forcing students into prostitution
fields.trailText: Students are being forced into prostitution and drug dealing because of debt and lack of financial support, according to research from Westminster University.
fields.body:
Students are being forced into vice, including prostitution and drug dealing, by debt and lack of financial support, according to research carried out by academics at Westminster University.

Researchers reject the argument that student prostitution is merely an urban myth. Dr Ron Roberts asked 500 students from Imperial College and the University of Westminster about their financial situation. Then the students were asked whether they knew anyone involved with prostitution, drugs or crime to support their studies.

Three and a half percent knew a student working as a prostitute, and 22% knew a drug dealer.

The survey was carried out during the abolition of the student grant scheme, but before the introduction of tuition fees. Dr Roberts believes that the decline in support for students has exacerbated, if not actually caused, the increase in student vice.

Last week, Liverpool University's student union rejected as an "urban myth" allegations that students were working in the sex trade to fund their degrees. But a leading expert on prostitution in the UK, Professor David Barrett, said that Professor Robert's figure on the student sex trade sounded about right.

"I have been writing about and researching this area for ten years, and always saying that I would be amazed if there is a university where some students are not involved in the sex trade - it happens everywhere," he said.

Although that message is not popular with individual vice chancellors, Professor Barrett believes that, for health reasons, it is important that it gets through. He is worried in particular by two facts: punters are paying £10 or £20 more for unprotected sex and there are a growing number of sexually transmitted diseases that it is difficult, if not impossible, to treat.

Together they suggest that unless safe sex is brought higher up the agenda at universities, there are serious implications for student health, not just for those directly involved with prostitution, but for all casual student relationships.

Given that various universities have moved from funding the free provision of condoms towards a restricted supply, Professor Barrett could have a point.

fields.headline: High anxiety
fields.standfirst: The stress of exams can precipitate student mental health problems.  Kate Coxon  investigates
fields.trailText: The stress of exams can precipitate student mental health problems. Kate Coxon investigates
fields.body:
Sitting exams is stressful enough, but if you are vulnerable to depression and anxiety it's nearly impossible. And if you don't yet have these problems, then worrying about getting that 2.1 and finding that job, or wasting your parents' money and paying back your debts may well bring them on.

Recent research studies suggest that mental health problems among students are becoming more widespread and more severe. Research by Thames Valley University for the Mental Health Foundation in Janu ary this year found 46% of male and 64% of female students to be suffering from possible clinical anxiety, with possible clinical depression in 12% and 25% respectively. This compares unfavourably with 1987 figures estimating that fewer than one in four students showed "significant emotional disturbance".

A survey of students at two London universities published last December showed that students had poorer physical and substantially poorer psychological health than non-students of the same age and sex. The latest Annual Survey of Counselling in Further and Higher Education confirmed that the proportion of "seri ously disturbed" students continues to increase. Meanwhile, student suicides have risen dramatically - from 2.4 per 100,000 students in 1983/4 to 9.7 in 1993/4 - a four-fold increase.

University counselling services certainly report increases in students seeking help, though Christopher Butler, head of the counselling service at Royal Holloway, London, cautions against jumping to conclusions. "My service is certainly busier, but we can't say with any certainty why this is so. For example, we may be publicising the service more effectively, or students may perceive it as being less stigmatising."

Two things are clear: student numbers have increased in recent years, and students are under more financial pressure. As well as being a source of stress, financial problems have clear links with depression and anxiety. Last year's survey of the two London universities found that poor mental health was linked to longer working hours outside university, and that students who were considering abandoning their studies because of finances were likely to have poorer mental health.

A current research project looking at suicide prevention from the student's perspective asks students to fill in an online questionnaire. "Finances and accommodation problems are emerging as key sources of stress for students," says Natasha Donnelly, a lecturer at University College Chichester, who is doing the research.

Some counselling services, such as Royal Holloway's, take a proactive approach at this time of year. "Exams can act as a 'precipitating event' to further problems," says Christopher Butler. "We offer a psychological profiling questionnaire for students to help them assess whether they are likely to have problems around exam time and provide support accordingly."

Additional pressures do not help. "Increasingly, students are forced to take on part-time jobs, and these exacerbate the stress of study," says Rachel Cashman, the National Union of Students vice-president for welfare. "In the run-up to exams, students who juggle revision with part-time work and other course demands are left with little time for relaxation, which makes them particularly vulnerable to stress."

The view of the NUS is that the introduction of tuition fees and scrapping of the maintenance grant, combined with a policy of wider access to higher education, have put pressure on student support services. These policies have not been accompanied by increased investment in student services.

Amidst growing concern, the Committee for Vice-Chancellors and Principals - now Universities UK -last year produced guidelines on student mental health,underlining the importance of professional support.

Universities UK and the Standing Conference of Principals also commissioned research into student suicides, although the project has been temporarily suspended due to the illness of the researcher.

Institutions have responded with a range of initiatives, largely funded by a £6m special funding programme from the Higher Education Funding Council for England to improve provision for students with disabilities. Nottingham Trent University and Lancaster University are disseminating good practice in supporting students with mental illness, and in Oxford health service agencies are developing work with universities and colleges.

Leicester University has set up two surveys - one of students, the other of staff - to identify the extent of psychological problems and explore the attitudes and training needs of staff. The project team has produced a guides and reports for students and staff, including non-teaching staff.

While counsellors argue that student mental health should be the concern of the whole institution, many universities are anxious about investigating what they regard as the sensitive subject of student mental health.

"We need more statistics in this area," says Rachel Cashman of the NUS, "but it can be a taboo subject. It's as if institutions are scared they'll be seen as a 'death trap' or as a place where students go to be unhappy."

If some universities are dragging their feet in researching this area, others are finding it a positive experience. Leicester University is in the process of repeating its survey, this time asking additional questions about student finances. This is surely a step in the right direction. More research is needed which looks at the links between stress, finances and student mental health. And more funds are necessary to support those who support the students.

Anna's story

Anna Peters (not her real name) completed a degree in business studies at a university in the south-east of England in 1999, having struggled with mental health problems throughout the course.

"My father died when I was 16, and some time after that I began to suffer from depression and panic attacks. By the time I was 18 I was self-harming as well, and had an eating disorder. I wasn't well enough to start my degree until I was 20. When I began the course, I lived for the first year with a friend, but she left at the end of my first year. In my second year I became very isolated and my panic attacks and eating problems returned. I went to the counselling service, but they seemed only able to help with the practicalities of my situation, such as accommodation.

"I had one friend on the course, and one day she just told me she was driving me to the doctor. He got me an appoint ment with a psychiatrist and I was admitted to hospital as an in-patient immediately. When I was in hospital I was advised that it would be better for my mental health if I could postpone my course for a while - the deadlines and exams were additional stresses - but I knew that if I did that I would never finish it.

"I spent the rest of my course in and out of hospital. I was on betablockers and antidepressants, and having cognitive behavioural therapy sessions at the hospital. I somehow kept up with the coursework, more or less. People lent me lecture notes and my tutor was very sympathetic - some of the deadlines were extended for me.

"When I finally came to sit my exams, special arrangements were made for me as I suffered from claustrophobic panic attacks and could never have done an exam in a room full of people. It's a miracle that I actually completed the course."

Where to go for help

Did you know that one in four people seeks help for mental health problems at some time in their lives?

The most common forms of mental distress are anxiety and depression: one person in 10 is likely to have a disabling anxiety disorder at some stage in their lives, and one in 10 people will have depression at any one time.

In 16- to 19-year-olds the incidence of serious mental illness increases twentyfold, compared with 13- to 15- year-olds.

Estimates suggest that the true suicide rate is 50-60% higher than the official rate.

University counselling services and student unions can offer advice on all aspects of student mental health. See below for a range of useful resources and contacts that can help students and their families through difficult times, particularly in the summer exam period when stress levels are often at their highest.

The Educational Development and Support Centre

Based at Leicester University, publishes a booklet called Helping Students in Difficulty, aimed at personal tutors and other staff. It also publishes a range of study skills guides for students on subjects such as revision, exam stress, stress management for presentations and interviews and time management. Contact: edsc@le.ac.uk

A research project which looks at student stress and support services from a student perspective. For information, see: www.studentstress.org/ (Current higher education students can also complete a questionnaire confidentially at this website address)

"In the run-up to exams, students who juggle revision with part-time work and other course demands are left with little time for relaxation, which makes them particularly vulnerable to stress." The view of the NUS is that the introduction of tuition fees and scrapping of the maintenance grant, combined with a policy of wider access to higher education, have put pressure on student support services. These policies have not been accompanied by increased investment in student services. Amidst growing concern, the Committee for Vice-Chancellors and Principals - now Universities UK -last year produced guidelines on student mental health,underlining the importance of professional support. Universities UK and the Standing Conference of Principals also commissioned research into student suicides, although the project has been temporarily suspended due to the illness of the researcher. Institutions have responded with a range of initiatives, largely funded by a £6m special funding programme from the Higher Education Funding Council for England to improve provision for students with disabilities. Nottingham Trent University and Lancaster University are disseminating good practice in supporting students with mental illness, and in Oxford health service agencies are developing work with universities and colleges. Leicester University has set up two surveys - one of students, the other of staff - to identify the extent of psychological problems and explore the attitudes and training needs of staff. The project team has produced a guides and reports for students and staff, including non-teaching staff. While counsellors argue that student mental health should be the concern of the whole institution, many universities are anxious about investigating what they regard as the sensitive subject of student mental health. "We need more statistics in this area," says Rachel Cashman of the NUS, "but it can be a taboo subject. It's as if institutions are scared they'll be seen as a 'death trap' or as a place where students go to be unhappy." If some universities are dragging their feet in researching this area, others are finding it a positive experience. Leicester University is in the process of repeating its survey, this time asking additional questions about student finances. This is surely a step in the right direction. More research is needed which looks at the links between stress, finances and student mental health. And more funds are necessary to support those who support the students. Anna's story Anna Peters (not her real name) completed a degree in business studies at a university in the south-east of England in 1999, having struggled with mental health problems throughout the course. "My father died when I was 16, and some time after that I began to suffer from depression and panic attacks. By the time I was 18 I was self-harming as well, and had an eating disorder. I wasn't well enough to start my degree until I was 20. When I began the course, I lived for the first year with a friend, but she left at the end of my first year. In my second year I became very isolated and my panic attacks and eating problems returned. I went to the counselling service, but they seemed only able to help with the practicalities of my situation, such as accommodation. "I had one friend on the course, and one day she just told me she was driving me to the doctor. He got me an appoint ment with a psychiatrist and I was admitted to hospital as an in-patient immediately. When I was in hospital I was advised that it would be better for my mental health if I could postpone my course for a while - the deadlines and exams were additional stresses - but I knew that if I did that I would never finish it. "I spent the rest of my course in and out of hospital. I was on betablockers and antidepressants, and having cognitive behavioural therapy sessions at the hospital. I somehow kept up with the coursework, more or less. People lent me lecture notes and my tutor was very sympathetic - some of the deadlines were extended for me. "When I finally came to sit my exams, special arrangements were made for me as I suffered from claustrophobic panic attacks and could never have done an exam in a room full of people. It's a miracle that I actually completed the course." Where to go for help Did you know that one in four people seeks help for mental health problems at some time in their lives? The most common forms of mental distress are anxiety and depression: one person in 10 is likely to have a disabling anxiety disorder at some stage in their lives, and one in 10 people will have depression at any one time. In 16- to 19-year-olds the incidence of serious mental illness increases twentyfold, compared with 13- to 15- year-olds. Estimates suggest that the true suicide rate is 50-60% higher than the official rate. University counselling services and student unions can offer advice on all aspects of student mental health. See below for a range of useful resources and contacts that can help students and their families through difficult times, particularly in the summer exam period when stress levels are often at their highest. The Educational Development and Support Centre Based at Leicester University, publishes a booklet called Helping Students in Difficulty, aimed at personal tutors and other staff. It also publishes a range of study skills guides for students on subjects such as revision, exam stress, stress management for presentations and interviews and time management. fields.headline: Singapore lecturers get salary cuts
fields.trailText: Educators at the National University of Singapore are ruing the decision to phase out the old civil service system inherited from colonialism. They've all just had their salaries cut, in some cases by up to 15%.
fields.body:
Nearly 100 educators at the National University of Singapore have already had reason to rue their institution's recent decision to phase out the old civil service system that the Southeast Asian city-state inherited from its erstwhile British colonial overlords. They've all just had their salaries cut, in some cases by up to 15%, according to official figures released this week.

Singapore's flagship institution of higher learning enrols some 30,000 students and employs around 1,600 faculty members.

The downward salary revisions were among the first fruits of a number of significant changes inaugurated last year by the Southeast Asian nation's government, which is looking for its centres of learning to find new and better ways of aggressively courting American and European scholars to collaborate in their global endeavours.

Singapore's two established universities have long been part of the former colony's strong British-style civil-service tradition, dating back to its independence in 1965, in which salary levels and pay increases have pretty much always been a sure fact of academic life. A third institution, the Singapore Management University, which opened for business nearly a year ago, already operates along private lines.

At the same time, new institutional initiatives at the universities have until now tended to be closely monitored by the state, as much as the wider systems of university governance.

"In the new global economy, however, we need to move beyond that," said C F Shih, the vice chancellor of the National University of Singapore, at the time of the announced changes.

"Higher education is no longer about simply being the best in Singapore or even the region - our universities have to operate as world-class institutions."

Effectively, he said, the universities are now operating in a manner similar to British universities, which, although publicly funded, enjoy autonomy in matters of governance and are free from overt political meddling.

Singapore's Ministry of Education will no longer scrutinise individual decisions and proposals made by its universities, and financial support from the public treasury will now be made in three-year cycles instead of annually.

For the first time this year, staff members were paid and received increments based solely on their performance, while aspiring professors have had to deal with considerably tougher standards for promotions. Applicants for a professorship, for example, must now be vetted by at least six external professors in their field, twice the previous number.

Here again, said Dr Shih, the national university was only following after a style "you would see at an elite American or European institution".

A majority of employees, however, received the kinds of salary increases this year to which they've traditionally been accustomed - some by as much as 30%, according to the figures released.

webTitle: Sideline rage at US school sports days

fields.headline: Sideline rage at US school sports days
fields.trailText: They are a familiar sight and sound at all school sporting events: parents urging their progeny to glory on the field. But in the US, some of them are not setting the younger generation an example in sportsmanship.
fields.body:
They are a familiar sight and sound at all school sporting events: parents urging their progeny to glory on the field. But in the US, some of them are not setting the younger generation an example in sportsmanship.

So competitive are these parents that physical or verbal abuse takes place on the sidelines at about 15% of events - triple the incidence five years ago, according to the National Alliance for Youth Sports.

More than 20 states have adopted, or are considering, tougher penalties against those who attack officials and in some places parents are obliged to have counselling before their children are allowed to play competitive sports. Other matches must be played in silence to combat "sideline rage".

One father from Reading, Massachusetts, goes on trial shortly, accused of killing another father in a dispute while they were watching their sons at hockey practice. He denies manslaughter.

Ten people were arrested when a fight broke out between more than 30 parents at a football game in El Paso, Texas. One father stabbed another between the eyes. A volleyball coach in Rockford, Illinois, was sacked after being accused of taking a meat cleaver to school after an argument with a referee.

"Many parents have lost sight of the purpose of sports," said Thomas Tutko, a clinical sports psychologist. "They're asking 'Is my kid going to get a scholarship? Is my kid going to win?'"

Parents in Jupiter, Florida, must attend an hour-long good-behaviour session before little Buddy is allowed to take the field and in El Paso, where the message clearly takes longer to sink in, the session takes three-and-a-half hours. Another 300 cities have plans to follow suit.

webTitle: Architect teams to compete on nursery design

fields.headline: Architect teams to compete on nursery design
fields.trailText: The government's plans for a network of 900 neighbourhood nurseries will take a step forward this week with the launch of an architectural competition to create the blueprint for the nursery of the future.
fields.body:
The government's plans for a network of 900 neighbourhood nurseries will take a step forward this week with the launch of an architectural competition to create the blueprint for the nursery of the future.

Cash prizes will be awarded to the team of architects which creates the most impressive designs for nurseries in three categories: newly built, conversions and extensions.

The judging panel will be chaired by Sir Nicholas Serota, director of Tate Modern, and will include the architect Lord Rogers, who heads a government taskforce on urban regeneration, and Jon Rouse, chief executive of the commission for architecture and the built environment.

Margaret Hodge, the early years minister, said: "We must put behind us the image of nurseries being provided in cramped, gloomy conditions when children deserve better."

Ministers have set the target of 900 nurseries, all in socially deprived areas, to be reached by 2003-04.

Typically, they are expected to be produced by public and private sector partnerships. Those that meet government criteria will be entitled to up to £270,000 in revenue support over three years for an average-sized nursery with 50 places.

In a commitment to creating purpose-built nurseries with top quality facilities and equipment, the government is putting £100m into the project from lottery money from the new opportunities fund, and £100m from the SureStart programme, which provides facilities for the under-fives.

Three or four big private sector providers, including the nursery company Jigsaw, are understood to be interested in setting up and running the nurseries.

The pre-school umbrella group, Pre-School Learning Alliance, is likely to bolster the project by expressing an interest in creating up to 150 of the 900. The alliance would take responsibility for running them, taking 5% of turnover.

All new nurseries and playgroups will be inspected by the office for standards in education from July, and will be subject to new national standards for childcare facilities due to be published this week.

The government is expected today to announce grants to nurseries and playgroups for outdoor play equipment and facilities such as flower gardens.

webTitle: Evolution is in our hands, say scientists

fields.headline: Evolution is in our hands, say scientists
fields.standfirst: Biologists warned to focus on the future, not the riddles of the past
fields.trailText: Evolution scientists today warn of the spread of a global "pest and weed" environment, with animals and plants such as rats, cockroaches, nettles and thistles flourishing at the expense of more specialised wild organisms.
fields.body:
Evolution scientists today warn of the spread of a global "pest and weed" environment, with animals and plants such as rats, cockroaches, nettles and thistles flourishing at the expense of more specialised wild organisms.

The scientists say that, in the next 5m years, short-term evolution will favour those species able to thrive in the margins of human settlement.

They also warned that decisions made in the next few decades will determine the fate of 500,000bn people, adding that efforts to protect species and wild habitats now will dictate the future course of evolution.

In their startling wake-up call, the group of US, African and British researchers writing in the US journal, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, compared the present mass extinction of species on Earth to past mass extinctions; then, it took roughly 5m years for biological diversity to reassert itself.

"Suppose that the average number of people on Earth during the future recovery period is 2.5bn, by contrast with the 6bn today," said two of the scientists, Norman Myers of Oxford University and Andrew Knoll of Harvard.

"Under these conditions, the total number of people affected by what we do - or do not do - during the next few decades will be in the order of 500 trillion, 10,000 times more people than have existed until now.

"We are thus engaged in by far the largest 'decision' every taken by one human community on the unconsulted behalf of future societies."

The scientists suggested that the world is entering a new period of geological time, the Homogecene, marked by all parts of the planet increasingly coming to resemble each other.

David Woodruff, of the University of California at San Diego, said that between 3,000 and 30,000 of Earth's estimated 10m species were disappearing each year.

"We live at a geological instant when global rates of extinction are at an all time high for the last 65m years, and are increasing," he said.

"The biosphere will have fewer species and be subject to more weed, pest and disease outbreaks...the new [habitats] will be more easily disturbed and invaded, and will have an aesthetically unappealing dullness."

None of this means that evolution will stop - just that it might go in an undesirable direction. "Evolution is not over - set back perhaps - but by no means over," Dr Woodruff said.

Scientists who studied evolution, he said, were obliged to abandon their preference for looking backwards and begin considering the future.

"Some of us advocate a shift from saving things, the products of evolution, to saving the underlying process, evolution itself," he said.

"Like it or not, evolutionary biologists have to recognise that the ultimate test of their science is not their ability to solve the riddles of the past and the origin of species, but rather to manage their viability and prevent their premature extinction - to manage the biosphere's future."

Dr Myers said that much more emphasis should be put on protecting plants and insects, to protect the evolutionary pool, rather than on preserving big beasts like tigers or elephants, which are too few to evolve.

Environmentalists needed to think not just about saving the species we have, but about protecting the planet's ability to generate the species of the future.

"A lot of people would say, 'no, we don't want creepy crawlies', but if we lost half the mammals, we could get by," Dr Myers said.

"If we lost half of all insects, with their pollinating function, our agriculture would be in trouble in just a few seasons.

"We live at a time when, in just the next two decades, we can save some very fundamental processes. If we do that, I think we will be thanked by hundreds of thousands of generations to come, and if we don't, we will be criticised for millions of years."

Going

Hamilton frogs

One of the rarest frogs in the world, Hamilton frogs are small amphibians endemic to Stephens Island in the Cook Strait, New Zealand. First discovered in 1915, about 200 exist. Their future is threatened by stoat invasions

Hawaiian fern

Only one single Diplazium molokaiensis, a member of the wood fern family, has been found in Hawaii during the past two decades, and the species' extinction seems inevitable

Alabama sturgeon

Endangered after a reduction of at least 80% of the population in 10 years. Overfishing, and loss of habitat to blame

Gone

Dusky seaside sparrow

Became extinct in 1987. It is widely considered to be the most recent, well-documented extinction of a vertebrate in the US. Disappearance due entirely to the loss of a natural habitat, the Everglades

Golden Toad

Discovered in Monteverde, Costa Rica, in 1963. Despite being protected, it was presumed extinct when by 1989 the one lone male disappeared

Charco Palma pupfish

Due to falling levels of essential water, the Charco Palma pupfish became extinct in 1994. The species was found at a single spring, Charco La Palma, Aramberri, southern Nuevo León, Mexico.

The 50-70 pupfish disappeared when the spring water was used for human consumption and for irrigation

webTitle: Book reviews:  Just Annoying! by Andy Griffiths, and Feeling Sorry for Celia by Jaclyn Moriarty

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at Just Annoying! by Andy Griffiths, and Feeling Sorry for Celia by Jaclyn Moriarty
fields.body:
Just Annoying!
Andy Griffiths, illustrated by Terry Denton
(Macmillan)

Price: £3.99

Age: 8-11 yrs

It wouldn't be risking much to say that this is not a book to attract literary prizes, but it should go down a storm with selected members of the class. Festooned with puerile cartoons, most of which have only the faintest of connections with the text, these nine accessible stories encapsulate the most irritating aspects of early adolescence - the bits of which grown-ups despair. Andy and his friends have developed being annoying into an art form, but by the end you're strangely fond of the boy. He's not bad, just wayward. And, of course, it's never his fault.

Feeling Sorry for Celia
Jaclyn Moriarty
(Macmillan)

Price: £4.99

Age: 11+

This hectic narrative stir-fry combines letters (imaginary and real) between friends, parents, and the parents of friends; bossy messages stuck to refrigerators; the paranoia of adolescence; moderate hysteria accompanying first love; and the edgy realisation that adults don't always know best. There are several strong plotlines, driven by the larger-than-life personalities who characterise so much Australian fiction for young people. Katherine, plagued by insecurities and a mother who is happiest communicating in capital letters, is at the heart of the action. This book celebrates eccentricity, while gently illuminating its pitfalls.

fields.standfirst: Number Puppies pack
fields.trailText: Number Puppies pack
fields.body:
(Hope Education, tel: 08702 433400, www.hope-education.co.uk)

Price: £116.94 inc VAT

Age/ability range: 5-7 yrs

The manufacturer says:

"The pack includes the full family of Number Puppies plus lots of additional resources, all specifically designed to increase the teaching opportunities, the enjoyment and the learning value of the Number Puppies concept."

Elizabeth Maddocks, reception/ KS1 teacher, Grangetown infants school, Cardiff, says:

"This versatile resource includes large cards, a washing line and small, medium and large plastic puppies. There are fan cards which have shapes on one side and puppies on the other and sorting cards which I particularly liked. It is unusual to find cards specifically made for sorting and they were good for work on sequence and progression. The cards could do with being a bit stronger; we laminated them to en sure they last. The children (4-5 year olds) really enjoyed the product. They learnt about ordering, shape and sorting which fits in very well with the curriculum. We used the pack with groups of four as there aren't enough puppies for larger groups. The children liked pegging the cards on to the washing line. This is a very structured resource which compares well with others of its type."

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Maths | Waves
fields.trailText: Maths | Waves
fields.byline: Compiled by Jim Merrett and Ken Zetie
fields.body:
Maths

All Math

www.allmath.com

Suitable for KS2 teachers

With worksheets, puzzles, lessons and articles, teachers will find plenty of helpful resources on this American site. Under "Kid Resources" there are some challenging investigations. The probability section is good, covering use of spinner, playing cards and dice, but all but the most able children will need an adult to help them.

Maths Tricks

math.educations.net/

Suitable for KS2 teachers & pupils

Offers teaching tips to improve mental maths agility. Techniques taught here include being able to multiply up to 20 x 20 in your head and learning how to square a two-digit number ending in a 5. (Works best on PCs.)

Maths Online

www.mathsonline.co.uk

Suitable for KS2/3 teachers

Offers multimedia facilities - flash movies, simulations and PowerPoint presentations - that liven up maths teaching. There are several tuition sections covering use of a spreadsheet to investigate percentage increases and decreases, volume and area.

Innovation in Maths Teaching

www.ex.ac.uk/cimt/

Suitable for KS2 teachers

The Quick Puzzles pages are well worth printing out as they contain many interesting activities which brighter children can try when they've finished other class tasks. Answers available.

NRICH

nrich.maths.org/primary/ Suitable for KS2 teachers & pupils

Investigations are an important element of the resources from this online maths club, which offers a wide choice of topics including number, space, logic, measurement, probability, shape and space. It also has some open-ended investigations plus parental advice.

Teaching Ideas

www.teachingideas.co.uk

Suitable for KS1/2 teachers

Some excellent investigative activities here, including "What's My Number" by Charlotte Hughes, a game that can be varied according to the age and ability of the children. How Many Squares on a Chessboard will get the children working hard, too (clue: it isn't 64).

Waves

Andy Darvill's Science Site

www.darvill.clara.net/emag/index.htm

Suitable for KS3/4 pupils & teachers

Science teacher Andy Darvill has built an excellent site. See the section on electromagnetic waves focusing on the important topics for GCSE. He also includes tests and worksheets . . . what more do you need?

Computer Animations

www.infoline.ru/g23/5495/Physics/English/waves.htm

Suitable for: Teachers

This Russian site uses animations to demonstrate different types of wave: longitudinal and transverse waves passing through a solid; ripple tank animations; and sound waves being produced by a loudspeaker. The quality is lovely and there are detailed theory pages. Best for demos rather than independent work.

Hunkin's Experiments

www.hunkinsexperiments.com/themes/themes_sound.htm

Suitable for KS3 pupils & teachers

For lovers of The Secret Life of Machines TV series, Tim Hunkin's site includes some of his classic silly yet instructive experiments. This page is all about making sounds - good fun, but it would need a teacher to guide a discussion into what is going on.

World Wide Earthquake Locator

www.geo.ed.ac.uk/quakes/quakes.html

Suitable for KS4 pupils & teachers

Includes background information on earthquakes, as well as up-to-the- minute earthquake reports. A little dry, but very useful.

Physics 2000

www.colorado.edu/physics/2000

Suitable for teachers

Colorado University has put together a great site to teach physics principles through cartoon characters, who ask questions of their cartoon professors. The page on polarisation has a clever applet, allowing you to see the effect of viewing reflected sunlight through a polariser that can be rotated. The explanation pages go rather deeper than necessary for GCSE.

How Stuff Works

www.howstuffworks.com/speaker.htm

Suitable for KS4 pupils & teachers

Great pictures and down-to-earth explanations. How a loudspeaker works, how we hear, innovative speaker designs - just the sort of thing students ask about.

fields.headline: Too much, too young
fields.standfirst: With a drink problem like ours, we shouldn't scoff at Americans, says  Andrew McNeill
fields.trailText: With a drink problem like ours, we shouldn't scoff at Americans, says Andrew McNeill
fields.body:
People in Britain seem to regard the arrest at the age of 19 of President Bush's daughter, Jenna, for underage drinking as confirming the strange illiberality of Americans. They think we are producing a population of drunks. Jenna, by all accounts, was having a beer in a bar but was sober. Euan Blair, three years younger than Jenna, was drunk and incapable in the street. The predominant reaction in the UK to Euan's case was "What is all the fuss about? He's only doing what all 16-year-olds do." As far as the facts were concerned, this was not too far wide of the mark but the complacency should be challenged.

We have one of the biggest youth alcohol problems in Europe. Our teenagers, along with the Danes and the Irish, drink more often and more heavily, get drunk more, and experience more problems related to alcohol than almost all others. Not merely by coincidence, British teenagers are also among the heaviest users of illegal drugs. A culture of intoxication has become entrenched in the youth scene, the main theatre of the "recreational drug wars" in which alcohol is now consumed as one psychoactive commodity among others. Induction into this culture begins early - 11- to 15-year-olds are reckoned to be "starter drinkers", helped on their way by the wide range of alcopops apparently designed especially for them. By the time they get to Euan's age, many teenagers are already looking down on alcopops as drinks for kids. They are now on their way to joining the heaviest drinkers in the population, the 18- to 24-year-old lads and ladettes who are the mainstays of the alcohol market and its branch offices in the accidents and emergencies departments.

If this is just youthful excess, there is a large price attached. Each year alcohol is responsible for the deaths of around 50,000 young Europeans. Here we have record numbers of teenagers admitted to hospital with alcoholic poisoning, - one of a whole range of potential disasters befalling individuals that add up to a national scandal.

Not all the problems caused by alcohol are as trivial or as transient as hangovers: some can last a lifetime, and they affect not just the drinkers but everyone around them. Alcohol-related violence is endemic. We also know that regular drinking in the teenage years increases the risk of alcohol dependence, with all that implies, in later life.

If we as a society really want to tackle this, then we are going to have to care more, and be more honest. We must abandon our present policy of veering erratically between hypocritical panic-mongering and complacency. The problems with our young people are real, but it is we who have made them as they are. There is a big problem with alcohol in society as a whole: the alcoholic excess of youth is not an act of rebellion but of conformity.

What do we do? We need to accept that alcohol is not a preferable alternative to "drugs": they are all part and parcel of the same scene and the one leads to the other.

We, especially parents, need to accept that the idea of inoculating children against alcohol problems by introducing them to it early is bunkum. The evidence is clear that delay is what is required. We need to reduce the pressure on young people to drink exerted by increasingly aggressive marketing campaigns of the alcohol industry. It is hardly surprising that alcohol is a problem when virtually the whole leisure environment of young people is permeated with messages urging them to drink it.

We should require our government to spend less time arranging for the pubs to be open 24 hours a day and rather more implementing a national strategy on alcohol misuse which will address the problems of young people without scapegoating them.

When we've done all that, we'll be in a better position to sneer at the Americans.

Andrew McNeill is co-director, Institute of Alcohol Studies.

webTitle: Government loses its nerve over radical reform

fields.headline: College grants fail to make manifesto
fields.standfirst: Government loses its nerve over radical reform. By  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Government loses its nerve over radical reform. By Peter Kingston
fields.body:
When, as everyone expects, Tony Blair calls the election tomorrow, supporters of one of the government's more successful education schemes are in for disappointment. Despite the strong evidence that Education Maintenance Allowances (Emas) are having a notable effect in keeping 16-year-olds on in learning, Labour's manifesto will not contain a proposal to extend them nationwide, senior sources say.

Officially the reason is that a national scheme must wait at least until the Comprehensive Spending Review in 2002. But there is suspicion that excessive political caution is behind its exclusion from the manifesto.

In opposition, Labour had proposed abolishing child benefit for those over 16 who stay on in education and replacing it by means-tested Emas. But fears that tampering with a supposedly sacred benefit would antagonise middle-class voters persuaded Labour to put the idea on ice before the election.

Now it is again resisting the opportunity to introduce a national targeted scheme linked to a scrapping of a universal benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds.

If Labour had put Emas on its election platform it would have completed the radical shift begun in scrapping maintenance grants for higher education students and reinforced the government's commitment to ensuring that more youngsters continue learning beyond compulsory school age.

New unpublished research by the Learning and Skills Development Agency reinforces earlier studies by the DfEE that the Emas, worth up to £40 a week, are influencing year 11 students to stay on in full-time education in areas where they are piloted.

In Middlesbrough, for instance, the proportion of year 11 leavers continuing in full-time education increased from 48% in 1998 to 64% in 1999, when Emas were introduced.

The first pilot programme impressed ministers sufficiently for the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to find £150m in last year's Comprehensive Spending Review to extend Emas across a third of the country.

The research found respectable increases in enrolment in schools or colleges in 2000/01 in Morpeth, Leicester and Nottingham.

It threw up a problem, too. Emas have so far been available to students for two years, the normal length of sixth-form study. But many students in colleges need three years to achieve a level 3 qualification. The report urges ministers to reconsider the two-year Ema. "To maximise the benefits to students it needs to be available for the duration of their studies. A three-year minimum is recommended."

fields.headline: Square eyes
fields.standfirst: Alan Smith on the educational outcomes of being banged up with a telly
fields.trailText: Alan Smith on the educational outcomes of being banged up with a telly
fields.body:
The guys have just got TVs in their cells. Yes I know, I know, it's a bit of a holiday camp, isn't it? I have to say I had a few misgivings myself. When I began teaching in the prison there was only a communal telly until bang-up and then transistor radios in the cells. The class I inherited were going for AS-level literature, they were all Radio 4 addicts and obsessive readers. It was a nightmare trying to keep up with them.

The very first time I was in the prison I had a class who pulled me into a discussion about how Ophelia could well be a Jane Austen heroine. Then, somehow, they were off on a sideline about Bret Easton Ellis and Hamlet.

There were, too, some pretty well informed perspectives on the psychopathology of revenge and violence not available to the average reader. These were guys who were getting through two or three books just at weekends; weekend bang-up left them nothing else to do. The reading could be a bit random and the connections they came up with were wonderful. Gwen is reading Macbeth with one of her groups at the moment and she tells me that the guys recognised him in a flash: "He's a genuine geezer," remarked someone who is quite well placed to know about these things.

For the first few weeks after in-cell TV we went through something of a cultural revolution; it was all "Did you see" and EastEnders; and I really cannot bring myself to tell you about the impact of late-night Channel 5.

All of this horrified Isaac who has been locked up since he was 17 and hasn't seen post-8.30 television for five years. "It's all sex," he told me, shaking his head, "even the adverts. The world's gone mad."

For a little while it was like being a schoolteacher again. There we were a few weeks away from the AS-level exams and they were watching Eurotrash and Antiques Roadshow and coming into class all bleary-eyed from late night repeats of I Love Lucy. How do you manage a homework crisis in the nick? Give them a detention, write to their mums, clip their ears?

But Lord Reith knew a thing or two when he saw television as being the great educator. Now that things have settled down it really is seen as being the mark of the drongo to watch rubbish. Last Thursday I overheard Steve saying: "I thought I'd be watching crap all the time, you know what I mean, but I watch the documentaries and all the history stuff."

"I watch Coronation Street," Alistair told him. Steve's lip curled, "That crap." Alistair gave him the sad, blue eyes: "My Mum watches it," he says, "so I watch it and I can think of her watching it with me." That shuts Steve up and uncurls his lip, but he is right about the way a lot of the guys edit out the nonsense.

Even so the telly is having an odd sort of influence, much odder than the random reading did. What sort of an education does someone get who watches all the OU programmes, jumping from microbiology to Renaissance architecture to advanced statistical analysis in the small hours, and then tries to thread it all into my lesson on Phillip Larkin. God knows what all of this is doing to me.

Favourite programme? Jeremy Paxman interviewing Jack Straw. They love it.

webTitle: So you want to learn...risk management

fields.headline: So you want to learn...risk management
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Oy! Stop pushing in. I'm not.

There's a queue. I know - that's why I'm here.

Right, well take your turn. You misunderstand. I'm taking a squint at the safety of these stairs.

Yeah, yeah, heard it before - just get to the back. Seriously, I'm a risk manager.

And what's that mean? A risk manager's job is to identify, assess and monitor, control or prevent risks that may threaten life or property, or a company's success.

Cor! How do you do that? By visiting a company's premises and inspecting the building, equipment or working practices to determine any risks which may lead to damage or loss to the company. The risk manager will then assess the potential financial impact of these risks.

What then? Once potential risks have been identified, risk managers negoti ate best premiums from insurance companies and brokers. They also examine contracts a client company draws up with third parties to root out anything that may trigger a claim against the company. Then they'll advise of any action to be taken. This could be anything from beefing up a contract to altering company health and safety procedures.

Nice work! And it's not all. Risk managers help draw up emergency plans for fire or flood; this would include ensuring there are back-up computer systems and guidance to employees so that losses are kept to a minimum. They also keep abreast of legislation which could affect a company and advise on ways to comply.

So what sort of people are you looking for? Risk managers need to be self-confident, but sensitive to other people's problems. They need to know occupational health and safety laws, the insurance market and accounting and actuarial systems. Numeracy is essential, as are problem-solving, negotiating and report presentation skills.

How do you get in? Some large companies with risk departments employ people straight from university. Most people take up the career after gaining another professional qualification, after working in other areas such as law, insurance, engineering and finance. Risk managers have to sit an Institute of Risk Management (IRM) exam for which they need a professional qualification, degree or diploma to register.

What about training? Mainly done on the job working alongside an experienced risk manager. Almost all employers expect risk managers to continue professional development with regular training courses.

And job opportunities? Risk managers work for all types of businesses as well as insurance companies and public sector organisations. They also work as consultants for those businesses that do not have their own risk management department or staff.

webTitle: How to keep your slide show audience awake

fields.headline: Make 'em laugh
fields.standfirst: How to keep your slide show audience awake. By  John Crace
fields.trailText: How to keep your slide show audience awake. By John Crace
fields.body:
What two words are guaranteed to make anyone working in further education want to slit their wrists? Funding deficit? College inspection? Not even close. They are "PowerPoint presentation". No meeting or lecture can take place these days without some earnest suit whipping out his or her laptop and flashing up a few blindingly obvious bullet points on to a white screen, while simultaneously regurgitating unintelligible jargonese for 30 minutes at a stretch without once stopping to draw breath. Moreover the speaker is almost always totally unaware that three-quarters of the audience have lapsed into coma.

Engaging the listeners is an arcane artform to many administrators and lecturers, but new research from Dr Tim Clark and Dr David Greatbatch of King's College London offers hope for both speakers and their audiences. The two academics found that unlike politicians, who use rhetorical devices such as contrast and three-part lists - Education, Education, Education - to generate applause, top management gurus, such as Tom Peters, Rosabeth Moss Kanter and Gary Hamil, use humour to get their audience onside.

"The point about laughter," says Dr Clark, reader in management at KCL, "is that it is an ambiguous response. People can either be laughing with you or at you, but no one in the audience can be sure exactly what someone else is feeling as the physical expression is the same, and the overall result is a positive feeling among the listeners.

"In presenting their ideas, charismatic management speakers often have to disparage practices that a great many of their listeners may be using and praise other working practices that their audience are unlikely to be using. The speakers are walking a tightrope: they want to get their message across, while both leaving the audience feeling good about themselves and keeping their reputations in tact. Laughter is an excellent way of achieving this."

Dr Clark maintains that laughter is not an automatic response. Rather it is a response to predetermined stimuli. It is hard to be sure whether management gurus have an intuitive feel for what works and use laughter stimuli without being conscious they are doing so, or whether their talks are scripted down to the last pause. Dr Clark inclines to a mixture of the two, but whatever the case, he and Greatbatch have identified some commonly used signals that generate the laughter response.

"The methods include both verbal and non-verbal signals," he continues. "There's a laughter smile, where the speaker bares his teeth, rolling the eyes, and even chuckling out loud. They also change the intonation of the voice, mimic people, or tell jokes and stories."

The bottom line of getting a laugh is that it creates an illusion of a common viewpoint regardless of whether any consensus has actually been reached. As such it seems the ideal tactic for all those engaged in further education. Chris Moiser, a lecturer in biology and zoology at Plymouth College, is more than well aware that many lecturers fail to come up to the mark when it comes to engaging their students' attention.

"Some of the students are really enthusiastic and on the ball, others are struggling to keep up and some are only there because their parents will kill them if they don't turn up," he says. "Somehow you've got to find a way of getting across specific information to all three groups at the same time, and it's very hard to do."

So what tactics has Moiser employed to grab back an audience whose attention has begun to wander? "I once pulled a ferret out of my trousers during a lecture on mammals," he continues, "but one of the best diversions I saw was a speaker at a zoological meeting who suddenly bunged a slide into his presentation that read, 'All illegally parked cars will be clamped'. That woke everyone up."

Pride of place, though, goes to one of Moiser's colleagues. "Some years ago he used to include a picture of a scantily clad woman into his lecture slides," smiles Moiser, "but he stopped when that sort of thing became un-PC. Still, there's a new round of redundancies in the offing and he's very keen to go, so he's told me that he might start including it again."

webTitle: Cash problems for the infant learning council

fields.headline: Teething troubles
fields.standfirst: The going is far from easy for the infant learning council, reports  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: The going is far from easy for the infant learning council, reports Nick Tester
fields.body:
It's Britain's biggest quango by a factor of 10 and it's barely had a month to make a dent in its six billion pound kitty. But the new-born Learning and Skills Council has already got cash problems.

Within weeks of taking charge of dishing out £815m a year for work-based training programmes it is provoking howls from private and voluntary sector trainers.

The new funding tariff is a bum deal, says their umbrella body, the Association of Learning Providers (ALP). Its complaints boiled over at a highly-charged meeting behind closed doors hosted by the Learning and Skills Council, at which the quango's representative found himself reportedly argued into a tight corner.

Tempers have not been improved by the difficulties of getting through to the new body. This is partly because there are as yet only 50 staff at its Coventry headquarters.

Any brand new organisation has teething problems, but when you are the size of the Learning and Skills Council they tend to be bigger.

Part of the problem in the ALP's reckoning is a devilishly complex funding scheme cobbled together under ministerial pressure by DfEE officials and the council earlier this year.

With little time for its subtler points to be grasped, confusion has simmered, inevitably prompting plaintive cries about an illogical and arbitrary funding mechanism. Although the first payments were promised by last Friday - or failing that, by this coming one - there is still uncertainty over how long trainers will have to wait for succeeding grants to arrive.

Amid the ensuing brouhaha, well-established training providers are complaining that organisations with little or no track record of success are cashing in.

From the government's viewpoint this is all part of a rigorously applied, transparently obvious "fierce competition" operation, designed to weed out the weak and stimulate rapid growth in the training market. A readily understood and accepted national funding formula will banish battles over payments and allow private and voluntary sector training providers to flourish.

While the further education colleges have been given a 16-month breathing space before the Learning and Skills Council takes full responsibility for this aspect of funding, work-based funding bodies have been forced to jump in at the deep end.

The policy of converging to a national formula through "dampening"and "cushioning" different grants has, it is being said, exposed a Whitehall flaw, namely that the Learning and Skills Council and the employment service - a tool of the DfEE - are not on the same wavelength.

"The DfEE has consistently maintained that a fundamental principle underpinning the recent post-16 learning reforms was the need for a new coherence in funding," says Bill Wood, the ALP deputy chairman. "The evident lack of co-ordination between the Learning and Skills Council and employment service suggests a failure at the first hurdle."

The ALP claimed that the way the new three-year contracts for doing work-based training had been processed was causing "perverse" results.

Well-established training providers are being overlooked, it said. Significant business is being swept away.

The Learning and Skills Council countered by pledging to examine any analysis of this plight and consider "further action". But, a spokeswoman added, "the new arrangements already seek to smooth the introduction of the new rates by cushioning providers where necessary".

Her statement also implied that the work-based trainers were guilty of double-talk. "At a recent meeting with the lifelong learning minister the ALP congratulated the Learning and Skills Council and DfEE on the new funding system. They acknowledged that a new system, with national rates for different types of provision, backed by national contracts, met the concerns they had over the previous 72 different TEC funding systems.

"They raised no concerns over the way the arrangements were being administered in practice, either at national or local level."

That doesn't square with the anxiety of Paul Convery, a member of the Learning and Skills Council's adult learning committee. For instance, he says, funding for 16- to 18-years-olds can now be up to 42% higher than that for those aged 19 plus.

"The assumption is that the latter age group need less money for training because it is thought they have had some prior learning. This is an arbitrary presumption and an irony, since the Learning and Skills Council has targets for equal numbers in both age groups." (During the current financial year 47,000 16- to 18-year-olds are predicted to start training while in work, compared to over 50,000 people of 19-plus.)

Convery, who is also director of the Training and Employment Network, which represents some 400 non-profitmaking training providers, says there are "substantially more losers than winners" because the government deliberately shifted money into manufacturing and engineering from the service industries.

"Large commercial organisations with, say, over 10,000 trainees in the hotel and catering businesses risk making a loss on each trainee. There is also a danger that some will be tempted to cut the quality of training in order to compensate for reduced funding."

Less training in the service industries could have profound implications for the re-skilling of women trainees, lower-achieving young people and others from disadvantaged social groups. Adults seeking to acquaint themselves with basic skills may also be marginalised.

Dr John Brennan, director of further education development at the Association of Colleges, whose 470-member colleges carry out about one-fifth of work-based training initiatives, is more sceptical about complaints. It is unreasonable, he says, to expect the wide funding variations endured under the old TEC agreements to be banished overnight.

"Obviously there is a degree of uncertainty about the new contractual arrangements. And the local LSCs are certainly interpreting the rules in different ways.

"But we need to consider the enormity of the task and address the big issues. It is not reasonable to expect this to be done entirely at this stage of the Learning and Skills Council regime. There has not been a collapse of the system."

Recent speculation that the DfEE will be broken up after the general election suggests less than total confidence in the new regime. The mooted plan is a new "working age ministry" to oversee training, industrial relations, unemployment benefits and New Deal. The big questions are whether the other half, a "department of education and lifelong learning", will be better placed to help future training work; and for how long the Learning and Skills Council's hand has to be held - or squeezed.

webTitle: Is yet more cash to colleges the way to widen participation?

fields.headline: Can't get the students
fields.standfirst: Is yet more cash to colleges the way to widen participation, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Is yet more cash to colleges the way to widen participation, asks Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The education secretary David Blunkett has called for a bigger slice of the six billion pound post-16 budget to go into the drive for "widening participation".

But there is a growing feeling in the sector that simply giving more cash to colleges and other training institutions for recruiting students from designated deprived areas is not working well enough.

It could prove more effective to pass the money direct to individuals as an incentive to stay with or return to learning after the age of 16.

Under the current scheme, colleges get extra cash for signing up students from sections of the population deemed to be under-represented in post-16 education and training.

New figures released by the Further Education Funding Council shortly before it was abolished last month show that increasing funding for these students using postcodes as an indicator of deprivation has not markedly boosted their recruitment. Blunkett has instructed the fledgling Learning and Skills Council to increase the "uplift" - the additional funding - for all learners in the widening participation categories. These include homeless adolescents, unemployed adults, young people in care and care-leavers, adults learning English as a second language and people in the lower socio-economic groups generally.

The education secretary wants the average uplift to rise to 15% of standard funding. The current uplift is 10%, and when the policy was launched in 1998 it was 6%.

On the face of it the most recent statistics appear to show that widening participation has had an effect. Over the three years 1997/8 to 1999/ 2000, the proportion of all students eligible for the widening participation uplift rose from 25% to 33%.

But over this period the student totals fell and the absolute numbers of students in the widening participation categories stayed pretty static.

"There is no obvious upward trend - especially if allowance is made for the policy changes which have widened the eligible groups during that time," says Dr John Brennan, director of further education development at the Association of Colleges.

The widening participation funding mechanism uses deprivation indices calculated for the Department of Environment Transport and the Regions. Students coming from post codes with indices higher than the national average attract extra funding on a sliding-upward scale.

According to critics the postcode system is too blunt. The area of a single code can be inhabited by a group of students with a widely diverse level of deprivation, ranging from none to the highest level.

The Learning and Skills Council's interim rates advisory group has agreed to organise research to establish whether it is better to pay colleges extra for widening participation on a simple incentive basis or whether it would be better to estimate the additional costs involved in teaching such students.

"It costs more money to deliver to these students," said one group member. "Some of them require smaller groups. Some of them are slower and in general they need additional support beyond what is given to other students."

But, says its chair, Steve Broomhead, chief executive of Warrington borough council, the group has no remit to investigate the merits of an incentive scheme which would pay money directly to students in the widening participation categories.

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
When I started writing this column a few months ago, as a new parent governor, I received a couple of letters in the early weeks. They were not exactly fanmail. Their comments were more along the lines of "Who is this fool?" and "How dare he besmirch the very serious and important work of governors with his ignorance and idiocy?"

I have a certain sympathy for that point of view. I was completely green. I was not even an "educated layperson", so far as having some knowledge of the functioning of school management or the role of governing bodies was concerned. But everyone has to start somewhere, don't they? Which is sort of the point of the experiment: how many parents who volunteer to become a governor have any real idea of what the job entails?

The comparison between governors and magistrates (and I'm sorry to harp on if you've heard me say this before) strikes me as more and more valid. The difference is that magistrates are required to undergo both initial and continuing training. You might say that this is only right and proper, since they have other people's welfare in their hands - even the power to bestow custodial sentences. But governors, too, have people's welfare in their hands - your children's - and what responsibility could be greater than that?

There is plenty of training available to governors, but none of it is mandatory. The local authority runs day courses for new governors, plus afternoon and evening classes for specific topics such as performance management. But, unless your school is exceptional in its tutorship of governors, you have to be self-starting, proactive and both willing and able to dedicate still more time than you had bargained for in order to find someone who will tell you what on earth you are for.

I admit that I did not score enormously highly on any of these criteria. My visit to Joan's office (the school secretary, who doubles as clerk to the governing body) was brief and fruitless.

Me: "Do you know if there are any courses for new governors?"

Joan (harassed): "Um, I don't know. I think there are some leaflets somewhere. Hold on." (Much shuffling of papers.) "Er, here, have a look at this." (Hands me a wedge of documents.)

Ten minutes of close scrutiny of sundry leaflets, flyers and pamphlets reveal that there are local authority courses for new governors. And the last one that term had been the previous week.

Discouraged, I assumed I would pick up this governing business as I went along. But the truth is that, if you are not extraordinarily well- informed by some independent means, you are only half there in those meetings. An unscrupulous headteacher (which Mr Richardson fortunately is not; mildly depressive, possibly, but definitely not lacking in scruples), in league with a ruthless clerk, could run rings around a governing body comprising governors like me. We do plenty of rubber-stamping as it is.

It was about time, I realised, to try again. I found I had a local authority bulletin with a governor support service number on it. There was just an answerphone, of course. But further scouring of the bulletin revealed a personal email address for someone. And so, finally, I obtained details of another course for governors, specifically of foundation schools, too (these are formerly "grant-maintained", which ours was).

After several wrong turnings and dead ends, I found myself in an annexe to the imposing, if shabby, Edwardian pile of a town hall, in meeting room 3e, along with four other governors. Our "teacher" introduced herself as a former schools inspector. Mrs Evans had taken early retirement and now, she candidly admitted, did "rather better" doing education professional training as a freelance contractor.

There followed a jog-trot through the regulations concerning the governance of foundation schools. The document she handed out was the usual bullet-point summary, bewildering in its staccato listing of policies, strategies, aims and objectives. In education, a particular species of bureaucratic language conspires to make all official documents virtually unreadable: it is, I think, an unholy hybrid of Whitehall statute-speak and management consultancy jargon.

But through Mrs Evans's presentation, all kinds of interesting matters arise. The first revelation is that the governing body of foundation schools not only employs the staff and controls admissions, but also owns the land and buildings of the school. Crikey, how come no one had ever mentioned this basic fact to me?

I leave the session feeling slightly blitzed by having to think hard about standing orders and strategic roles, but also energised. I feel it's just the beginning of my training, and I could do with much more. Above all, I feel inspired by Mrs Evans's speech about governors being responsible for seeing that their school has a wider definition of "standards" than merely Sats results and numbers of exclusions. I even have a list of things I want to raise at the next governors' meeting. I might actually be more than half there.
