webTitle: Who is to blame for the growing funding gap between our old and new universities?

fields.headline: Union's blood is up
fields.standfirst: Who is to blame for the growing funding gap between our old and new universities, asks  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Who is to blame for the growing funding gap between our old and new universities, asks Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
The funding council has angrily rejected claims by the lecturers' union, Natfhe, that the new universities are getting a raw deal.

Figures for the coming year's grants for teaching show a widening funding gap between the old universities and the former polytechnics, says the union. Much of the difference is accounted for by the old universities' greater income from endowments, donations and interest on assets but Natfhe argues that more than £700 of the gap per student is due to unequal distribution of public money through the funding councils. Next week it will lobby the Department for Education and Employment with a giant invoice for the £473.5m which the new universities are "owed".

The average figures conceal huge disparities between individual institutions. Imperial College London, for instance, received £15,588 per student, Cambridge £11,578 while Oxford Brookes was the highest of the new universities at £6,393 and Lincolnshire and Humberside could count on only £3,965 per head.

Tom Wilson, the union's higher education secretary, said no one would tolerate some hospitals or schools receiving five times the funding of others. "Why should we tolerate such unfairness being applied to our university students? These figures show that shocking inequalities in funding still persist a decade after the ending of the binary divide was supposed to put all higher education institutions on a level playing field. The government cannot continue to turn a blind eye."

New universities were unfairly losing government funding and suffered the double whammy of receiving far less in alternative income, said Wilson.

But the Higher Education Funding Council for England dismissed Natfhe's claim of a £700 gap as "illusory" because the difference was accounted for by the subject mix in old and new universities.

Clinical medicine courses - only run at old universities - accounted for half the difference alone, said Mario Ferelli, head of analytical services. Laboratory-based science and engineering, which attract more funding than classrom- or studio-based courses, also tend to be located in the old sector.

Ferelli said the funding council had devised a model to iron out the previous inequalities which existed when the polytechnics became universities in 1992. For any given course, funding had now converged to plus or minus 5%, and the new universities were not below average on the model, he said.

Several new universities are facing financial difficulties and an estimated 1,000 posts are due to be axed - de Montfort and Nottingham Trent were the latest to announce redundancies last week. But Ferelli said the difficul ties of these institutions were due to the market, not the funding council's sysytem. "Many of them grew fast early on in the 1990s and are having difficulties maintaining numbers. That is why their income is falling."

Natfhe remains unrepentant. The gap between classroom and other subjects was too large, said Wilson. Kings College London received £13,000 per student, while Brighton, Staffordshire and Sheffield Hallam, which had a similar subject mix, re ceived less than £5,000 each, he said.

He conceded that many of the old universities were little better funded than the new institutions. Greenwich receives slightly more per head than Hull; Sunderland and Westminster do better than Sussex and the University of East Anglia.

"Over three quarters of the entire assets of the whole sector are held by just 15 old universities. The whole sector needs both more and fairer funding," said Wilson.

Top 10 (for non-research income in 1999/2000):

Imperial, University College London, Kings College London, Cambridge, Oxford, Surrey, Umist, Queen Mary and Westfield, Warwick, Manchester.

Bottom 10:

Lincolnshire and Humberside, Open University, University College Northampton, King Alfred's College Winchester, Staffordshire, Brighton, Sheffield Hallam, University College Worcester, University of the West of England, Cheltenham and Gloucester College.

Funding divide

Average funding per student in both old and new university sectors

England

Old sector average: 8,243

New sector average: 5,320

Scotland

Old 8,389

New 6,171

Wales

Old 7,069

New 4,914

webTitle: Ppioneering scheme aims to teach French to four-year-olds

fields.headline: Baby bilinguals
fields.standfirst: Britain could soon be ejected from the "world's worst linguists" tables, thanks to a pioneering scheme to teach French to four-year-olds, says  Helen Carter
fields.trailText: Britain could soon be ejected from the "world's worst linguists" tables, thanks to a pioneering scheme to teach French to four-year-olds, says Helen Carter
fields.body:
If you asked a four-year-old child in any British school: "Parlez-vous français?", most of them would look at you blankly and be unable to answer your question. Not so for reception class children in Liverpool, who will soon be able to converse confidently in either French, German or Spanish.

A three-year pilot scheme, costing £500,000, is to be launched at selected primary schools in the city, with children from the very beginning of their education learning a second language for one-and-a-half hours a week.

Schools have been bidding to take part in the project and the first three to be chosen will be announced later this month. Specialist language teachers and classroom assistants will then be recruited. In the second year of the scheme, six schools will take part and it will be expanded to nine the following year.

There is a firm emphasis on making languages fun and relevant to the young children by initially concentrating on speech until they become more proficient and able to cope with the principles of grammar.

The aim is to create a bilingual generation of children in Liverpool, which will become a model for other cities. By the time they reach their 11th birthdays, it is envisaged that more than half of their lessons will be taught in their chosen second language.

Children at Blackmoor Park infants' school in the pleasant suburb of West Derby are already entering into the spirit of the project, which begins in September. Some of them are dressed in French, Spanish and German national costumes; four-year-old girls are wearing frilly Spanish dresses and boys sport berets, striped tops and strings of plastic onions around their necks.

Many of the older children here are learning French already. They have a classroom assistant from Avignon who, for the last eight months, has been running a popular weekly lunchtime language club for six- and seven-year-olds.

Ashley Morrissey, seven, who is a member of the club, grins broadly when asked if she wants to visit France. She nods and says: "Oui."

"It was kind of a bit strange at first because of the different way we speak," she says. "I have never been to France, but I would like to go there now I am learning French. If I went and couldn't speak the language, then I wouldn't be able to make friends or ask for things in shops. We also learn songs and there is one that I cannot stop singing."

Claire Johnson, also seven, says she enjoyed speaking the language when she visited France. "It made me feel good being able to speak French," she says. "I think it is important to speak the language and people smiled at me when I did."

It helps that Ann Straddon, the school's headteacher, is a self-confessed Francophile. "Children love speaking the language, they are so enthusiastic," she says. "So many of them are visiting France on holiday and it gives them a headstart if they can communicate with French children, rather than relying on the French children speaking in English. It is giving them the same advantage with languages that other European countries already have.

"They have the additional experience of hearing the language spoken by a French person, so they can hear a real French accent - which is a tremendous advantage."

The school will also use the internet to find sites that are of interest to the children, such as Thomas the Tank Engine and Bob the Builder websites written in French. The school has found them email pals with whom they must communicate in French. "It is the ideal time for them to start to learn, because at infant school we try to make learning fun," says Straddon.

Liz Kelly, senior effectiveness officer (languages) at the city council, agrees that the problem with current language teaching is that it starts far too late. "At the moment we start teaching languages when they are about to become like Kevin and Perry in one of Harry Enfield's sketches. They are about to become adolescents, which could not be a worse time to start learning."

She says research has shown that learning another language does not interfere with the child's own language skills but, in fact, enhances them. By the time the children reach key stage 2, their teachers will start introducing grammar. By the time they start secondary school, they will have become good linguists and should, Kelly suggests, be able to take a GCSE in languages early.

Kelly stresses that there is no point comparing the project with similar schemes in Holland or Germany; English as a second language has status to children there. "English is the language of youth culture, pop music and American films," she explains. "We can't look to them for comparisons."

A better template is found closer to home. A project in Scotland teaching French or Spanish to nine- to 11-year-olds, which began in the late 1980s, has had a huge impact on children's language skills.

News of the project has filtered through to parents and heads in Liverpool, and the council has been overwhelmed by the positive response from schools.

"We are all guilty of being little Englanders," says Mike Storey, the leader of Liverpool city council, and himself a headteacher. "If people don't understand us abroad, then we just speak English even louder. As an educationist, I know that children at their youngest are most receptive."

The message certainly appears to be getting across at Blackmoor Park. "Au revoir," chorus the children as you say goodbye.

Scotland: streets ahead

The Liverpool scheme may seem revolutionary, but early language teaching is a principle that Scottish schools have embraced for some time. The Scottish Executive continues to provide funding for teachers to introduce foreign language teaching in primary 6 and 7 (years 5 and 6), and last year 95%of primary schools were doing just this. French is the most popular choice, although German, Spanish and Italian are also on offer. A new scheme to extend the opportunity to younger children is currently being piloted in an Aberdeen school, where primary 1 children are learning their bilingual basics.

fields.headline: Many hands
fields.standfirst: As the government announces plans to recruit more classroom assistants,  Laura Barton  finds there's more to the job than paint pots and toilet trips
fields.trailText: As the government announces plans to recruit more classroom assistants, Laura Barton finds there's more to the job than paint pots and toilet trips
fields.body:
The small boy with the bowlcut hair is scribbling over his drawing of a cow with a stubby blue crayon. "It's mud" he announces. "Very good," I say, encouragingly. This morning, I am masquerading as a classroom assistant. The government has announced that it intends to increase their ranks in order to take some of the strain off overworked teaching staff, and so here I am, sitting on an infant-sized chair, anticipating a busy morning of washing out paint pots and maybe sticking a plaster on the odd grazed knee.

This is how we think of the classroom assistant: as someone - a parent, perhaps - who pops in on the odd afternoon and lends a hand in the reading hour. Nothing too vexing.

But the role has changed substantially over the years. Unison senior national officer for school staff, Christina McAnea, claims that classroom assistants "play an increasingly vital part in the drive to raise standards in schools. And yet they are too often overlooked or ignored."

This is the reception class at Kilmorie Primary School, in Forest Hill, south London. One of the children explains to me that, although some of the class are five years old, herself included, some of them are only four, but this does not prevent them being friends. I nod sagely, whilst attempting to control the minor scuffle which has broken out over the alphabet butterfly jigsaw puzzle.

The teacher is reading a story about Mrs Wishy-washy, and we are all joining in. There are two classroom assistants, Pat and Coleen, who keep an eye on the group, whispering to them when their attention strays from the Wishy-washing and the cow in the mud. When the story is over, we all shake our hands to get rid of the fidgets. Then we're writing on the board. "Capital letter, capital T," says the teacher. A fluffy-headed blond boy goes to write the letter C. We clap. "What is 'wuh' in Letterland?" the teacher asks. And then we are drawing letter 'm's in the air, "Down, up, over, over, flip".

The class is split into groups, each group overseen by a different classroom assistant. Some of the children are playing on the computer, some are glueing words onto paper in a comprehension exercise, and others are tipping over the box of crayons and loudly pretending to be holding mobile phone conversations. Mine is this last group; I am fast realising that being a classroom assistant involves bucketloads of patience. One boy shows me his drawing. "Is it a, errr... pig?" I ask. The pig has nine legs, and is next to the duck, which is pink.

In response to last week's proposals, Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, remarked: "The government must try not to obscure the need to improve pupil-teacher ratios by increasing the number of adults to pupils in our schools." The classroom assistants at Kilmorie agree.

"There aren't enough teachers and that's why we're doing a lot more work," says one. Sharon Gooddy, another classroom assistant, is more blunt: "It's cheap teaching."

In the case of a statemented child, the classroom assistant has to go to the child's review, and is asked to write a report and to keep daily records on the child. This, they say, is not too problematic for a single child, but there could be 16 statemented children, leaving only half an hour to be spent with each child. Then there's also the physical side of the job, "the primary helper tasks - taking them to the toilets, changing pants_" Much of the job resembles teaching: they must plan lessons and are working with what one assistant terms "the high percentage of needy children" at the school.

"Teachers are trained before they go into the job," says Sharon, "but helpers are trained on the job. We've all had to learn sign language, and we've children with Downs Syndrome and a lot with English as a second language."

They have also had to become familiar with computers. Fortunately the school has trained them and they have been able to follow NVQ courses. "But," says Jo Ives, "you don't want to do the work out of school, because you're not paid enough."

Pay is a big issue. "If the government is serious about recruiting additional classroom assistants, they must take a long, hard look at training and pay," says McAnea, and the classroom assistants at Kilmorie agree that pay, or the lack of it, is a problem: "Every year, the job changes, the hours change, and we only get half-pay in the holidays."

It is only recently that assistants, who were classified as manual workers, have become "office workers"; it is a shift which has earned them an extra 70p an hour. They have also encountered difficulties with the local education board - "they dropped us two pay scales with out telling us." Fortunately, the school rallied round; they now have had their pay scale reinstated and also receive a London weighting. Nevertheless, one of the assistants is leaving for a job in administration. "We're losing Joy because this job means she doesn't have enough money or security to get a mortgage," Sharon says.

But they are very happy at Kilmorie. Ken Johnson, Kilmorie's headteacher, explains that classroom assistants are trained both on the job and upstairs in the school's professional development centre. They learn about the numeracy and literacy strategies and are trained in dealing with special educational needs. "Primary helpers support learning," he says, "but it would be wholly inappropriate for them to be used as replacement teachers; the roles are distinctly different."

fields.bodyText: The small boy with the bowlcut hair is scribbling over his drawing of a cow with a stubby blue crayon. "It's mud" he announces. "Very good," I say, encouragingly. This morning, I am masquerading as a classroom assistant. The government has announced that it intends to increase their ranks in order to take some of the strain off overworked teaching staff, and so here I am, sitting on an infant-sized chair, anticipating a busy morning of washing out paint pots and maybe sticking a plaster on the odd grazed knee. This is how we think of the classroom assistant: as someone - a parent, perhaps - who pops in on the odd afternoon and lends a hand in the reading hour. Nothing too vexing. But the role has changed substantially over the years. Unison senior national officer for school staff, Christina McAnea, claims that classroom assistants "play an increasingly vital part in the drive to raise standards in schools. And yet they are too often overlooked or ignored." This is the reception class at Kilmorie Primary School, in Forest Hill, south London. One of the children explains to me that, although some of the class are five years old, herself included, some of them are only four, but this does not prevent them being friends. I nod sagely, whilst attempting to control the minor scuffle which has broken out over the alphabet butterfly jigsaw puzzle. The teacher is reading a story about Mrs Wishy-washy, and we are all joining in. There are two classroom assistants, Pat and Coleen, who keep an eye on the group, whispering to them when their attention strays from the Wishy-washing and the cow in the mud. When the story is over, we all shake our hands to get rid of the fidgets. Then we're writing on the board. "Capital letter, capital T," says the teacher. A fluffy-headed blond boy goes to write the letter C. We clap. "What is 'wuh' in Letterland?" the teacher asks. And then we are drawing letter 'm's in the air, "Down, up, over, over, flip". The class is split into groups, each group overseen by a different classroom assistant. Some of the children are playing on the computer, some are glueing words onto paper in a comprehension exercise, and others are tipping over the box of crayons and loudly pretending to be holding mobile phone conversations. Mine is this last group; I am fast realising that being a classroom assistant involves bucketloads of patience. One boy shows me his drawing. "Is it a, errr... pig?" I ask. The pig has nine legs, and is next to the duck, which is pink. In response to last week's proposals, Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, remarked: "The government must try not to obscure the need to improve pupil-teacher ratios by increasing the number of adults to pupils in our schools." The classroom assistants at Kilmorie agree. "There aren't enough teachers and that's why we're doing a lot more work," says one. Sharon Gooddy, another classroom assistant, is more blunt: "It's cheap teaching." In the case of a statemented child, the classroom assistant has to go to the child's review, and is asked to write a report and to keep daily records on the child. This, they say, is not too problematic for a single child, but there could be 16 statemented children, leaving only half an hour to be spent with each child. Then there's also the physical side of the job, "the primary helper tasks - taking them to the toilets, changing pants_" Much of the job resembles teaching: they must plan lessons and are working with what one assistant terms "the high percentage of needy children" at the school. "Teachers are trained before they go into the job," says Sharon, "but helpers are trained on the job. We've all had to learn sign language, and we've children with Downs Syndrome and a lot with English as a second language." They have also had to become familiar with computers. Fortunately the school has trained them and they have been able to follow NVQ courses. "But," says Jo Ives, "you don't want to do the work out of school, because you're not paid enough." "Primary helpers support learning," he says, "but it would be wholly inappropriate for them to be used as replacement teachers; the roles are distinctly different." You can see this in the classroom. fields.headline: Dad will use money for legal fees, says Biggs's son
fields.trailText: The son of Ronnie Biggs says the money the family receive from The Sun will go towards legal fees and his granddaughter adding the Great Train Robber does not want to be a "burden on the British taxpayer, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The son of great train robber Ronnie Biggs today collapsed in tears as he told how he had begged his father not to return to Britain.

He denied he had come back to get free health care and said any payment made by the Sun newspaper was not for his father's direct benefit.

He has returned to England to end his days in the country that he still thinks of as home," said Michael Biggs, 26.

"At the age of 71 and fearing that the end of his life is close, he has chosen to voluntarily return to this country."

"This decision was contrary to my wishes and neither myself nor his family and friends in Brazil could talk him out of it," Mr Biggs said at the Tower Thistle Hotel in London, struggling to hold back the tears.

Then, as he told how he had been unable to talk the veteran crook out of returning to Britain, he broke down saying: "I'm sorry. Please continue", passing his prepared statement to Judy Totton, a public relations consultant hired by the family.

In the rest of the 300-word statement, Mr Biggs insisted that his father could have paid for health care in Brazil and had not returned to Britain simply to receive treatment.

He also insisted that payments made by the Sun were not for his father's direct benefit.

"Contrary to some press reports, he has not returned to the UK simply to receive health care. Health care was available in Brazil and my father had many friends and supporters who would certainly have contributed to any such expenses.

"He has returned to England to end his days in the country that he still thinks of as home.

"As far as financial payments are concerned any payments made by the press are not for my father's direct benefit. As he knows all too well, he has no need of money now.

"Any payments received will be used to contribute to his retrial and legal expenses. He does not wish to be a burden on the British taxpayer. He is also concerned to make some provision for his family, in particular myself and his grandaughter who he may not see again."

As Ms Totton read the words, Biggs screwed up his face and buried his eyes in a white handkerchief.

The tears continued as Ms Totton referred in his statement to Biggs's granddaughter, "who he may not see again".

Michael said his father would appeal against the 28 years that remains of his prison sentence.

If that failed he would even ask the home secretary to consider whether so many years was, at this stage of his life, an appropriate sentence.

He added: "All I ask for, on his behalf, is a fair hearing and a balanced consideration of the true events of the last 35 years of his life."

He ended his statement with: "I have nothing further to say at this stage other than I love my dad."

webTitle: Conservatives on health: time for an NHS cultural revolution

fields.headline: Time for an NHS cultural revolution
fields.standfirst: The Tories want to take the politics out of NHS management and allow a better resourced health service to get on with the job without intereference from ministers
fields.trailText: The Tories want to take the politics out of NHS management and allow a better resourced health service to get on with the job without intereference from ministers
fields.body:
&#149 Will not cut NHS spending. Conservatives have pledged to maintain levels of public spending set out in the March 2000 Budget.

&#149 Transform the culture of the NHS. Restrict the role of the secretary of state for health in order to take politics out of the day-to-day management of the NHS.

&#149 Introduce a patients' guarantee which gives cancer and cardiology patients a maximum waiting time based on their medical need.

&#149 Encourage growth of private healthcare.

&#149 Introduce an exceptional medicines fund to end the "postcard lottery" in prescription of drugs.

&#149 Increase recruitment of doctors and nurses. Offer "exceptional incentives" for trained staff to return to the NHS.

&#149 Increase the current one-year pre-registration period for junior doctors to two years.

fields.headline: Agatha Christie
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know on the net about the world's greatest mystery writer
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know on the net about the world's greatest mystery writer
fields.body:
1. An Essex theatre is to stage all 23 of Agatha Christie's plays in a 12-week season to mark the 25th anniversary of the mystery writer's death.

2. The Palace Theatre in Westcliff on Sea will use six directors and 25 actors for the 135 performances.

3. Christie is the best-selling mystery novelist of all time, having flogged more than 2 billion books.

4. But it took her nearly six years to find a publisher for her first book, The Mysterious Affair at Styles.

5. Once started, she clocked them up fast. She wrote 66 books and 145 short stories.

6. She also sneakily churned out six romance novels under the nom de plume of Mary Westmacott.

7. Christie picked up her knowledge of poison - her preferred murder weapon - while working in a WW1 hospital.

8. Despite not being short of a shilling, Christie never owned her own TV, but her grandson Matthew Prichard reckons she would have embraced the internet had she been around now.

9. Captain Arthur Hastings is the most popular Christie character in Iceland Poirot's valet George is second best.

10. A librarian in Newfoundland - where it is clearly too cold to get out much - has written standalone biographies of Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple http://www.angelfire.com/fl/christianx/agatha.html

fields.headline: Big Brother house gets the decorators in
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Channel 4's Big Brother house has been given a Changing Rooms-style makeover, writes Jason Deans.

Big Brother website
fields.body:
Prison chic is out, cabin fever is in for Big Brother 2 - the interior of the Channel 4 show's house has been given a Changing Rooms-style makeover for its return later this month.

Wood panelling, rugs and a central log fire have replaced the spartan, prefab look of last summer's first series, giving the house an altogether more friendly and welcoming feel.

Big Brother's producer, Endemol Entertainment UK, has also built a mystery pyramid-shaped structure in the garden of the house.

Series producer Jeremy Phillips confirmed that the structure would have cameras inside and could be used for some of the tasks Big Brother contestants are asked to perform.

But Mr Phillips would reveal nothing more about the new feature when journalists got their first look at the revamped Big Brother house today, leaving them to speculate that it might be a sauna.

Other changes include the enlargement of the main room, a decked patio in the garden and an en-suite bathroom with a whirlpool bath in one of the bedrooms.

This will add to the friction and petty jealousies that will inevitably consume the group over nine weeks.

The redesign has been overseen by Colin Piggott, who was also behind the look of the first run of the show.

Around 350 production staff will be working at the Three Mills Studio in Bow, east London, dubbed "the new Soho" by Channel 4's commissioning editor for Big Brother, Liz Warner.

The nightly weekday edition of Big Brother on Channel 4 is expected to go out from 10pm from Sunday, May 25.

There will also be two eviction night shows on Friday night, a 60-minute weekly show looking at the behaviour of contestants and a weekend round-up.

E4 is to broadcast a live feed from the Big Brother house for up to 21 hours a day, beginning when the main nightly Channel 4 show ends and running through to 5.30pm the next day.

There will also be a 30-minute daily Big Brother studio show on E4 presented by Dermot O'Leary, featuring interviews with evictees, as well as friends, relatives, celebrities, journalists and psychologists.

Users of the Big Brother website will be able to access two new features: the "Fave Cam" - a video stream following the most popular housemate; and "Pan Cam", a panoramic camera mounted in the circular dining table that can be rotated through 360 degrees by users.

fields.headline: Cannes you believe it
fields.standfirst: Guardian writer Amy Fleming is at Cannes in the company of three young British producers intent on raising funds for their next feature. In the first of four diary reports, she anticipates life at the business end of the world's most glamorous film festival
fields.trailText: Guardian writer Amy Fleming is at Cannes in the company of three young British producers intent on raising funds for their next feature. In the first of four diary reports, she anticipates life at the business end of the world's most glamorous film festival
fields.body:
Each year some 4000 journalists from around the world descend upon Cannes at film festival time. Their main objectives are to see as many films as possible and get good interviews which, from what I hear, is much harder than it sounds. Everything has to be officially set-up and policed through PRs. What we mostly see at home is the whole red-carpet Hollywood glamour thing. But what exactly goes on behind all of that?

The town is literally humming with the global film industry's great and good and, therefore, bursting with the opportunity for thrusting young producers to do more business in a week than they would usually achieve in six months. Fortuitously for me, three film producer friends of mine will be seizing these very opportunities at Cannes this year and they're taking me along for the ride.

This will be Pikka and Philippa's third trip to the Festival and this year will be crucial to the development of their feature film about Salvador Dali, Little Ashes. Pikka and Philippa set up their production company Wanton Muse just over two years ago (Moira, the third Muse, joined a year later) and they went to the Festival for the first time in May 1999. They had set up meetings with a lot of European production companies - one of which was Amsterdam based Egmond, who were particularly impressed by the Muse's sketchy one-page outline for Little Ashes.

One year later, when Wanton Muse returned with a screenplay, Egmond came on board as co-producers. They agreed to put up 50% of the $10m (£6.6m) budget and brought in Academy Award-winning director, Marleen Gorris (who won the Best Foreign Film Oscar for Antonia's Line and also directed Mrs Dalloway). The financial backer behind Wanton Muse's start-up, Tony Defries (a music manager best remembered for discovering the likes of David Bowie, Iggy Pop and Stevie Wonder), is putting in a further 10%.

The plan is to start shooting this coming September. As a result Pikka, Moira and Philippa will be going hell for leather in Cannes to attach cast, meet sales agents, executive producers and get that final 40%. With US cash and actors likely to be off limits due to the strikes, this will be even more challenging. Thank goodness Jude Law is a Brit, because he is their number one choice to play Dali.

And so it is that, whilst only a few weeks ago I was lamenting missing the Oscars on TV because I don't have Sky, tomorrow I'll be on the French Riviera, sipping champagne at the premiere party for Baz Luhrmann's latest offering, Moulin Rouge (starring Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor and due for UK release later this year).

We have to meet as many people as possible and schmoozing is an essential part of that. Pikka is a card-carrying member of London industry hang-out Soho House, whose Cannes boat proves popular with the top dogs so we've a little head-start there. If all goes well, there will be many, many meetings - especially this weekend when the director, Marleen Gorris arrives for a few days. I have no idea what to expect but suspect that it will definitely beat watching the Oscars on TV. I'll keep you posted.

webTitle: Angus defends his fee for Baftas

fields.headline: Angus defends his fee for Baftas
fields.trailText: Angus Deayton says presenting the BAFTA awards is not the doddle that it is made out to be. There's a script, rehearsals and potential disasters, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Angus Deayton has defended the size of his fee for presenting the Bafta Television Awards, claiming the £50,000 figure was exaggerated.

And he took a swipe at the papers who reported his cash deal to do the star-studded event which will be broadcast on BBC1 next Sunday.

"It would have been nice if the papers had done research into what people get paid for hosting awards ceremonies. What I'm getting is not different to that." he says in an interview in the Radio Times.

The fee of around £50,000 was first revealed by the Guardian and is some £30,000 higher than normal.

Deayton insisted that the high fees showbusiness stars can command are justified.

"To read the papers you'd think all I had to do was swan in, dish out a few awards and go home.

"Not so. There's a script, rehearsals and potential disasters to be steered around.

"You try to make it a mixture of scripted and ad lib, but things don't always go to plan.

"I remember introducing Emma Thompson at one ceremony, and just as I prepared to launch into a bit of chat she said, 'Leave me alone'. I took the hint," he said.

webTitle: Comment:  Racism has now been enshrined in statute

fields.headline: Labour's law of ethnic punishment shames us all
fields.standfirst:
Racism has now been enshrined in statute

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Racism has now been enshrined in statute.
fields.body:
Just before the second term launches, consider one thing the first has done. Catch it before it departs into the maw of another mandate where all is forgiven and much forgotten. See what power did in one particular zone, which I'm still prepared to call the moral sensibility of ministers. Not only have their arteries hardened and their consciences grown dull. That's to be expected under the weight of office. More startling is how easily the gates of perception, their sense of what they are doing, have been closed and locked.

When they came to power, one principle they seemed unbreakably attached to was a detestation of racial prejudice. Equality of racial justice and hostility to ethnic discrimination were ideals that united old and new Labour. To men like Tony Blair and Jack Straw they were articles of faith, which lay behind both the swift abolition of the Tories' primary-purpose rule challenging migrant spouses to prove they had any right to join their partners, and the later setting up of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. To Blair and Straw it is unimaginable that they could be party to anything but the most impeccable correctness in all matters that touch on race.

Yet they have been. Two weeks ago, I wrote about the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000, which outlawed ethnic discrimination by public authorities but made an exception for the immigration service. I unearthed a ministerial order which authorised immigration officers to treat people of certain nationalities - unspecified, but to be identified at the future decision of ministers and officials - worse than other people. Replying to the critique, Straw pleaded a mere drafting technicality and termed my attack "bizarre".

But this order was only a beginning. There has now been a second one, dated April 23, which extends the reach from nationalities to what it describes, in its own headline, as "discrimination on ground of ethnic or national origin". This time the ethnics in question are listed: "a) Kurd, b) Roma, c) Albanian, d) Tamil, e) Pontic Greek, f) Somali, g) Afghan". All persons of these origins are now to be subject "to a more rigorous examination than other persons in the same circumstances". They can be detained, questioned and rejected, as a class, more freely than other people because they are now deemed prima facie more likely to be illegal immigrants or bogus asylum-seekers.

They have something else in common, however. There is no Kurdish passport, there is no Roma passport. Identifying these people can be attempted through little more than their personal appearance, plus some inference from the flight or possibly boat they arrive on. So, not only is the bar on collective discrimination being ditched, but a peculiarly vicious form of sorting is written into statute, whereby immigration officers herd together anyone who looks like a Kurd or a Tamil or a Pontic Greek - regardless of whether these come, as Tamils do, from Sri Lanka, Canada, India or even the UK - and impose special oppression on them.

Ministers' handling of this law went through two phases. The first, during passage, was to pretend it was benign. The only purpose they cited was to make it easier to discriminate in favour of, say, Kosovan refugees. When pressed by Liberal Democrats such as Lord Lester, that was the scenario they repeatedly mentioned. They were lying. It is quite apparent from the April 23 order that what they wanted all along was the power to authorise state-sponsored mass exclusion of certain ethnic groups, without regard for individual justice, on a scale never before seen in this country.

Phase two came last week. The new law, said Barbara Roche, Straw's minion in charge of immigration, was merely giving formal shape to a practice that had been going on a long time. She was almost flippant in her incredulity that anyone should complain about a long-established pattern of ethnic selection. She talked about the need for "objective evidence" against each migrant. But no one has explained how a Roma is meant to overcome the ethnic evidence against him, especially in view of the further sub-clause in the order which states, almost incredibly: "If the information [needed to pursue an application to enter] is not available in a language which the person understands, it is not necessary to provide the information in a language which he does understand."

Three conclusions can be drawn from this. First, whether or not ethnic selection went on before, it has now been systematised. If an apparent Kurd, or potential Roma, or notional Pontic Greek has by some oversight not been discriminated against, ministers may want to know the reason why. Immigration controllers are now on formal notice as to which ethnic and national origins are especially unwelcome in Britain. Their conduct will be policed by someone called a "race monitor", but only retrospectively and without attention to individual cases. The monitor is plainly a PR stooge in the making.

Second, as the government's contribution to present discontents over asylum, this is political cowardice on a grand scale. No one disputes the need for immigration control. But faced by the mighty force of Ann Widdecombe, Blair and Straw are evidently terrified of electoral punishment if they can't match her rhetoric of national alarm with measures of ethnic hostility. Though all these politicians avow their respect for genuine cases, it's the tritest lip service. Straw collaborates with Widdecombe in a discourse from which only the Lib Dems stand aside, that stigmatises asylum itself as presumptively a bogus concept, eating away at the resources of the fifth largest economy in the world.

Third, something unpleasant has happened to Labour in power. For all sorts of reasons, they need to win the election. I hope they do. They're the only plausible choice on offer and defend several important policies that will probably, given time, make this country a better place. But their immigration regime shows not only that they've become, in a vital area, as bad as the Tories, but that they have lost their intellectual as well as moral faculties. They appear not to know what they're doing. They sincerely believe they do not favour ethnic discrimination. Straw, the posturing anti-racist, thinks any challenge to his law can only be "bizarre". He is surrounded by a party that seems to believe the same - barely a squeak came out of it when the law went through.

Such, it seems, is today's corruption of power: not so much a conspiracy of self-interest as the building of a wall of righteous self-belief. A power-driven certainty that, because one is who one is, one can by definition do no wrong. This law of ethnic punishment is a disgrace. Perhaps only a party infused by belief in its own anti-racism would have the nerve to smuggle it past the frontier that separates a decent country from a shameful one.

fields.headline: Official: June 7 polling day
fields.standfirst:
• Blair fires election starting gun
• 'Battle for hearts and minds' begins
• PM highlights education record

Election 2001
fields.trailText:
• Blair fires election starting gun
• 'Battle for hearts and minds' begins
• PM highlights education record

Election 2001
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, this afternoon announced that the general election will be held on June 7.

Speaking at a south London secondary school, Mr Blair asked voters to grant him "a mandate for fresh and radical change" to finish the job the Labour party began when it took office four years ago.

"Every vote in this election is precious, no one's support should ever be assumed," he said. "We earned the trust of the people after 18 long years of opposition. We earned that trust some four years ago, and now we have to earn that trust again.

"Four years ago this country gave us new labour, with a majority larger than I or anyone else would have thought possible. But that large majority was never a reason to do the job quickly but to do it properly for the long term in a way that would last."

He said that Labour had delivered a fundamental economic stability that would make all other changes possible, and he promised to make schools and hospitals the top priority in a second Labour term. He said the government was on track to deliver an increase in the numbers of police officers, a continued decrease in unemployment, and a Northern Ireland peace process that can work.

Mr Blair also reiterated his 1997 campaign theme of meritocracy, saying: "We must create a society in which everyone, not just those at the top, gets a chance to succeed and make the most of their abilities."

The month-long election campaign finally got under way today when the prime minister went to Buckingham Palace to ask the Queen to rubber-stamp his decision and dissolve parliament.

His 15-minute audience with the Queen was followed by a tour of St Saviour's & St Olave's Church of England girls secondary school in Southwark, south London. Breaking with the recent tradition of calling the election outside 10 Downing Street, Mr Blair confirmed in a speech at the school that the country will go to the polls on June 7.

The prime minister's choice of venue for the announcement and the presence of the education secretary, David Blunkett, reflect Mr Blair's determination to highlight the government's record on education.

But the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, responded: "Tony Blair quite extraordinarily made this announcement in a school that Harriet Harman did not believe good enough for her daughter."

At the height of the foot and mouth crisis in April, Mr Blair postponed the local elections from May 3, which was also believed to be his preferred date for a general election. The move meant that Labour now fights national and local election campaigns with the disease largely under control and off the front pages. The election announcement coincided with the allocation of an extra £15m to farmers hit by foot and mouth.

At an emergency cabinet meeting yesterday, Mr Blair warned ministers not to expect an easy election victory despite opinion polls that show Labour far in the lead.

Both the Tory leader, William Hague, and the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, began campaigning today with visits to schools. Outside the Watford Grammar school for boys, Mr Hague repeated his pledge to lower taxes and roll back the frontiers of the state.

He also attacked Labour's record, saying the party was not so much asking for a second term as a second chance.

Mr Kennedy toured a south London school this morning, and he used the occasion to announce that education would be at the heart of his party's campaign.

Last night Liberal Democrat MP Menzies Campbell said on behalf of his party: "People are disappointed with Labour and continue to distrust the Conservatives, so this election will provide an opportunity for real change in Britain."

The dissolution of parliament is now expected on Friday or Monday, clearing the way for a frenzy of campaigning over the next four and a half weeks.

fields.headline: Down Rio way
fields.trailText:
5pm update: Alex Bellos joins the media scrum in Rio to watch the Ronnie Biggs drama unfold.

08.05.2001: Sun keeps mum on Biggs bounty
08.05.2001: Sun 'paid Biggs £350,000' to return
08.05.2001: PCC to probe Sun role
Photo gallery: the Biggs story
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The BBC flew in a team. So did the Mail on Sunday. A Mirror journalist who had been on another assignment in South America was also switched to Rio, although he flew home on Saturday night, missing the big event on Sunday afternoon.

When Ronnie Biggs arrived in white mini-van - complete with a freshly painted Sun logo - at Rio de Janeiro airport at around 3pm on Sunday the pack of journalists waiting was about 50 strong.

The international news agencies were represented as were all the main Brazilian TV channels, although there were no live feeds since airport rules prohibit it.

As soon as the van parked in Terminal Two's disabled space, Biggs could be seen in the middle of the second row and Bruce and Nick Reynolds were in the back. The other passengers in suits were looking hot, sweaty and nervous - presumably journalists from the Sun.

But the press surrounded the van making it impossible for the airport staff who were waiting to help Biggs onto an airport wheelchair. The van sped off, chased by photographers.

Ten minutes later the head of airport security informed the press pack that the van had driven to Terminal One where Biggs had got out and he was already in the area restricted for those who are about to fly.

Geoff Cowling, the consul general of the British consulate in Rio, was seen with a Sun reporter walking through the departure gates.

Mr Cowling has free access as a diplomat but the Sun journalist showed no documentation, identity tag or boarding pass as he walked through into the restricted area, raising questions about an extraordinary sweetheart deal struck with a tabloid newspaper.

While the British consulate appeared to be bending over backwards to work for the Sun, they left everyone else in the wilderness.

Officials refused to divulge any relevant information to journalists belonging to any other media organisation - diverting all enquiries to a press officer in Brasilia.

It was left to the Brazilian authorities to relay everything that happened to Biggs as he was going through the airport's official procedures.

Clovis Franco, press officer for the federal police, witnessed the 45-minute interview that Biggs and his son Mike were obliged to have with police officers.

Mr Franco released a copy of Biggs declaration that he was leaving of his own free will as soon as it was typed. The flight plan - to Cape Verde for refuelling and then to RAF Northolt - was also released by the Brazilian authorities.

One Brazilian journalist, Antonio Werneck, of Rio daily O Globo, managed to gain access to the restricted area and snapped a quick shot on a small camera of Mike Biggs wheeling his father, accompanied by Mr Cowling.

Sources present say that Mike was very aggressive and almost hit Mr Werneck, shouting: "You can't take a picture because it will be sold all over the world."

The picture was sold all over the world and on the cover of yesterday's Telegraph, Independent and Times.

The picture was also in the Brazilian media, although the reports of Biggs' flight home was overshadowed by other domestic stories.

Brazilians are as intrigued by the international interest in the story as they are by the story itself. Ronnie Biggs always remained more of a household name in the UK than he ever was in Brazil.

In Biggs' declaration to the federal police he thanked the Brazilian government and people for their hospitality and said he one day hoped to return.

webTitle: Schröder sets the agenda of European left

fields.headline: Schröder sets the agenda of European left
fields.standfirst: The German chancellor is wielding increasing influence over the European Union, reports John Hooper
fields.trailText: May 8: The German chancellor is wielding increasing influence over the European Union, reports John Hooper.
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder has done it again. This week, the leaders of the European left have been meeting in Berlin, slightly uneasy in the knowledge that the underlying agenda for their discussions has once more been set by the German chancellor.

Seven days before the start of a congress of the Party of European Socialists, Mr Schröder's Social Democratic party (SDP) unveiled his grand plan for Europe's future and stirred up a controversy that has since spanned the continent.

Mr Schröder's scheme would involve turning the European Union's executive, the Commission, into a true government with much enhanced powers and making the EU's council of ministers, which is currently the main decision-making body, into the upper house of a much strengthened European Parliament.

The chancellor pulled off a similar trick last year when he floated proposals for a European constitution just days before Tony Blair and the French president, Jacques Chirac, were expected in town. Then, as now, a sensation was created of German leadership in Europe - an impression that it was the German chancellor who had the really big ideas about the European Union's future and that other heads of state and government came to the German capital to discuss them with him.

On Monday, Mr Schröder went a step further, claiming for his party the key role in Europe. In a speech welcoming delegates, he declared that integration of the continent was essential to the identity of today's Germany. Then he added: "German social democracy will take upon itself the role of being the party of European integration".

It is all heady stuff. But if Mr Schröder and the social democrats are to steer the ship of Europe, what about the passengers? So far, very few seem willing to accept a ticket. The British, and increasingly the French, are concerned to preserve the powers of the national governments and parliaments.

In Hanover last year the French president, Jacques Chirac, said he wanted a "United Europe of States", but not a "United States of Europe". In similarly aphoristic vein, Tony Blair declared in Warsaw a few months later that his aim was a "European superpower", but not a "European superstate".

Then there are the Spanish. They have traditionally been among the most enthusiastic of Europeans. However, for them "Europe" till now has meant abundant subsidies for the modernisation of the Spanish economy. And few of us would turn down the opportunity to join a club that paid us to be a member.

As part of the Schröder scheme countries like Spain would have to pay their way. Now the Spanish, led by their prime minister, José María Aznar, are not at all sure they want that sort of integration.

It leaves Mr Schröder and his fellow-social democrats navigating a vessel that only has Italy and the Benelux countries booked in for the full voyage. Even Italy's ticket is subject to cancellation should Silvio Berlusconi come to power at the head of a right-wing coalition. Its partners could be expected to lay far more stress than the present centre-left alliance on national interests and national sovereignty.

Several commentators in Germany itself have questioned whether Mr Schröder was wise to push himself and his party forward in this way.

And yet the logic of the German position is hard to fault. The European Union is set to expand to take in up to 27 states. Without a more solid structure to hold them all in place, there is a real danger that the whole European experiment could spin out of control in a welter of rancorous, mistrustful self-interest. And that fact seems to be accepted, however tacitly and ruefully, by Germany's EU partners.

The plain fact is that Mr Schröder's first big idea was loudly decried but then quietly accepted. At their summit in Nice at the end of last year, the EU's leaders signed up for what, in fact if not in name, will be a constitutional convention or conference in 2004.

When it begins, they are going to have to talk about something. And the German chancellor, free of many of the domestic pressures which inhibit his counterparts in the rest of the EU, has put forward a plan which can at least serve as a touchstone for discussion between now and then. Amid so much dissent, it may be that an unpopular idea is better than none.

fields.bodyText: Gerhard Schröder has done it again. This week, the leaders of the European left have been meeting in Berlin, slightly uneasy in the knowledge that the underlying agenda for their discussions has once more been set by the German chancellor. Seven days before the start of a congress of the Party of European Socialists, Mr Schröder's Social Democratic party (SDP) unveiled his grand plan for Europe's future and stirred up a controversy that has since spanned the continent. Mr Schröder's scheme would involve turning the European Union's executive, the Commission, into a true government with much enhanced powers and making the EU's council of ministers, which is currently the main decision-making body, into the upper house of a much strengthened European Parliament. The chancellor pulled off a similar trick last year when he floated proposals for a European constitution just days before Tony Blair and the French president, Jacques Chirac, were expected in town. In a speech welcoming delegates, he declared that integration of the continent was essential to the identity of today's Germany. Then he added: "German social democracy will take upon itself the role of being the party of European integration". It is all heady stuff. But if Mr Schröder and the social democrats are to steer the ship of Europe, what about the passengers? So far, very few seem willing to accept a ticket. The British, and increasingly the French, are concerned to preserve the powers of the national governments and parliaments. fields.headline: Tories blow the first raspberry
fields.trailText: It took precisely 11 minutes for "Campaign 2001 - this time it's irrelevant" to turn nasty.
fields.body:
It took precisely 11 minutes for "Campaign 2001 - this time it's irrelevant" to turn nasty.

The chirruping choirgirls at St Saviour's & St Olave's Church of England School, in sunny Bermondsey, south London, had barely sat down from serenading "Uncle Tony" before nice-but-folkie Tory chairman Michael Ancram was blowing raspberries.

Downing Street had gone to great pains to brief Westminster hacks as to what a "beacon" school St Saviour's was. Not only that, but it even had stained glass windows - perfect for TV pictures.

Fortunately, someone at Conservative central office was a little more inquisitive than Fleet Street's finest - and remembered this was the school Harriet Harman had snubbed when picking a school for Harriet jnr.

Cue Mr Ancram: "Tony Blair quite extraordinarily made this announcement in a school that Harriet Harman did not believe good enough for her daughter."

Tories 1. Labour nil.

webTitle: Good weather draws visitors to countryside

fields.headline: Good weather draws visitors to countryside
fields.standfirst:
Some attractions have to turn holiday crowds away

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The fine weather was a bank holiday pick-me-up for the British tourist industry as daytrippers flooded in to attractions yesterday.
fields.body:
The fine weather was a bank holiday pick-me-up for the British tourist industry as daytrippers flooded in to attractions yesterday.

With the Easter holidays blighted by foot and mouth disease, the weekend offered hope as visitor numbers rose. A safari park in Scotland and a Cardiff museum even had to turn people away.

But as some restrictions on walking remained in place, things were not yet back to normal in many areas.

The roads were busier this weekend than at Easter, the AA said. Traffic was heavy on a number of coastal routes, especially on the south coast east of Devon.

Sunshine brought tourists back to the North York Moors national park, where foot and mouth had cut visitor numbers by half.

At Northumberland national park, a spokesman said the weather had brought the crowds back, but there was only 70% of the number of visitors that came on last May's bank holiday.

Roads to the Lake District, where tourism has been badly damaged by the countryside crisis, were busy but not congested.

In Scotland, roads in the north and west were particularly busy as temperatures inland and in the Highlands continued to rise from the weekend highs.

By noon staff at Blair Drummond safari and adventure park, near Stirling, were discouraging visitors after queues three miles long built up at its three entrances.

Its chief executive, Bob Fotheringham, said: "We want people to come here and enjoy themselves, but there is serious traffic congestion."

The Museum of Welsh Life in Cardiff had to close its doors after more than 12,000 visitors turned up. Helen Jones, spokeswoman for the museum, which is holding its annual May fair with traditional dancing, rural crafts and a Victorian fair, said it had reached capacity.

"I think the success is a combination of beautiful weather and the fact that we now operate a free for all policy," she said. "Also, people know that the museum is definitely open."

At Snowdon, officials were delighted with the public's response after four paths to the summit were reopened for the first time since the foot and mouth crisis began.

A spokesman for Snowdonia national park said: "It is not normally a very busy weekend for us. The number of visitors picked up slowly on Saturday, and we have been very busy ever since.

"The weather has helped, and we have had full cooperation from walkers, who have been disinfecting and heeding our advice on things like not discarding food on the mountain."

Welsh seaside towns and resorts have reported a good number of visitors over the bank holiday, but areas affected by foot and mouth have not done so well.

The Wales tourist board chief executive, Jonathan Jones, said: "If you look at those areas where the access to the countryside has been closed since February, they are doing badly.

"In general throughout the whole of Wales, however, the main worrying factor is that the forward bookings for June, July and August are still down. Those people who have cancelled remain cancelled. Bookings are not coming in for those three crucial months of the year."

fields.headline: Rocket lacks power to beat ITV
fields.trailText: 5pm TV overnights: 'Rocket' Ronnie O'Sullivan's snooker triumph could not propel BBC2 to the top of the ratings last night. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
"Rocket" Ronnie O'Sullivan's triumph in the World Snooker Championships could not propel BBC2 to the top of the ratings last night.

The Essex boy's win was watched by 4.8m viewers and claimed a 20% share between 8pm and 10pm.

But it was beaten by a bank holiday You've Been Framed special, which racked up a 7m audience and a 29% share for ITV at 8.15pm.

It's bad news for the BBC, which was hoping that the presence of crowd favourite O'Sullivan would push viewing figures to the heights of 1985, when 12m people watched Dennis Taylor beat Steve Davis in a last-frame thriller.

Elsewhere, Clocking Off pulled in 5.9m viewers at 9.15pm on BBC1, beating Channel 4's As Good As It Gets, with the Jack Nicholson vehicle registering 2.8m at 9.15pm.

It was a much closer struggle with ITV's Inspector Morse, which grabbed 5.5m at 9.15pm, but took a wider audience share of 26%.

However, the snooker final managed to dominate afternoon viewing, pulling in a dominant 3.1m and 31% share between 3pm and 6pm.

webTitle: Weekend brake for lovers of life in the fast lane

fields.headline: Weekend brake for lovers of life in the fast lane
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Central reservations take on a new meaning for British tourism this week, with the launch of the country's first mini-break for motorway enthusiasts.
fields.body:
Central reservations take on a new meaning for British tourism this week, with the launch of the country's first mini-break for motorway enthusiasts.

Themed on the history of the big roads, going back to the experimental Ross Spur in 1961, the £155-a-head weekend includes an advanced driving lesson and meals named after interesting stretches of roads.

Organised discussions on motorway themes such as "What is the point of the M606?" (Britain's shortest motorway between two parts of Bradford) are optional, but all guests receive a £25 petrol voucher and a planned itinerary of nearby "motorway highs".

Early applicants will also be able to book a room with a motorway view - of the A1M which passes the Bridge Inn hotel at Wetherby, whose manager Brian Cunningham is trialling the weekends.

"I used to have to drive 50,000 miles a year in a former job and I hated the things," he said yesterday. "But there are plenty of people who seem to love them.

"We get loads of guests here already who bring road maps with them and spend the whole time poring over ideal routes," said Mr Cunningham. "This is for them - the people who never tire of Tarmac."

The Bridge has already found a niche market for anti-road rage breaks. These offer a candlelit bath in aromatic oils for any frustrated long-haul traveller prepared to pay £25 for two hours' rest.

"The motorway-lover weekends partly grew out of that experiment," said Mr Cunningham. The weekend caters for motorway fatigue with an aromatherapy massage and offers sessions on a local skidpan at a former airfield, where for an extra fee you can drive a lorry, just like the ones in the slow lane.

webTitle: Can higher education maintain the balance between  mass access and high standards?

fields.headline: A perfect poise
fields.standfirst: Britain's higher education has evolved a fine balance between mass access and high standards. But can that balance survive?  Peter Scott  reports
fields.trailText: Britain's higher education has evolved a fine balance between mass access and high standards. But can that balance survive? Peter Scott reports
fields.body:
There are two stories of British higher education. The first is one of triumph. British higher education enjoys the best of both worlds. It has become the largest producer of graduates in Europe, and the British people enjoy unprecedented levels of access to higher education. And yet it still embodies a commitment to excellence and high standards which extends far beyond a dying nostalgia for elitist values - a higher education that acts mass but thinks elite.

British universities and colleges are delicately balanced between old and new. Innovation has been embraced, tradition preserved. But perhaps that balance cannot be held. Two "falls" are possible. Either this curious "elite-mass" system will prove incapable of further expansion and adaptation and, as a result, be out-flanked by novel and rival forms of higher education that are mass in spirit as well as form; or the system will slough off its elite characteristics as budgets decline and more abrasive and urgent imperatives emerge.

But, for the moment, the achievement of British higher education deserves to be celebrated. One form of British exceptionalism - low levels of participation, with access inequitably rationed - has been replaced by another - much higher levels of participation, which approximate to those in other developed countries without compromising the integrity of traditional academic culture. That is British higher education's first story.

Autonomy eroded

The second story is one of retreat and even defeat. In 1960 British higher education was regarded as exceptional in another sense: although overwhelmingly dependent on public funding, it enjoyed a very high level of autonomy.

Buffered from the state by that uniquely British institution, the Uni versity Grants Committee (UGC), our universities enjoyed far greater freedom than universities in the rest of the world. As late as 1981 ministers received almost no advance warning of the grants committee's allocations as deep, and selective, cuts were made in university budgets.

But the exceptional degree of autonomy apparently possessed by British universities during the high-noon of the grants-committee era reflected two special factors which could not be sustained indefinitely - first, the collusive character of post-war elites; and second, the strong political consensus that prevailed during this period, the so-called "post-war settlement". Large parts of British higher education lay outside the grants-committee sector: the polytechnics (now the "new" universities) and teacher training.

Exaggerated or not, this autonomy has certainly been eroded. Accountability has been tightened by a rapid series of acronymic shifts. The UGC was abolished and replaced by the Universities Funding Council. This was partnered by the Polytechnics and Colleges Funding Council, which emerged after the eviction of local education authorities from higher education. Neither lasted long.

Today the boss agency is the Higher Education Funding Council for England (Hefce) and its analogous agencies in Scotland and Wales. Almost nothing is left of the "donnish dominion".

There is more. The academic culture that flourished in Britain's universities in the third quarter of the 20th century was exceptionally vibrant, despite the universities' corporate conservatism. The revolution in biological sciences and the intoxication of the social sciences promised extraordinarily powerful alliances between fundamental science and public intellectuals. That promise, too, has faded.

First came the ideological revanche of Thatcherism. Then the remorseless bureaucracies of academic accountability - the Research Assessment Exercise (RAE) and Quality Assurance Agency - further eroded those crucial margins of irresponsibility and creativity. This is the second story: a retreat certainly, and perhaps even a defeat.

Two paradoxes

These two stories, both true, confront us with two paradoxes. First, a higher education that acts mass but thinks elite. Second, a higher education system that is both opening, in terms of its social reach, and (maybe) closing, in terms of its intellectual ambitions. The two may be connected - not because "more means worse" or because access and excellence are a zero-sum game, but because the dissonance be tween mass form and elite mentality may have led to intellectual closure.

The big question is whether this elite-mass system is capable of extension and elaboration, or whether it has reached the limits of its potential. The answers to more detailed questions - on structure, funding and quality - depend on this. If future growth is likely to take place outside the sector, there is little point tinkering with the structure of higher education. Also, the choice between different funding and quality regimes will depend on whether higher education is still seen as a public service or is to be treated as a semi-privatised sector of the "knowledge industry".

Expansion is the key. The government is committed to raising participation to 50% from today's 33%. But the most important drivers of expansion appear largely external to the higher education system. One is the government's commitment to raising standards in schools; another is the perceived need to provide the skills for a knowledge-based economy.

Two components of the govern ment's strategy reflect these drivers. The first is the decision to establish two-year foundation degrees. The second is the development of alternative institutions uncluttered with the "academic" baggage which burdens existing universities. The University for Industry, now Learn Direct, comes to mind. Some of this expansion may also be channelled through other forms of "virtual" university, either joint ventures by existing universities or public-private partnerships, or through corporate universities.

Perhaps a new binary division is developing - not a hierarchical division between more and less noble higher education institutions, but between public-sector, public-service higher education and new providers, whether novel vehicles like theUniversity for Industry, spin-offs of traditional institutions, public-private alliances or corporate universities. If this happened, the relationship between the two halves of this neo-binary system would be crucial - rivalry or synergy?

However, even within the present system, pressure for change is building up. First comes the reviving debate about restructuring. We all have to be collaborators now. But should higher education be remodelled top-down along the lines of Wisconsin, where 26 universities are linked under a single governing body and divide up the academic labour between them, or will more chaotic forms of collaboration between institutions emerge? Each week there is a headline about a new alliance. Which are real, which a sham?

The second is the devolutionary dynamic. The most high-profile example is the abolition of tuition fees for Scottish-domiciled students in Scottish universities. But equally significant, although less political, is the emergence of a stronger regional dimension in England after the creation of regional development agencies.

Third, the future organisation of research remains unresolved. The traditional dual-support system has been undermined - by the RAE, which has externalised the universities' internal research priorities, and by the increasingly dirigisme and instrumentalism of the research councils, under pressure from the Office of Science and Technology (OST). The funding councils are fighting a dogged battle to defend their stake in research by conducting a "fundamental review" of the research assessment exercise (partly a re-engineering of the process but largely a re-justification). The outcome is unclear.

Non-state money

But the implications for the character of institutions and the shape of the system are important. The future of funding in British higher education is similarly clouded. The state is the majority stake-holder in higher education - and likely to remain so indefinitely despite the encouragement universities have received to diversify their income. But the prospects for a significant uplift in public expenditure on universities are bleak. The government, nominally Labour, has lost heart in social democracy (never mind socialism). But because it is nominally Labour, the prospects for more radical forms of privatisation are also slight.

The probable scenario for future funding, therefore, is a system still largely dependent on public expenditure and subject to perennial "efficiency gains", but increasingly encouraged to form entrepreneurial alliances with the private sector and to generate more non-state income.

But more radical approaches to funding cannot be discounted. After all, the traditional pattern of "free" higher education available to all those who were willing and qualified - the Robbins formula influenced by the National Health Service - was dismantled with ease during the 1990s.

But the question "can Britain's elite-mass system survive?" is of more than local significance. It matters not only in Britain, where the transition to a mass-universal system would strain existing structures, but also for the wider potential for building a democratic system of higher education.

In the US very high levels of participation have been produced by the incorporation of all types of post-secondary education within a highly stratified higher education system. In (nearly all) the rest of Europe expansion has taken place within traditional binary structures which protect, and privilege, traditional universities. Only in Britain has an attempt been made to increase social opportunities for higher education through a system that retains traditional academic attributes in nearly all institutions, and not just in a segregated elite sector. Is this bold, if unconscious, experiment a (more substantial) Third Way?

Peter Scott is vice-chancellor of Kingston University.
