fields.bodyText: There are two stories of British higher education. The first is one of triumph. British higher education enjoys the best of both worlds. It has become the largest producer of graduates in Europe, and the British people enjoy unprecedented levels of access to higher education. And yet it still embodies a commitment to excellence and high standards which extends far beyond a dying nostalgia for elitist values - a higher education that acts mass but thinks elite. British universities and colleges are delicately balanced between old and new. Innovation has been embraced, tradition preserved. But perhaps that balance cannot be held. Two "falls" are possible. Either this curious "elite-mass" system will prove incapable of further expansion and adaptation and, as a result, be out-flanked by novel and rival forms of higher education that are mass in spirit as well as form; or the system will slough off its elite characteristics as budgets decline and more abrasive and urgent imperatives emerge. But, for the moment, the achievement of British higher education deserves to be celebrated. One form of British exceptionalism - low levels of participation, with access inequitably rationed - has been replaced by another - much higher levels of participation, which approximate to those in other developed countries without compromising the integrity of traditional academic culture. That is British higher education's first story. Autonomy eroded The second story is one of retreat and even defeat. In 1960 British higher education was regarded as exceptional in another sense: although overwhelmingly dependent on public funding, it enjoyed a very high level of autonomy. Buffered from the state by that uniquely British institution, the Uni versity Grants Committee (UGC), our universities enjoyed far greater freedom than universities in the rest of the world. As late as 1981 ministers received almost no advance warning of the grants committee's allocations as deep, and selective, cuts were made in university budgets. But the exceptional degree of autonomy apparently possessed by British universities during the high-noon of the grants-committee era reflected two special factors which could not be sustained indefinitely - first, the collusive character of post-war elites; and second, the strong political consensus that prevailed during this period, the so-called "post-war settlement". Large parts of British higher education lay outside the grants-committee sector: the polytechnics (now the "new" universities) and teacher training. Exaggerated or not, this autonomy has certainly been eroded. Accountability has been tightened by a rapid series of acronymic shifts. The UGC was abolished and replaced by the Universities Funding Council. This was partnered by the Polytechnics and Colleges Funding Council, which emerged after the eviction of local education authorities from higher education. Neither lasted long. Today the boss agency is the Higher Education Funding Council for England (Hefce) and its analogous agencies in Scotland and Wales. Almost nothing is left of the "donnish dominion". There is more. The academic culture that flourished in Britain's universities in the third quarter of the 20th century was exceptionally vibrant, despite the universities' corporate conservatism. The revolution in biological sciences and the intoxication of the social sciences promised extraordinarily powerful alliances between fundamental science and public intellectuals. That promise, too, has faded. First came the ideological revanche of Thatcherism. Then the remorseless bureaucracies of academic accountability - the Research Assessment Exercise (RAE) and Quality Assurance Agency - further eroded those crucial margins of irresponsibility and creativity. This is the second story: a retreat certainly, and perhaps even a defeat. Two paradoxes These two stories, both true, confront us with two paradoxes. First, a higher education that acts mass but thinks elite. Second, a higher education system that is both opening, in terms of its social reach, and (maybe) closing, in terms of its intellectual ambitions. The two may be connected - not because "more means worse" or because access and excellence are a zero-sum game, but because the dissonance be tween mass form and elite mentality may have led to intellectual closure. The big question is whether this elite-mass system is capable of extension and elaboration, or whether it has reached the limits of its potential. The answers to more detailed questions - on structure, funding and quality - depend on this. If future growth is likely to take place outside the sector, there is little point tinkering with the structure of higher education. Also, the choice between different funding and quality regimes will depend on whether higher education is still seen as a public service or is to be treated as a semi-privatised sector of the "knowledge industry". Expansion is the key. The government is committed to raising participation to 50% from today's 33%. But the most important drivers of expansion appear largely external to the higher education system. One is the government's commitment to raising standards in schools; another is the perceived need to provide the skills for a knowledge-based economy. Two components of the govern ment's strategy reflect these drivers. The first is the decision to establish two-year foundation degrees. The second is the development of alternative institutions uncluttered with the "academic" baggage which burdens existing universities. The University for Industry, now Learn Direct, comes to mind. Some of this expansion may also be channelled through other forms of "virtual" university, either joint ventures by existing universities or public-private partnerships, or through corporate universities. Perhaps a new binary division is developing - not a hierarchical division between more and less noble higher education institutions, but between public-sector, public-service higher education and new providers, whether novel vehicles like theUniversity for Industry, spin-offs of traditional institutions, public-private alliances or corporate universities. If this happened, the relationship between the two halves of this neo-binary system would be crucial - rivalry or synergy? However, even within the present system, pressure for change is building up. First comes the reviving debate about restructuring. We all have to be collaborators now. But should higher education be remodelled top-down along the lines of Wisconsin, where 26 universities are linked under a single governing body and divide up the academic labour between them, or will more chaotic forms of collaboration between institutions emerge? Each week there is a headline about a new alliance. Which are real, which a sham? The second is the devolutionary dynamic. The most high-profile example is the abolition of tuition fees for Scottish-domiciled students in Scottish universities. But equally significant, although less political, is the emergence of a stronger regional dimension in England after the creation of regional development agencies. Third, the future organisation of research remains unresolved. The traditional dual-support system has been undermined - by the RAE, which has externalised the universities' internal research priorities, and by the increasingly dirigisme and instrumentalism of the research councils, under pressure from the Office of Science and Technology (OST). The funding councils are fighting a dogged battle to defend their stake in research by conducting a "fundamental review" of the research assessment exercise (partly a re-engineering of the process but largely a re-justification). The outcome is unclear. Non-state money But the implications for the character of institutions and the shape of the system are important. The future of funding in British higher education is similarly clouded. The state is the majority stake-holder in higher education - and likely to remain so indefinitely despite the encouragement universities have received to diversify their income. But the prospects for a significant uplift in public expenditure on universities are bleak. The government, nominally Labour, has lost heart in social democracy (never mind socialism). But because it is nominally Labour, the prospects for more radical forms of privatisation are also slight. webTitle: Simon Schama's seminar on liberty and slavery is a hot new weapon in the webucation war

fields.headline: Fathom it out
fields.standfirst: Simon Schama's seminar on liberty and slavery is a hot new weapon in the webucation war, says  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Simon Schama's seminar on liberty and slavery is a hot new weapon in the webucation war, says Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
History star Simon Schama is the latest recruit in the "webucation" battle. This summer hundreds of people will be able to take part in an e-seminar prepared by the historian whose History of Britain starts its second series today. His topic is Liberty and Slavery in the early British Empire - so it deals with the slave trade and the American Declaration of Independence, topics calculated to have appeal on the other side of the Atlantic.

As this is cyberspace, the seminar can take three hours or a month, depending on how you want to tackle it, but participants will be able to put questions to Professor Schama dur ing the five weeks the seminar is expected to be online on the Fathom.com website. For Fathom, which has gone into partnership with the BBC in this venture, Schama's ability to attract paying customers could be crucial. (The price of taking part in the online seminar is $45/£32.)

Set up by Columbia University in alliance with 13 partners, including the London School of Economics, Fathom offers lifelong learning and professional development online. The member institutions include Cambridge University Press, the British Library, the New York Public Library, the University of Chicago, the University of Michigan, the American Film Institute, RAND, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Science Museum and the Natural History Museum .

With these huge storehouses of knowledge on tap and providing a lot of material on the site for free, Fathom aims to attract people to pay for distance learning.

Learners have been chary of taking courses lasting weeks or months, however, and the site's emphasis has switched to shorter courses and self-contained seminars. Columbia was reported earlier this year to be putting a further $10m into the project to keep it afloat - on top of the $18m it has already invested.

Fathom is just one player in the global game of e-learning which is becoming increasingly frenetic, with as yet no clear winners. Like the great colonial powers of the 18th century that Schama will be dealing with, groups of universities are vying for position in the rich uncharted territories of cyberspace. The potential rewards are huge in a world where developing countries are desperate for affordable knowledge and industrialised nations must reskill again and again to keep in the race.

In Britain the e-university is one model being backed by the funding councils to try to select courses from several universities in the UK and sell them abroad. The Open University, which successfully used television and the technology of the 1960s, is moving online. A totally different approach is being tried by Universitas 21, a consortium of universities in the UK, north America, Europe and China, which will validate each others' degrees.

Meanwhile the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has said it is putting its course materials on the internet for free. Like newspapers, universities are finding it easy to give away their "content" through websites, but hard to discover what people will pay for. "It's going to be a long hard road," admits Ann Kirschner, president of Fathom. "This is not for the faint of heart - only those with institutional and strategic commitment are going to make it."

But, she adds, "rumours of our death are exaggerated". It would, she said, be at least two years before Fathom proved itself a successful business, but the institutions involved were wanting an online showcase as well as return on their investment.

Simon Schama said his course was a baby step in what ought to become a great advance. He was delighted by the visual elements, and by its relevance to today's world: "In our 18th-century course we've tried to capitalise on the contemporary hunger for images to build a genuinely scholarly and question-raising approach to issues that still matter - power, profit, race and war. If I weren't teaching this course, I would be one of the first to take it."

Details at www.fathom.com

fields.headline: Co-op Bank profits from morality
fields.trailText: The Co-operative Bank is benefiting from the promotion of its ethical stance and claims to be making a profit, writes Roger Crowe.
fields.body:
The Co-op Bank has for the first time put a price on its ethical stance - and claims to be showing a profit.

Its positions on issues such as the arms trade and renewable energy made it £16m better off last year. That is about 16% of pre-tax profit, and comes after extra costs of more than £2m.

The figures are published today in the bank's fourth annual "Partnership report", which details financial, ethical and environmental performance in 2000.

Introducing the report, chief executive Mervyn Pedelty says the bank's distinctive position had been important in producing a seventh successive year of increased profits. Mr Pedelty says ethics are just one aspect of the bank's brand. But in the first cost-benefit exercise of its kind, marketing and finance specialists have estimated that these values are responsible for between 15% and 18% of the £96m pre-tax profit.

The figures are based on detailed analysis of the Co-op brand value, and market research findings from Mori that more than a quarter of current account customers cited ethics or the environment as the reason for opening their accounts.

Paul Monahan, the partnership development manager, said the results demonstrated the business case for sustainable development. "People often claim that ethical business is good business, but nobody has had hard numbers before."

The extra profits are despite turning down 105 of the 270 referrals to the bank's policy unit, mostly because of the ecological impact of the applicant's business. This is estimated to have cost the bank £1.7m in lost profits. On the other hand efforts to reduce the use of paper have saved nearly £3m.

Mr Monahan said the bank's energy bills show that many businesses overestimate the cost of going green. Using renewable energy in all the main office locations has added an annual cost of just £41,000. This has allowed the bank to achieve its target of cutting the carbon dioxide emissions it is responsible for by 60% since 1997 - three times the government's 20% reduction target.

In the current year the bank will benefit from national insurance savings following the introduction of the climate change levy. Mr Monahan said this would cancel the extra energy costs.

"It means we will have gone green and saved money."

The report details progress against 68 targets set last year. Of these, 47 have been completely achieved but no progress has been made on 10. Most significant is the failure to persuade staff that their salaries and benefits are good enough.

The bank has missed its target of getting 70% of staff to agree that salaries are at least "quite good".

Mr Monahan said this was partly due to a different approach to measuring staff attitudes, but new efforts will be made to boost staff satisfaction levels.

fields.headline: Tony Blair: 'A mandate for radical change'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Election 2001
fields.trailText: Earlier today, I saw the Queen at Buckingham Palace to ask for a dissolution of parliament so that there can be a general election on June 7.
fields.body:
Earlier today, I saw the Queen at Buckingham Palace to ask for a dissolution of parliament so that there can be a general election on June 7.

Every vote in this election is precious. No-one's support should ever be assumed. That is the strength of our democracy.

We earned the trust of the people in 1997 - after 18 long years of opposition.

Today we have to earn that trust again.

I stand before you today with a sense both of humility and of hope.

Humility, because though we can take pride in many achievements since May 1997, we know we still have so much to do, so many challenges still to overcome; and we know also that though we have striven at all times for your trust, there have been times of difficulty too.

Hope, because in every area of our national life that we promised change, however much remains to do, there are also the foundations laid for a brighter future, real progress, beacons lit showing us a better way.

Four years ago, you gave us, New Labour, a majority larger than I, or anyone else, believed you would. That large majority was never a reason to do the job quickly. It added the responsibility to do it properly, for the long term.

No government of change, in any country I can think of, has done it all in one programme, one budget, or one term. Four years has given us the chance to build foundations. But now the work must go on. There is a lot done, a lot more to do and a lot at stake in this election, which offers a more fundamental choice between the two main parties than for many years.

So what are these foundations and what must we build upon them?

The achievement that has most gladdened our supporters and surprised our doubters has been our economic record.

This is a New Labour government pursuing economic prosperity and social justice together.

Today, Britain is the fourth largest economy in the world. With the lowest inflation in Europe, mortgage rates half of what they were in the 80s and 90s, and more people in work than ever before, living standards are rising. It didn't happen by chance, but because we took the tough decisions needed to lay the foundations of economic stability.

Now we must go further, meet the challenge of economic change sweeping the world, and give our people the skills, the technology, the know-how, so that everyone gets the chance not just of a job, but of a career, able to earn a decent living and to make the most of themselves.

Nothing is possible without that basic, hard-won economic stability. When we came to power in May 1997, Britain spent more on interest payments on the National Debt than we spent on schools. We worked hard to put our country*s house in order.

This year, because of the difficult choices we made in our first two years, we will spend £10bn more on schools. There is a different set of priorities in our country today.

When we had the money to invest, we were clear what the number 1 priority would be. Education. Education. Education. The priority then, now and in the future.

In nurseries and primary schools in particular, we have seen real progress as real investment and change has taken place. In 1997, barely 50% of 11 year olds passed their tests. This year, it will be almost 80%.

But now the same step-change must be driven through our secondary schools and universities, so that we end once and for all the old sense of resignation among too many in Britain that their children can't get ahead. that there are two systems of education, one for the privileged, the other narrow and steep for the rest of the young.

In the NHS, waiting lists are lower, new hospitals are being built, there are 17,000 more nurses. Visit many A & E departments or use NHS Direct and you can see change. But we still have much further to go, if we are to see the NHS rebuilt according to its founding principle of quality health care available on the basis of need, not ability to pay.

Crime has fallen 10% since 1997 and police numbers after falling for a decade are now rising again. But drug abuse still blights too many lives. Violent crime still threatens too many communities. So progress, but again, further to go before, with the new investment, we have the largest ever number of police officers Britain has seen.

The New Deal has shown that governments can make a difference in the fight against unemployment. Our programme of welfare reform has led to benefit bills falling in real terms for the first time in decades. At the same time, the minimum wage has lifted the pay of hundreds of thousands.

But we know that there are still one in six non-pensioner homes with no-one working; and still, despite the recent rises in pension, and the winter allowance, we need to reward our pensioners who have saved hard all their lives. Full employment for our generation and security for that of our parents and grandparents.

In other areas like transport or inner city regeneration, there are plans for investment and renewal, but we are acutely aware of how big the challenge is that lies ahead.

Through devolution, a new partnership that has strengthened the United Kingdom and a peace process in Northern Ireland that offers the only hope of a peaceful future. But again much more to do.

So the work goes on and now I seek a mandate not simply for more of the same; I seek a fresh mandate for radical change.

Most people, quite rightly, do not pass their time immersed in politics.

They have the bills to pay, the job to do, the family to raise, the thousand different pressures of everyday life with which to contend. But a general election is different. It is a chance to explain, to engage in a sustained argument about the big issues, and about the country's destiny and direction. The decision as to who governs is a fundamental one for any nation. So in an election that dialogue is possible. People listen. They hear the arguments.

I will travel to every part of the country, not just defending our record, but arguing for the changes our country needs. The spine of my campaign will be a series of speeches that set out the challenge facing the country, and the reforms needed to meet them.

It's great that we have stable economic management. But it's not enough. We need a step-change in productivity, skills and enterprise. And we need reform to deliver it.

I'm proud that we're getting in record investment in our schools and hospitals. But it's not just money our public services need, but real reform to make that money work, and make our public services work for the people who depend on them.

It's a step in the right direction to get police numbers rising again. But on it's own, that's not enough. Not when we have a 19th century criminal justice system coping with 21st century crime.

It's an achievement that we have the welfare bills falling. But there are still too many people not working who could be, and so continuing welfare reform will be essential to our second term agenda.

I'm proud too that Britain is no longer marginalised and isolated in Europe. But we are not yet the leading nation in Europe that our weight, prosperity and history demand.

As New Labour, we seek a mandate not just for continuity but for change, for a Britain, strong, modern and fair.

We seek a mandate to make all the reforms necessary to strengthen, modernise and revitalise our schools and hospitals.

We seek a mandate for investment. Investment to extend opportunities. Ending years of cut backs that denied young people the chance to get on.

We seek a mandate for further reform of the welfare state. To make the tax and benefit system reward work, tackle poverty and penalise irresponsibility.

We seek a mandate to make Britain stronger - stronger because we are engaged with Europe and the wider world, showing our leadership, not in retreat.

But it is a choice that I cannot make alone. The challenge is there for you as well as me. For I see the differences between the main two parties as more stark than at any time since 1983.

For we know today's Conservative party would take us back, back to negative equity, high mortgage rates and boom and bust; back to cuts in public services; back to social division; back to the margins of influence in Europe and the wider world.

So there is a choice. This election is about which party can be trusted with the economy, which party will invest more in our public services, which party is capable of leading Britain into the future.

We have made our choice. It won't be easy. Nothing good ever is.

You all know that any success you have ever had in life, whether an exam passed or a promotion gained, has had its mixture of tough choices, personal application and even pain.

But afterwards, comes the fulfilment of a great goal achieved. And my goal at this election is this: it is not just to win your vote, but to win your support, win your heart and mind in the fight for change that I am leading. And it is change for a purpose: to create a society and nation, where everyone, not just the privileged few, gets the chance to succeed.

We have all heard the term "people in their place". I say to you today; we must reach a time, in our time, when the only rightful place for every man, woman and child in Britain is where their talents take them.

So the great issue of this election is opportunity for all, not just the few. This election is about a radical vision of lifting barriers and liberating people*s potential in a decent society, where everyone gets the chance to make the most of their God-given talent.

We stand:

For more investment, not less,

Economic stability the foundation,

Schools and hospitals first,

Radical reforms and equal chances.

Britain is a great nation. It has so many strengths. But its biggest strength is its people. They, you young people here today, are the nation's potential. This is the time, and ours is the task, to set your talents free and build a land of hope and opportunity for all.

Now you, the people, will decide.

fields.bodyText: Earlier today, I saw the Queen at Buckingham Palace to ask for a dissolution of parliament so that there can be a general election on June 7. Every vote in this election is precious. No-one's support should ever be assumed. That is the strength of our democracy. We earned the trust of the people in 1997 - after 18 long years of opposition. Today we have to earn that trust again. I stand before you today with a sense both of humility and of hope. Humility, because though we can take pride in many achievements since May 1997, we know we still have so much to do, so many challenges still to overcome; and we know also that though we have striven at all times for your trust, there have been times of difficulty too. Hope, because in every area of our national life that we promised change, however much remains to do, there are also the foundations laid for a brighter future, real progress, beacons lit showing us a better way. Four years ago, you gave us, New Labour, a majority larger than I, or anyone else, believed you would. That large majority was never a reason to do the job quickly. It added the responsibility to do it properly, for the long term. No government of change, in any country I can think of, has done it all in one programme, one budget, or one term. Four years has given us the chance to build foundations. But now the work must go on. There is a lot done, a lot more to do and a lot at stake in this election, which offers a more fundamental choice between the two main parties than for many years. So what are these foundations and what must we build upon them? The achievement that has most gladdened our supporters and surprised our doubters has been our economic record. This is a New Labour government pursuing economic prosperity and social justice together. Today, Britain is the fourth largest economy in the world. With the lowest inflation in Europe, mortgage rates half of what they were in the 80s and 90s, and more people in work than ever before, living standards are rising. It didn't happen by chance, but because we took the tough decisions needed to lay the foundations of economic stability. Now we must go further, meet the challenge of economic change sweeping the world, and give our people the skills, the technology, the know-how, so that everyone gets the chance not just of a job, but of a career, able to earn a decent living and to make the most of themselves. Nothing is possible without that basic, hard-won economic stability. When we came to power in May 1997, Britain spent more on interest payments on the National Debt than we spent on schools. We worked hard to put our country*s house in order. This year, because of the difficult choices we made in our first two years, we will spend £10bn more on schools. There is a different set of priorities in our country today. When we had the money to invest, we were clear what the number 1 priority would be. Education. Education. Education. The priority then, now and in the future. In nurseries and primary schools in particular, we have seen real progress as real investment and change has taken place. In 1997, barely 50% of 11 year olds passed their tests. This year, it will be almost 80%. But now the same step-change must be driven through our secondary schools and universities, so that we end once and for all the old sense of resignation among too many in Britain that their children can't get ahead. that there are two systems of education, one for the privileged, the other narrow and steep for the rest of the young. In the NHS, waiting lists are lower, new hospitals are being built, there are 17,000 more nurses. Visit many A & E departments or use NHS Direct and you can see change. But we still have much further to go, if we are to see the NHS rebuilt according to its founding principle of quality health care available on the basis of need, not ability to pay. Crime has fallen 10% since 1997 and police numbers after falling for a decade are now rising again. But drug abuse still blights too many lives. Violent crime still threatens too many communities. So progress, but again, further to go before, with the new investment, we have the largest ever number of police officers Britain has seen. The New Deal has shown that governments can make a difference in the fight against unemployment. Our programme of welfare reform has led to benefit bills falling in real terms for the first time in decades. At the same time, the minimum wage has lifted the pay of hundreds of thousands. But we know that there are still one in six non-pensioner homes with no-one working; and still, despite the recent rises in pension, and the winter allowance, we need to reward our pensioners who have saved hard all their lives. Full employment for our generation and security for that of our parents and grandparents. In other areas like transport or inner city regeneration, there are plans for investment and renewal, but we are acutely aware of how big the challenge is that lies ahead. Through devolution, a new partnership that has strengthened the United Kingdom and a peace process in Northern Ireland that offers the only hope of a peaceful future. But again much more to do. So the work goes on and now I seek a mandate not simply for more of the same; I seek a fresh mandate for radical change. Most people, quite rightly, do not pass their time immersed in politics. They have the bills to pay, the job to do, the family to raise, the thousand different pressures of everyday life with which to contend. But a general election is different. It is a chance to explain, to engage in a sustained argument about the big issues, and about the country's destiny and direction. The decision as to who governs is a fundamental one for any nation. So in an election that dialogue is possible. People listen. They hear the arguments. I will travel to every part of the country, not just defending our record, but arguing for the changes our country needs. The spine of my campaign will be a series of speeches that set out the challenge facing the country, and the reforms needed to meet them. It's great that we have stable economic management. But it's not enough. We need a step-change in productivity, skills and enterprise. And we need reform to deliver it. I'm proud that we're getting in record investment in our schools and hospitals. But it's not just money our public services need, but real reform to make that money work, and make our public services work for the people who depend on them. It's a step in the right direction to get police numbers rising again. But on it's own, that's not enough. Not when we have a 19th century criminal justice system coping with 21st century crime. It's an achievement that we have the welfare bills falling. But there are still too many people not working who could be, and so continuing welfare reform will be essential to our second term agenda. I'm proud too that Britain is no longer marginalised and isolated in Europe. But we are not yet the leading nation in Europe that our weight, prosperity and history demand. As New Labour, we seek a mandate not just for continuity but for change, for a Britain, strong, modern and fair. We seek a mandate to make all the reforms necessary to strengthen, modernise and revitalise our schools and hospitals. We seek a mandate for investment. Investment to extend opportunities. Ending years of cut backs that denied young people the chance to get on. We seek a mandate for further reform of the welfare state. To make the tax and benefit system reward work, tackle poverty and penalise irresponsibility. We seek a mandate to make Britain stronger - stronger because we are engaged with Europe and the wider world, showing our leadership, not in retreat. But it is a choice that I cannot make alone. The challenge is there for you as well as me. For I see the differences between the main two parties as more stark than at any time since 1983. For we know today's Conservative party would take us back, back to negative equity, high mortgage rates and boom and bust; back to cuts in public services; back to social division; back to the margins of influence in Europe and the wider world. So there is a choice. This election is about which party can be trusted with the economy, which party will invest more in our public services, which party is capable of leading Britain into the future. We have made our choice. It won't be easy. Nothing good ever is. You all know that any success you have ever had in life, whether an exam passed or a promotion gained, has had its mixture of tough choices, personal application and even pain. But afterwards, comes the fulfilment of a great goal achieved. And my goal at this election is this: it is not just to win your vote, but to win your support, win your heart and mind in the fight for change that I am leading. And it is change for a purpose: to create a society and nation, where everyone, not just the privileged few, gets the chance to succeed. We have all heard the term "people in their place". I say to you today; we must reach a time, in our time, when the only rightful place for every man, woman and child in Britain is where their talents take them. So the great issue of this election is opportunity for all, not just the few. This election is about a radical vision of lifting barriers and liberating people*s potential in a decent society, where everyone gets the chance to make the most of their God-given talent. We stand: For more investment, not less, Economic stability the foundation, Schools and hospitals first, Radical reforms and equal chances. Britain is a great nation. It has so many strengths. But its biggest strength is its people. They, you young people here today, are the nation's potential. This is the time, and ours is the task, to set your talents free and build a land of hope and opportunity for all. Now you, the people, will decide. webTitle: Bush's men on charm offensive for missile defence

fields.headline: Bush's men on charm offensive for missile defence
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Lieutenants of the US president, George Bush, met Nato officials in Brussels today as part of his international charm offensive, designed to garner approval for his missile defence plan.
fields.body:
Lieutenants of the US president, George Bush, met Nato officials in Brussels today as part of his international charm offensive, designed to garner approval for his missile defence plan.

Under-secretary of state for political affairs, Marc Grossman, and deputy assistant for national security affairs, Stephen Hadley, briefed Nato delegates this morning.

This follows yesterday's meeting between US deputy secretary of defence, Richard Armitage, and senior Japanese officials.

Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, welcomed US efforts to forge a dialogue with its allies on Bush's missile defence plan, dubbed "Son of Star Wars".

He said in a statement: "This is just the beginning of a thorough process and I particularly appreciate the commitment to consultation in the North Atlantic Council before any decisions have been made."

Following Mr Armitage's Japanese trip, he will spend Wednesday and Thursday meeting South Korean officials, before moving on to India on Friday.

The US deputy defence secretary, Paul Wolfowitz, is expected to visit Moscow later this week to discuss Mr Bush's plans to implement a nationwide security system designed to shoot down missiles attacking US territory.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, has given Mr Bush's plans a cautious welcome but is said to disagree with the American president's desire to tear apart the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with Russia.

Russia says the treaty is a foundation of world security and should be preserved

fields.headline: May 08 2001
fields.trailText: In a week in which it was reported that graduates are now leaving college with average debts of £10,000 - up from just £6,500 last year, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for impoverished young professionals.
fields.body:
In a week in which it was reported that graduates are now leaving college with average debts of £10,000 - up from just £6,500 last year, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for impoverished young professionals.

If you were too busy catching the summer's first rays, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 5 May).

Sarah Richardson looked at the recent disasters that have befallen the agricultural industry and asked what impact they have had on its ability to attract high calibre workers.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,486130,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Rise's own high flyer Annabelle Thorpe suggests how you can develop your own brand of a "can-do attitude" - it's not about saying yes to everything but being open, positive and up-beat, she says.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,486132,00.html?bnr=email.grad

NEXT WEEK'S RISE gives advice to those in the envious position of being offered more than one job. David Williams looks at a new Premier League style breakaway by several university careers services, and there is even some advice on how to overcome shyness as you enter the job market.

This week's RISE GOLD gives some advice on how to act the part. You may have just landed a great job but you're worried that someone is going to come up and say that there's been a terrible mistake.. Read this, and you'll be fine.

http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4045347,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP is.cheer up. Young single workers are the most miserable people in Britain - with more than two-thirds complaining they are stressed, claims a recent survey. Start giving out some positive energy and good things might start happening to you.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS

If you are a graduate with an eye on getting into human resources, the regional development agency, Sussex Enterprise, is looking for an HR assistant it can develop and even put through their exams. It's also looking for an economic information analyst.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116742,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Would you believe there is a job as a Home Composting Project Liaison Officer? HDRA Consultants is looking for just such a person to be based in Preston for two years. The lucky person will organise "home composting roadshows" and also train community volunteers. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116634,00.html?bnr=email.grad

University College London's British Heart Foundation research group is looking for a pro-active, numerate, computer literate graduate with some financial and administrative experience to help run its research labs. It's paying up to £27K.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100117440,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Calling all potential geography teachers: Sydenham School in south-east London wants to train you up as a classroom teacher through the Graduate Trainee Programme, and will pay you while it's happening. Got to be worth a look.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100117382,00.html?bnr=email.grad

The New Economics Foundation is looking for an economist with a difference. It specialises in resourcing and supporting economic justice campaigners around the world on issues like third world debt and international finance. And they'll even pay you - up to £26,000.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115211,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Science graduates looking to go into publishing should look no further. The Society for General Microbiology is looking for a science grad to work on its "three learned journals". Got to have a sound understanding of molecular biology and biochemistry.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100117203,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you've always wanted to write about TV, the listings guides are one way in. The BiG Listings Co is looking for someone who can handle the programme information/schedules from over 200 channels. Only £14k - the only way is up.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100117055,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And finally, if you are into "policy innovation", Portsmouth City Council is looking for a strategic thinker to help the council best direct its resources and take advantage of any Government funding that is available. They want a 2:1 degree in a social science or business discipline.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116759,00.html?bnr=email.grad

fields.headline: Reaction to the election announcement
fields.trailText: The opposing party leaders were quick to take to the airwaves to give their views on the forthcoming election.
fields.body:
The opposing party leaders were quick to take to the airwaves to give their views on the forthcoming election.

The Conservative leader, William Hague, said: "Labour has squandered a huge Commons majority, the goodwill of the people of this country, and the best set of economic conditions any government has ever inherited. "Never has a party had so much, but achieved so little."

The leader of the Liberal Democrats, Charles Kennedy, said: "People also know we have reached the end of the road in terms of cutting income tax.

"We want a constructive rather than destructive campaign. People are truly sceptical and an honest approach from us is something that goes down well."

The chairman of the Conservative party, Michael Ancram, said: "No person in the street thinks their lives have been made better by Labour's spin doctors. People will not forget the lessons of the last four years."

The Scottish secretary, Helen Liddell, answering questions in the Commons just after the announcement of the election date was made, said: "Much has been done. There is much to do. But there is also much to lose and I would agree that it is time for a general election."

A spokesman for the Green party, Mike Woodin, said: "Green policies are increasingly popular. Public opinion has swung our way on roadbuilding, on rail nationalisation, on climate change, on food safety, on agriculture, even on globalisation.

"We know there are millions of potential green votes out there. Tony Blair knows it too, which is why he keeps masquerading as green."

Councillor Dave Nellist, the leader of the Socialist Alliance, said: "In this election we won't get the same attention as the main parties - but we aim to be the major, minor party. Whilst the establishment parties hide in the television studios, we'll be out canvassing, campaigning, holding public meetings and talking to people in the streets. In most towns and cities people will have a good chance of meeting a socialist campaigner."

Following Mr Blair's speech, Downing Street released an official statement: "The prime minister has today asked Her Majesty the Queen to proclaim the dissolution of parliament.

"Her Majesty has been graciously pleased to signify that she will comply with this request.

"Parliament will be dissolved on Monday, 14th May. The general election will take place on Thursday, 7th June.

"The new parliament will be summoned to meet on Wednesday, 13th June, when the first business will be the election of the Speaker and the swearing-in of members.

"The State Opening will be on Wednesday, 20th June."

webTitle: Free market a turn-off for the bulk of Leeds fans

fields.headline: Free market a turn-off for the bulk of Leeds fans
fields.trailText: Sport is all about building a customer base and protecting assets. Expect football clubs to end up selling the rights to everything, from match reporting to the air you breath at a game.
fields.body:
At a christening recently I noticed that the words of the baptism had been copyrighted by the General Synod of the Church of England. When I asked the vicar about it afterwards he explained that the action had been taken to prevent the words of church services being used in the media without permission.

In an age when you cannot rebroadcast Christ's message of hope for all mankind without the threat of litigation I suppose we should not expect much in the way of charity from anyone involved with football. The game after all is about as far removed from Christian principles as the New Wembley is from becoming reality. If God wants a percentage, why shouldn't Ken Bates?

Digital television has much going for it. For one thing you can at least direct your fees. One of the most painful things about parting with the TV licence fee has always been the knowledge that some of that £104 is going to end up in Roy Keane's wallet. Unfortunately there is a downside, too.

Tonight Leeds play Valencia in arguably the Elland Road club's most important match since they took on Barcelona at the same stage of the European Cup 26 years ago. Despite the game's magnitude it will not be shown live on mainstream television. The rights to broadcast it belong to Ondigital. That in itself should not have been an insurmountable obstacle. According to Uefa, ITV are allowed to air the match live provided they come to an agreement with the digital broadcaster. Since two ITV companies, Carlton and Granada, jointly own Ondigital, you might think that would be a possibility. It is not going to happen, though. A spokesman for Ondigital commented with commendable frankness: "We have paid a lot of money for these rights. Why should we give them away?"

A fair enough argument, surely? This is a free market and, as we are all aware by now, a free market does not come cheap, especially to the consumer. In truth, though, it is not about giving anything away - ITV would, presumably, have compensated Ondigital financially) - but about building a customer base and protecting assets.

This will become increasingly important over the next few years as clubs begin to exercise ever greater control over what sports teams in the United States refer to as their "content" and who is allowed to use it. The exact scope of the "content", like Andy Goram, grows wider by the day. It began with shirts and what an NBA spokesman referred to recently as "our corporate logos" (that is club badges to any romantic chuckleheads still left out there), moved on to images of players and is now beginning to encircle factual information.

In the US lawyers repre senting the main sports bodies have begun looking at ways to prevent websites posting up results. The argument runs that since the teams themselves generate the results they rightfully belong to them. If the likes of the NBA and NFL win, it is a safe bet they will sell off the rights to broadcast and publish the scores to the highest bidder. Like Ondigital the eventual buyers will not give those scores away for free.

The same could soon be true in Britain. The fixture list is already copyrighted and the Premier League is moving to license those companies who collate and sell statistics. It is unlikely to stop there.

A year or so ago a Premiership chairman accused a fanzine editor of "living off the back of this football club for 10 years". That the football club had been living off the back of the supporters for well over a century had apparently escaped his notice. If this gentleman felt that about a fanzine, what must he feel about the fact that newspapers get to cover the matches for nothing?

For many years we took it for granted we could see top-class sport on TV more or less free. That right has now been taken away. And if Sky can own exclusive rights to show the Premiership live, why should their sister company News International not buy exclusive rights to report on the games and to carry the results and the league tables?

The readership would have to pay through the nose for the privilege of seeing them, of course. But what else would you expect? After all, as Milton Friedman wisely observed: "In this society there is no such thing as a free-kick."

fields.headline: Lyle and Musgrove team up again after a dozen years
fields.trailText: One of the most famous and effective player-caddie partnerships in the modern game will be revived this week when Sandy Lyle and Dave Musgrove team up at the Benson & Hedges International at the Belfry this week for the first time in 10 years.
fields.body:
One of the most famous and effective player-caddie partnerships in the modern game will be revived this week. Sandy Lyle and Dave Musgrove, who won the Open in 1985 and the 1988 US Masters together, will work together at the Benson & Hedges International at the Belfry this week, their first outing for more than 10 years.

Musgrove, who has carried for many of the game's best players, including Tom Watson, Severiano Ballesteros and, lately, Lee Janzen has been concentrating on building up a book-selling business he runs from home.

But the chance to work again with a man who was more of a friend than a boss was too tempting and the pair will also compete at the Volvo PGA Championship at Wentworth and the Victor Chandler British Masters at Woburn this month.

Musgrove first worked with Lyle at the 1981 Ryder Cup at Walton Heath and they won 15 times together in the 80s. They were such a familiar sight that they inspired a book, Life With Lyle - His Caddie's Diary, with John Hopkins.

In it Musgrove, who stayed at "Lyle Towers" as he called his boss's home at Wentworth when in the United Kingdom, said: "Who has got the best job in the world? Why, Sandy Lyle of course. But who has got the second-best job in the world? Easy, David Musgrove. He even brings me tea in the morning."

The partnership flourished throughout the 80s and never more so than at the Masters in 1988. After leading for most of the final round Lyle found the water at the short 12th, fell behind Mark Calcavecchia and was close to panic. Musgrove, recognising this was the time to earn his pay, said: "Let someone else take the strain and lead for a bit. We've got plenty of time."

The advice calmed Lyle and, with two birdies in the last three holes, including what has been called the best bunker shot ever - the seven-iron from a fairway bunker to 10 feet at the 18th for the second birdie - he collected his green jacket.

Musgrove was invited to appear on a television show after that but refused. Musgrove, from Kirkby-in-Ashfield, near Mansfield, has solid northern values and said: "That's a pain in the arse. I don't want to put my best suit on, go to London and answer a lot of questions in front of an audience. I'd rather stay at home and scrub the floor."

They parted in 1989, after Lyle had struggled for most of that year. Musgrove said then he thought "someone else would do him better; a change would be better than a rest". But Lyle has continued, mostly, to struggle and it will be interesting to see if these old friends can re-ignite the flame that once burned so brightly.

fields.headline: Rusedski dances in the rain
fields.trailText: Grey skies failed to clear up but at least Greg Rusedski was able to put on a happy face at the Foro Italico yesterday, winning for only the second time in seven years at the Italian Open.
fields.body:
Grey skies failed to clear up but at least Greg Rusedski was able to put on a happy face at the Foro Italico yesterday, winning for only the second time in seven years at the Italian Open.

His German opponent David Prinosil had thumped Rusedksi 6-3, 6-2 six weeks ago in the Miami sunshine but on sodden Roman red clay courts, suggestive of a tide-swept beach, the reversal was surprisingly stark, with Rusedski winning by the same score.

In the morning there had seemed little chance of any play at all. "Good preparation for Wimbledon," quipped Rusedski as he hustled away for an early lunch.

By mid-afternoon the rain had eased to what Michael Fish refers to as spits and spots and the first-round match finally began on the Pallacorda, a sunken court encircled by marble steps and huge statues, all pre-war Mussolini grandiloquence.

There have been times during the last 12 months when Rusedski has not moved much faster than these statues. Since losing in the first round at Monte Carlo three weeks ago he has been training hard at a private club north of Barcelona.

Rusedski did not hit a ball for 10 days. "We just did a lot of running, weights and conditioning and then last week my coach Brad Langevad came down to Spain."

In Spain he hit with another German, Marc-Kevin Goellner, who is based in London. "We have played doubles together and we get on well socially," Rusedski said.

Prinosil, who in 1999 had the same foot operation as Rusedski, reached the quarter-finals of the Italian Open that same year but is not a renowned clay-court player, having done better at Wimbledon than Roland Garros over the last nine years.

"It was quite a good draw for me," admitted Rusedski, who quickly took a 2-0 first-set lead. He immediately dropped his serve but thereafter was never really stretched.

"I was really looking forward to the match because David beat me pretty badly in Miami and I wanted to get my revenge on him. Brad and I sat down and worked out a good game plan."

With the court damp and in a decided chill, Rusedski was clearly expecting a tougher match but Prinosil was unable to find, let alone sustain, any sort of rhythm in an atmosphere of barely suppressed gloom among the scattering of spectators, many huddled under umbrellas.

The British No2 now faces a decidedly harder match against Slovakia's Dominik Hrbaty or the South African Wayne Ferreira.

There was gloom in bucketfuls for Sweden's Magnus Norman, who won the title here last year on his way to the final of the French Open which he narrowly lost to Brazil's Gustavo Kuerten, the world No1.

Norman, to the astonishment of most Romans who have long become used to lack of home success, was defeated 6-4, 6-3 by Italy's Vincenzo Santopadre, a wild card and ranked a lowly No180.

"I played one of the worst matches in my entire career," said Norman, who finished No4 in the world last year but is currently suffering from a crisis of confidence.

"You really get to know who your friends are at these times, said Norman. "The mobile phone doesn't call as much as before. My coach is there, and my family, but that's about it."

No amount of practice - and Norman is one of the more assiduous workers on the circuit - is currently making any difference. "I'm devastated and I don't know what to do. Sooner or later I hope I can find a way of digging myself out of this but as soon as I get on court I get so tight."

A small number of Italians were themselves getting tight last night on the strength of Santopadre's victory.

fields.headline: O'Sullivan shows his mettle
fields.trailText: With 20 titles to show from his 28 finals, O'Sullivan rarely shows any inhibitions in clinching winning positions. At the Crucible last night he held his nerve once more and finally realised his dream to become world champion.
fields.body:
Ronnie O'Sullivan realised a dream last night to take the Embassy World Championship here at the Crucible.

Leading 14-7, he was closing in on the record £250,000 first prize but faltered in the latter part of the afternoon session against John Higgins and the 1998 champion restricted his advantage to 14-10 going into their final session.

O'Sullivan began the afternoon as he had concluded the previous evening, when the last four frames had yielded breaks of 99, 100 and 99 to him against one of 107 for Higgins.

From his overnight 10-6 he won four of the day's first five frames with runs of 81, 139, 85 and 86 with Higgins securing the other with 65.

At one stage, as O'Sullivan accumulated 362 unanswered points, it seemed as if the evening session might be brief but, as Terry Griffiths, the 1979 champion, once remarked: "The worst time is when you've almost won; when you're a long way in front and you need only a couple of frames to know that, realistically, you can't be caught."

Matthew Stevens was at such a juncture in last year's final when he led 13-7, only to have his lead reduced to 13-11 after three sessions on his way to an 18-16 defeat by Mark Williams.

Initially Higgins did not seem to be playing well enough for a similar recovery to be contemplated but he struggled through the scrappiest frame of the match as O'Sullivan's form abruptly declined, clinched another with a break of 65 and, with confidence and hope restored, added the last of the afternoon with 98.

With 20 titles to show from his 28 finals, O'Sullivan rarely shows any inhibitions in clinching winning positions but Crucible finals, particularly for players who have never won, are in a class of their own and Jimmy White fans remember how their man had led Stephen Hendry 14-8 in the 1992 final only to lose 18-14.

O'Sullivan was left with a couple of hours to refocus and prepare for the most important session of his career, facing just the possibility that his heart's desire - that of any contender - could be snatched away at the last.

It had always seemed his destiny to be world champion but, having reached the age of 25 without making it happen, the pressure was upon him to fulfil the immense expectations engendered by a youthful talent so prodigious that, as with other geniuses, it removed him at an early age from normality.

From the time he won his first pro-am at the age of 12 he was living essentially like an adult, playing here, there and everywhere. He could not evade the claims of real life, however, once his carefree youth ended at the age of 16.

While he was in the process of winning 72 of his first 74 professional matches in qualifying competitions during a long summer at Blackpool, his father was on trial at the Old Bailey. Ronnie Senior has been serving a life sentence ever since.

Some of the remedies to which the young O'Sullivan turned to ease the black depressions which began to descend simply created more problems. He had to forfeit the 1998 Irish Masters title and the £61,000 prize-money through testing positive for marijuana; and he lost his driving licence for speeding.

For three years he has been supporting the daughter of a former girlfriend. And in 1996 his pent-up emotions caused him to snap so uncharacteristically that he assaulted a press officer here.

"There are a lot of things I would like to change and do differently," said O'Sullivan, who has also undergone extensive psychotherapy. "But I've just got to accept it and just get on with it."

webTitle: Hills to enjoy his Big Moment

fields.headline: Hills to enjoy his Big Moment
fields.trailText: Barry Hills has an excellent record at Chester's May meeting and can pull off a double with Amicable (2.40) and Big Moment (4.10) on the first day of the fixture, writes Tony Paley.
fields.body:
Barry Hills has an excellent record at Chester's May meeting and can pull off a double with Amicable (2.40) and Big Moment (4.10) on the first day of the fixture, writes Tony Paley.

A low draw and the ability to be prominent early are major assets around this tight track and the promising Amicable has both those factors in his favour.

Big Moment has run two eye-catching races in defeat and looks to have been found an ideal race in which to break his duck.

Kieren Fallon can also bag a brace of winners with course-and-distance scorer Batswing (3.40), who shouldn't be as inconvenienced by the fast ground as other fancied runners, and the speedy, firm-ground specialist Proud Boast (4.40).

Celtic Exit (4.20), working well at home and very fairly treated, rates the nap at Leicester.

webTitle: Fortune favours Nimello in record win

fields.headline: Fortune favours Nimello in record win
fields.standfirst: Cole's plan works to perfection with his firm favourite
fields.trailText: Nimello sent favourite backers home happy and created a piece of handicap history when winning the big betting race of the Bank Holiday at Kempton yesterday.
fields.body:
Nimello sent favourite backers home happy and created a piece of handicap history when winning the big betting race of the Bank Holiday at Kempton yesterday.

The five-year-old's victory in the Doubleprint Stakes meant he became the first horse to win both this race, which had been run as the Jubilee Stakes from 1897 until a new sponsor changed its name last year, and the Lincoln (founded in 1853) in the same season. It also saw the gelding take his earnings through the £100,000 mark.

Nimello's win was all the more meritorious as his rider Jimmy Fortune had a wall of horses in front of him in the home straight before finding a way through to cut down Bold King well inside the final furlong and land the spoils by one and a quarter lengths.

Nimello's trainer Paul Cole said: "The plan was always to go for this and he did well to get up. He really only goes on this ground and he might go for a Group Two in Italy at the end of the month."

Richard Hills's decision to go for a daring run between horses in the closing stages of the Tripleprint Handicap paid off by galvanising reluctant hero Admirals Place to provide trainer Hugh Collingridge with a first strike of the season.

"Trainers like me need winners like this," said Collingridge after Admirals Place, a 20-1 shot, was switched inside to attack Hambleden and sneak past for a short-head triumph.

"This was his first time over a mile and a half," added Collingridge. "There wasn't a lot of pace on early and Richard said he pulled very hard. When Richard produced him down the outside he did not want to go past, so he put him in between two horses and Admirals Place did the business."

Monica Geller gained compensation for her intended target being washed away at Sandown last month when storming to a six-length triumph in the Bonusprint Handicap.

Trainer Conrad Allen had high hopes for Monica Geller in the Esher Cup at Sandown but that race was one of the two Flat races which were abandoned on rain-soaked Whitbread day.

"I was very disappointed that those 'soft' Flat jockeys did not want to run the Esher Cup. I did fancy her then so I'm just very glad to get this," said Allen.

Michael Jarvis and Philip Robinson picked up where they left off from Ameerat's success in Sunday's Sagitta 1,000 Guineas when delivering favourite Pulau Tioman to win the Bonusfilm Conditions Stakes.

 Muwakleh, runner-up in Sunday's 1,000 Guineas, has been retired to stud due to a fracture to her right knee which she sustained during the Newmarket Classic.

webTitle: Mathematical courses have highest dropout rate

fields.headline: Mathematical courses have highest dropout rate
fields.trailText: Courses that involve maths have one of the highest dropout rates and more boys leave university than girls, a new study by Dublin City University has found.
fields.body:
Students cannot hack maths and more boys leave university than girls, according to research released in Ireland yesterday. A new study suggests students are more likely to complete their degrees only on certain courses and at certain institutions.

The study, by Dr Mark Morgan from Dublin City University and his colleagues, looked at the progress of all 1992-3 entrants to the Republic of Ireland's seven universities.

Overall, the drop out rate was 20% higher for boys than it was for girls, although there are differences between institutions.

One of the most interesting findings is that students do better when they are in a minority. For example, almost all of the girls on engineering courses or boys on social studies courses finished their degrees.

Professor Maggie Woodrow, executive director of the European Access Network at Westminster University, said the research made sense: "To get onto these courses you probably had to be pretty determined to start with, pretty tough."

Fewer students completed courses that involved mathematics, a trend that Dr Morgan felt was most pronounced where students were surprised by that part of the course.

For example, the course with the lowest completion rate was computer studies, which he felt some students might sign up for without being aware of what was involved. In all universities, over one quarter of students did not complete their computer studies courses.

However, Professor Woodrow suggested that the dropout rate might be caused by the amount of tutor contact on computer courses, which the UK higher education select committee's report identified as a key factor in student retention.

Medicine was found to have one of the lowest dropout rates, contrary to traditional expectations, as the course is always thought to be one of the most rigorous. However, president of the Barthes and London medical student association, Tom Dolphin, said it made sense that medics stuck with their courses. "It is more of a vocation. People choose medicine because they want to be doctors and stopping short is not really an option. I know of a lot of people getting kicked out or dropping down a year, but not many leaving university," he said.

The report also emphasises the clear, though possibly not direct, relationship of entry qualifications to course completion. The higher a student's marks on entry, the more likely they are to finish. However, it is not clear how much of this is because of ability or commitment and how much is influenced by the facilities and finances of the institution they attend.

Dr Morgan stressed the difficulty of applying the Irish findings to UK higher education. The seven Irish universities have kept a traditional structure, remaining clearly divided from polytechnics, and cater to a relatively small population.

fields.headline: Lehmann's lashing cannot hurt losers
fields.standfirst:
Benson & Hedges Cup
Yorkshire 257-7 Durham 227-4
Yorkshire won by 30 runs
fields.trailText: Yorkshire won this match at a canter. And by virtue of far superior run-rates to Leicestershire, both they and Durham have made it to the quarter-finals, along with the north division winners Nottinghamshire.
fields.body:
At this time of year football likes to think it is in a mire of complicated promotion and relegation mathematics. But it has nothing on cricket. Run-rates and zonal gobbledegook conspire to make the spectator feel an idiot.

But even to those not equipped with Sky television one thing was clear: Yorkshire won this match at a canter. And by virtue of far superior run-rates to Leicestershire, both they and Durham have made it to the quarter-finals, along with the north division winners Nottinghamshire.

So everyone was happy and, despite the maths, it was a tip-top bank holiday afternoon for the 4,250 paying spectators and the one hard-hatted workman who sat alone on the unfinished Western terrace for most of the day.

These are the dream-seam teams. Yorkshire's England lot are the more cocksure and the more blessed with star quality; Chris Silverwood warmed up at lunchtime watched by a gaggle of admiring kids.

But Durham's pack, minus the injured Neil Killeen and Simon Brown, are rawer but just as fast, so almost more exciting. The most successful yesterday was 20-year-old Ian Hunter, who spent 15 days in winter at Dennis Lillee's coaching school. He delivered two no-balls and a wide in his first over but quickly recovered his composure as Lillee would surely have taught him.

He was swift enough to disorient and nearly disembowel David Byas, who was in good touch, before destroying his stumps and those of Gary Fellows and Michael Lumb. And he avoided getting his confidence blown to pieces by bowling first change and at the death, thereby avoiding most of Darren Lehmann.

Lehmann bestrides Headingley like a rich gentleman farmer but dispatches the ball like a hungry ploughman dissatisfied with his pickled onions. He really does wallop the ball and it was a surprise that he hit only two sixes on the way to his third gold award in eight days.

He ruined Andrew Pratt's otherwise immaculate day behind the stumps when he was dropped on 15 and destroyed Stephen Harmison's figures: eight overs for 19 became 10 for 50 after a late-order spree.

He and Anthony McGrath powered their way to a stand of 114 to take the game away from Durham and, more importantly, whack up Yorkshire's run rate. The strain was such that Lehmann pulled a hamstring and had to sit out Durham's reply with a cigarette.

Theirs was inevitably going to be a lower-key effort than Yorkshire's. They knew from the start that they had to make only 195 to qualify on run rate, whatever happened elsewhere. When Jimmy Daley pulled a hamstring too and retired hurt on 14 and they lost Michael Gough, who had just made his first one-day 50, in a flurry of middle-order wickets, the die was cast.

In the late afternoon Danny Law and Jon Lewis took Durham past the magic figures with four overs to spare. It was as sweet a contrived finish as possible.

fields.headline: Sussex storm West End stage
fields.trailText: Sussex revelled on the West End stage to beat Hampshire and finish top of the South Division.
fields.body:
Sussex revelled on the West End stage to beat Hampshire and finish top of the South Division. The Utrecht-born Bas Zuiderent became the first centurymaker at the new Southampton ground but his 102 not out was upstaged by his stand-in captain James Kirtley. He managed the venue's first hat-trick as Sussex won by 60 runs to earn a home quarter-final tie against Surrey, who finished group runners-up to them.

Zuiderent hit 13 fours in Sussex's total of 255 for seven and Hampshire struggled despite Robin Smith's unbeaten 77. The decisive over was the 46th, Kirtley's eighth, in which, with the last three deliveries, he bowled Alex Morris, his younger brother Zac and then had Adrian Aymes lbw with a full toss.

In the same group Middlesex were knocked out after a 71-run defeat against Essex at Chelmsford. The New Zealand captain Stephen Fleming made 73, but the visitors' total of five points from five games was not enough.

Nottinghamshire earned a home quarter-final tie against Warwickshire with a seven-wicket win against Lancashire at Trent Bridge to finish clear of the three counties that had been nipping at their heels in the North Division.

Joe Scuderi, born in Queensland but England-qualified, had hit 73 not out to nudge Lancashire to 203 for six but Nottinghamshire's stand-in captain Darren Bicknell scored 89 and Usman Afzaal an unbeaten 56 as they inflicted Lancashire's fourth defeat in five group matches.

Leicestershire were the group's fall guys as Yorkshire and Durham marched on, even though the Foxes beat Derbyshire at Grace Road. Their inferior net run-rate was damaged by Michael di Venuto's 108 from 131 balls as Derbyshire fell 21 runs short.

Northamptonshire saved face at Cardiff in the battle of the bottom two of the Midlands Division, inflicting Glamorgan's fifth defeat in five group games. The Australian Michael Hussey finished on 114 not out as the visitors coasted home with three overs in hand.

 England are likely to be without the left-arm spinner Ashley Giles for the first Test against Pakistan which begins at Lord's on May 17. He has not played since being told to rest an achilles tendon problem after the winter series in Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

Benson & Hedges Cup quarter-final draw:

Gloucestershire v Durham

Sussex v Surrey

Somerset v Yorkshire

Nottinghamshire v Warwickshire

Matches to be played on May 22 or 23.

fields.headline: Trescothick blazes familiar trail
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 262-9 Gloucestershire 154
Somerset won by 108 runs
fields.trailText: As Dickens almost said, Marcus is willing. Allowed the opportunity to play for his county in these days of the central contract, Marcus Trescothick gave his all with a match-winning performance yesterday.
fields.body:
As Dickens almost said, Marcus is willing. Allowed the opportunity to play for his county in these days of the central contract, Marcus Trescothick gives his all. He warmed up for his international summer with a match-winning performance yesterday, steering Somerset towards a home tie in the quarter-finals with 112 runs, three wickets and a slip catch.

A full crowd turned out in fine weather for what was not only a traditional bank holiday West Country derby but a crucial one in deciding the B&H pecking order, and they were well rewarded. The Gloucestershire juggernaut, which has rumbled to five one-day titles in two seasons and had been unbeaten in this competition this year, was finally checked by their neighbours, though both teams qualify for the knock-out stage.

Trescothick has made an extraordinary start to the season, scoring 147 not out, 113, 23, 16, 109 not out and now 112 in his six knocks for Somerset. Although he will never be the Fred Astaire of the crease, he has now added mental determination to the eagle eye, the Swiss-precision timing and the occasional exuberant village-green smash that will always identify him as a true cricketing son of Somerset.

He announced himself with a glorious, effortless straight drive to the Old Pavilion fence from the second ball of the day as his partner Peter Bowler only stuttered into life. Bowler was lucky to survive the second over, tickling Jon Lewis for a regulation, but spilled, slip catch to Rob Cunliffe, but he then played steadily at one end while Trescothick, at more than a run a ball, blazed at the other.

When Mike Cawdron dropped a delivery slightly short, Trescothick simply pivoted, his arms locked in perfect harmony, for a flat six to the long Coal Orchard boundary. After Bowler and the brisker Ian Blackwell had supported him to put on 194 at five an over for the first two wickets, Trescothick tried an agricultural sweep to a gentle Jeremy Snape off-break and was gone, having faced 99 balls.

Injury-hit Gloucestershire's acting captain Tim Hancock and the old campaigner Kim Barnett sprinted off in pursuit. But once wickets began to fall - not to the mighty Andy Caddick but to such support players as Jason Kerr and the occasional bowler Trescothick - a home win came inexorably closer and Somerset were through.

fields.headline: Giddins falls at the last
fields.standfirst:
Kent 265-9 Surrey 264
Kent won by one run
fields.trailText: Two runs were needed from the final over. Surrey's problem was that Ed Giddins was facing. He had helped Ben Hollioake put on 20 for the final wicket, mainly by staying off strike, but a straight one from James Golding was too much for him and he was leg before.
fields.body:
The most that Surrey sacrificed by losing their final South Division match was a home tie in the quarter-finals but for all the talent in their line-up, the masters of the four-day game are surprisingly vulnerable in the shorter form.

Two runs were needed from the final over. Surrey's problem was that Ed Giddins was facing. He had helped Ben Hollioake put on 20 for the final wicket, mainly by staying off strike, but a straight one from James Golding was too much for him and he was leg before. Frustratingly for Surrey, Hollioake was stranded on 50 not out. The ball before he had hoisted Martin McCague over square leg for six.

Hollioake hinted at the form that briefly rattled the Australians four years ago yet nothing could surpass the quality of Alec Stewart's innings. Prevented from playing by Duncan Fletcher until last Saturday, he has begun the season with scores of 59 and 92. Here, he drilled out 15 fours, sending the ball through mid-wicket like a puck across an ice rink.

His second-wicket partnership with Mark Ramprakash lasted only 53 balls but it was long enough to demonstrate what the county game lacks when the best players are unavailable. Fifty of the 59 runs scored came in boundaries as the 15-over rule was fully exploited by sweet timing rather than brute force.

In contrast, Graham Thorpe never found his touch and his off-stump was knocked back by Matthew Fleming for four.

Unable to qualify for the quarter-finals before play started, Kent took a more carefree approach to batting than is expected in the one-day game. Their batsmen even attempted to hit boundaries between the 15th and 40th overs and Paul Nixon clubbed 65 not out from 56 balls to ensure a challenging, and ultimately winning, total.
