fields.headline: Dagnall puts on late golden show
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 138-9 Warwickshire 142-9
Warwickshire won by one wicket
fields.trailText: As Worcestershire's £40,000 Flood Appeal was promoted and wickets fell frequently, it was apparent the ducks of mid-winter had given way to cricketing ducks of approaching summer.
fields.body:
Worcester's worst floods for more than half a century have long receded, and even the grubby old pavilion perked up in the sunshine as if it was no longer feeling its rheumatism quite so badly, but the after-effects will remain apparent for a while yet as batsmen repeatedly drown without trace on New Road's alluvial plains.

As Worcestershire's £40,000 Flood Appeal was promoted and wickets fell frequently, it was apparent the ducks of mid-winter had given way to cricketing ducks of approaching summer.

On such days of gripping seam and capricious bounce, Worcestershire' all-rounders, Stuart Lampitt and David Leatherdale, grow in stature. They gathered 82 of Worcestershire's 139 for nine and took five cheap wickets. When Warwickshire's ninth wicket fell at 105, a home victory seemed assured. But they had not reckoned on Charlie Dagnall.

Dagnall is an incorrigible showman. Before his startling appearance at No11 yesterday he was probably better known as Thelonius Phonq, a singer in the soul/funk band Frisco Crabbe and the Atlantic Frantics, or as a presenter on Sky TV's Shopping Channel. A handful of appearances had brought him a grand total of 16 runs and he had not batted competitively since September. Logic dictated he was a loser.

Instead, 13 overs later, after an unbroken last-wicket stand of 38 with Mohammad Sheikh, a former Worcestershire second teamer, Dagnall took his gold award and Warwickshire had stolen the quarter-final place.

There was a pulled boundary against Alamgir Sheriyar, Leatherdale was cut, Lampitt driven, and Sheikh's composure avoided the obligatory run-out as Leatherdale pounced at short extra. The winning hit was a stylish late cut off Leatherdale. Dagnall might well be unique in winning an English cup-tie with a top score at No11.

His new-ball spell had demanded attention, too, as he hit the stumps of both Graeme Hick, who played on, and Philip Weston. Dagnall's shoulder-length, dyed blond hair and effervescence revived memories of a former Warwickshire all-rounder, Paul Smith, although Dagnall's bowling action is much smoother.

Worcestershire were 62 for six before Leatherdale and Lampitt rallied.

"Maybe this is the start of a new approach - don't bat for seven months and then go out to have a go," he said. It's quite a day. I felt like ringing my dad when I got Graeme Hick out."

But Dagnall's long hair will soon be no more - Bob Woolmer, Warwickshire's coach, has told him to get it cut. "I might have a bob," he mused. "They're in at the moment." More to the point, so was Charlie - right to the end.

fields.headline: Terra Lycos cuts jobs
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Spanish internet service provider Terra Lycos is slashing its workforce by 15%, writes Dan Milmo.

Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
The Spanish internet service provider, Terra Lycos, is slashing its workforce by 15% in a bid to stem losses.

The world's third largest ISP will cut over 500 employees from its 3,352-strong workforce after a slowdown in web advertising revenue.

Terra made the announcement alongside narrower-than-expected first quarter losses of £47m, which pushed its shares up by 6% on the Madrid stock exchange.

Although analysts praised the loss, which came before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization (LBITDA), they pointed out that gross profits had fallen by 10%.

"The LBITDA losses are the key figure, and they are good, but the gross profits are disappointing," said Bob Kommers, analyst at ABN Amro.

"At first the results look quite good, but if you dig deeper they are not very strong, so it's mixed feelings."

Analysts also expect Terra Lycos to abandon its wildly optimistic prediction that it would earn £630m this year. They expect £475m to be a more realistic figure.

The company was formed when Spanish internet firm Terra Networks bought its US rival, Lycos, for £3.2bn last year, creating an ISP with a presence in 42 countries.

But the Spanish outfit, which has 7m subscribers, has a long way to go before it can break into the top two of America Online or Microsoft, and will have to make acquisitions.

It remains to be seen if the company's controlling shareholder, the Telefonica phone group, will sanction a spending spree in the current market conditions.

Furthermore, the Terra Lycos management board is hardly in a position to bed down new acquisitions, following the resignation of three senior executives over the past 12 months.

webTitle: BBC mag found at George's home

fields.headline: BBC magazine found at George's home
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Two copies of Ariel featuring full-face pictures of Jill Dando on the front page were found at the murder suspect's flat.
08.05.2001: Dando cuttings found in flat of accused
08.05.2001: 'Compelling evidence' of George's guilt
fields.body:
Two copies of the BBC in-house magazine, Ariel, showing a full-face picture of Jill Dando on the front page, were found at the flat of the man on trial for the presenter's murder.

Barry George allegedly said he had picked up a second copy for a family who lived across the road from his home.

In his last interview, he allegedly denied he had a "great" interest in the death of Ms Dando.

The court heard today that Mr George told police he had never seen Ms Dando in the flesh. He told denied he knew the location of Gowan Avenue - the street where she lived.

He allegedly said he could not remember telling one woman of his dislike of the BBC or its treatment of Freddie Mercury. He confirmed he was not Mr Mercury's cousin.

"He said he had no problem with Jill Dando because she was a journalist or because she worked for the BBC," said Orlando Pownall, the barrister for the prosecution.

"He maintained that, before her death, he would not have been able to recognise her.

"From other photographs developed from Mr George's rolls of film - found at his flat in Crookham Road - he was shown a number taken of the television and of female presenters. He said he could not recall having taken them," he added.

Police questioned Mr George about his visit on April 28 to the Hammersmith and Fulham Action for Disability centre - where prosecution allege he had hoped to establish an alibi.

"He sought to explain this visit on the basis he wanted to account for his movements because people had said he was similar in appearance to the photofit picture that had been released," said Mr Pownall.

"As you know, the E fit was not released until two days later - April 30."

Asked if he had seen anything unusual on the day of the murder, Mr George allegedly said he had seen a four-wheel drive vehicle go down a dead-end road close to Gowan Avenue that evening and claimed the driver looked suspicious.

He had reported his concerns to a uniformed officer manning the cordons round Ms Dando's home, which the officer noted.

"None of the officers concerned has a note of this exchange," said Mr Pownall.

Mr George allegedly told police he collected military surplus, particularly items relating to the Special Air Service.

"He said more than 10 years ago he had been a member of a gun club - where he had fired rifles and pistols belonging to the club - according to the prosecution in the trial," said Mr Pownall.

But he denied owning, handling or firing a Browning 9mm replica gun - a type that the prosecution suggested might have been modified for use in shooting Ms Dando.

An advert for the sale of guns was shown to him from Exchange and Mart magazine.

Mr George denied buying a gun from this, another magazine or from any of the military surplus shops he visited, said Mr Pownall.

"Shown a photograph of a man wearing a respirator and holding a pistol, he denied it was him and said he did not recognise the gun - a further lie," added Mr Pownall.

"It was only when he was told the photograph had been developed from a film recovered from his flat in Crookham Road that he said the gun had been a replica and it may, in fact, have been him photographed holding it.

"Eventually, Mr George agreed he had, in fact, owned a replica gun but denied he was responsible for the alteration that exposed the spring mechanism," said Mr Pownall.

webTitle: Liberal Democrats on regeneration: sorting out the funding maze

fields.headline: Sorting out the funding maze
fields.standfirst: The Liberal Democrats propose a single grants scheme, as well as new measures to protect greefield sites
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats propose a single grants scheme, as well as new measures to protect greefield sites.
fields.body:
 Single regeneration grants scheme to encompass all funding.

 Protect greenfield sites and encourage urban regeneration by building more partnerships between local authorities and private enterprise.

 Introduce a greenfield development tax to encourage developers to look for brownfield sites before building in the countryside.

 The restoration and reuse of existing buildings encouraged rather than building on new land.

 Local councils will be able to replace the uniform business rate with a system based on the value of each site (site value rating) so that improvements of sites are not financially penalised.

 At local community level, promote local exchange trading schemes, community banking, time banks, mutual volunteering and credit unions.

 Committed to providing free personal care for all elderly people by implementing the Sutherland report on long term care in full.

 Free nursery places for all three and four-year-olds.

 Pensions to be linked with average earnings.

 Condemns New Deal as a flop. Wants Scotland's New Deal budget to be spent on housing, health care, transport and "real" jobs.

 In favour of specialised courts for drugs and domestic violence offenders.

webTitle: Conservatives on the voluntary sector: new opportunities for charities to deliver services

fields.headline: New opportunities for charities to deliver services
fields.standfirst: The voluntary sector is being offered a voice at the highest level of government as well as an opportunity to provide more public services
fields.trailText: The voluntary sector is being offered a voice at the highest level of government as well as an opportunity to provide more public services.
fields.body:
 William Hague set out his agenda for the voluntary sector at NCVO's annual conference in February.

 He talked of "a principled partnership" that will give the voluntary sector a voice at the top of government. It will also revolutionise the process of applying for grants, give charities new opportunities to run schools and regenerate disadvantaged communities.

 To achieve this he plans to establish an Office of Civil Society reporting to a cabinet minister. The office will be staffed by charities, faith communities and family groups.

The office will oversee the following promises:

 A simple form for funding applications across all government departments.

 A one stop website to record basic information about all public sector grant opportunities

 Coordinating the investment in the infrastructure of the voluntary sector to encourage greater charity involvement in public services.

 Training for civil servants to improve their understanding of voluntary groups including specific efforts to encourage more engagement with faith communities.

 Review of the work of the sector and government, for example progress made on the Compact - the concordat between the two.

 Double the percentage of development expenditure that goes through NGOs.

 Set up a website and call centre to match the needs of the developing world with willing helpers in Britain.

 Send 5,000 young people to serve abroad each year.

 Without giving details, Mr Hague also promised to "create a tax system and a culture of volunteering that encourages generosity" and to "end discrimination against faith communities".

fields.trailText: The Conservatives are pledging to sweep away many of Labour's local government reforms.

 Create "free councils". Local councils that can demonstrate proven levels of democratic participation, financial efficiency and service delivery will be able to apply for greater freedom from central government controls.

 Abolish the council role in frontline education, creating so-called "free-schools" with wide-ranging powers to run their own affairs.

fields.standfirst: Recognising and rewarding the work of dedicated volunteers will boost the number of recruits, believe the Liberal Democrats
fields.trailText: Recognising and rewarding the work of dedicated volunteers will boost the number of recruits, believe the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
Spokesman on voluntary sector, Bob Russell MP, says there needs to be greater recognition of the work of volunteers.

In order to achieve this, he thinks consideration should be given to the following:

 Paying volunteers expenses
 Tax breaks for people who regularly volunteer

"We need to restore the concept of society and encourage more people to volunteer, especially those who might be put off because they are financially strapped. In the same way that people are offered tax incentives to give money, they could receive a tax allowance for giving time."

Mr Russell sees the benefits of volunteering spreading across society: "Fewer young people would drift into anti-social ways in the first place, because, with more volunteers running clubs and other organisations, there would be more outlets enabling them to occupy their time and energies productively."

fields.headline: Official: June 7 polling day
fields.trailText: Tony Blair this afternoon announced that the general election will be held on June 7.
fields.body:
Tony Blair this afternoon announced that the general election will be held on June 7.

The month-long election campaign finally got under way today when the prime minister went to Buckingham Palace to ask the Queen to rubber-stamp his decision and dissolve parliament.

Mr Blair's audience with the Queen took place in the audience room on the first floor of the palace and lasted for 15 minutes.

Following a tour of the St Saviour's & St Olave's Church of England Girls secondary school in Southwark, south London, Mr Blair confirmed that the country will go to the polls on June 7, breaking with the recent tradition of calling the election outside 10 Downing Street.

His choice of venue at which to make the announcement and the presence of the education secretary, David Blunkett, reflects Mr Blair's determination to highlight the government's record on education.

The dissolution of parliament is expected to follow on Friday or Monday and will clear the way for a month-long election campaign.

At the height of the foot and mouth crisis in April, Mr Blair postponed the local elections from May 3, which was also believed to be his preferred date for a general election. The move meant that Labour now fights an election campaign with the disease largely under control and off the front pages. The election announcement coincided with the allocation of an extra £15m to farmers hit by foot and mouth.

At an emergency cabinet meeting yesterday, Mr Blair warned ministers not to expect an easy election victory despite opinion polls that show Labour far in the lead. He said that Labour has not accomplished much of what it promised, particularly in the areas of health care and education, and that it could expect to be punished for those shortcomings during the campaign. The Tory leader, William Hague, began campaigning in Watford today in advance of Mr Blair's expected announcement. He repeated his pledge to lower taxes and roll back the frontiers of the state.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, had also toured a south London school this morning, and he used the occasion to announce that education would be at the heart of his party's campaign.

Last night Liberal Democrat MP Menzies Campbell said on behalf of his party: "People are disappointed with Labour and continue to distrust the Conservatives, so this election will provide an opportunity for real change in Britain.

"The message is clear. We need more investment, more quickly in services such as health, education and a better deal for pensioners. The more seats the Liberal Democrats win, and the more votes we get, the more of these aims we will achieve."

Last night Liberal Democrat MP Menzies Campbell said on behalf of his party: "People are disappointed with Labour and continue to distrust the Conservatives, so this election will provide an opportunity for real change in Britain. "The message is clear. We need more investment, more quickly in services such as health, education and a better deal for pensioners. The more seats the Liberal Democrats win, and the more votes we get, the more of these aims we will achieve."

webTitle: Labour on the voluntary sector: encouraging people to give their time and money

fields.headline: Encouraging people to give their time and money
fields.standfirst: In a second term, Labour would build on its moves to promote volunteering
fields.trailText: In a second term, Labour would build on its moves to promote volunteering.
fields.body:
 Paul Boateng, minister with responsibility for the voluntary sector, said in a recent speech in the House of Commons that the government recognises the need to encourage giving, and to create a tax framework for the voluntary sector that supports their efforts and the contribution that they make to society. "We must explore innovative, flexible ways of enabling people to do that: the internet is one; utilising new technology is another."

 Labour also wants to encourage older people to volunteer and has launched an older volunteer initiative. On January 11, the government announced that a group of experts, led by Lady Greengross, is to develop ideas and advise the government on how to enable more over-50s to become active in their own communities.

 Mr Boateng also said: "It is important for local government to consider the voluntary sector as a genuinely equal partner. To a certain extent, central government are sometimes slightly ahead of local government in that regard - some local authorities still harbour suspicion of the voluntary sector that is quite unfounded. I hope that the existence and development of local compacts will help to overcome that."

Promises for funding of volunteers made by Labour:

 A funding package of £300m was announced on January 11 as part of Labour's neighbourhood renewal initiative.

 A further £120m of new funding for volunteering opportunities in the public sector over the next three years, was pledged by Lord Falconer and Paul Boateng in January.

 £450m that will be distributed to combat poverty among children and young people through the Children's Fund

 The Department for Culture, Media and Sport volunteering programme will run from 2002 to 2004, with £4m of Exchequer funding and £3m from the active community unit. In each of its two years, it will include opportunities for 4,500 older volunteers to act as mentors and coaches to the main core of young 14 to 19-year-old volunteers.

 In February, education and employment secretary David Blunkett announced a tripling over the next three years - to £3m - in the size of the government's "community champions" fund. This initiative has so far helped more than 700 individuals and community groups to build their skills and encourage others to get involved in regeneration activity.

The expanded fund should bring a greater focus on marginalised groups such as older volunteers and people with disabilities, the minister said. "We need local people to get fully involved in driving change forward if we are to see real improvements in our deprived communities."

fields.headline: Emap ready to turn on Heat TV
fields.trailText: 3pm: Emap's has confirmed plans to turn celebrity magazine Heat into a TV show, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap's beleaguered chief executive, Kevin Hand, has confirmed that the company already has well-developed plans to turn its successful celebrity magazine Heat into a TV show.

Speaking at the Periodical Publishers Association's annual conference, Mr Hand said that Heat "would be a mass-market TV service within the next 12 months".

Heat, which boosted its circulation by nearly 140% at the last ABCs, is considered as one of Emap's greatest success stories and ripe for exploitation as a TV format.

But celebrity TV - although compelling to both viewers and advertisers in theory - has proved difficult to pull off.

Last year ITV showed a masthead version of celebrity magazine OK!, fronted by GMTV's Fiona Phillips.

However, a second series was never commissioned after a dispute between ITV chiefs and OK!'s publisher, Richard Desmond.

Emap executives have been poring over the strategy for some time and believe they have the in-house knowledge to make a success of Heat TV.

Earlier in the year, Emap appointed the former Empire publishing director, Steve Buckley, to focus on developing masthead TV brand spin-offs for some of Emap Elan's most successful magazines.

And Emap Elan has been working with the independent Picture Production Company on plans.

The move mirrors a similar strategy at Emap Performance, where magazines including Q, Kerrang! and Smash Hits have already been turned into 24-hour live TV channels.

fields.headline: Government forces shell rebel village
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian government forces today unleashed a fierce assault on a village held by ethnic Albanian rebels.
fields.body:
Macedonian government forces today unleashed a fierce assault on a village held by ethnic Albanian rebels.

Helicopter gunships, heavy artillery and machine guns pounded Vaksince in an attempt to destroy NLA sniper nests and suspected guerilla positions on the outskirts of the village.

At the peak of the attack, one shell was fired every 30 seconds. There was no immediate word on civilian casualties, or indication that the rebels were returning fire.

But an NLA leader, who only goes by the name Commander Hoxha, said that the rebels had not withdrawn, as the Macedonian authorities have claimed.

He renewed the rebels' call for talks with the government which, he said, was "in deep crisis" because of widespread support for the NLA.

The government refuses to negotiate directly with the rebels, but has said that it is prepared to hold talks over constitutional reform with members of ethnic Albanian political parties.

Macedonia's prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, has invited the two main opposition parties - one of them ethnic Albanian - to form a coalition government for national unity.

Their inclusion marks an attempt to end the fighting between the government troops and the rebels, who say they are fighting for greater rights and recognition for the country's minority ethnic Albanians.

The UN estimates that 6,000 ethnic Albanians have fled from Macedonia to Kosovo since February. Under increasing pressure from the EU and Nato, the government backed away yesterday from its push to declare a state of war.

Western officials believed such a move could push more ethnic Albanians to support the rebels and provoke a civil war.

fields.headline: NatMags chief criticises 'misguided' rivals
fields.trailText: 3pm: Terry Mansfield has accused publishers of older women's magazines of ignoring their readers' needs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Terry Mansfield, the National Magazine Company's managing director, has accused publishing houses of focusing on "demographics" not "needs" in their bid to grab hold of the lucrative market for older women's magazines

Speaking at the Periodical Publishers Association's annual conference, Mr Mansfield, who has headed NatMags since 1982, said he had witnessed many "misguided" attempts at launching magazines for older women.

In what was clearly a dig at his rivals - particularly Emap, IPC, BBC Worldwide and H Bauer - Mr Mansfield said most recent launches in this sector were "aimed at the advertising sales communities, which are driven by demographics".

Instead, he said, publishers should be thinking more about the needs of readers in this "uncomfortable demographic".

His remarks come just weeks after IPC folded its long-running woman's weekly, Woman's Realm, and announced its plans for a title called Your Life.

IPC's move reflects its belief women over the age of 40 no longer want to be treated as part of a different generation.

But Mr Mansfield said there was a danger that publishers were targeting a "demographic condition" rather than real readers.

In a wide-ranging speech on the future of the magazine industry, Mr Mansfield said publishers needed to remember a slight downturn in advertising was "inevitable".

Brand extension and diversification into new areas of business would be "paramount", he added.

IPC's move reflects its belief women over the age of 40 no longer want to be treated as part of a different generation. But Mr Mansfield said there was a danger that publishers were targeting a "demographic condition" rather than real readers. In a wide-ranging speech on the future of the magazine industry, Mr Mansfield said publishers needed to remember a slight downturn in advertising was "inevitable". Brand extension and diversification into new areas of business would be "paramount", he added.

webTitle: When a campaign is not a campaign

fields.headline: When a campaign is not a campaign
fields.standfirst:
Q. When is a campaign not a campaign?
A. When a charity is "promoting a recommendation".
fields.trailText: May 8 is International Red Cross day but the organisation cannot launch campaigns, instead it must 'promote a recommendation'. Louise Tickle reports.
fields.body:
Today is International Red Cross Day and the organisation has launched a report suggesting that with 3,500 people dying every year on our roads there is an extremely good case to be made for all learner drivers having to gain a first aid qualification before being awarded their licence.

With more than 37m licence holders in the UK this sounds like an excellent idea. The pool of people with first aid skills would be increased and the survival chances of accident victims who would otherwise die could be greatly enhanced. Well worth campaigning for, one might think.

The Red Cross is calling on the government to legislate for a first aid qualification to be a requirement before learner drivers get their hot, sticky paws on that treasured license to roam the country's highways and byways. Yet, no matter how sensible this proposal might be, the Red Cross can't actually campaign for it. But if it is not campaigning, what exactly is it doing?

My conversation to find out more went a bit like this - the following isn't verbatim, but it gives the general idea.

Me : "So, this campaign to get the government to make it compulsory for all learner drivers to get a first aid qualification before getting their licence... "

Red Cross: "Oh no, it's not a campaign."

Me: "But your report here asks for legislation for all learner drivers to be able to do simple first aid before they're issued with a licence..."

RC "Mmm, yes, but we're not campaigning for it."

Me: "Oh, um, right. But you are launching this report on International Red Cross Day to highlight how many people die on the roads and that all learner drivers need to learn first aid skills before..."

RC: "Yes, we are saying that we'd like the government to legislate for that, but we're definitely not campaigning for it."

Me: "Well, what are you doing if you're not campaigning but you are asking the government to introduce new legislative measures?"

RC (Very firmly): "We're recommending"

This might seem like rather a piffling matter of semantics, but for the Red Cross, the words that are chosen to describe its recommendations to government are of crucial importance. Because of its status under the Geneva Convention the organisation must remain neutral and impartial - which in practice means no campaigning.

The red cross emblem is protected by the Geneva Convention, giving Red Cross workers vital protection in trouble spots. Each national Red Cross society has a specially constituted role as an auxiliary to the national government of the country where it works. Adherence to the neutral and impartial role is seen as vital to the organisation's effectiveness in relieving suffering in areas of conflict.

Interestingly, this can create a dilemma when the organisation works on issues that are without any doubt directly within its remit of caring for people in crisis. Four years ago, the Red Cross hosted princess Diana's controversial visit to Angola to raise awareness of the crusade for the global abolition of landmines.

The organisation now says that its role in the landmines issue was not explicitly a campaign - the use of landmines contravened international humanitarian law, which is the Red Cross's remit to uphold.

However, as a high profile member of the international coalition demanding that governments sign the Ottawa Convention banning landmines, the Red Cross has clearly had to tread carefully in managing perception of how its involvement is construed.

It's a sensitive issue, and in a world where non-governmental organisations and charities are battling hard to raise awareness of hundreds of issues, treading the fine line between running a campaign and promoting a recommendation is clearly a job for media-savvy etymological experts.

fields.headline: Absolut loses its bottle
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Absolut Vodka is experimenting with advertising that omits the famous image of its vodka bottle, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Absolut Vodka is experimenting with advertising that leaves out its famous vodka bottle image.

The minimalist Absolut bottle has featured in the brand's advertising for 21 years but, although the device will not disappear, the company is looking at new ways of presenting the brand.

An eight-page advertising insert to appear in Time later this month features photographs of Swedish landscapes shot by the legendary fashion photographer, Helmut Newton.

The bottle reference appears on only one page of the insert.

Absolut's vice president of marketing, Eva Kemper-Forsberg, said although the project was a one-off collaboration with Newton, the brand was considering similar projects.

Linking up with artists or fashion designers to produce similar advertising was a possibility, said Ms Kemper-Forsberg, who denied consumers were tired of the vodka bottle concept

"We believe in the strategy of the bottle image within ads - and we can do new things with it to surprise our audience - but we will be experimenting even more and the Newton insert is a good example of that," said Ms Kemper-Forsberg.

The vodka brand, owned by Vin & Spirit, has a long-term relationship with the advertising agency, TBWA Chiat Day.

Related stories

fields.headline: Grand vision for a 'world city'
fields.standfirst: London deputy-mayor Nicky Gavron's vision for London's long-term future takes a crucial step forward today with publication of a GLA consultation document
fields.trailText: London deputy-mayor Nicky Gavron's vision for London's long-term future takes a crucial step forward today with publication of a GLA consultation document. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Nicky Gavron has a vision of what London will look like in 20 years' time: "It's a city where people have choices, where people want to live and can live. A city where everyone wants to live, has the choices they want and can feel safe."

From the mouth of some politicians, such a statement would sound like a pseudo-utopian platitude. But Ms Gavron, the deputy-mayor of London, is working on a plan to make it happen. In legal terms, it's called the spatial development strategy (SDS), and Ms Gavron has waited years for the chance to help put it together.

This is partly because Ms Gavron has seen London's planning at its worst. From the end of the second world war until the 1970s there was a policy of dispersing the capital's population and businesses to new and expanding towns beyond the green belt. The capital's population dipped to 6.8m in 1983 before starting to rise again, down from more than 8m in 1945.

The policy was abandoned as housing redevelopment programmes were wound up and people realised that London was losing skills and dynamic companies, eroding its potential for prosperity. With no city-wide strategic body available after the abolition of the Greater London Council (GLC), the capital was left to boom without a clear vision behind its development.

Enter Nicky Gavron as Labour leader and chair of the London planning advisory committee, a poor replacement for the GLC's elected strategic control which the deputy-mayor herself admits had "rubber teeth". She came upon the scene in time to witness the capital's failure to match living standards, housing, transport and office stock to the pace of growth in both the economy and population.

Ms Gavron now has a decade of planning experience in London, and is mayor Ken Livingstone's cabinet adviser on planning. Consequently, she has played a vital role in forging the ideas that will inform the SDS.

Cynics say that, despite her title, Ms Gavron has done little since becoming the mayor's deputy. Mr Livingstone is said to call her "my lovely lady mayoress", and she seemed to spend the Greater London authority's early days glad-handing dignitaries instead of wielding the real power she wanted.

Today, however, the world gets to see what she has really been up to for the last year. The Greater London authority is unveiling the first consultation document for the SDS, or the London plan as it has wisely been renamed.

The final version, probably published next year, will essentially be a planning document, setting out what London should look like in 15-20 years' time by spelling out in broad terms how land should be used and which areas should be candidates for change. It will also provide guidance for the London boroughs on their planning work.

It also brings in most aspects of mayor Livingstone's work - the new developments will need decent transport links, and can contribute heavily to regeneration if they are intelligently guided. In addition, the mayor is legally bound to take into account equal opportunites and the health of Londoners when preparing the strategy.

Ms Gavron is highly enthusiastic about this "uber-plan". She has become an encyclopaedic master of its detail and can talk about it at length. This seems to spring from a heartfelt desire to ensure the strategy is fully understood by the press and the public, despite the fact that many of the consultation paper's policy directions are entirely uncontroversial.

Take, for example, the mayor's fundamental premise, that sustainable development - accepting massive growth but tackling it in a socially and environmentally responsible manner - is the only way forward for the capital. The consultation paper, entitled Towards the London Plan, adds: "This is in line with government policy". The only alternative is drastically to rein in growth through a return to dispersal, a move that would almost certainly diminish London's status as a "world city".

The Americans, too, have bought into the idea. Ms Gavron tells a story about a recent trip to New York, during which an official explained that "sustainable development" was a concept the city's voters wouldn't buy. So the politicians renamed it "smart growth".

But the broader vision for London is a more exciting one. As far as regeneration goes, says Ms Gavron, "the focus will be eastwards". The Thames Gateway, described in today's document as "the largest regeneration opportunity in London", offers 10 square kilometres of development land next to one of the capital's most deprived areas.

Towards the London Plan promises to ensure the area makes a major contribution towards the minimum 23,000 new homes a year the mayor wants to see built. It also pledges to set a target for increasing the proportion of affordable housing development in the capital. Public transport will be improved to support the new developments, promises Mr Livingstone, as will standards of building design.

The Lee and Wandle valleys, and the so-called "Western wedge", stretching from Paddington to Heathrow, are also promised their own development plans to help them tackle deprivation.

Throughout the rest of London, the capital's 200 major town centres and 1,500 neighbourhood centres can all look forward to support. The mayor promises to promote active town centre management and support a presumption against out-of-town retail and leisure developments.

Intriguingly, Towards a London Plan also promises that large, underused brownfield sites will be turned into "urban villages", offering new, high-density, mixed-tenure housing alongside shops, offices and perhaps even schools. The GLA is currently working with its partners to develop and test the idea.

The final plan will be significantly long-term, and it is unlikely that Mr Livingstone or Ms Gavron will still be in power to see their vision realised. Ms Gavron is aware that all this work could be undone the second someone takes the mayoral mantle from Ken Livingstone, but insists this plan is the right course of action: "People are really willing politicians to take the long-term view. It must be visionary, but then it's about the paces - what can we do by 2004, what can we do by 2008?"

The final London plan will have to answer these difficult questions, about how and when the mayor and his advisers intend to deliver on their laudable goals. But if Mr Livingstone and his advisers get it right, we really might see Ms Gavron's vision for London become a reality.

webTitle: Shell loses fight for US gas producer

fields.headline: Shell loses fight for US gas producer
fields.standfirst: Barret Resources reveals preference for domestic rival
fields.trailText: Royal Dutch Shell, the Anglo-Dutch oil group, yesterday dropped its hostile $2bn bid for Barrett Resources after the US oil company plumped for another suitor.
fields.body:
Royal Dutch Shell, the Anglo-Dutch oil group, yesterday dropped its hostile $2bn bid for Barrett Resources after the US oil company plumped for another suitor.

Barrett scuppered Shell's ambitions to expand in the US natural gas market yesterday after it agreed to a rival bid from Williams Companies, a US energy pipeline company. The winning cash-and-shares bid valued Barrett at $2.45bn when it was announced yesterday morning. A subsequent fall in the Williams' share price saw the value of the bid decline by about $100m.

Shell had underlined its keenness to acquire Barrett recently by increasing its bid from $55 to $60 a share, adding that it was "prepared to negotiate all terms" as it increased its bid from $55-a-share to $60.

But there was a strong hint later that Shell was unwilling to get involved in a bidding war over Barrett. Chairman Sir Mark Moody- Stuart said last Thursday that the company would not "pursue targets purely in the interests of making a deal."

Yesterday, the world's second-largest oil group said that it was not prepared to overpay for Denver-based Barrett. Walter van de Vijver, the head of Shell Exploration and Production, said that the target "would have been an excellent fit for all involved, but only at the right price".

"We have no intention of abandoning our economic discipline and pursuing an acquisition at price levels that cease to add value for our shareholders just for the sake of making a deal," he added.

Never-the-less the decision to drop the bid for Barrett marks a further setback for Shell. It had earlier seen an effort to convert its minority stake in Woodside Petroleum in Australia into a controlling interest blocked by the Aus tralian government.

Shell ranks third in natural gas production in the US behind rivals BP and Exxon Mobil. It is expected to slip even further after Chevron completes its acquisition of Texaco later this year.

Barrett's chief attraction is a natural gas field in the Wind River Basin of the Rocky Mountains, an area which is becoming valuable to gas producers because of declining production in other markets. But it also owns gas production and exploration sites in the Gulf of Mexico and Peru.

Steven Malcolm, president of Williams Energy Services, described Barrett and its 2.1 trillion cubic feet of gas reserves as an "ideal fit" for the Oaklahoma-based company. The bid adds a production capacity to Williams's existing distribution and trading operation.

Keith Bailey, chairman and chief executive of Williams, said in a conference call to analysts yesterday that "one of the real attractions of Barrett is the significant inventory."

Wall Street analysts welcomed the strategic rationale for the bid but worried about the price - $73-a-share in cash and the rest in Williams shares at a fixed ratio of 1.767 per Barrett share. Shares in Barrett rose more than 2 per cent yesterday to $68.95.

At yesterday's opening price, the deal values Barrett at 51 per cent more than its share price before Shell made its offer in March. Williams will also assume about $300m in debt.

Shares in Williams fell almost 9 per cent after announcing the deal to just over $38 yesterday. The company, which operates a coast-to-coast pipeline, is involved in energy trading and marketing as well as exploration, production and retail sales.

The oil sector was particularly busy yesterday, a symptom of the higher prices and more favourable regulatory framework in the industry. Valero Energy also announced a $4bn cash-and-share deal for US rival, Ultramar Diamond Shamrock yesterday. Valero would rank second only to Exxon Mobil, the world's largest oil group, in terms of US refining capacity after the proposed merger.

webTitle: Tories hope for repeat of history

fields.headline: Tories hope for repeat of history
fields.standfirst: While William Hague protests that the Tories can win the election, few in his own party believe him. Alan Travis explains why
fields.trailText: While William Hague protests that the Tories can win the election, few in his own party believe him. Alan Travis explains why.
fields.body:
It is William Hague's job to remain 100% loyal to the idea that the Conservatives can pull off a shock election victory.

But even within the Conservative central office "war room" they know in their hearts that the only worthwhile speculation is over the scale of their coming defeat.

Some are even prepared to gamble that it will prove so crushing that Mr Hague finds himself the shortest lived Tory party leader since Harold Wilson sent Sir Alec Douglas-Home back to spend more time on his beloved grouse moors in 1964.

Mr Hague may dream of a repeat of the Tories surprise 1970 general election victory when virtually all the opinion polls had also agreed that, as now, a relatively successful Labour government would be returned to office with a comfortable majority.

In May 1970 Mr Wilson called an election for that June on the basis of opinion polls which gave him a 7-point poll lead over the Conservatives. Six weeks later Ted Heath pulled off a famous victory by turning that 7-point deficit in the polls into a 3-point lead in the popular vote to give him a Commons majority of 30.

What chance is there a repeat of that shock scenario?

Mr Wilson's government may have been successful but it was deeply unpopular compared with New Labour. He lost his opinion poll lead within a year of the 1966 election and his claim that Labour was now the "natural party of government" was repeatedly battered by byelection losses and Gallup polls showing the Tories lead averaging 16 points throughout 1968 and 1969.

So what does the long term four year trend in the polls tell us about what is likely to happen in this general election? First it is well to remember what the historic 1997 landslide result actually was.

Labour won by a margin of 13 points with 44% of the vote compared with the Tories 31%. The Liberal Democrats took 17% of the vote.

Some 31m people voted on a turnout of 71% of the registered electors. It was enough to give Tony Blair the 179-seat majority he needed to form the first Labour government in Britain for 18 years.

Since then Labour has registered unprecedented opinion poll leads for a governing party. The Guardian/ICM poll recorded an average Labour lead of 19 points in 1998; of 18 points in 1999; and an average of 9 points last year.

The only blip has proved to be last September when the briefly lived popular revolt over petrol briefly puts the Tories ahead by a nose.

The last four years have seen the Conservative party floundering in the immediate aftermath of the Blair victory, hitting rock bottom at 23% in October 1997 before recovering a measure of dignity in early 1998 when it clawed its way back to about 30% in the polls. Here it stayed for most of 1998 and 1999 during two years of "flatlining".

Last summer saw a modest advance for Mr Hague as Tony Blair admitted in a leaked memo that the government was widely perceived to be "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts" on key issues such as crime and asylum seekers.

The Tory share of the vote went up to the 34/35% level on the Guardian/ICM poll where it has remained ever since.

If the Liberal Democrats share of the vote stays at the 16/17 point level it has remained for nearly the whole of the last parliament, it can be expected that a nine point lead for Labour could still translate into a 140 seat plus majority for Tony Blair.

Meanwhile, Mr Hague must hope that he can squeeze the current 15 point Labour lead during the campaign and if he is to survive as Conservative party leader then he must cut Labour's majority to less than below 100 seats.

In crude terms that goal will mean cutting Labour's lead to below 5 points. A rough guide is that for every point over 5% he cuts Labour's lead the Tories gain about 10 seats.

Once Labour's lead drops below five points many more seats become marginal and the Tories can gain 20-30 seats for every extra one point share of the popular vote.

In part whether Mr Hague survives will depend on the turnout. Recent polling evidence has supported the academic argument that the greater reluctance of core Labour voters to get to the polling booths is strongest in its heartland seats where it already has piled up big majorities.

As an ICM/News of the World poll recently showed, Labour's vote in 139 key marginal seats has actually gone up by 3.9% since May 1997 and in the same seats the Tories have only made a gain of 0.9%.

The implication is clearly that Mr Blair could win big again on June 7 with a majority of more than 100 even if the turnout falls to its lowest level for 50 years. In fact it is possible that the bigger the turnout, the bigger the Labour majority.

The scale of tactical voting in individual seats is expected to be less developed than in 1997 but for many voters it seems the prospect of a Hague government is even less of an attraction than John Major's proved to be in 1997.

Perhaps for Mr Hague the most apt comparison is not 1970 but Mrs Thatcher's 1987 general election victory. Then the governing party was re-elected on 42% of the vote with the main opposition party taking 31%.

Mrs Thatcher's majority was cut to 101, a net loss of 21 seats. Add around 40 to reflect Tony Blair's higher first term majority and the figures don't look too far out of line with what the polls have been telling us for the past four years.

The Labour party gave Neil Kinnock the benefit of the doubt in the aftermath of their 1987 general election defeat - it would not be too surprising if the Conservatives were to do the same with William Hague.

webTitle: Labour defends EU move on national powers

fields.headline: Labour defends EU move on national powers
fields.standfirst:
Cook insists socialist parties' declaration on parliaments is in line with UK stance

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today take over responsibility for implementing a potentially controversial pledge to redefine the powers of Westminster and other European national parliaments.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today take over responsibility for implementing a potentially controversial pledge to redefine the powers of Westminster and other European national parliaments.

Mr Cook is to be chosen as president of a social democrats' umbrella group, the Party of European Socialists, at a congress in Berlin.

In a declaration of agreed principles, of which the final draft was circulating last night, member parties call for a "new definition of the role of national parliaments in the building of Europe while strengthening the European parliament".

Mr Cook said he had no difficulty with the wording, arguing that it was consistent with Tony Blair's proposal last November of a second chamber for the European parliament to made up of members chosen in national legislatures.

"I welcome the fact that the party of European socialists (PES) also recognises that we should find a place for the national parliaments in the architecture of Europe," he added.

But in a febrile pre-campaign atmosphere, the passage was likely to be seized on by Labour's opponents as evidence that the party is ready to compromise on the sovereignty of Westminster.

The Tories argued last night that comment yesterday by the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder's that the British government should "work in Europe for Europe" were highly significant. The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, claimed they meant that "for the first time a senior European politician has stated what Labour dare not admit: that Tony Blair wants to take Britain into an EU superstate.

"Shortly, Tony Blair will fire the starting gun on the general election, to be held on June 7. Britain has a real choice - to remain an independent, self-governing nation or to continue down the path towards a European superstate. Labour can no longer pretend that that is not their agenda, after today's admission by Mr Schröder."

Mr Cook's fellow delegates stressed that the wording of the European socialists' declaration was ambiguous but did not necessarily offer backing for the British proposal. "It could mean that. This wording leaves the question open," said Jacques Poos, the former Luxembourg foreign minister.

Mr Cook's election to the presidency of the PES will put him in a position to exert considerable influence over the direction of the debate on the European Union's future in a crucial phase. Over the next two and a half years, the EU will be preparing for a conference or convention in 2004 on its future structure.

The question of the EU's fu ture was given added urgency last week when the German chancellor launched an unapologetically federalist plan which also envisaged a second chamber, but one formed by the council of ministers.

The effect would be to turn ministers and heads of government into Euro-senators and the chancellor's plan has met with deep misgivings in London and several other EU capitals. After it was presented, Mr Blair's aides first confirmed, then announced the cancellation of his attendance at the left's summit in Berlin.

The Schröder blueprint was yesterday unanimously adopted by the party board of his ruling Social Democratic party, and the chancellor used the congress to press German claims to leadership in Europe.

Welcoming delegates, he declared that European integration was essential to the identity of today's Germany.

Mr Schröder added: "German Social Democrats will take upon themselves the role of being the party of European integration".

But his, and their, problem are that few other countries are generating the same degree of enthusiasm for a quasi-federal Europe, and deep divisions remain, even among political allies, on questions of fundamental principle.

webTitle: Hague confident of moving into No 10

fields.headline: Hague confident of moving into No 10
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, today insisted he could overcome the longest odds in postwar politics to win the general election and walk down Downing Street as the youngest prime minister since Pitt the Younger.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, today insisted he could overcome the longest odds in postwar politics to win the general election and walk down Downing Street as the youngest prime minister since Pitt the Younger.

Flanked by his wife Ffion, who has taken a month's break from her job as a city headhunter, Mr Hague told supporters Labour was not looking for a second term, but "a second chance."

And copying a trick from John Major's successful 1992 campaign, he took to a soapbox to tell voters in Watford: "We have had four years in which class sizes have got bigger, waiting lists have got longer and taxes have gone up.

"If people want the chance to hit crime hard, to keep taxes down, to improve their schools then this is their chance to do so."

Earlier Mr Hague told friends, supporters and staff at Conservative central office in Westminster: "Ffion and I are looking forward to touring the country straight away and we are going to campaign harder than we have ever done before."

But Mr Hague was beaten in to second place on the campaign trail by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, who boarded his battlebus yesterday.

However, Mr Hague, who has worked out three times a week in the gym since taking over the party leadership in 1997, is believed to be in the best physical shape of the three party leaders.

Mr Blair finds little time as prime minister to pursue his favourite sport - tennis - and Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy, despite a recent diet and bid to quit smoking - is not up to the fitness levels of former marine Paddy Ashdown.

Asked by reporters today whether he was seen as an asset or a liability to the party, Mr Hague replied: "Everyone in the party is an asset. I certainly believe we can win, after all we have done well in all recent elections and we have the opportunity to win."

Asked whether he would be walking down Downing Street in a month's time, the Tory leader replied: "Oh yes."

Mr Hague added: "I want people to realise that this election matters. It is very arrogant for people to tell them the results have already been decided.

"I do want people to get out and vote and take an interest in this election."

He said he was "not going to be put off by opinion polls", adding that he was confident the Tories would win the election on their policies.

Asked if he had a "big idea", he said: "We are going to be tough on crime. We have had a Labour government that has been pathetically weak on crime."

Mr Hague said Labour had "squandered a huge Commons majority, the goodwill of the people of this country, and the best set of economic conditions any government has ever inherited. Never has a party had so much, but achieved so little."

webTitle: Trimble threatens to resign over IRA arsenal

fields.headline: Trimble threatens to resign over IRA arsenal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble today warned he will resign as first minister of the Northern Ireland executive unless the IRA begins to hand over its illegal arsenal.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble today warned he will resign as first minister of the Northern Ireland executive unless the IRA begins to hand over its illegal arsenal.

Mr Trimble confirmed that he had handed a post-dated letter of resignation to assembly speaker Lord Alderdice threatening to resign on July 1 if substantial disarmament does not take place.

The international body overseeing decommissioning has set a deadline of June 30 for the complete handing in of paramilitary weapons.

But Mr Trimble has hit out, insisting that there were now less than eight weeks for the Provisionals to meet promises made at Hillsborough in May 2000.

He said: "Because there is so little time left, because some in the Republican movement think they can avoid their obligations, and because there have been comments, purporting to come from government, casting doubt on that date, I have decided to reinforce the agreement made at Hillsborough.

"Mr Speaker, I have this day signed and lodged with you a letter resigning as first minister as from 1 July 2001. This letter will take effect unless before that date, the republican movement keeps the promise it made over a year ago."

The assembly was previously suspended in February 2000 by the former Northern Ireland Secretary, Peter Mandelson, to prevent the institutions collapsing.

Mr Trimble had left a notice of intention with his party chairman threatening to resign in the absence of IRA decommissioning.

The assembly was restored in May 2000 after the IRA made a series of pledges to begin the process of disarmament.

But a Stormont insider said today's letter provided a much greater threat to the Good Friday agreement.

"This was given to the speaker which makes it much less in dispute. It is a very definite step he has taken and it will be much harder for him to draw back from," he said.

A spokesman for the Prime Minister said that it would be "highly regrettable" if Mr Trimble were to resign his post for any reason.

He said that the government had made it clear in May of last year that it hoped and expected progress on all these issues to be made by June of this year.

The Northern Ireland Secretary, John Reid, also said that Mr Trimble's resignation would be "highly regrettable".

He said the government had already made it clear that for the Good Friday agreement to succeed, everyone needed to meet their commitments.

webTitle: Sacked Tory to back UKIP candidate

fields.headline: Sacked Tory to back UKIP candidate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Charles Wardle, former Conservative minister who fell out with William Hague, is poised to take his revenge by backing the UK Independence Party in his east Sussex constituency - against the Tory candidate picked to succeed him.
fields.body:
Charles Wardle, former Conservative minister who fell out with William Hague, is poised to take his revenge by backing the UK Independence Party in his east Sussex constituency - against the Tory candidate picked to succeed him.

In an unexpected attempt to up the stakes in the Tory stronghold of Bexhill and Battle, Nigel Farage, one of the three UKIP MEPs in the Strasbourg parliament, announced yesterday that he will be standing in the seat instead of the local contender tipped as the UKIP candidate. But Mr Farage has only stepped in be cause he has been offered "help from some influential supporters in the bitterly divided" local Conservative association. It has been hit by a feud over the choice of Gregory Barker to succeed 61-year-old Mr Wardle, who is standing down.

Though he was not confirming it yesterday, the outgoing MP, a former immigration minister under John Major, is almost certain to announce his support for Mr Farage as soon as parliament is dissolved.

Mr Wardle was deprived of the Tory whip at Westminster on April 11 on the basis of a press report that he was supporting an independent candidate in Bexhill. When Mr Hague refused to do the same to John Townend when he broke ranks over immigration the Wardle case embarrassed the Tory leadership for its apparent inconsistency.

The MP had backed local protests that Mr Barker's CV at the selection meeting was inaccurate in important details. After an investigation, party HQ in London backed Mr Barker, who will inherit a 1997 majority of 11,000.

What has encouraged Mr Farage is that UKIP then came second in the Bexhill constituency. Mr Wardle is a maverick rightwinger who became a director of Harrods and a sharp critic of Tory immigration policy.

webTitle: Election machine braces itself for spanners

fields.headline: Election machine braces itself for spanners
fields.standfirst: With Labour's position looking strong, the 2001 election campaign threatens to be a dull one - at least until the next political gaffe, says Nicholas Watt, political correspondent
fields.trailText: With Labour's position looking strong, the 2001 election campaign threatens to be a dull one - at least until the next political gaffe, says Nicholas Watt, political correspondent.
fields.body:
As the prime minister's Jaguar glided down the Mall to Buckingham Palace this morning, Tony Blair must have reflected on Roy Jenkins' cutting remark about his position in the run up to the last election.

Dinner guests laughed in 1996 as the grand old man of the centre left likened the Labour leader to a curator nervously carrying a priceless Ming vase across a freshly polished museum floor. One slip and it smashes, Lord Jenkins quipped.

The prime minister, who enjoys the same opinion poll lead as he did in 1996, knows that his position is stronger than that of the sweating curator. But he also knows that even the most finely tuned party machines can come unstuck during the heat of a campaign.

Labour needs no reminding of the Jennifer's ear debacle of 1992, when Neil Kinnock's attempts to use the plight of a young girl to demonstrate the crumbling nature of the NHS backfired spectacularly. The prime minister is still said to cringe when reminded of the 1992 election campaign - not least the notorious Sheffield rally when Mr Kinnock appalled voters with his triumphal punching of the air.

However - and this could prove an embarrassing hostage to fortune - disasters tend to beset parties that are struggling anyway. Parties that are ahead in the polls tend to develop a Teflon-like quality and manage to repel potential setbacks before they become serious. Millbank made a serious mistake last month when it accused the Conservative party of withdrawing a black man and his son from an election poster because of their race. The claims turned out to be completely without foundation - the man had withdrawn because of objections from his former wife.

If Labour were struggling in the polls, such a mistake would have been seized on as a sign that the party was losing its grip. Instead, the story made a few light-hearted paragraphs in newspaper diaries.

However, Labour knows that there may well be hiccups in its campaign. Even in 1987, when Margaret Thatcher cruised to her third successive win, Conservative central office suffered a few famous "wobbles".

Europe could present a threat to Labour. A few unguarded remarks from a European politician about the need for tax harmonisation would, in the heat of the election battle, provide powerful ammunition to William Hague who will devote two-thirds of his campaign to Europe. Disgruntled left-wing Labour MPs, who have kept quiet for the past four years, could feel that the time has come to argue for the unmentionable: increased income taxes. Such a demand would be stamped on by the Labour leadership, but would be seized on by the Tories.

However, the Tories are most likely to provide the greatest entertainment during the campaign. Hardly a soul at Conservative central office believes that Mr Hague can win, guaranteeing a lack of discipline. The John Townend affair gave a taste of what can happen to a party during an election if it is regarded as a joke. His recent outbursts on race dominated the political agenda for two weeks because the Tories had nothing better to offer during the political vacuum after the prime minister delayed the election.

Mr Townend has, probably, been placed in a box for the duration of the election, but the Tories will enter rough waters during the campaign because the party is seriously divided across a range of issues. Kenneth Clarke, the former chancellor, will lead a group of moderate Tories who will publish election addresses that will contradict Mr Hague's hardline stance on the single currency. Although the pro-euro addresses will be couched in diplomatic language, they will destabilise the Tory campaign because people know that the failure to include the likes of Mr Clarke on the front bench symbolises the desperate plight of the Tories.

The shadow cabinet, which is jostling for position behind the scenes, have been on its best behaviour since Christmas. But if Mr Hague struggles over the next four weeks, a whispering campaign will start.

On paper, this should be a dull general election campaign because the main question appears to be whether forklift trucks will be needed to carry Labour's ballot papers on election night. However, a campaign that promises to be dull invariably comes alive, to the dismay of election planners on all sides who want everything to run according to their own "grids".

webTitle: Sun keeps mum on Biggs bounty

fields.headline: Sun keeps mum on Biggs bounty
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The Sun has refused to say how much it spent to bring train robber Ronnie Biggs back home, writes Julia Day.

Sun 'paid Biggs £350,000 to return
PCC to probe Sun role
fields.body:
The Sun today refused to say how much cash it parted with to bring train robber Ronnie Biggs back home.

The figure, reported to be upwards of £350,000, could total even more if the expense of bringing Biggs back to the UK is taken into account.

Chauffair, one of Britain's leading private jet hire firms, estimated it would have cost "in the region of £130,000" to fly Biggs back from Rio in the Dassault Falcon 500, with stop-offs in Africa on both legs of the journey for refuelling.

And seasoned journalists on rival papers believe the Sun has paid a "considerable" amount to secure the return of Biggs to face UK justice.

Kevin Crace, reported to be "a Biggs family friend", is rumoured to have been paid generously to help set up the 71-year-old robber's return.

Fleet Street is awash with rumours about the size of the bounty Mr Bigg's son Michael landed for his part in bringing his father to justice.

According to reports over the weekend, he received £20,000. However, today the talk is of a sum closer to £120,000.

"The money spoken of is on the conservative side. Why would Ronnie Biggs come home for £20,000? This has got to be his pension and legacy for his family," said one journalist.

It is believed the News of the World tried to "buy up" fellow great train robber Bruce Reynolds and his son Nick, who travelled with the Sun to Rio.

Sources say Reynolds is being paid £12,000 in expenses by the Sun.

Other expenses include jetting out four squads of Sun journalists to Rio over the past month and the cost of putting up them, Biggs and his entourage in the hotel.

A spokeswoman refused to comment on the cost of the deal. "We don't want to say anything about this at the moment," she said.

The newspaper also said it would be co-operating fully with any investigation by the Press Complaints Commission, hinting strongly that it would be using the "public interest" argument in its defence.

"The requirements of the PCC code were fully taken into account," the spokeswoman said.

"We are happy to co-operate and will be making clear the massive public interest in returning a convicted criminal home to face justice at no cost to the taxpayer."

The Sun sent six journalists and two photographers to Rio, but other UK newspapers took a more low-key approach.

The Mail sent Paul Henderson to the Rio media scrum but the Express's Harold Emert is based in Brazil and the Daily Telegraph used Rio stringer Andrew Downie.

The Mirror didn't bother sending anyone and today played down the story by placing it on page five.

According to one journalist on a rival paper, this was partly for reasons of cost and partly because of scepticism that the Sun would be able to pull off the move.

The last minute doubt over whether Biggs would get on a plane, combined with the general cutbacks on newspapers, conspired against an exotic trip out for Fleet Street's crime correspondents.

"People are cutting back on budgets in Fleet Street and they were sceptical as to whether he [Mr Biggs] would actually come back.

"Also, with Biggs tucked away with [Sun reporter] John Askill, the press were wondering if there would be a scene to report on," said one journalist.

fields.headline: Wieden & Kennedy picks up Vodafone
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: The mobile phone giant has hired Wieden & Kennedy to handle its worldwide advertising business, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The mobile phone giant, Vodafone, has confirmed the appointment of Wieden & Kennedy to handle its worldwide advertising business as it prepares to roll out the Vodafone brand globally.

W&K, a US-based advertising network whose clients include Nike and Coca-Cola, will work alongside Vodafone's local agencies.

The group will provide global campaigns that can be adapted for local markets.

Vodafone said it had already completed the first phase of its global brand roll-out by introducing its name alongside its subsidiary networks around Europe.

The company will begin to phase out its other brands.

W&K pitched against incumbent agency McCann-Erickson and Vodafone's UK agency, WCRS, for the account.

Vodafone is one of the UK's biggest advertisers, spending £47m on advertising last year.

The appointment of Wieden & Kennedy, which had been widely tipped to win the business, completes a major overhaul of the company's marketing.

News: Mayor's blueprint for London

London mayor Ken Livingstone will today publish the blueprint for a massive redevelopment of London, the first strategic plan for the capital for a generation.

Conservative leader William Hague has unveiled his party's manifesto for local government.

Tony Blair secretly scrapped an official report detailing how Britain's public services are still failing.

Interview: How firebrand Milburn became a model manager

Health secretary Alan Milburn is the Trotskyist revolutionary who became the archetypal New Labour model manager. Edward Stourton interviews the architect of the government's NHS plan.

Health: Medical scandals leave trust in doctors unshaken

Doctors are still viewed as the people the public most trust, research has revealed, despite a wealth of recent adverse publicity.

Local government: Ramblers angry as footpaths stay closed

Councils have been accused of dragging their heels over the reopening of thousands of miles of paths closed by foot and mouth.

Health: Snack scheme aims to cut NHS wastage

A 24-hour service of free snacks in NHS hospitals will be launched by ministers this week in a £40m programme to improve the quality of patients' food.

Social care: Government backs down over health and social care bill

Health minister Lord Hunt has made key concessions over two of the most controversial parts of the health and social care bill in order to ease its passage through parliament before the general election.

Regeneration: Councillor investigated over regeneration funds

Police are investigating the affairs of a Labour councillor who allegedly channelled thousands of pounds of regeneration funding into his own private company.

Social care: Family sue race watchdog over jail murder inquiry

The family of an Asian teenager murdered by his cellmate at Feltham youth jail is to take the commission for racial equality to court to stop it holding an inquiry into prison racism behind closed doors.

Child protection: Witness appeal on Anna death inquiry

Lord Laming, head of a public inquiry into the killing of eight-year-old Anna Climbié, has appealed for witnesses to provide evidence that could lead to a fundamental overhaul of child protection in England.

Drugs and alcohol: Australia opens first heroin injecting room

Australia's first legal heroin injecting room, the largest 'shooting gallery' in the world, has opened its doors to drug users in Sydney's red-light district, despite opposition.

Race equality: Pensioners spark race row at home

As an original member of the Specials, Clifton Golding's son Lynval is something of a local hero in Coventry. But the celebrityconnection cut no ice last week when Mr Golding senior tried to move into one of the city's residential homes only to be told he would not be welcome - because he was black.

Policy: Tories pledge to protect green belt

The Conservatives have attempted to make protecting the green belt from housebuilding a key election issue.
