webTitle: Chairman: Royle's City reign will continue

fields.headline: Chairman: Royle's City reign will continue
fields.trailText: Joe Royle will be the manager of Manchester City next season, despite the club's relegation from the Premiership last night.
fields.body:
Joe Royle will be the manager of Manchester City next season, despite the club's relegation from the Premiership last night.

City will return to the Nationwide League following their 2-1 defeat at Ipswich, but club chairman David Bernstein this morning confirmed that Royle will remain in charge.

"Joe has done a very good job for us over the previous two years and the last thing we need is unnecessary change. We will not be changing the position of manager.

"But there has to be understanding within the club, between the manager and the board, as to what we need to learn. And that is very important or there is no point in these exercises.

"Failure is all about learning from failure, and recovering from it. We are very disappointed and if we go on the same way, then no doubt if we come up again we will go down again very quickly so we have to move forward."

Bernstein admitted City had been taken by surprise by the quality of the Premiership on their return after an absence of four years.

"There certainly was a culture shock. I have to say we knew there was a gap but I think the gap is possibly bigger than we anticipated.

"It is a very high standard in the Premier League and it does take attuning to, and clearly we didn't do it well enough."

Relegation will not affect the club's plans to leave Maine Road, their home since 1923, and move into the Commonwealth Games stadium.

"Absolutely not. We are in legally bound and in every way we want to go to the new stadium," Bernstein told BBC Radio 5 Live.

"It's a fantastic structure, it has a 50,000 capacity and it should be the making of the club, but we need to playing Premier League football there. This certainly will not affect our moving there."

webTitle: Labour on housing: quality and choice at heart of pledges

fields.headline: Quality and choice at heart of pledges
fields.standfirst: As well as promising to improve thestandard of social housing, Labour wants to give tenants a greater degree of flexibility in choosing where to live
fields.trailText: As well as promising to improve the standard of social housing, Labour wants to give tenants a greater degree of flexibility in choosing where to live.
fields.body:
 An extra £1.6bn for social housing.

 All social housing to be of a decent standard within 10 years.

 Improvements to the quality of social housing construction.

 Tenants to be given a greater choice over where they live, instead of being offered housing a "take it or leave it" basis.

 Stabilise rents in social housing at affordable levels.

 High performing local authorities to set up arm's-length companies to manage local housing, with the power to borrow money for investment.  Interest-free loans to help key workers such as nurses and teachers get a foot on the housing ladder.

 Grants and low cost loans to help pensioners and others to improve their homes.

 Target of reducing rough sleeping by two-thirds by 2002. Rough Sleepers Unit has £180m to coordinate homelessness strategy.

webTitle: America's war with an invisible enemy

fields.headline: America's war with an invisible enemy
fields.standfirst: Computer hackers have renewed attacks on US governmental and academic institutions, reports Julian Borger
fields.trailText: Computer hackers have renewed attacks on America's governmental and academic institutions, reports Julian Borger.
fields.body:
The United States has been under sustained attack for the past three years. It is an onslaught aimed not only at the US military, but also at Nasa, the machinery of government, the country's universities and the research laboratories.

The offensive, codenamed Moonlight Maze by the Pentagon, is a cyber-attack in which a group of hackers have gained access to supposedly protected computers and gained access to a large amount of sensitive information.

Even though the Pentagon was alerted to the intrusions in March, 1998, it has only been partially successful in parrying the attacks. In an article in the journal Foreign Affairs James Adams, a cyber-war expert and an advisor to the US national security agency, said there were "disturbingly few clues" about who is behind the onslaught.

"We know there's been widespread penetration," Mr Adams said. "We think that a large amount of data has been taken ... We don't actually know, despite a very large effort, who is behind it. We don't know why they're doing what they're doing".

What footprints there were seemed to come from Russia. Last year the US presented Moscow with a list of telephone numbers from which the Americans said the attacks were coming from, but the Russians said the numbers were no longer in service. In the Pentagon's eyes, Moscow is either behind the hackers or deliberately dragging its feet in the effort to unearth them.

But, by the very nature of information warfare, there is no proof of state involvement. US cyber-warriors have hesitated before launching a counterattack lest the return address lead back to the Russian military- in which case "return-to-sender" countermeasures, known as "hack-backs", could be construed as an act of war.

Acknowledging the attacks for the first time last year, one of the FBI's top computer experts, Michael Vatis, told Congress that the hackers had stolen "unclassified but still sensitive information about essential defence technical research matters".

The problems the US has faced in confronting Moonlight Maze have starkly revealed the country's vulnerability. A handful of anonymous hackers have succeeded in turning the superpower's might and technological superiority to their own advantage.

They not only broke through the security around Pentagon and other government computers but they also inserted codes into the operating systems which allowed them to exert remote control over the software and to steal data. It is a sophisticated technique known as "tunneling" and it is extremely hard to detect.

According to the FBI's national infrastructure protection centre, there were 1,300 serious cyber-attacks on US military targets in 1999 and 2000. Some appeared to be randomly timed. But many appeared to be retaliation for US actions abroad. Serb hackers penetrated US computer defences in 1999 during the Kosovo conflict.

After last month's collision between a US spy-plane and a Chinese fighter jet, which caused the death of the Chinese pilot, US government computers were hacked into and the dead pilot's face appeared on screens around the country.

China's people's liberation army is thought to be taking the new possibilities of cyber-war extremely seriously. Two PLA colonels have produced a book, Unrestricted Warfare, on the subject, and Beijing has created a special information-warfare group to coordinate national cyber-war policy.

However, one of the defining characteristics of this new form of warfare is that the threat can come from anywhere, from anyone using a decent laptop with access to the internet where thousands of hacking tools are freely available for downloading.

In 1998, the Pentagon's computer systems came under a series of hacking attacks, codenamed Solar Sunrise.

It was a time of high tensions with Iraq and the attacks seemed to be coming from an address in Abu Dhabi. A strike force was dispatched only to find that the suspect address simply housed an internet server, through which the offensive had been routed. It turned out the hackers were a pair of teenagers in California.

Suddenly, as a result of technology it helped develop, the US "military-industrial complex" does not seem so mighty.

fields.headline: Police found Dando cuttings in accused man's home
fields.standfirst: Special report: Jill Dando trial
fields.trailText: Torn newspaper reports about Jill Dando's death and written references to other women celebrities were found at the flat of the jobless man accused of murdering the TV presenter, the Old Bailey heard today.
fields.body:
Torn newspaper reports about Jill Dando's death and written references to other women celebrities were found at the flat of the jobless man accused of murdering the TV presenter, the Old Bailey heard today.

Orlando Pownall, prosecuting, alleged that police had discovered a list of film and television personalities, and another list of models with some details of home addresses, agencies and newspapers.

"There were two copies - one torn - of the Metro newspaper referring to the death of Jill Dando," Mr Pownall said. "You may think it follows the defendant would look at individuals that caught his eye and make a list."

Mr Pownall today continued to open the prosecution case against Barry George, 41, who denies shooting Miss Dando through the head as she crouched on the doorstep of her home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, south-west London, in April 1999.

The prosecution alleges that Mr George had an obsession with the army, guns and celebrities. He had allegedly claimed to be the cousin of the singer with Queen - the late Freddie Mercury - and called himself Barry Bulsara.

When police searched his flat they found a number of things relating to weaponry and the army, the court has heard. In addition were "other relevant items", said Mr Pownall.

They allegedly included a handwritten note bearing reference to the Big Breakfast - giving a number - and Carlton TV's news programme London Tonight.

There was a piece of paper headed: "I have got a secret. Room 408" with a handwritten reference to the BBC, a calling card in the name of Mr George with handwritten note detailing "Breakfast News", references to GMTV and phone numbers and a map showing the location of the BBC shop.

Also listed by Mr Pownall was a handwritten note referring to BBC London Plus, a notebook with reference to Dominic English, a researcher for the Big Breakfast, and a celebrity bulletin letter that stated "enclosed are samples showing the kind of news we publish".

There was a list of names and movements of individuals mentioned - "still further evidence of this defendant's fascination with celebrities", said Mr Pownall.

"They also found a photograph of the defendant outside the home address of Freddie Mercury, a Bulsara business card with the name Dando thereon, a torn section of a Dando police appeal poster with telephone number on the reverse and two Cecil Gee receipts for clothing."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Australia opens first heroin injecting room

fields.headline: Australia opens first heroin injecting room
fields.trailText: Australia's first legal heroin injecting room, the largest 'shooting gallery' in the world, has opened its doors to drug users in Sydney's red-light district, despite opposition.
fields.body:
Australia's first legal heroin injecting room, the largest "shooting gallery" in the world, has opened its doors to drug users in Sydney's red-light district despite opposition from Aborigines and local business people.

The 18-month trial in Kings Cross, an inner city area notorious for prostitution and drug dealing, will aim to cut the country's drug overdose deaths, which have soared from six in 1964 to 958 in 1999.

Since it was proposed two years ago, the injecting room has attracted criticism from local people, the Australian prime minister and the Pope, who sent a letter forbidding the Sisters of Charity order to run the centre, where nurses provide supervision and sterile equipment for addicts to inject drugs.

An Aboriginal elder lodged a complaint with the Land Titles Office last Friday, claiming that the $A500,000 (£185,000) injecting room was close to an indigenous burial ground. Uniting Care, the charity running the centre, has 21 days to respond.

The controversial trial was originally intended to involve several other shooting galleries, but two court challenges and divided public opinion led New South Wales's Labor government to support a single centre.

The NSW premier, Bob Carr, whose brother died from a drug overdose, and the police have backed the project, which is funded by money confiscated from convicted drug dealers.

The local chamber of commerce, which lost a Supreme Court challenge to the injecting room last month, claimed the centre was already exacerbating drug use in Kings Cross. "As of the last 24 hours there's been an enormous increase in the number of drug addicts and dealers in this area," its spokesman Paul Haege said.

Local drug users last night welcomed the shooting gallery, which can offer 200 injections daily, but many said they had been scared off by media attention. Just eight users stepped past waiting camera crews to enter the centre on its first day.

"I think it's a good thing, otherwise there are people shooting up in the gutters," said Helen. "But I wouldn't use it after last night when I saw all my friends walking in there on TV."

She said she regularly witnessed about five overdoses a night in Kings Cross and believed that the injecting room would definitely help cut drug-related deaths. One in five drug overdoses in New South Wales occur in the district.

Critics of the injecting room pointed out that it failed to stop ambulances being called out to three overdoses in Kings Cross on its first night, but the centre's staff appealed for time and space for the trial, the first in an English-speaking country, to work properly.

fields.headline: Batalla campal por un graffiti
fields.standfirst: Recently a young man began drawing graffiti in Valencia and his action led to a pitched battle with police. Producing graffiti is illegal in Spain, but Eulàlia Furriol finds not every young person thinks that way
fields.trailText: Recently a young man began drawing graffiti in Valencia and his action led to a pitched battle with police. Producing graffiti is illegal in Spain, but Eulàlia Furriol finds not every young person thinks that way
fields.body:
Empezó con un graffiti y acabó en una batalla campal. Un joven hacía un graffiti en Valencia el pasado abril cuando le sorprendió un policía. Los vecinos intentaron impedir el arresto del joven y el policía pidió refuerzos. Al final se enfrentaron veinte policías con más de cincuenta vecinos.

Los graffitis son parte del paisaje urbano. Un paisaje, sin embargo, que no gusta a todos. Sus autores se mantienen en el anonimato y se identifican con una firma o con el nombre de un grupo. Hacer graffitis es ilegal. Es usar un espacio público sin permiso. Tres jóvenes graffiteros nos dan su punto de vista sobre el graffiti. Piden el anonimato y dan su firma: FKI, Eme y Snipe. Claire es una de las personas que observan sus graffitis. Todos viven en Sant Cugat del Vallés, un pueblo cerca de Barcelona.

El graffiti, ¿es arte? ¿comunicación? ¿vandalismo? ¿rebelión?

FKI (18 años): Es arte y es comunicación. Es la pintura que ve más gente, aunque muchos no la entienden.

Eme (17 años): Graffiti es comunicación y rebelión. Es querer decir algo que nadie ha dicho. Y la mejor forma de hacerlo es una pared. Asílo ve todo el mundo.

Snipe (18 años): Es una forma de expresión. Algunos graffitis son grandes, son legales y son arte. Otros son sólo una firma en sitios muy públicos y son vandalismo. Pero también son arte.

Claire (16 años): Es un tipo de arte para llamar la atención y para reivindicar algo. El hecho de que "graffiti" se diga "spray can art" en inglés no es anodino. Pero también puede ser vandalismo, según los sitios donde se pinta. Algunos graffitis me gustan. Depende de si están bien hechos y en un sitio adecuado.

¿Eres graffitero? ¿Por qué o por qué no?

FKI: Soy graffitero. Me gusta hacer dibujos guapos. El próximo año estudiaré Bellas Artes en la universidad. Tengo colegas que pintan su firma por todas partes y ya está. A mi no me atrae, pues les falta ideología. Ir a las cuatro de la madrugada a pintar un nombre en un tren y salir corriendo es un rollo que no me va.

Eme: Sí, empecé a escuchar música hip-hop y luego a pintar. Mi estilo es un poco raro. Uno de mis graffitis es una pared pintada de negro y en medio, en blanco, la palabra feo. Yo pinto para que sepan quien soy.

Snipe: Yo empecé cuando tenía diez años con un amigo. Queríamos enseñar lo que sabíamos hacer y era vandalismo puro. Un día otros graffiteros nos echaron una bronca y nos explicaron de qué va el tema. Ahora pido permiso para pintar. Ver tu dibujo en la pared da mucha satisfacción. Y me anima mucho si alguien que pasa por allícuando pinto me dice: "Muy bien, chaval". O se queda mirando y dice: "¡Olé!"

Claire: No soy graffitera porque tendría que denunciar tantas injusticias que no habría suficientes paredes. Prefiero usar el lenguaje. Hablar, por ejemplo, o escribir en la revista del colegio. O a través del teatro. El lenguaje ofrece muchas más posibilidades de matizar. Además, yo no pinto muy bien.

¿Hacer un graffiti debe ser un delito?

FKI: La esencia del graffiti es que sea un delito. Pero los ayuntamientos deberían facilitar espacios. Aunque hay cosas, como pintar trenes, que no se pueden legalizar.

Eme: Si fuera legal perdería mucho atractivo. El graffiti es salvaje. Es competición. Es mejor una pintada en medio de la ciudad que treinta fuera. Pero debería haber más sitios legales.

Snipe: He pintado en paredes del ayuntamiento y de la escuela, porque van contra nosotros. Necesitamos paredes para expresarnos. Mi madre se enfada conmigo pues conoce mi firma. Las paredes de mi habitación son un graffiti.

Claire: Si los graffiteros disfrutan tanto pintando paredes, ¿por qué prohibírselo? Pero hay que establecer unos límites. No pueden pintar en cualquier sitio con el pretexto de que se quieren rebelar.

Glosario/glossary

una batalla campal a pitched battle

echar una bronca (coll) to scold

un chaval (coll) a kid, youngster

un colega (coll) a mate

un delito a crime, an offence

disfrutar to enjoy

enfadarse to get angry, to get mad

feo ugly

guapo (coll) nice

los refuerzos reinforcements

reivindicar to claim as of right

un rollo que no me va (coll) something I don't like

salvaje wild

fields.headline: Desmond close to selling porn titles
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Northern & Shell has found three buyers for the magazines and a sale should go through within three months, reports Dan Milmo.<A HREF=" http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk/presspublishing/story/0,7495,421043,00.html"> 11.01.2001: Desmond's top-shelf titles 'not worth tuppence' says rival
fields.body:
The Express Newspapers owner, Richard Desmond, is close to selling his troublesome portfolio of top-shelf magazines but will hang on to his X-rated Fantasy Channel station.

His Northern & Shell company has found three buyers for the magazines - which include adult titles such as Asian Babes and Forum - and a sale should go through within three months.

The news is a public relations coup for the publishing tycoon, who is desperate to shake off his "porn baron" reputation.

A spokeswoman for Northern & Shell confirmed the imminent sale but declined to name the buyers or reveal a price for the deal.

"Three companies have been shortlisted and are being subjected to due diligence procedures. Northern & Shell is at the stage where it is simply choosing the buyer," said the spokeswoman.

It is understood Mr Desmond has offered the stable of magazines to several overseas businesses.

The magazines are owned by Mr Desmond's Portland Investments and Fantasy Publications companies.

However, his money-spinning adult Fantasy Channel will not be included in the sale.

The continued presence of the Fantasy Channel in the Northern & Shell group could scupper Mr Desmond's plans to float his publishing empire, which is valued at £500m.

City advisers will think twice about associating themselves with a company that still has links with the porn business.

Mr Desmond has also been forced into a sale for financial reasons, with Portland's latest accounts showing the magazines lost £870,000 in 1999 and Fantasy Publications lost £815,000 in the same year.

Analysts have suggested the titles may fetch up to £20m.

Last year's £125m acquisition of the Daily Express, the Sunday Express and the Daily Star from United Business Media was financed by a £97m loan from Commerzbank, which sparked a cost-cutting spree at Northern & Shell.

The publisher of OK! is following the lead of fellow porn tycoon, David Sullivan, who recently gave away his adult titles after complaining the porn publishing business was past its sell-by date.

webTitle: Winona Ryder denies clash with Richard Gere

fields.headline: Winona Ryder denies clash with Richard Gere
fields.standfirst: Plus: Will Smith writes children's book; Terry Gillam finishes Terry Pratchettt adaption; and Sam Neill backs hunting
fields.trailText: Plus: Will Smith writes children's book; Terry Gillam finishes Terry Pratchettt adaption; and Sam Neill backs hunting
fields.body:
Waif-like Winona Ryder has talked up her co-star Richard Gere in response to rumours of sour off-screen shenanigans on the weepie Autumn in New York. Apparently Gere demanded a script re-write at Ryder's expense, but the star of Heathers and Reality Bites star told the Sunday Express magazine: "He was wonderful. Basically we're in 90% of the scenes together so it's ridiculous to think that Richard was asking for more dialogue. That's the kind of stupid rumour which has no basis in fact." So know we know.

The multi-talented Will Smith has written a children's book, Just the Two of Us, which will be published in the US later this month. USA Today reports the picture book is based on Smith's hit song of the same name written for son Trey, now eight. The actor, who is working on Ali, the biopic of Muhammad Ali, says the book could be the first of many. He has agreed to do some additional work with publisher's Scholastic, along with wife Jada Pinkett Smith. "We have lots of ideas that we are kicking around. Jada and I are just starting to test the waters with this book."

Terry Gilliam is reported to have finished work on the script for Good Omens, an adaptation of Terry Pratchett's fantasy caper. The director told a correspondent for Aint It Cool News: "Tony [Grisoni] and I may have actually finished a sufficiently good enough draft of Good Omens to start moving forward with the business of making it." Thus far no casting news has been announced.

Antipodean star Sam Neill, of the Jurassic Park films who will soon be seen in Aussie space race drama The Dish, has revealed a passion for hunting. Speaking to The Sunday Telegraph, Neill said: "I'd always thought that hunting was brutal, just as protesters would have you believe, and this was always met with hot opposition from my parents, who said it was the most egalitarian of pursuits and that it brought everyone together in the country." He continued: "I think it is absolutely fundamental to the history and culture of Britain. It would be an absolute crime to stop it and, much as a lot of my views tend to be left-wing, I'm completely pro-hunting."

webTitle: Poor Depor let Real off the hook

fields.headline: Poor Depor let Real off the hook
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe with the lowdown on a Champions League-obsessed Primera Division
fields.trailText: They're kicking themselves in La Coruña. Earlier in the week, Deportivo coach Javier Irureta predicted a re-opening of the title race. All it needed, he said, was a defeat for Madrid at Celta de Vigo and a victory for Depor against struggling Rayo Vallecano.
fields.body:
They're kicking themselves in La Coruña. Earlier in the week, Deportivo coach Javier Irureta predicted a re-opening of the title race. All it needed, he said, was a defeat for Madrid at Celta de Vigo and a victory for Depor against struggling Rayo Vallecano.

The first half of the plan worked a treat. A weakened Madrid side, with Macca, Hierro, Makelele, and Karanka rested, were thumped 3-0 by Víctor Fernández's men. But Irureta's no Hannibal Smith - this plan didn't come together, with Depor only managing a 1-1 draw in Vallecas. Perhaps not surprising: the champions haven't won away for two months.

Depor had the better of a scrappy first half and should have been 1-0 up after Fran contrived to produce an amazing miss from a yard out that would embarrass Ronny Rosenthal.

Rayo had their chances too. Bolo hit the bar in the first half and opened the scoring in the second, with a superb side-footed volley. He had another opportunity ten minutes later, only to see Molina block his shot and Depor race down the other end to equalise through Valerón.

"We'll keep looking upwards," Irureta insisted afterwards, borrowing Juanito Oiarzabal's pick-axe from Jordi Cruyff. "When you're climbing a mountain you can't look down. You have to look towards the summit."

Let off in the league, the Man in the Moustache is now looking towards Munich. As far as the, erm, totally objective Madrid press is concerned, last week "was like a film where the baddie wins". Real's players, apparently forgetting last year's results, insist that they're a "better side" and that Bayern will be well beaten. "I don't see what's so difficult", Roberto Carlos told Marca, "we're going to win because we're better than them."

Valencia get ready for Davy's babies while Toshack sweats

Fans in Valencia are just as confident: "Ya tenemos plan, nos vamos a Milan." [We've got a plan - we're going to Milan.] That's the word from the stands anyway. Héctor Cúper's side prepared for Davy's babies with a 2-1 win over Real Sociedad. Pablo Aimar was the best player on view but it was - just for a change - a referee who had the biggest impact. Step forward Señor Medina Cantalejo.

La Real were down to nine men before half-time, and the Anoeta crowd was far from happy: the hijo de puta in the black had to be escorted off the field under armed guard, while his assistant was hit on the head by a missile. For once, the Federación has responded positively to scenes all too common in Spain - the Anoeta will be closed for a match early next season.

JB wasn't impressed with the ref. "He's a sad man who can't even look you in the eye. He provoked us right from the start," he said, citing precedent: "He's refereed us twice and we've had three players sent to the street before half-time."

Despite improving since JB's arrival, la Real are back in the bottom three and sweating like a whore in the confession box. "We need nine points in five games," JB admitted. "I don't know where from, but we will need to beat Osasuna."

Easier said than done. After drawing in the Bernabéu last week, Osasuna secured a surprise win over Mallorca. Armentano got the only goal, slipping a tidy finish past Mallorca's returning keeper, heavy metaller "El Mono" Burgos. (Burgos's new album is available in all good record shops, and probably a few crap ones, from Friday.)

The struggle and the strugglers

Out of the bottom three, Osasuna are a point behind Real Oviedo. The Carbayones momentarily forgot themselves to administer a 5-0 hammering to Athletic Bilbao. Things aren't looking any better for cash-strapped Valladolid, though. Their unpaid players produced another 0-0 bore - this time with Málaga.

Meanwhile, Numancia and Racing Santander remain in trouble after comprehensive away defeats. The sorianos lost 3-1 in Zaragoza, while Racing were thumped 5-1 by Uefa Cup finalists Alavés.

It's Uefa Cup time! (This season including added Barcelona!)

It's been a great week for the Alavés faithful. They collected their Uefa Cup final tickets; were repaid for their loyalty by the release of a new shirt interwoven with their names; saw the Federación bring next week's game forward to help their side prepare for Liverpool; and welcomed back Javi Moreno after a month out injured. The albiazules' top scorer was quickly into the swing of things, scoring twice to go back to the top of the Pichichi table [for top scorer] with 20 for the season.

While Alavés prepare for this year's Uefa Cup, Villarreal are looking forward to next year's - they're just a point off a European place after a 2-1 win against Las Palmas.

Barcelona might also be forced to look to the Uefa Cup as their Champions League chances fade - they've only won one in ten after another draw for Charly Rexach.

And Barça's draw hurt all the more because the opponents were their city rivals Espanyol. The Budgies handed out nearly fifteen thousand "streamers" (ie. bog rolls) before the game, but in the pouring rain the expected 35,000 didn't make it, leaving the Montjuïc looking depressingly empty - as usual.

Espanyol fans still managed to enjoy themselves, with chants of "Figo!, Figo!, Figo!", flying bog-rolls, and blazing firecrackers (one of which hit a security guard).

It's a good job they kept themselves amused: on a pitch as wet as an otter's pocket, the match itself was absolutely dire - it finished 0-0.

Earlier in the week, Barça president Joan Gaspart insisted on attending the derbi despite being declared persona non grata - last year he accused Espanyol of having "no heritage". As president of Barça and vice-president of the Federación Catalana, Gaspart couldn't be refused entry, but Espanyol's directors weren't impressed with his decision to attend.

"He has the right to go," a club spokesman announced, "but if he does he'll be doing it deliberately to wind us up." Vincenç Nos, the president of the Espanyol's Federació de Penyas agreed: "Gaspart loves winding people up. He shouldn't throw stones and hide his hands. If he's going to come to the match he'll just have to sit in the stand with the Espanyol fans".

A week's bickering and a humiliating public apology later, Gaspart took up his seat. Was it really worth the effort?

webTitle: Pope's visit brings Syrian ghost town to life

fields.headline: Pope's visit brings Syrian ghost town to life
fields.standfirst: Pontiff prays for peace on Golan visit
fields.trailText: The Pope arrived in the ghost town on the Golan Heights - a symbol of the destructive forces of war yesterday - and knelt in the husk of a destroyed church to pray for peace.
fields.body:
The Pope arrived in the ghost town on the Golan Heights that is a symbol of the destructive forces of war yesterday, kneeling in the husk of a destroyed church to pray for peace, in the most politically sensitive stop of his pilgrimage to Christian sites in Syria.

The Pope has made war and peace a crucial theme of his four-day visit to Syria, where he has retraced the footsteps of St Paul, who converted to Christianity on the road to Damascus.

Quneitra was the most symbolic stop on his itinerary. The town was occupied by Israeli forces in 1967 and destroyed during their withdrawal seven years later. It has been deliberately left a ruin since being abandoned to the winds that sweep across this high grassy plateau.

But yesterday the eerie ghost town was full of people - including those who fled in the 1967 war - bussed in by the thousand by the Syrian government, and lined up in front of the television cameras recording the Pope's visit.

In the ruined Greek Orthodox church, he prayed for peace and reconciliation in a quavering voice. "From this place, so disfigured by war, I wish to raise my voice in prayer for peace in the Holy Land and the world," he said.

A contingent from the UN peacekeeping forces stood outside under their blue flag.

Damascus refuses to rebuild the town or let more than a handful of its 50,000 residents return, vowing to preserve it as a macabre shrine to Israeli aggression, until the entire Golan is back in Syrian hands.

From this wasteland of razed houses and shell-scarred churches and mosques, Israeli positions and radar posts are clearly visible beyond coils of barbed wire that mark the ceasefire line.

This is the Israeli-occupied portion of the Golan Heights, where some 18,000 Druze and other residents hunger for unification with their kin in Syria.

The Pope's message was far less political than Syria might have wished, and avoided explicit criticism of the Jewish state. "We pray for the peoples of the Middle East. Help them to break down walls of hostility and division and to build together a world of justice and solidarity," he said.

The Vatican has repeatedly called for a peaceful resolution that would return captured land to its original owners, but the Pope is unlikely to move beyond those appeals to open criticism of Israel before ending his pilgrimage today.

Instead, his visit has focused on reconciliation between Christians and Muslims, symbolised by the first visit of any pontiff to a mosque at the weekend.

But his message of mutual understanding has left a residue of bitterness in the region. In his welcoming speech, the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, likened the Israelis to the betrayers of Jesus; the Israeli government in reply accused Damascus of anti-semitism.

After praying, the Pope watered a small olive tree, before leaving for Damascus.

For the people of the Golan Heights, the visit was hugely symbolic. Mohammed Anis Hussein, a civil servant who was among those taken to Quneitra yesterday, said it would show the world "there are people under occupation and moved from their land".

fields.headline: 'Compelling evidence' of George's guilt
fields.standfirst: Dando cuttings in flat of accused
fields.trailText: A scientific link between Barry George and the scene of Jill Dando's shooting provided 'compelling evidence of his guilt', the Old Bailey heard today.
fields.body:
A scientific link between Barry George and the scene of Jill Dando's shooting provided "compelling evidence of his guilt", the Old Bailey heard today.

A particle of discharge residue was found in the pocket of a blue Cecil Gee coat belonging to George which probably came from a firearm, said Orlando Pownall, prosecuting.

"The presence of lead in the particle from the defendant's coat pocket further supports that view as does the similarity in the composition of particles from the defendant's coat and from the coat worn by the deceased."

X-Ray spectra of two of the particles found in Miss Dando's hair and the particle from the coat were "very similar in that they contain comparable proportions of the main chemical elements, barium and aluminium.

"The three particles from the hair and the single particle from the coat could all have originated during the firing of the cartridge that contained the cartridge case recovered at Gowan Avenue, (Miss Dando's home address)," said Mr Pownall.

He said fireworks also produced spherical particles of barium and aluminium. But they generally also contained other elements as well. Their absence in the particle recovered from George's coat led a forensic scientist to conclude "that the source was a firearm, rather than fireworks".

The prosecution also said it would have been difficult for the coat to have been deliberately contaminated with the particle.

"Great care was taken by the police, none of whom were firearms officers or had access to firearms," Mr Pownall said.

"They wore overalls and latex gloves and the coat was sealed in a bag to prevent contamination."

It was also possible George innocently came into contact with an object bearing a residue particle which was later deposited in his coat pocket, the court heard. The coat and jacket were photographed at the police photographic studio before being examined by a forensic scientist.

"Might the particle have become lodged in the pocket there as a result of contamination from other items photographed at an earlier date?

"We submit that it did not and it is no coincidence that - taken in conjunction with the identification and other surrounding evidence - this defendant happens to have a particle in the inside pocket of his coat which is comprised of the same elements as were found on the coat of Jill Dando and in the same proportion.

"This aspect of the case provides compelling evidence of his guilt," said Mr Pownall.

webTitle: Africa's old guard stands firm against change

fields.headline: Africa's old guard stands firm against change
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe and Zambia's Frederick Chiluba are prepared to go to any lengths - even to the point of violence - to stay in power, says Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe and Zambia's Frederick Chiluba are prepared to go to any lengths - even to the point of violence - to stay in power, says Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two presidents - men who rule neighbouring countries and who would both like to go on doing so for as long as they are still breathing, whatever the people may think.

Everything was looking rosy for Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, but over the past year it has become apparent that both men have overstayed their welcomes.

Mr Mugabe has bludgeoned his opponents into near-paralysis since they came close to seizing control of parliament last year. Few people would be so foolish as to predict that he will not still be president after the elections some time in the next year.

Mr Chiluba was on course to amend Zambia's constitution to permit him to run for a third term as president and was, apparently, more than willing to use a few of Mr Mugabe's tactics to ensure that he emerged victorious from this year's ballot. The Zambian president is not afraid to use violence to get his way.

But a few days ago, the two men's paths diverged. Frederick Chiluba ran into what Mr Mugabe has managed to stifle - popular and parliamentary opposition. Last week, Mr Chiluba manoeuvred his ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) into changing its rules so that he could run for a third five-year term as president. The next step was to tamper with the constitution, which limits presidents to serving two terms. Mr Chiluba has already been in power for a decade.

When others members of the MMD objected to Mr Chiluba's scheme, they were slung out of the party after a few of them were beaten up at the party congress. The country's vice-president and eight other cabinet ministers were expelled, even though they had won a high court order forbidding the move.

But within days Mr Chiluba was being forced to backtrack. More than half the members of parliament, including many from the president's own party, said they would not deliver the two-thirds majority necessary to change the constitution. Some MPs laid a motion to impeach Mr Chiluba for abuse of power, and the expelled cabinet ministers were heading back to the high court.

On Friday, Mr Chiluba backed away and said he would not run for president again. Many Zambians did not believe him because he qualified the statement by saying that he could always call a referendum on amending the constitution. Two days later, Mr Chiluba spoke again. This time he said he wanted to make it "clear, clear, clear" that he would not be seeking another term in office and that there would be no referendum.

It would appear that Zambia's president has finally surrendered to popular sentiment after his own security people warned him that the country might become ungovernable if he clung to power. It is a very different story in Zimbabwe. On Monday, Mr Mugabe faced an important, but by no means catastrophic, setback in his strategy to hang on to power by preventing the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, from running for president. A high court judge ruled on the first day of Mr Tsvangirai's trial for terrorism (for calling for the violent overthrow of Mr Mugabe) that the oppressive British colonial-era security laws he was charged under may well be unconstitutional and kicked the case up to a higher court.

Mr Mugabe's plan is to see Mr Tsvangirai jailed for more than six months and, therefore, constitutionally barred from running for president. But even if that scheme does not work, the Zimbabwean president has many other weapons to hand.

While popular protest and, crucially, resistance within the ruling party forced Mr Chiluba to abandon his bid to extend his rule, Mr Mugabe faces no such challenges. Zimbabwe's president has a much tighter grip on his own party. Dissidents have been sidelined and purged, with the thuggish "war veterans" lending a violent hand if an awkward Zanu-PF member decides to put up a fight.

More importantly, popular resistance has also been doused. Last June, the opposition came within a whisker of winning the parliamentary elections. The MDC probably would have had it not been for intimidation and ballot rigging. Still, Mr Tsvangirai and his supporters were on a high. The president would have to go, they said, forgetting that even if he has since fallen out of favour, Mr Mugabe was elected, popularly and fairly, to rule his country.

In any case, Mr Tsvangirai had misjudged his enemy. Far from giving up the fight, Mr Mugabe unleashed a new wave of violence against his opponents and let it be known that if they tried to take to the streets with popular protests they would be crushed.

Nine months after the jubilation of the MDC's surge in parliament, the party is not broken but certainly bowed.

Still, both Mr Chiluba and Mr Mugabe must envy Sam Nujoma of Namibia, who decreed a constitutional amendment permitting him a third term as president with barely a peep of protest. Now he talking about running for a fourth time.

Mr Chiluba was on course to amend Zambia's constitution to permit him to run for a third term as president and was, apparently, more than willing to use a few of Mr Mugabe's tactics to ensure that he emerged victorious from this year's ballot. The Zambian president is not afraid to use violence to get his way. But a few days ago, the two men's paths diverged. Frederick Chiluba ran into what Mr Mugabe has managed to stifle - popular and parliamentary opposition. Last week, Mr Chiluba manoeuvred his ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) into changing its rules so that he could run for a third five-year term as president. The next step was to tamper with the constitution, which limits presidents to serving two terms. Mr Chiluba has already been in power for a decade. When others members of the MMD objected to Mr Chiluba's scheme, they were slung out of the party after a few of them were beaten up at the party congress. The country's vice-president and eight other cabinet ministers were expelled, even though they had won a high court order forbidding the move. But within days Mr Chiluba was being forced to backtrack. More than half the members of parliament, including many from the president's own party, said they would not deliver the two-thirds majority necessary to change the constitution. Some MPs laid a motion to impeach Mr Chiluba for abuse of power, and the expelled cabinet ministers were heading back to the high court. On Friday, Mr Chiluba backed away and said he would not run for president again. Many Zambians did not believe him because he qualified the statement by saying that he could always call a referendum on amending the constitution. Two days later, Mr Chiluba spoke again. This time he said he wanted to make it "clear, clear, clear" that he would not be seeking another term in office and that there would be no referendum. It would appear that Zambia's president has finally surrendered to popular sentiment after his own security people warned him that the country might become ungovernable if he clung to power. It is a very different story in Zimbabwe. On Monday, Mr Mugabe faced an important, but by no means catastrophic, setback in his strategy to hang on to power by preventing the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, from running for president. A high court judge ruled on the first day of Mr Tsvangirai's trial for terrorism (for calling for the violent overthrow of Mr Mugabe) that the oppressive British colonial-era security laws he was charged under may well be unconstitutional and kicked the case up to a higher court. Mr Mugabe's plan is to see Mr Tsvangirai jailed for more than six months and, therefore, constitutionally barred from running for president. But even if that scheme does not work, the Zimbabwean president has many other weapons to hand. While popular protest and, crucially, resistance within the ruling party forced Mr Chiluba to abandon his bid to extend his rule, Mr Mugabe faces no such challenges. Zimbabwe's president has a much tighter grip on his own party. Dissidents have been sidelined and purged, with the thuggish "war veterans" lending a violent hand if an awkward Zanu-PF member decides to put up a fight. More importantly, popular resistance has also been doused. Last June, the opposition came within a whisker of winning the parliamentary elections. The MDC probably would have had it not been for intimidation and ballot rigging. Still, Mr Tsvangirai and his supporters were on a high. The president would have to go, they said, forgetting that even if he has since fallen out of favour, Mr Mugabe was elected, popularly and fairly, to rule his country. In any case, Mr Tsvangirai had misjudged his enemy. Far from giving up the fight, Mr Mugabe unleashed a new wave of violence against his opponents and let it be known that if they tried to take to the streets with popular protests they would be crushed. Nine months after the jubilation of the MDC's surge in parliament, the party is not broken but certainly bowed. Still, both Mr Chiluba and Mr Mugabe must envy Sam Nujoma of Namibia, who decreed a constitutional amendment permitting him a third term as president with barely a peep of protest. Now he talking about running for a fourth time. fields.headline: Why the election matters
fields.standfirst: Julian Glover explains five ways the general election could shape the very nature of the nation
fields.trailText: Julian Glover explains five ways the general election could shape the very nature of the nation.
fields.body:
In what may turn out to be the most unimaginative election campaign for a generation, voters are expected to ignore politics and stay away from the ballot box in record numbers.

This is a mistake. The campaign may not seem exciting but that doesn't mean it is irrelevant. In fact it could shape the nature of Britain. How? Here are five ways it might happen.

1) The euro

This election is likely to decide whether Britain joins the single currency.

Although all three main parties support versions of the same policy - to hold a referendum on the issue before Britain ever joins - the big question, which will be answered by this campaign, is whether a referendum in the near future is a serious possibility.

This means that the next few weeks will really be an election about whether there ought to be an election.

Politicians will be watching out for signs that a referendum might be won by the pro-euro camp - and will adjust their positions on the issue accordingly. The less the euro is mentioned on the doorstep and in the media, the more confident the prime minister will be that his aim of holding a referendum in next couple of years is the right one. He thinks that the British public and his cabinet can be persuaded to join - but isn't ready to try convincing them yet.

The more the euro crops in the campaign up the more uneasy this will make Tony Blair. If he begins to take a battering now over the single currency - if, for instance, some Labour candidates openly oppose membership - the more cautious he'll be about exposing himself on the issue again in the near future.

This will be the case particularly if Labour's line on the euro is seen to help William Hague gain seats his party would otherwise have lost.

Likewise, members of the cabinet who are sceptical about the merits of the single currency will harden their line if Labour hits trouble over the issue now.

And that matters. Without cabinet backing, Mr Blair cannot get Britain into the single currency. That would not destroy his prime ministership, but it would threaten his place in history.

2) Parliament

MPs and journalists alike have complained that since 1997, parliament - and especially the House of Commons - has been moribund. The government's big majority means it runs little risk of defeat, and neither the prime minister nor the chancellor has shown much enthusiasm for attending.

The election could change all that. First, if the government is elected with a small majority the Commons will, by the natural force of the mathematics involved, come to matter more. Opposition and dissident government MPs will stand some chance of defeating official policy and, even if they fail, the attempt will at least make the Commons interesting again.

Second, if the government retains a big majority then some Labour MPs who have been loyal up until now are likely to build upon the confidence this gives them to demand a greater say. They may try to reinstate the Commons reform process begun after 1997 and may find that the Conservative party, desperate for some means of reining in Tony Blair, is willing to help them. Signs of this are already emerging.

There is even some chance that MPs may press for a more dynamic speaker than the current incumbent, Michael Martin, in the hope that this would help put the executive under pressure.

3) The Liberal Democrats

This campaign is significant for the Lib Dems in two ways.

First, Charles Kennedy, the party's leader, needs to make an impact before polling day. Some opinion polls actually show he is less well known among voters now than when he became leader in 1999. Although all eyes are on William Hague's future as party leader, Mr Kennedy may also find himself under pressure after the election if his party loses seats.

Second, the tone of the campaign and its outcome may determine whether the Lib Dems ever enter government. No one imagines that the election will lead to a hung parliament, but a small majority would make the 40-odd Lib Dem MPs an important bulwark for Tony Blair against his left wing. Mr Blair might even decide to press ahead with voting reform, which would give the Lib Dems a chance of getting a share of power.

In contrast another massive Labour win would blow reform off the government's agenda.

4) Scotland

Scotland has its own government and parliament - unaffected by this election - and the general election will probably be of only passing interest to most voters north of the border.

However the general election campaign will test the robustness Scotland's new federal political culture. Are Scots happy that some issues - such as foreign affairs - remain at Westminster while others - such as education - are run from Edinburgh?

If the campaign runs smoothly then politicians will take the result as a sign that Scots have come to accept the current halfway house between union and independence, brought in by Labour.

Any other result - particularly gains by the opposition SNP - will leave a question mark hanging over devolution and the route to full independence still open.

5) Tax and spending

The election could shape the future of the welfare state.

Officially, no major British political party proposes great changes to the level of government spending. Even the Liberal Democrats, who talk about the need to increase taxation, plan only small increases above those already announced by Gordon Brown.

This means that whatever happens on polling day the welfare state will continue in its current form for at least the next five years.

Beyond this, however, policy options begin to differ. Most Conservatives and some Labour ministers see the need for massive welfare reform, handing more responsibility to individuals to provide for themselves. Lib Dems and most Labour MPs disagree.

This split is what matters. Will students have to pay the full cost of their education, pensioners fund all their retirement costs and patients pay for medical expenses? Or will the state carry the burden?

The election could provide the answer. If Labour is seen to falter, the Conservative party may become more confident about pressing home its claim to be the party of low tax, even if this threatens some services. Likewise Labour will want to avoid discussing possible rises in taxation but may emerge from the campaign convinced that they are, in fact, politically possible.

How the public judge these two positions on polling day could decide what happens to the welfare state.

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours can't see it lasting. She's 17 years younger than him, for a start!
fields.trailText: Will relegated Coventry keep hold of John Hartson? According to his agent Jonathan Barnett, there would be "no shortage of clubs" willing to offer the Welshman Premiership football next season; clubs believed to be interested include Leicester, Derby and Middlesbrough. However, Barnett offers Cov's depressed fans a little cheer: "If Coventry prefer to keep John then the matter is closed. John has no get-out clause in his contract and in any case he has formed an excellent relationship with manager Gordon Strachan. Additionally, he feels very grateful towards Coventry for signing him in the first place."
fields.body:
Will relegated Coventry keep hold of John Hartson? According to his agent Jonathan Barnett, there would be "no shortage of clubs" willing to offer the Welshman Premiership football next season; clubs believed to be interested include Leicester, Derby and Middlesbrough. However, Barnett offers Cov's depressed fans a little cheer: "If Coventry prefer to keep John then the matter is closed. John has no get-out clause in his contract and in any case he has formed an excellent relationship with manager Gordon Strachan. Additionally, he feels very grateful towards Coventry for signing him in the first place."

Arsenal, Tottenham, Fulham and Chelsea brace yourselves. Emmanuel Petit is getting on well with new Nou Camp coach Carlos Rexach, and looks like staying with Barcelona for at least one more season. "He has told me that he is going to count on me a lot and that I have his full confidence," Petit wrote on his website. "I like Rexach a lot. We have had two conversations in ten days now, which is more than I ever spoke to [former coach Llorenc] Serra Ferrer in eight months. Furthermore, Rexach is allowing me to play in centre midfield and not in defence, which I evidently prefer."

Red Star Belgrade captain Goran Bunjevcevic is confident he will soon complete a £4m move to Tottenham. The 28-year-old central defender says his agent Dennis Roach will try and finalise the deal before the end of the week, telling onefootball.com: "I know that Spurs want me and it will be real challenge to play in England.

Teddy Sheringham is a target for seven Premiership clubs, at the latest count. Tottenham, Middlesbrough, Leicester, Aston Villa, West Ham, Charlton and Fulham are all waving two-year deals in his face, says the Sun.

Chelsea are after French player of the year Eric Carrière. "Chelsea are one of the many clubs that want me," the 27-year-old Nantes midfielder told Midas Soccer.

Meanwhile, the latest members of the Chelsea squad tipped to leave Stamford Bridge in the summer are Albert Ferrer, Winston Bogarde and, according to the Express, "possibly Gus Poyet".

Wolves manager Dave Jones has been given £15m to spend by Sir Jack "Golden Tit" Hayward. "I am going to make my money available," said the Molineux benefactor. "I think you can expect almost a new team next season." Leicester winger Steve Guppy is rumoured to be the first target for Jones.

Portsmouth manager Graham Rix has similar funds to play with next season. Owner Milan Mandaric has tipped £12m out of his purse.

Funds for the manager - it's the new craze! Because Crystal Palace chairman Simon Jordan has also promised to spend money next season - "almost £9m on new players" according to the London Evening Standard. Jordan is also interested in buying Selhurst Park from former Palace owner Ron Noades.

Brian McClair is expected to return to Manchester United in a coaching capacity. The 37-year-old former United and Celtic striker has flown out to Sydney to help set up United's football academy in Australia, and a full-time post is expected to be offered to him on his return. McClair left Old Trafford in 1998 to work with Brian Kidd at Blackburn.

fields.headline: Pearson takes Diamond role on BBC2
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Neil Pearson is to play the late John Diamond in a BBC2 drama, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Neil Pearson is to play the late John Diamond in a BBC2 adaptation of the play based on his weekly columns in the Times about his fight against cancer.

Pearson read extracts from Diamond's columns at his funeral in March.

"We want to bring John's writing to a wider audience with this film," he said.

"I hope that people can get a sense of the man John was and the honesty, wit and humour with which he bore his illness."

A Lump in my Throat, which has been adapted for TV by Victoria Coren from her own stage play, is due to begin production in London this month.

The drama will go out on BBC2 later this year.

It is to be directed by Olivia Lichtenstein, the producer/director of the BBC's John Diamond documentary, Tongue Tied, and executive produced by Susan Spindler.

fields.headline: BBC may take stake in horseracing consortium
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The BBC has the option to take a 5% stake in the Go Racing horseracing media rights consortium, writes Jason Deans.

08.05.2001: Gor Racing plans spring launch for pay-TV channel
fields.body:
The BBC has an option to take a 5% stake in the Go Racing consortium, which is on the verge of concluding a £400m horseracing media rights deal.

Go Racing's partners, Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure, have granted the corporation a 30-day window to exercise its option following the signing of the deal, which is expected to take place on Friday.

The BBC will hold onto its existing major horseracing events, including the Grand National, and win back the Derby as part of the TV rights deal it has negotiated with Go Racing.

In return the corporation will have to contribute 5% of Go Racing's annual funding for the 10-year duration of the agreement.

The BBC director general, Greg Dyke, is also laying the groundwork for a pay-TV sports channel, with NTL its preferred partner.

The NTL subsidiary, Premium TV, has also been granted a 70-day window to take a 10% stake in the consortium.

This would leave the other three shareholders each with a 28.33% stake.

Go Racing has already signed up 32 of the 59 UK racetracks to its agreement and the rest have until Friday to follow suit.

But the deal is also conditional upon Arena Leisure raising £60m by the end of June.

The publicly listed company, which suspended its shares on April 27, is planning to raise £85m through a share offering to investors.

Go Racing has offered £125m over 10 years for the TV rights to horseracing, which it expects to recoup from selling on the rights to broadcasters.

The consortium has also promised the racing industry a £195m minimum guaranteed share of betting and other revenue from media rights exploitation over the same period.

In addition, it has committed to spending at least £80m on marketing the sport.

Go Racing is planning to fund these payments in part with £50m from initial broadcast licensing income and a loan from Arena Leisure.

The consortium's shareholders, including the BBC and NTL if they take up their stakes, will contribute a further £70m, with individual contributions dependent on each backer's shareholding.

Separately, Arena Leisure has agreed to provide £80m in funding to Go Racing as part of a loan facility over the 10 years of the agreement.

In return, the racecourse owner will receive 3% of gross betting turnover from all Go Racing media outlets.

Go Racing is planning to launch a horseracing pay-TV channel and website, which will both offer an interactive betting service, as well as sub-licensing TV and radio rights to broadcasters including the BBC.

Channel 4 and BSkyB will also continue to broadcast horseracing.

The Go Racing pay-TV channel will have carriage on Sky Digital, digital terrestrial and NTL's cable networks.

Arena's Trackplay system will be the technology used to drive the Go Racing interactive betting service.

Go Racing will offer a pool betting service, which operates in a way similar to a lottery, rather than fixed odds betting.

webTitle: The car that went back in time

fields.headline: The car that went back in time
fields.standfirst: Take a Hyundai Lantra, stretch it a bit, move the airbags a touch, add the letter 'E' and, as if by magic, you get the Elantra: a tacky 1980s throwback
fields.trailText: Take a Hyundai Lantra, stretch it a bit, move the airbags a touch, add the letter 'E' and, as if by magic, you get the Elantra: a tacky 1980s throwback.
fields.body:
Car relaunches are quite frequently less exciting than car manufacturers would like us to believe. What gets trumpeted as an earnest return to the drawing board, leading to a fearlessly radical reappraisal of an old motoring favourite, often turns out, on closer inspection, to be the same old car with a slightly differently shaped gear fob and a minutely foreshortened indicator stalk.

In some cases, a fractionally improved braking system might be in place, but its effects will be discernible only to Michael Schumacher and those with the gift of extra-sensory perception.

Hyundai seems, at first sight, to be going for new records in this department with their relaunch of the Elantra, which arrives among us with an extra letter in its name from last time out. The Elantra used to be known as the Lantra, though only in Britain. In the rest of the world - or at least in those extensive parts of it in which the Korean company sells cars - it was known as the Elantra. Here, Lotus, who make a car called an Elan, objected to the use of the word Elantra on trademark grounds.

You can see Lotus's point: on the one hand, the Elantra, a cut-price saloon, aimed at people who would probably like a BMW but can only budget for half of one; on the other hand, the Elan, a sharply angled, deeply uneconomical, pigeon-frightening road-burner, aimed at hobbyists looking for pure pleasure from their third car. People were going to be getting them mixed up all the time.

Recently, however, Lotus must have decided to say "What the heck" because Hyundai is now free to release a British Elantra and unify the global brand under the one title.

Apart from the fact the car now takes longer to write, the new model does make some advances on the now discontinued Lantra, and not all of them of the order of "new soundproofing under the rear shelf" and "improved gear teeth design" in the manual transmission.

For instance, consider the new position of the passenger's airbag - not where it used to be, halfway up the dashboard, but stuffed under a panel on top. According to Hyundai, this "helps further to reduce the risk of injury on inflation". There we all were thinking that airbags were intended to spare you from injury, when actually it turns out they are lethal if they catch you from the wrong angle. Is nothing safe?

I was unable to find a passenger willing to let me put these claims for the airbag to the test, so we will have to take Hyundai's word for it. They should know. While building the Elantra, they involved it in no fewer than 150 collisions, which was either very thorough of them or very careless.

Another difference from the Lantra: the new car is wider, taller and longer. Altogether, its shape looks something like a throwback to the early 1980s, before cars - even saloons - took it upon themselves to turn all snubby on us. Hyundai seems to have thought: "If Duran Duran can come back, then why not cars that have the Ford Granada as their template?"

Whatever, the Elantra is now more capacious than many of the rivals in its class, including the Vauxhall Vectra and the Nissan Primera. Hyundai even fearlessly points out that the Elantra is bigger than the Volvo 540 - so is a Portakabin, but that doesn't mean that people who have it in mind to buy a Volvo are likely to change their ideas and purchase a demountable building instead.

Nor, probably, an Elantra. For all the safety testing and the minute attention to airbags, there seemed to me to be something thin and frail about it, and something very definitely at a remove from Volvo's big lumps of Swedish metal. The boot on the Elantra closes with a confidence-sapping "poink". The door handles are as light as cup cakes and the doors themselves seem to share certain important physical qualities with Coke cans. As for the ridges along the bonnet and down the side of the car, they add a fizz to the car's appearance, but they also look like something you might have put in it yourself, with access to a metal ruler and a steady hand.

Inside, it's the places where the car attempts to score points for luxury that the Elantra most reveals its nature. The top of the range 2.0 CDX that I drove contained large amounts of slippery leather and an acre or two of mock walnut, as if attempting to look like the library in a stately home. That's not such a bad idea in itself, but unfortunately the walnut was so triumphantly mock, it looked more plastic than the parts of the dashboard, which weren't pretending to be anything else.

To drive, the car was slick to the touch - all easy gear changes and light pedals - but it wasn't really the driving that stayed in the mind; it was the contrary nature of Hyundai's achievement, at this of all times. As manufacturers compete to produce ever bigger bargains in ever more surprising packages, Hyundai has pulled off a trick whose effects are almost reassuring: the production of a car that is not only cheap, but feels like it.

webTitle: Hague pledges hard line on unwed mothers and travellers

fields.headline: Hague pledges hard line on unwed mothers and travellers
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday unveiled a series of hardline policies in an attempt to shore up the Tory vote in the local and general elections on June 7.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday unveiled a series of hardline policies in an attempt to shore up the Tory vote in the local and general elections on June 7.

At the launch of the Tory manifesto for the local elections, Mr Hague pledged to put pressure on councils to make unmarried young mothers live at home rather than take up precious public housing.

He also made clear that a Tory government would reject the "politically correct view" that minor crimes by travellers should be ignored.

The joint crackdown on young mothers and travellers was the most controversial aspect of the Tory manifesto for the local elections which will be held on the same day as the general election.

Mr Hague hopes to encourage a high turnout on June 7 by pledging to introduce a series of hardline measures that will appeal to traditional Tory supporters.

The pledges unveiled in the local election manifesto pro vided a taster of the rightwing policies which will form the centrepiece of the Tories' general election manifesto.

In a section in the local election manifesto, entitled Helping Teenage Mothers and Families, the Tories pledged to scrap Labour plans to house unmarried teenage mothers in special hostels.

"The first question when an unwed teenager is pregnant should not be whether there is council flat for her, but whether her parents can support her and her child when she finishes school or look for work," the manifesto said. "Councils and housing associations need to think very carefully about the signals they send out when they allocate social housing."

Threatening to remove the right of unmarried young mothers to a council flat will upset some Tories on the left of the party. They remember the embarrassment the party faced in the 1990s when the former social security secretary, Peter Lilley, launched his notorious "little list" crackdown on teenage mothers.

The Tory leadership under lined its determination to fight the elections from the right with a pledge to crack down on "troublesome travellers".

"Conservatives will introduce tough new measures to stop illegal camps of travellers blighting local communities," the manifesto said. "We reject the politically correct view that a blind eye should be turned to minor crimes by many travellers just because of their alternative lifestyle."

Mr Hague pledged to counter voter apathy in the local elections by promising populist measures to crack down on graffiti and to hand greater powers to local councils.

Under the Tory plans, well run local authorities will be classified as "free councils" and given greater powers to run their own affairs.

The Tory leader said: "Few things are more important to people than the state of their immediate neighbourhood, things like litter, graffiti, noisy neighbours, their local services and how much they cost. Labour want these to be the forgotten elections because they want people to forget their appalling record in local government."

The Tories launched their local election campaign with a brief video which highlighted the "incompetence, gross mismanagement and corruption" of local councils.

But there was embarrassment after a misspelt caption in the video talked of "town halls in Britian".

The Tories faced further embarassment last night after details leaked out of the party's election campaign timetable. A Labour party activist, who logged on to the website of the young Conservative Future group, was emailed a 21-day timetable showing where the party would concentrate its efforts throughout the campaign.

On the first day of the campaign, supporters were asked to flood into Norfolk where there are a series of key marginal seats.

But the Conservatives, who still call themselves the party of the union, asked supporters to go to Wales on only one day and to Scotland on only two days.

Tory plans for town halls

 End capping of council budgets

 Hand greater powers to well-run councils. "Free councils" will have fewer Whitehall inspections and more freedom to raise funds for capital investment

 End regional bureaucracy in England by abolishing regional chambers and development agencies

 Defend "metric martyrs" by allowing loose goods to be sold in pounds and ounces

 Tough measures to crack down on travellers

 Abolish national and regional house building targets

 Give residents more say in planning process by allowing right of counter appeal

 Crack down on litter and graffiti by allowing councils to keep revenues from fines

 Set up regeneration companies to help rejuvenate rundown areas

 Crack down on "neighbours from hell" by introducing fast track evictions

 Give greater powers to schools by handing head teachers and governors full control over budgets

 Allow councils to end "cabinet" system of government and return to old committee system

 Encourage teenage mothers to live with parents rather than "off the welfare state".
