fields.headline: John Madden at the NFT
fields.standfirst: Following a screening of their eagerly anticipated adaptation of the bestselling novel Captain Corelli's Mandolin, director John Madden and screenwriter Shawn Slovo took to the stage at the NFT to discuss the movie alongside Guardian film writer Derek Malcolm
fields.trailText: Following a screening of their eagerly anticipated adaptation of the bestselling novel Captain Corelli's Mandolin, director John Madden and screenwriter Shawn Slovo took to the stage at the NFT to be interviewed by the Guardian film writer Derek Malcolm
fields.body:
Derek Malcolm: John, you realise you've ruined this island - in the next few years there'll be nothing but hotels and tourists.

John Madden: They've got their priorities right on the island. They've refused to build any hotels on the beaches we shot on up until now and I'm sure they'll do the same after the film's been released. At the same time there are plenty of people on the island who are desperate for an economic boost

DM: It's a pretty poor island, and not a tourist island really.

JM: No. It's way down the league table.

DM But it won't be anymore, will it?

JM: Well, it's a complicated business really. There'll be many people on the island who'll be absolutely delighted - they're already delighted, I think, with the attention they've got from the book. From our point of view it's a mixed blessing, but it's not up to me to decide. It's up to them

DM: Are there lots of tourist places there?

JM: No. There's a strip on the southern side of the island which is pretty well developed for tourism, but most of the rest of the island is not, and any kind of stampede that might or might not be generated in that direction will be limited by the amount of accommodation that's available.

DM: You came into this film quite late - Roger Michell was originally going to direct it, but unfortunately suffered a heart attack

JM: From which he's recovered, I hasten to add. And he's made another film since.

DM: At what stage did you get involved?

JM: Well, Roger had just completed Notting Hill and was resuming work on a script that had been in development by Shawn and Kevin Loader, the producer, after about a year's hiatus, I think I'm right in saying, then fell ill. At that point, the medical advice he was given was that he should think very carefully about whether or not he should proceed with this. Roger is somebody I know, and he and Kevin and Working Title approached me saying that should Roger not be able to proceed, would it be something I would be willing to think about?

DM: Had you read Captain Corelli's Mandolin?

JM: I had not read the book, no. I read the script first and was enormously beguiled, but I didn't think it worked as a film. Then I read the book and I read the book again and I said, 'Alright. I'm absolutely on for this, but I have to go back and start from scratch.

DM: Had it already been cast?

JM: No, it hadn't. Nicolas Cage was committed to the project which, since I'm sure I'm amongst a group of people who are aware of how these things work, had made the film a 'Go' project - meaning that they people were prepared to commit to vastly less than the film was going to cost, which is how these things work. So it was a Go project in that sense, but Nick was the only element that was committed, and he was committed to the project, though not necessarily the script at that point.

DM: And you had to rewrite the script for this man, Shawn?

Shawn Slovo: Well, any director who comes on will have his own take on how he sees the film. I think it's a miracle I survived the transition, really, given the number of credits you see on films. I had a lot of support from John and the producers, so I saw it through from beginning to end.

DM: How did you originally write the script? Were you given an offer to write it, or did you just write it yourself?

SS: No. Kevin Loader optioned the book together with Roger Michell and together they took it to Working Title, who agreed to finance the development. Working Title brought me onboard because I have a long-standing relationship with them.

DM: After A World Apart?

SS: Yes. The first film I made, and the only other film I've had made, was with Working Title way back in their early days.

DM: There's been some argument about the changes made from book to film. Are you happy with those changes? Are you both happy with the ending, because it's very different from the book? Why did you change the ending?

JM: I have to take responsibility for this. This is part of a much larger argument which I'm happy to discuss. You take on any kind of a book and you have to consider it from a cinematic perspective. You have to consider why you were attracted to it in terms of what it's saying, what its world is, what its characters are and what its themes are. Then you have to examine the narrative means that are already in place in the novel.

It was never, for its manifold virtues and extraordinary qualities, a narrative that could be replicated on screen. In simple terms, and I can talk about it completely mechanically, I felt it was a matter of analysing - and I would stress before I say this that it is a book that invites an extraordinary range of interpretations of its major themes, love, waste, war, survival, continuity, political factionalism - the end of the book, which was not achievable cinematically. The artifice that would have been needed to realise it - the layers of prosthetic make up needed to age the actors - would explode people out of the film in a way that I think would not have been helpful. Never mind the editorial and grammatical effort involved in jumping from the climax in the film to a time that distant.

To me it was more a matter of taking the elements involved, which meant analysing Corelli's departure from the island and then his return and how that would play out for the characters in that situation. Whatever perspective it's now viewed from, I can argue quite happily about why I came to the conclusions that I did. There was never in my mind any sense that I was doing a disservice to the book by changing that ending, nor do I think that Louis thinks that either.

DM: Do you think that there was one theme when you wrote the script that was more important to you than others? Did you think it was a love story?

SS: I think that's what I was most interested in, and that is the hook. The relationship between those two characters takes you through the film. As anyone who has read the book will know, there is so much more, there's such a myriad of characters to follow, but you only have two hours of film.

DM: You have to simplify it in some way. And I don't mean that rudely.

SS: Well, yes. We try to get the Carlo story working as well, which is one of the strongest elements in the book. Carlo has a homosexual love longing with Corelli. The time spent on that took away from the main story, so we kind of lost that in the process.

DM: What about the political aspect of the book? He was very rude about the Greek communists, wasn't he? That wasn't in the film, was it?

SS: Well we haven't negated it. It's true that there were atrocities on all sides, including the Greek partisan sides, during that struggle. I think that when you see the girl hanging that that is an indication. When you're doing something that is about the Second World War, about the extent of the German massacre on the island, the Germans are the villains of the piece, really. I think that also it is historically accurate that the partisans were allied with the Italians in the fight against the Germans, so that's something we've brought to the fore.

DM: And the character of her lover, hasn't that been changed from the book?

SS: Mandras? Well I think he was quite a victim. He started off as a simple fisherman who goes to war and is brutalised by the war.

JM: Hangs out with the communists and becomes corrupted

SS: He returns and attempts to rape Pelagia. There was an attempt to give him more of a journey and more dignity. I always felt that the stronger the relationship between him and Pelagia, the stronger that would make the relationship between Corelli and Pelagia.

DM: Have you had any criticism politically from Italians or the Greeks, or is it too early to say?

JM: Well the film hasn't really opened there yet. It's no secret that the partisan issue is one of immense political sensitivity in Greece, the book of course has run into great controversy. In papers here, this was assumed to be an enormous obstacle in the making of the film. It was suggested that there was great resentment and hostility, and I can vouch that there was. It is a complicated and difficult issue.

I think it is assumed that we have taken a line in the film that has avoided those issues. I think I'm the best person to argue for that, because the transformation of the Mandras character was essentially a development that I brought to the film, which had no political motivation I have to say, but a dramatic motivation. I don't think that a film could take on the complexities of those arguments and still function.

The book has an astonishing amplitude and range of reference; it is very digressive and jumps across locales. It spends time with Mandras and Hector and so forth in the ideological indoctrination and the beginnings of factionalism that led to the Greek civil war. In film terms, you simply have to create a hierarchy - what is the story? That would never have been in the brief of the film. Mandras' character and development had more to do with the way that character functions in the central story.

The book presents you with certain challenges when trying to present a film story because the characters are strangely disconnected from one another's lives and experiences in the book. For example, Mandras and Corelli never meet in the book at all. The relationship Pelagia has with Mandras is over before Corelli arrives. The relationship with Corelli, the atrocities and the departure from the island is all over before Mandras returns. In simple dramatic terms, that seemed to me to be a lost opportunity. Not that that's a problem in the book, but in terms of examining that in the film, making every character's relationship to the central characters something organic, that was the idea at work.

The Carlo situation is a similar one. Creating that hierarchy is a disappointing one in some ways because you're desperate to produce the richness of the book in the film as far as you can, and I struggled - I would like to say heroically - with Shawn, in order to bring that into the story, but in the end all we were doing was tokenising the story. We decided on a more radical inversion of that character that allowed him to work cinematically in a slightly different way.

At the same time you are creating a piece that you hope stands alongside the book, independently of the book - because there'll be many people who will see the film who haven't read the book and I hope will then go to the book - but you will never do anyone a service by simply treading in the footsteps of the book.

DM: You did as far as locations are concerned. Most films aren't shot on location, was it easy to choose the right location?

JM: It was very hot and logistically seemed suicidal in many ways. Not so much of the money ends up onscreen theoretically because the reality is that it is an island and there is no infrastructure for making a film. You have to bring all the crew in from elsewhere in Greece. Obviously vast numbers of the construction crew were on the island, as you can see from the number of family names that crop up in the credits. Nevertheless, the majority of the crew has to be brought there and housed and everything else. Every single element of the production design was imported because every building was flattened by the earthquake of 1953, and destroyed everything pre-1953.

DM: Absolutely everything?

JM: Well, the only real house in it, oddly enough, is the scene that takes place at the beginning of the film where the pea is extracted from Stamatis's ear, that one building exists but everything else you see is built. In industry terms it made no sense, but in every other way, and ultimately in industry terms, it made a lot of sense. The film was very economic to make, but more significantly there was a quality about the island and the light and most significantly a quality about the people and the experiences that they'd had that was an invaluable resource for the film and kept us honest in a way.

We were able to create, in a film grammar now of such sophistication it doesn't seem to be necessary, but we were able to connect one place to another on the island. You could see the village from the doctor's house, you could relate the beach that we'd decided to locate the Italian encampment on and so on. Some smell and dust and so forth of the actual experience that makes up the experience of that island, not to mention the cicadas, translates into the film and can't be eradicated from the film, even with modern technology - that was amazing.

Particularly for me, when I went to the island and at the point I came onto the film, the island was a possibility for the film, Corfu was another favoured possibility, I was overwhelmed by the visual iconography of the place. By which I mean the rubble of the destruction, the routine destruction in historical terms of that island, is everywhere evident. They simply move down the hill and build the village again. They don't really bother to remove the rubble or indeed they build the house on top of the rubble of the one just destroyed. Something about that sense resonated incredibly for me with the themes of the book that I responded to that were to do with healing and regeneration and continuity and survival. My first instinct was how are we going to do this? We would have to hide the earthquake because it doesn't happen in the book and it wasn't in the script that I originally received. Then I felt that actually the opposite was true and it was a visual metaphor that was available all the time and crucial to the whole experience and meaning of the film.

DM: Were you there during the shoot, Shawn? Did you feel like you wanted to change some things when you got there?

SS: I think I was there because John came on so late

JM: I'd have had you there anyway

SS: Soon you'll have no choice - you'll have me on the call sheet and the clapperboard. Because John came in so late there was stuff that was unfinished. Because there was so much going on for him we couldn't actually focus until the end. Things kept changing

JM: Yes, we kept working on it right until the end of the film.

SS: It was a very dynamic process, it was very exciting.

DM: It's not very often you can do that as a writer.

SS: I don't think so, no.

JM: That's why she was the only writer. I don't think I could have had ten of them there

DM: Do you think it would ever be possible to make that sort of film with Italians playing Italians, Greeks playing Greeks and so on?

JM: I think in all honesty, no. No. I would love it to be possible but I think the resources to realise a film of this size would prohibit it. I was not involved in the financing process of it, but as I referred to earlier, I'm not saying it was a prerequisite that we had an American actor. We might have had an Australian actor, guess who, we might have had an English actor, guess who, we might have had an Irish actor

DM: Well, who?

JM: Whether we could have had an Italian actorcertainly if I'd had been in at that part of the game and I had looked there and had found that actor I would not have hesitated to fight for that tooth and nail. Do I, in the reality of my own experience, think that that would have been possible without some counterbalance somewhere else, I don't think so.

You make movies these days within a contextual reality. You shouldn't really attempt this sort of movie given the kind of resources it commands without to some extent absorbing that reality and accepting that reality.

DM: The reality is that you have to sell in the American market? I'm not criticising

JM: I don't take it as a criticism. You're stating a fact. I think that is probably true in terms of the first equation that has to be made. Take, for example, Enemy at the Gate, which is entirely European financed and does not have an American headlining star. It has two or three big English names and was made through a consortium and cost considerably more than this

DM: The most expensive European film ever, I believe.

JM: Indeed. This is a great development in the British movie industry that Jude Law, Rachel Weisz and Jo Fiennes are considered to be of a magnitude in the world market that justifies that kind of investment. Whether or not a relatively unknown Italian actor and Greek actress, who again we certainly would have cast - Viki Maragaki who plays Eleni was an actress who Roger Michell was looking at and certainly I was too - even with a European consortium could have sold the film, I very much doubt.

DM: Is it not possible for a film to be successful in Europe and elsewhere without an American star for the American market?

JM: No, I didn't say that. I don't think that the film would ever have been paid for. I think that that's the crucial issue, not whether it would have been successful. Unfortunately it's hard to get to the point where you can make that argument. But it has to do with the scale and ambition of the movie you're making. Wonderful movies are made that cost infinitely less than that. If you know you're going to take on this sort of story you know that it has a certain kind of scale and that's something you choose to accept or you don't. At the point that that particular choice presented itself to me, I made a decision, which is why I'm here.

DM: Well, you've made three pretty successful decisions up to now. Do you think this is luck or good management?

JM: Very kind of you to say so!

DM: Well, I think this will make its money back, if nothing else.

JM: Please quote that! We're going to put it on the posters tomorrow! I think the answer to your question is that luck is never far away. It's a very odd business.

DM: You must have been very surprised, for instance, with Mrs Brown.

JM: Well, yes. Incredibly surprised. All I ever think about is is this movie something I can muster my belief in sufficiently to carry everyone with you that you need to make the film? Will it work on its own terms? I don't think about the larger landscape, including this film, until now. It's very hard to know what contributes to it. I didn't know how Mrs Brown would turn out, though I certainly hoped that the film would end up in the cinema as it did. I had no expectation of where Shakespeare In Love would end up, I imagined it might work for a small coterie of people that had the same interest that I had. Likewise this. You just get on and make the film. You don't think about the rest of it.

DM: And there's a lot of bad luck too. A World Apart was a very good film and never really did the business that was hoped.

SS: That proves the importance of distribution, that's what it proves. The American backers went bankrupt so there were, I think, sixteen prints in the whole of America. It doesn't matter how good the film is if not enough people can get to see it. Thank you for that.

DM: I'm sure there's some questions.

Q1: Could you explain the process by which you wrote the script? Did Shawn write it and then John made his comments? To what extent was it working together and how did that change during the shoot?

SS: It was a truly collaborative process, which is, I think, the best you can hope for in screenwriting - to be working with the director. We worked intensely together. We had long discussions in John's kitchen with Irena Brignall who was the story editor, brought in to speed up the process. John and Irena, because we had so little time, would plot ahead. John was also working out the film in his mind to make it his. I would go away and write, present the pages and then get brought up to speed, then go away and write. I wasn't dictated to, I have to say. That was the process.

JM: It was very intense and very compressed because I originally assumed that the timetable of the film was very flexible, but Nicholas Cage had a John Woo picture to do and all we could do in the end was move their picture back a couple of weeks and frontload the schedule, so that most of Nick's work was done at the beginning. We had five months from when I came on board to assemble the film and rewrite it from scratch, which was an educational and thrilling process.

The normal process of writing a script is normally a discussion followed by a complete draft from a writer which you then turn over and discuss and then the writer comes up with another draft. That wasn't possible in this case.

SS: That was the way I worked with Roger, but we had four years.

JM: And no deadline. Then suddenly we had a deadline and nothing else! It's not to say that Roger's script might not have gone on to develop in another way. It's got nothing to do with ego, but as a director you have to commit to and be accountable for every single decision and moment in the film because they'll be thousands of decisions that rest on that one choice. So you've got to know where you are and believe in it. It's a massive book and you have to say, 'This is my way through this book'.

The process of working on it was a weird one because you'd get so far and then before you could ratify that you had to go back and make other changes, so we really didn't ever get as far as a first draft of the script until about a month before we were due to go there. That's when Louis came into the equation. At my behest we left certain parts of the film in what I would call a holding pattern, they were stacked up and waiting to land. As the identity of the film began to emerge in the shooting process, certain ideas started to slot into place about the form the script should take. That went on for the whole period we were shooting.

Q: With regard to the finance, is it possible to open up to small investors, like a sort of stock market?

JM: An extraordinary amount of imagination is used now in the financing of movies. As regards to the financing of this movie, many of those elements were already in place. I don't know if I'm the best person to speak about that at this juncture, but that certainly is a way of going, but it's extraordinarily difficult. The huge struggle for many movies is to put the finance in place and for everybody to lock and agree that the financing is there. Almost always that financing is based on elements that are involved in the film that give the investors some guarantee of visibility, some sense that the movie can open because of the interest generated by the elements involved and those are things you don't know in advance.

The more expensive the film, the more difficult it becomes.

DM: Is it getting easier or more difficult to write an intelligent script? How easy is it to get it through?

SS: You mean to get an intelligent script made? I think that there is a dumbing down at every single level because films are so expensive people are unwilling to take risks. Independent film-making is not what it was and theatres are closing all over the country here, independent theatres.

DM: But audiences are increasing, but for the same old films.

SS: It's youth that goes to the cinema, and they seem quite happy with what they get. For older people it's getting harder and harder to find something interesting to see at the cinema.

JM: Those kind of films do get through, but they're the ones that come from behind and buck the system. I think in mainstream movie-making your question is a valid one. I think that even if a script does break through, certain pressures are brought to bear on it that threaten the degree of new territory it's carving out.

Q: How did Nicolas Cage become involved and what influence did he have on how the film was made?

JM: The answer is he became involved because he was enormously attracted to the material. He did the movie for a fraction of his normal price - still expensive, but not punitively expensive. He is an actor who I would fly the flag for whether he was in my film or not because he is an actor who is hungry and curious and to some extent swims in the mainstream precisely because it gives him the opportunity to swim up the tributaries now and then. The film for which he is most applauded for is a film nobody in the mainstream would have made, Leaving Las Vegas. He is attracted to areas he has not explored as an actor before, and that is to be applauded in a business where you are encouraged to stay exactly where you are.

Also, he had never made a film outside of America. I'm not sure he'd left California, God bless him.

SS: He experienced jetlag!

JM: That's why he took it on. The only way in which he affected production where circumstances not really under his control which had to do with deadlines. He is a consummate professional. A man without any grandeur on the set. He comes, like any actor, you hope, very well prepared having thought incredibly hard about what he's doing, with a suitcase full of nutty ideas. The first rehearsal of any scene was always entertaining, and he's very happy to put those ideas back in the suitcase, and frequently he did. He's completely delightful, serious, professional, imaginative and daring.

For an actor who is pretty much at the top of the tree in the system, I love that about him. I think he is a top man and he has been completely supportive of the film and he will go anywhere to support it, within the terms of his own schedule, and good for him.

Q: What was it like to work with Pénelope Cruz?

JM: She's an actress in a very peculiar position at the moment. She is a hugely well-respected actress in Spain who has done an enormous range of work. She is somebody who, because of the way she looks and because of the sequence of movies she has made, has got a profile which belies who she really is. This culminated in a scurrilous and disgusting article that appeared, I think, in ES magazine, and whoever wrote it had no right to do so, because she is the most real person imaginable.

She is an actress of extraordinary skill and you can compare her to Liv Ulman, who I've also worked with. She has a capacity to reveal herself, simply open herself to the camera, not to indicate anything, not to put a spin on anything. I think she's an extraordinary talent who has a fantastic future. She must now continue to work in her own culture, and she's making a film in Spain as we speak. I think you're only just beginning to see what she's capable of. She can transform herself, in this film, from someone who is eighteen years of age to someone who carries the weight and melancholy of someone who is three times that age.

Q: That's a very different Pénelope Cruz from the Pénelope Cruz in the magazines.

JM: Well, I hope so. Because she is somebody who is happy to have her photograph taken, all kinds of motives are imputed to her, it seems, that are without justification. She was on the island the entire time with her family, eating at the next-door table to us all the time. She is someone who is born to act, I think, she naturally inhabits other personae with an invisible grace and skill, but she's, above all, real. She knows who she is, she knows who her friends are, she knows what life's about, she won't mind if it all goes away, which it won't and I'm astonished at the degree of cynicism there is about that.

I'm astonished in one way, and in another I'm not. We all have to work within this system of hype and so forth. She is somebody who has got used to the way the press manipulate her.

Q: Can you tell us about the involvement of Louis De Bernières?

JM: Well Louis was offered the opportunity to adapt the material and write it for a film, but nothing would bore him more, I think. Film writing is a completely inferior process.

SS: He says it's lower than being a schoolteacher.

JM: He had no interest in that. He had interest only in the fact that the film was made by a British company and in Europe with European sensibilities in mind. That was his concern, and that was fulfilled when Working Title became involved. Aside from reading the draft of the script as it came along, he was very happy to be at arm length. My normal instinct would have been to absolutely rope him into the process, but under the circumstances under which I came into the film, I simply could not do that because of the constraints I was under. There wasn't time.

I had to essentially go to him with a first draft of the script which he was alarmed and intrigued by. He came out and joined us on the film for two or three weeks while we were shooting and he had a whale of a time. He didn't really come back into the process until I showed him my first cut of the film and he was, I think, rather thrilled and rather baffled. He is a great friend of Esther Freud who is married to David Morrissey who plays Weber in the film, so I knew he was terrified of seeing it because he was terrified of it being absolutely awful. He was terrified also that it might be rather good. I imagine he found it to be somewhere in-between. I don't know. He was very excited, but still not quite sure. He saw it again a month later and became very pleased with it. He's now seen it six times and he's very happy.

I have to say that given the journalistic line about us being unfaithful to the book, he has an absolutely admirable attitude which is that the film and the book must be seen as two different things. As long as I'm committed to the emotional arc of the story, then fine. The book will always be there on the shelves and hopefully many people will go back and read it. He is incredibly funny and loose about it and was as involved as he wanted to be really.

JM: No. It's way down the league table. DM But it won't be anymore, will it? JM: Well, it's a complicated business really. There'll be many people on the island who'll be absolutely delighted - they're already delighted, I think, with the attention they've got from the book. The artifice that would have been needed to realise it - the layers of prosthetic make up needed to age the actors - would explode people out of the film in a way that I think would not have been helpful. Whatever perspective it's now viewed from, I can argue quite happily about why I came to the conclusions that I did. DM: Do you think that there was one theme when you wrote the script that was more important to you than others? Did you think it was a love story? SS: I think that's what I was most interested in, and that is the hook. The relationship between those two characters takes you through the film. That wasn't in the film, was it? SS: Well we haven't negated it. It's true that there were atrocities on all sides, including the Greek partisan sides, during that struggle. I think that when you see the girl hanging that that is an indication. When you're doing something that is about the Second World War, about the extent of the German massacre on the island, the Germans are the villains of the piece, really. I think that also it is historically accurate that the partisans were allied with the Italians in the fight against the Germans, so that's something we've brought to the fore. DM: And the character of her lover, hasn't that been changed from the book? SS: Mandras? Well I think he was quite a victim. He started off as a simple fisherman who goes to war and is brutalised by the war. JM: Hangs out with the communists and becomes corrupted SS: He returns and attempts to rape Pelagia. There was an attempt to give him more of a journey and more dignity. I always felt that the stronger the relationship between him and Pelagia, the stronger that would make the relationship between Corelli and Pelagia. DM: Have you had any criticism politically from Italians or the Greeks, or is it too early to say? JM: Well the film hasn't really opened there yet. It's no secret that the partisan issue is one of immense political sensitivity in Greece, the book of course has run into great controversy. In papers here, this was assumed to be an enormous obstacle in the making of the film. It was suggested that there was great resentment and hostility, and I can vouch that there was. It is a complicated and difficult issue. I think it is assumed that we have taken a line in the film that has avoided those issues. I think I'm the best person to argue for that, because the transformation of the Mandras character was essentially a development that I brought to the film, which had no political motivation I have to say, but a dramatic motivation. I don't think that a film could take on the complexities of those arguments and still function. The book has an astonishing amplitude and range of reference; it is very digressive and jumps across locales. It spends time with Mandras and Hector and so forth in the ideological indoctrination and the beginnings of factionalism that led to the Greek civil war. In film terms, you simply have to create a hierarchy - what is the story? That would never have been in the brief of the film. Mandras' character and development had more to do with the way that character functions in the central story. The book presents you with certain challenges when trying to present a film story because the characters are strangely disconnected from one another's lives and experiences in the book. For example, Mandras and Corelli never meet in the book at all. The relationship Pelagia has with Mandras is over before Corelli arrives. The relationship with Corelli, the atrocities and the departure from the island is all over before Mandras returns. In simple dramatic terms, that seemed to me to be a lost opportunity. Not that that's a problem in the book, but in terms of examining that in the film, making every character's relationship to the central characters something organic, that was the idea at work. The Carlo situation is a similar one. Creating that hierarchy is a disappointing one in some ways because you're desperate to produce the richness of the book in the film as far as you can, and I struggled - I would like to say heroically - with Shawn, in order to bring that into the story, but in the end all we were doing was tokenising the story. We decided on a more radical inversion of that character that allowed him to work cinematically in a slightly different way. At the same time you are creating a piece that you hope stands alongside the book, independently of the book - because there'll be many people who will see the film who haven't read the book and I hope will then go to the book - but you will never do anyone a service by simply treading in the footsteps of the book. DM: You did as far as locations are concerned. Most films aren't shot on location, was it easy to choose the right location? JM: It was very hot and logistically seemed suicidal in many ways. Not so much of the money ends up onscreen theoretically because the reality is that it is an island and there is no infrastructure for making a film. You have to bring all the crew in from elsewhere in Greece. Obviously vast numbers of the construction crew were on the island, as you can see from the number of family names that crop up in the credits. Nevertheless, the majority of the crew has to be brought there and housed and everything else. Every single element of the production design was imported because every building was flattened by the earthquake of 1953, and destroyed everything pre-1953. DM: Absolutely everything? JM: Well, the only real house in it, oddly enough, is the scene that takes place at the beginning of the film where the pea is extracted from Stamatis's ear, that one building exists but everything else you see is built. In industry terms it made no sense, but in every other way, and ultimately in industry terms, it made a lot of sense. The film was very economic to make, but more significantly there was a quality about the island and the light and most significantly a quality about the people and the experiences that they'd had that was an invaluable resource for the film and kept us honest in a way. We were able to create, in a film grammar now of such sophistication it doesn't seem to be necessary, but we were able to connect one place to another on the island. You could see the village from the doctor's house, you could relate the beach that we'd decided to locate the Italian encampment on and so on. Some smell and dust and so forth of the actual experience that makes up the experience of that island, not to mention the cicadas, translates into the film and can't be eradicated from the film, even with modern technology - that was amazing. Particularly for me, when I went to the island and at the point I came onto the film, the island was a possibility for the film, Corfu was another favoured possibility, I was overwhelmed by the visual iconography of the place. By which I mean the rubble of the destruction, the routine destruction in historical terms of that island, is everywhere evident. They simply move down the hill and build the village again. They don't really bother to remove the rubble or indeed they build the house on top of the rubble of the one just destroyed. Something about that sense resonated incredibly for me with the themes of the book that I responded to that were to do with healing and regeneration and continuity and survival. My first instinct was how are we going to do this? We would have to hide the earthquake because it doesn't happen in the book and it wasn't in the script that I originally received. Then I felt that actually the opposite was true and it was a visual metaphor that was available all the time and crucial to the whole experience and meaning of the film. DM: Were you there during the shoot, Shawn? Did you feel like you wanted to change some things when you got there? SS: I think I was there because John came on so late JM: I'd have had you there anyway SS: Soon you'll have no choice - you'll have me on the call sheet and the clapperboard. Because John came in so late there was stuff that was unfinished. Because there was so much going on for him we couldn't actually focus until the end. Things kept changing JM: Yes, we kept working on it right until the end of the film. SS: It was a very dynamic process, it was very exciting. DM: It's not very often you can do that as a writer. SS: I don't think so, no. JM: That's why she was the only writer. I don't think I could have had ten of them there DM: Do you think it would ever be possible to make that sort of film with Italians playing Italians, Greeks playing Greeks and so on? JM: I think in all honesty, no. No. I would love it to be possible but I think the resources to realise a film of this size would prohibit it. I was not involved in the financing process of it, but as I referred to earlier, I'm not saying it was a prerequisite that we had an American actor. We might have had an Australian actor, guess who, we might have had an English actor, guess who, we might have had an Irish actor DM: Well, who? JM: Whether we could have had an Italian actorcertainly if I'd had been in at that part of the game and I had looked there and had found that actor I would not have hesitated to fight for that tooth and nail. Do I, in the reality of my own experience, think that that would have been possible without some counterbalance somewhere else, I don't think so. You make movies these days within a contextual reality. You shouldn't really attempt this sort of movie given the kind of resources it commands without to some extent absorbing that reality and accepting that reality. DM: The reality is that you have to sell in the American market? I'm not criticising JM: I don't take it as a criticism. You're stating a fact. I think that is probably true in terms of the first equation that has to be made. Take, for example, Enemy at the Gate, which is entirely European financed and does not have an American headlining star. It has two or three big English names and was made through a consortium and cost considerably more than this DM: The most expensive European film ever, I believe. JM: Indeed. This is a great development in the British movie industry that Jude Law, Rachel Weisz and Jo Fiennes are considered to be of a magnitude in the world market that justifies that kind of investment. Whether or not a relatively unknown Italian actor and Greek actress, who again we certainly would have cast - Viki Maragaki who plays Eleni was an actress who Roger Michell was looking at and certainly I was too - even with a European consortium could have sold the film, I very much doubt. DM: Is it not possible for a film to be successful in Europe and elsewhere without an American star for the American market? JM: No, I didn't say that. I don't think that the film would ever have been paid for. I think that that's the crucial issue, not whether it would have been successful. Unfortunately it's hard to get to the point where you can make that argument. But it has to do with the scale and ambition of the movie you're making. Wonderful movies are made that cost infinitely less than that. If you know you're going to take on this sort of story you know that it has a certain kind of scale and that's something you choose to accept or you don't. At the point that that particular choice presented itself to me, I made a decision, which is why I'm here. DM: Well, you've made three pretty successful decisions up to now. Do you think this is luck or good management? JM: Very kind of you to say so! DM: Well, I think this will make its money back, if nothing else. JM: Please quote that! We're going to put it on the posters tomorrow! I think the answer to your question is that luck is never far away. It's a very odd business. DM: You must have been very surprised, for instance, with Mrs Brown. JM: Well, yes. Incredibly surprised. All I ever think about is is this movie something I can muster my belief in sufficiently to carry everyone with you that you need to make the film? Will it work on its own terms? I don't think about the larger landscape, including this film, until now. It's very hard to know what contributes to it. I didn't know how Mrs Brown would turn out, though I certainly hoped that the film would end up in the cinema as it did. I had no expectation of where Shakespeare In Love would end up, I imagined it might work for a small coterie of people that had the same interest that I had. Likewise this. You just get on and make the film. You don't think about the rest of it. DM: And there's a lot of bad luck too. A World Apart was a very good film and never really did the business that was hoped. SS: That proves the importance of distribution, that's what it proves. The American backers went bankrupt so there were, I think, sixteen prints in the whole of America. It doesn't matter how good the film is if not enough people can get to see it. Thank you for that. DM: I'm sure there's some questions. Q1: Could you explain the process by which you wrote the script? Did Shawn write it and then John made his comments? To what extent was it working together and how did that change during the shoot? SS: It was a truly collaborative process, which is, I think, the best you can hope for in screenwriting - to be working with the director. We worked intensely together. We had long discussions in John's kitchen with Irena Brignall who was the story editor, brought in to speed up the process. John and Irena, because we had so little time, would plot ahead. John was also working out the film in his mind to make it his. I would go away and write, present the pages and then get brought up to speed, then go away and write. I wasn't dictated to, I have to say. That was the process. JM: It was very intense and very compressed because I originally assumed that the timetable of the film was very flexible, but Nicholas Cage had a John Woo picture to do and all we could do in the end was move their picture back a couple of weeks and frontload the schedule, so that most of Nick's work was done at the beginning. We had five months from when I came on board to assemble the film and rewrite it from scratch, which was an educational and thrilling process. The normal process of writing a script is normally a discussion followed by a complete draft from a writer which you then turn over and discuss and then the writer comes up with another draft. That wasn't possible in this case. SS: That was the way I worked with Roger, but we had four years. JM: And no deadline. Then suddenly we had a deadline and nothing else! It's not to say that Roger's script might not have gone on to develop in another way. It's got nothing to do with ego, but as a director you have to commit to and be accountable for every single decision and moment in the film because they'll be thousands of decisions that rest on that one choice. So you've got to know where you are and believe in it. It's a massive book and you have to say, 'This is my way through this book'. The process of working on it was a weird one because you'd get so far and then before you could ratify that you had to go back and make other changes, so we really didn't ever get as far as a first draft of the script until about a month before we were due to go there. That's when Louis came into the equation. At my behest we left certain parts of the film in what I would call a holding pattern, they were stacked up and waiting to land. As the identity of the film began to emerge in the shooting process, certain ideas started to slot into place about the form the script should take. That went on for the whole period we were shooting. Q: With regard to the finance, is it possible to open up to small investors, like a sort of stock market? JM: An extraordinary amount of imagination is used now in the financing of movies. As regards to the financing of this movie, many of those elements were already in place. I don't know if I'm the best person to speak about that at this juncture, but that certainly is a way of going, but it's extraordinarily difficult. The huge struggle for many movies is to put the finance in place and for everybody to lock and agree that the financing is there. Almost always that financing is based on elements that are involved in the film that give the investors some guarantee of visibility, some sense that the movie can open because of the interest generated by the elements involved and those are things you don't know in advance. The more expensive the film, the more difficult it becomes. DM: Is it getting easier or more difficult to write an intelligent script? How easy is it to get it through? SS: You mean to get an intelligent script made? I think that there is a dumbing down at every single level because films are so expensive people are unwilling to take risks. Independent film-making is not what it was and theatres are closing all over the country here, independent theatres. DM: But audiences are increasing, but for the same old films. SS: It's youth that goes to the cinema, and they seem quite happy with what they get. For older people it's getting harder and harder to find something interesting to see at the cinema. JM: Those kind of films do get through, but they're the ones that come from behind and buck the system. I think in mainstream movie-making your question is a valid one. I think that even if a script does break through, certain pressures are brought to bear on it that threaten the degree of new territory it's carving out. Q: How did Nicolas Cage become involved and what influence did he have on how the film was made? JM: The answer is he became involved because he was enormously attracted to the material. He did the movie for a fraction of his normal price - still expensive, but not punitively expensive. He is an actor who I would fly the flag for whether he was in my film or not because he is an actor who is hungry and curious and to some extent swims in the mainstream precisely because it gives him the opportunity to swim up the tributaries now and then. The film for which he is most applauded for is a film nobody in the mainstream would have made, Leaving Las Vegas. He is attracted to areas he has not explored as an actor before, and that is to be applauded in a business where you are encouraged to stay exactly where you are. Also, he had never made a film outside of America. I'm not sure he'd left California, God bless him. SS: He experienced jetlag! JM: That's why he took it on. The only way in which he affected production where circumstances not really under his control which had to do with deadlines. He is a consummate professional. A man without any grandeur on the set. He comes, like any actor, you hope, very well prepared having thought incredibly hard about what he's doing, with a suitcase full of nutty ideas. The first rehearsal of any scene was always entertaining, and he's very happy to put those ideas back in the suitcase, and frequently he did. He's completely delightful, serious, professional, imaginative and daring. For an actor who is pretty much at the top of the tree in the system, I love that about him. I think he is a top man and he has been completely supportive of the film and he will go anywhere to support it, within the terms of his own schedule, and good for him. Q: What was it like to work with Pénelope Cruz? JM: She's an actress in a very peculiar position at the moment. She is a hugely well-respected actress in Spain who has done an enormous range of work. She is somebody who, because of the way she looks and because of the sequence of movies she has made, has got a profile which belies who she really is. This culminated in a scurrilous and disgusting article that appeared, I think, in ES magazine, and whoever wrote it had no right to do so, because she is the most real person imaginable. She is an actress of extraordinary skill and you can compare her to Liv Ulman, who I've also worked with. She has a capacity to reveal herself, simply open herself to the camera, not to indicate anything, not to put a spin on anything. I think she's an extraordinary talent who has a fantastic future. She must now continue to work in her own culture, and she's making a film in Spain as we speak. I think you're only just beginning to see what she's capable of. She can transform herself, in this film, from someone who is eighteen years of age to someone who carries the weight and melancholy of someone who is three times that age. Q: That's a very different Pénelope Cruz from the Pénelope Cruz in the magazines. JM: Well, I hope so. Because she is somebody who is happy to have her photograph taken, all kinds of motives are imputed to her, it seems, that are without justification. She was on the island the entire time with her family, eating at the next-door table to us all the time. She is someone who is born to act, I think, she naturally inhabits other personae with an invisible grace and skill, but she's, above all, real. She knows who she is, she knows who her friends are, she knows what life's about, she won't mind if it all goes away, which it won't and I'm astonished at the degree of cynicism there is about that. I'm astonished in one way, and in another I'm not. We all have to work within this system of hype and so forth. She is somebody who has got used to the way the press manipulate her. Q: Can you tell us about the involvement of Louis De Bernières? JM: Well Louis was offered the opportunity to adapt the material and write it for a film, but nothing would bore him more, I think. Film writing is a completely inferior process. SS: He says it's lower than being a schoolteacher. JM: He had no interest in that. He had interest only in the fact that the film was made by a British company and in Europe with European sensibilities in mind. That was his concern, and that was fulfilled when Working Title became involved. Aside from reading the draft of the script as it came along, he was very happy to be at arm length. My normal instinct would have been to absolutely rope him into the process, but under the circumstances under which I came into the film, I simply could not do that because of the constraints I was under. There wasn't time. I had to essentially go to him with a first draft of the script which he was alarmed and intrigued by. He came out and joined us on the film for two or three weeks while we were shooting and he had a whale of a time. He didn't really come back into the process until I showed him my first cut of the film and he was, I think, rather thrilled and rather baffled. He is a great friend of Esther Freud who is married to David Morrissey who plays Weber in the film, so I knew he was terrified of seeing it because he was terrified of it being absolutely awful. He was terrified also that it might be rather good. I imagine he found it to be somewhere in-between. I don't know. He was very excited, but still not quite sure. He saw it again a month later and became very pleased with it. He's now seen it six times and he's very happy. I have to say that given the journalistic line about us being unfaithful to the book, he has an absolutely admirable attitude which is that the film and the book must be seen as two different things. As long as I'm committed to the emotional arc of the story, then fine. The book will always be there on the shelves and hopefully many people will go back and read it. He is incredibly funny and loose about it and was as involved as he wanted to be really.

fields.headline: The task ahead
fields.trailText: Patrick Wintour describes the task facing the three party leaders who will have to undergo the bubble of exhaustion, self-doubt, fear and extraordinary feats of logistics that is the election campaign.
fields.body:
Party political leaders in today's increasingly presidential election campaigns survive in a bubble of exhaustion, self-doubt, fear and extraordinary feats of logistics.

Rumours abound and egos grate. Highs, as voters respond warmly to the candidate on the stump, or a poll signals a turning of the tide, can be followed by moments of grim realism or explosive anger at some crass mistake within the campaign team. It all requires an extraordinary self-discipline, stagecraft and resilience.

For two candidates this time, the pressures will be a novel experience. In 1997 William Hague spent his time in the obscurity of Wales watching Tory held seats fall to Labour. Charles Kennedy can claim the experience of chairing the party's 1994 European election campaign, but spent much of 1997 in Skye. Only Blair has undergone the rigours of an election campaign.

No leader will be under greater personal pressure than the 40-year-old Hague, and no leader on the surface seems better equipped to handle it. He appears to have superhuman strengths of resilience and seems unaffected by criticism. Some put it down to judo, some to transcendental calm and others to his private belief that he doesn't expect to win this election.

The mystery is what kind of image he will present on the stump. He has flirted with so many different persona, it is difficult to predict. He has been the multicultural carnival jiver, the Sun-reading man in the white van, the political trainspotter, the drunken Yorkshireman, the husband of glamour and the management consultant in the double-breasted suit. Yet his personal ratings remain doggedly miserable. He is widely seen as a drag on the party's poll standing. Despite the best efforts of Amanda Platell, the word wally is beginning to hang round his neck, along with Alastair Campbell's other sobriquet, Billy Bandwagon.

As a result many observers expect the story of the election to revolve round the slow disintegration of his campaign and the increasingly open scramble for his succession. For if the media collectively decides the election is over, and become bored by the Hague-Blair contest, they will train their sights on Hague's battle to retain the leadership. It will then be difficult for him to keep his agenda running.

He may also feel politically and physically isolated, for he has elected to forego London press conferences, in favour of a regional campaign in which he may receive more sympathetic press coverage. He will also try to reproduce some of the underdog spirit. But with two of his closest advisers, George Osborne and Danny Finkelstein themselves fighting seats, he will be dependent on Michael Portillo and Francis Maude to keep him informed of the national picture and the mood within central office. To make matters worse, both men are out of sympathy with Hague's core vote campaign.

It is essential that Hague campaigns well on the stump and comes out of the election looking like a potential winner. Neil Kinnock in 1987 should be his model. If Hague retreats ever further back into the laager of Europe, asylum seekers and tax cuts, he is likely to be doomed.

By tradition, Tory MPs are not tolerant of failure. Few Conservative leaders have survived losing an election badly. Calculations abound but the message is straightforward Hague must gain seats.

Charles Kennedy also faces a difficult first outing on the stump. He has about 12% of the big parties' cash, and will rely on the broadcasting rules for TV impact. He does not have the enthusiasm for campaigns of his predecessor Paddy Ashdown. Indeed, some Liberal Democrat MPs believe Kennedy is so uneasy as party leader that he will resign after the election. Despite the bonhomie he displays in chat shows, he is prone to self-doubt. By nature he is a shy man who does not respond well to the inherent absurdities of the campaign trail. Kennedy relished the idea of TV debates between himself and the other leaders partly because it would give him the excuse to stay in London and prepare. He has even had to go on trial helicopter rides to cure himself of a fear of flying.

He does have the advantage of being a refreshing and unknown quantity for many voters. Two years after taking on the party leadership, voters still have surprising little feel for him. Some 46% of voters cannot express a view when asked. However, those that have formed an opinion do like him. A poll conducted by the party in February in 40 of its key seats show that Kennedy is trusted much more than the other two leaders.

His difficulty is that his key seats are spread across the country. In effect he will be running 50 different byelections simultaneously whilst pretending he is running a national campaign. There are worrying signs that the Lib Dem vote has fallen back most in the south-west, once a fortress for the party. The departure of Paddy Ashdown, a Yeovil MP, has depressed support in the Liberal Democrat stronghold. The party's strong pro-European views also do not help in a region so dependent on farming and fisheries.

Meanwhile Tony Blair enjoys thinking through the strategy behind campaigns, but is tired from four years at the helm in Downing Street. Instinctively, he knows when he is connecting with a campaign, and when it is missing the spot. He will have familiar and trusted faces around him, apart from Peter Mandelson, a loss to the Millbank esprit de corps. The usual team of Gordon Brown, Alastair Campbell, Philip Gould, Margaret McDonagh, Lord Irvine, and his pollster Greg Cook, will reassure him. Their aim will be to show Blair as a friendly figure in relatively small, warm and intimate surroundings - the opposite of the Sheffield rally of the 1992 election. He will be looking for what he describes as a vocabulary of achievement - a way of setting out the government's record without sounding arrogant.

Blair also needs a rhetoric to galvanise the Labour core vote, which has been turned off politics and not turned on to him personally. It will mean many unconventional appearances on apolitical soft programmes - more Richard and Judy than Paxman and Wark.

His aides say the big trick is to prevent a sense of inevitable victory and keep the Hague threat alive to play up the need to get out and vote. High turnout, after all, is essential for Blair to secure his coveted second term and a big majority.

 Patrick Wintour is chief political correspondent of the Guardian

His aides say the big trick is to prevent a sense of inevitable victory and keep the Hague threat alive to play up the need to get out and vote. High turnout, after all, is essential for Blair to secure his coveted second term and a big majority.  Patrick Wintour is chief political correspondent of the Guardian

fields.headline: Sun 'paid Biggs £350,000' to return
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The Sun promised to pay Ronnie Biggs at least £350,000 to return home, Brazilian newspapers have claimed. By Julia Day.

PCC to investigate Sun role in Biggs' return

Useful link: Sun website

Brazilian newspaper Estado.com

Brazilian newspaper O Globo.com
fields.body:
The Sun promised to pay Ronnie Biggs at least £350,000 to return home to the UK, Brazilian newspapers have claimed.

The offer lured the 60s train robber back to Britain to face justice, Mr Bigg's former lawyer, Wellington Lins, reportedly told two of the country's papers.

But a row has broken out between Mr Lins and the papers. He denied he made the comments about the bung, but the papers stand by their stories.

The reports said Mr Biggs thought the only way to leave a legacy for his partner, Raimunda, and his son, Michael, was to take the money from the Sun.

The Sun has not yet commented on the reports from Brazil.

Until now the sums involved were believed to be closer to £44,000 with £20,000 going to his son.

However, Graham Dudman, head of the Sun's team of reporters, reveals in today's paper that Biggs did make unrealistic demands.

In a piece headlined "How we got our man", Dudman describes his first meeting with the Biggs team.

"Predictably, the initial demands bordered on the absurd. 'Look fellas,' I told them, 'if you are realistic, we can make this work,'" he said.

Payments to criminals and their associates, including friends and family, is outlawed under the Press Complaints Commission code.

The PCC is to launch an investigation into the Sun's role in bringing Mr Biggs home but newspaper says there is a "massive public interest defence" for its actions.

fields.headline: Rising star
fields.standfirst: Prince Edward has suffered his criticism; the BBC has felt his crusading spirit and an inexhaustible energy - who will Wayne Garvie's stars collide with next?
fields.trailText: May 8: What's in the stars for the BBC's head of entertainment, music and features, Wayne Garvie, asks Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Wayne Garvie, head of entertainment, music and features at the BBC, has made the headlines with his outspoken criticism of Ardent Productions, headed by Prince Edward. Edward's dismal record, despite his silver spoon, makes Garvie's point that it takes " talent, drive and vision to succeed ". And he should know. He's got all three of them himself, in abundance.

Garvie (September 9 1969) is a hard-working, meticulous Virgo, a sign famous for its critical abilities, but he has both female planets in the flamboyant sign of the Leo lion. This suggests he adores women and that female celebrities love him to bits, but it also gives him a populist appeal and an entertainer's instinct. Add to that a dose of persuasive, charmball Libra and this is a man who can skillfully talk things up and get everyone buzzing together. But we're not talking Butlins and happy-campers. This combination demands class and quality and the huge personal pride Garvie takes in his achievements may harbour a disdainful streak for anything he reckons is second-rate.

The toughness in his horoscope comes from a square contact of blitzkrieg Pluto to aggressive Mars in frank-and-fearless Sagittarius. This gives a crusading spirit and an inexhaustible energy, but also threatens an occasional outburst of fury. A person with this aspect "hates to do anything half way and has a propensity to cut to the core of any problem without flinching from the potential repercussions... there is also limitless courage and an unusual capacity for resourceful and decisive action in any emergency". (Stephen Arroyo).

This is a landmine configuration which can go off at any time. Greg Dyke needs to keep an eye on it because Garvie's Sagittarian Mars keys in dramatically with the BBC.

It falls exactly on the BBC's Mercury incorporation (January 1 1927), which is also Jupiter's degree in its first television broadcast (November 2 1936). These placings symbolise the BBC's public service role and although there may not be much evidence of this yet, in the long run Captain Garvie could end up on the front line of the BBC's fight for its freedom.

So has he been a loose cannon in the attack on Edward? There is a personal clash of styles here. Garvie and Edward, born six months apart, are on the other half of the zodiac circle from each other, so Garvie's sharp, perceptive Virgo Sun doesn't rate Edward's cushy-number Pisces and his vague, wishy-washy Mercury.

What's fascinating in the astrological connections between them all - Garvie, Edward, the BBC - is that on this occasion, it looks like a case of his master's voice and Garvie has probably expressed a widely held view that cannot be said publicly.

The incident presages a future pattern, one in which he seems certain to go far as a BBC mover and shaker. There is more contention to come next spring when his Mars runs riot again, but look out for his talents hitting the mark with popular programming in both October 2002 and throughout 2003. Jupiter brings him benefits then, both in and out of the BBC, through hiccups and upsets which befall others. It could knock out the competition in good time to help Wayne Garvie fulfil his destiny as a rising star.

fields.headline: Tait departs Scotsman
fields.trailText: 0.45am: The commercial director of Scotsman Publications, Stephen Tait, has quit unexpectedly, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The commercial director of Scotsman Publications, Stephen Tait, has quit unexpectedly.

And Sue Douglas, the former Sunday Express editor who has worked as a consultant on the redesign of the Scotsman and the launch of Sunday Business, has also left Scotsman Publications.

Ms Douglas, who has already worked with Conde Nast as a consultant on the launch of Conde Nast's Glamour and Vogue's website, Vogue.com, is taking a full-time job at the company.

Meanwhile, Mr Tait is leaving the company after six months in the post. He does not have another job to go to.

Scotsman Publications has recently ordered editorial department heads to cut budgets by around 10% after a period of turbulence at the paper.

The Scotsman has had three editors in the past 18 months, and Scotsman Publications' editor-in-chief, Andrew Neil, recently revealed that the price-cutting, promotions and relaunch of the paper has cost the group up to £5m.

webTitle: Go Racing plans spring launch for pay-TV channel

fields.headline: Go Racing plans spring launch for pay-TV channel
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The horseracing channel is pencilled in for an April 2002 launch, writes Jason Deans.
04.05.01: Go Racing on course to acquire TV rights
fields.body:
The Go Racing consortium, which is expected to conclude its UK horseracing media rights deal later this week, is planning to launch a pay-TV horseracing channel next spring.

The channel, which will be available to Sky Digital subscribers from the outset, is pencilled in for an April 2002 launch.

The consortium, comprising Channel 4, Sky Digital operator BSkyB and racecourse owner Arena Leisure, is also planning to launch a Go Racing website and an interactive betting service this autumn.

The website is due to go live in October, with interactive betting to follow the next month.

Go Racing announced last week it had secured acceptance from 32 out of the 59 British racecourses, giving it the required 70% of horseracing betting turnover required for the deal to go through.

The remaining racecourses have until Friday May 11 to sign up to the Go Racing agreement.

Arena Leisure is expected to unveil details of plans to raise £80m in funding for Go Racing later today.

The racetrack owner suspended its shares on April 27 in preparation for an announcement about its Go Racing investment plans.

Go Racing is promising the horseracing industry a minimum £400m investment over 10 years, with a predicted return to the sector of £750m or more over the same period.

Related story

webTitle: Blair warns of bruising poll battle

fields.headline: Blair warns of bruising poll battle
fields.standfirst: PM on the defensive as he prepares to visit Queen today
fields.trailText: PM on the defensive as he prepares to visit Queen today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday braced his party for bruising setbacks in the election campaign he will launch today when he admitted that the Labour government has "not done everything people want" and must fight for every vote.

As the prime minister primed the cabinet for his ritual drive to Buckingham Palace to inform the Queen - probably this afternoon - he had already been shown how even the best-laid campaign strategies can be blown off course.

William Hague used what was officially billed as the launch of the Conservatives' manifesto for local election day - also on June 7 - to argue that Labour has "the same record of incompetence, arrogance, mismanagement and efficiency in local government" as at national level.

There were also two unwelcome sallies for Labour from Europe. In an ill-timed initiative for the government, German chancellor Gerhard Schröder told fellow socialist leaders in Berlin, including the foreign secretary Robin Cook, deputising for Mr Blair, that they must "rigorously further develop the European integration process".

In Brussels - before flying home in time for the special cabinet - Gordon Brown, the chancellor, was also forced on the defensive to denounce integrationist forces in the shape of a European commission critique of his ambitious spending plans for health and education in 2001-4.

His complaints were ignored, guaranteeing that it will resurface at the next meeting of EU finance ministers on June 5, two days before polling day.

The commitment to "investment and reform" in the public services is the centrepiece of Labour's election campaign - just as a fierce determination to prove that Mr Brown's "stealth taxes" have been wasted is crucial to Mr Hague's slim hopes of an upset.

At yesterday's cabinet meeting to rubberstamp Labour's manifesto, Mr Blair admitted it would be tricky to ignite public enthusiasm for revitalised schools and hospitals at the same time as confessing to only limited success so far.

"We have to go out and earn every single piece of support wherever it is and do so with a sense of humility. We have not done everything people want and the focus of our campaign will be every bit as much on what we still have to do as what we have done," he admitted.

The Tories will seize upon that. Labour talk of "building the foundations" is a coded admission that it has not built much more, the Conservative chairman, Michael Ancram, said.

The prime minister warned his cabinet team: "Forget the polls and commentators, this is going to be a far tougher fight than people imagine." Convinced that key Labour achievements - school repairs, higher child benefit - are not widely recognised, he wants to make the campaign "a real grown-up sustained debate about the challenges we face".

Mr Hague called Labour "a national and a local disgrace. It makes no difference where Labour politicians are given the opportunity to govern - in Whitehall or the town hall - the story is exactly the same: higher taxes on those who can least afford to pay and poorer services for those who need them most - all spin and no delivery."

Mr Blair's defensive tone also shone through his insistence that his "massive majority was never a reason to do the job quickly" when it should be done properly. "No successful government ever achieved everything in its first term."

After the meeting Alan Milburn, the health secretary, told reporters: "We will fight this campaign, whenever it comes, as if it were on a knife-edge. We are not going to take a single vote for granted."

Equally on message, David Blunkett, the education secretary, added: "Four years is a very short period in time to actually make the investment count and actually make a difference to people's lives."

William Hill made Labour 20-1 on to win the election - the hottest favourites since election betting began. Odds on a Tory win were 8-1 and on the Liberal Democrats 150-1.

webTitle: Comment:  Quotas should ensure adequate number of female MPs

fields.headline: Women lose ground
fields.standfirst:
Quotas are the only way to ensure an adequate number of female MPs

Special report: House of Commons
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Lesley Abdela: Quotas are the only way to ensure an adequate number of female MPs.
fields.body:
Margaret Jay now promises the Labour manifesto will propose laws at some point in the future to permit women-only shortlists for MPs. Meanwhile, however, this will be the first general election since I started the 300 Group 20 years ago in which the number of women in parliament will drop. There was a fall at the 1979 general election which saw Margaret Thatcher become prime minister. In the debating chamber she was to see only 18 other women. Now this year there could also be fewer women at Westminster.

The 300 Group's aim, as the name shows, is that at least half the members of the Commons should be women. Until now we have seen steady upward progress. The most heart-warming advance was recorded at the last election when numbers doubled to 121 women, 101 in New Labour alone. More than half of these New Labour women were selected through all-female shortlists.

But take a look at the figures published by the Fawcett Society for the 2001 election. An outrageous 86% of Conservative candidates are men. An appalling 79% of Liberal Democrat candidates are men. An astonishing 77% of Labour candidates are men. I've run out of adjectives but 82% of Plaid Cymru candidates are men and 79% of SNP candidates are men.

Male politicians with no real stomach to fight for more women in parliament have hidden behind the skirts of the Sex Discrimination Act. A law crafted to help women has been used as a weapon against them. Women-only shortlists were dropped after two disgruntled male candidates felt their toys had been taken away. They obtained a finding that under employment laws all-female shortlists were illegal. Party managers quickly shied away from any form of positive equalisation for fear of costly litigation.

I certainly understand people who are opposed to the introduction of quotas because I used to feel the same. Aware of the sheer breadth of female talent in this country, I thought women would get selected as candidates in large numbers. I went through the arguments - quotas are demeaning, women must be chosen on merit; quotas are reverse discrimination against men.

But experience convinces me that millennia of cultural baggage can be broken only with the sledgehammer of a quota system. What do you say about a mother of parliaments in which only 18% of MPs are women?

Do people seriously believe British women less capable of running their country than their European sisters? Modern democracies with between 30% and 44% female representation in parliament include Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, the Netherlands and Germany. Parties in those states use quota systems.

In France, an astonishing change took place this year. Under new parity laws, political parties must field at least 40% male candidates and at least 40% female candidates. The greatest obstacle in the UK is the candidate selection process. As (Groucho) Marx put it, "I'd give up my seat for you if it wasn't for the fact I'm sitting in it myself." Selection meetings still reek more of after-shave than eau de toilette. Without quotas, male opportunism and long-standing prejudices come into play. Four men are being selected for each woman.

In Wales, seven Labour MPs are standing down. In each seat, local Labour members have chosen men to succeed them. In the rest of the Labour party only four women have been chosen to replace retiring MPs. Even the redoubtable Betty Boothroyd has been replaced by a man.

Liberal Democrats currently have four women and 43 men MPs. Mark Wickham-Jones of Bristol University predicts that a swing of as little as 5% away from the Liberal Democrats could reduce the party to male-only MPs. Only a handful of the Lib Dems' 50 target seats have female candidates. Ray Michie MP is standing down from Argyll and Bute. She will be replaced by a man.

The scene for women Tories is bleak. Not one woman has been selected where a Tory MP is retiring. Essex woman Teresa Gorman will be replaced by Essex man. If the remaining 13 women MPs hold their seats there will be the same number of Tory women in the house as back in 1931.

Meg Russell, of University College London's constitution unit, has proposed taking UK candidate selection out of the Sex Discrimination Act. This would allow the parties to take "proportionate action" to ensure the representation of historically under-represented groups.

My choice would be parity quotas, which apply to men and women alike. There are varieties of parity systems. In England and Wales, for the European elections, Liberal Democrats used a zipper - alternate men's and women's names on candidate lists. As a result, five men and five women MEPs were elected. For the Welsh assembly and Scottish parliament, Labour twinned constituencies between one male candidate and one female candidate. As a result 37% of the Scottish parliament and 40% of the Welsh assembly are female.

In the words of the famous ad, women would refresh the parts other lagers don't reach. And the goddess of democracy knows the body politic needs refreshing right now.
