webTitle: Comment: It's painful to be a Tory

fields.headline: It's painful to be a Tory
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Now that the election is due, gallant Conservative activists are rushing about trying to line up the cavalry against the cannon with all the resolution of despair, but we all know there is very likely going to be a massacre.
fields.body:
Sometimes it's hard to be a Tory. Now that the election is due, gallant Conservative activists are rushing about trying to line up the cavalry against the cannon with all the resolution of despair, but we all know there is very likely going to be a massacre. This may be a very amusing spectacle for Guardian readers, but anyone with Conservative sympathies like me must prepare to bite the bullet.

I don't actually belong to the Conservative party, and never have. I am, none the less, a conservative, with a small c if not necessarily a large one, and I have been writing as a libertarian fellow traveller for the Telegraph papers for more than 10 years. A Labour victory will depress me just as much as the most tireless canvasser in the shires.

It will also astonish me. I simply cannot understand why the electorate has not yet seen through the People's Prime Minister, with his adjustable accent, his adjustable features and his adjustable biography. I cannot see why Labour supporters are not now miserably ashamed of him. I cannot imagine why nothing seems to touch Labour's truly astonishing lead. What would it take? The Conservatives at their worst produced nothing to compare with Robinson, Vaz, Ecclestone, Irvine, the Hindujas, Falconer, Mandelson, the Dome, a House of Lords packed (in the name of democratic reform) with Tony's cronies, and the astonishingly cynical rescue of Phoenix the calf, who rose up ludicrously from the dying ashes of Labour government incompetence and of Labour party morality. And this in only four years.

Perhaps voters don't care. Perhaps they assume all politicians are determined to get their trotters into the top trough, and better our politicians than theirs. This is the Clinton effect: pork and porkies don't matter so long as there is plenty of prosperity.

But even so, there have been all kinds of disasters and promises broken that ought by themselves to have slashed the Labour lead. The NHS is a disgrace. So are most schools and most public transport. Most people with any money pay their way out of public services; continental Europeans can hardly believe how bad they are.

Yet taxes have gone up hugely under Labour, along with government intervention and red tape. This has hit the poorest hardest; the gap between rich and poor is now much greater than when Blair and Brown came to power, productivity is down and savings have collapsed.

Why should all this lead to a Labour landslide? The answer is deeply humiliating. It is not that the voters love Labour - Blair is actually more unpopular than Neil Kinnock and Blair's so-called landslide of 1997 got fewer votes than Major's win in 1992. It isn't even that Hague is so desperately unpopular. It must be that people truly loathe the Conservatives. What's more, quite a lot of Conservatives rather loathe themselves or each other; the Left was never right, we feel, but the Right, though right, has often been rather Repulsive, as in 1066 and All That.

This doesn't matter much in itself, I suppose; we can't all expect to like each other, and life seems to be irredeemably tribal. But I think it matters for this country. Conservatism has saved Britain from ruin. Conservatism gave it the prosperity it now enjoys. Even New Labour saw that and tried to steal its clothes, but has unfortunately not known how to wear them, or keep them on. It would be a great pity if an unthinking loathing for Conservatives, based on old-fashioned stereotypes of hatchet-faced bigots from the shires, and heartless tax avoiders in City suits, were to blind people to the real virtues of Conservatism.

Just as most people have been misled by Mr Blair's bogus charm, most people have been misled by Conservatives' bogus beastliness. It's true we do have some people saying very hard things about standing on your own feet, or getting on your own bike, and a few others saying quite unspeakable things about race. And I find it deeply embarrassing to say I support a party in which Ann Widdecombe is such a star, and in my view so deeply un-Conservative. Conservatism all too often manages to be wearing its most unacceptable face, with a perversity that perhaps explains its reputation as the stupid people's party.

In fact, real Conservatism is for the intelligent. It doesn't offer the easy-to-follow feel-good promises of socialism or of New Labour, as in oxymoronic slogans like Excellence For All. It rests on a complex collection of ideas which are not in themselves very inspiring - realism, compromise, scepticism and the pragmatic pursuit of the least worst in government, with as little government intrusion as possible. It stands for freedom, for its own sake and as a defence against the evils of statism. That is Conservatism. Voters may not want it, but it hardly deserves the astonishing humiliation it is receiving.

webTitle: New social care regulator names chief executive

fields.headline: New social care regulator names chief executive
fields.trailText: A former social worker has been appointed as chief executive of the General Social Care Council (GSCC), the organisation set up to oversee training and regulation of the profession.
fields.body:
A former social worker has been appointed as chief executive of the General Social Care Council (GSCC), the organisation set up to oversee training and regulation of the profession.

Lynne Berry, who is currently chief executive of the Equal Opportunities Commission (EOC), will join the GSCC in September, a month before it begins its work.

The council is being set up to raise standards in social care by regulating staff training, setting conduct and practice standards, and registering staff in sensitive jobs such as child protection.

Ms Berry qualified as a social worker and has worked in the social care field in the statutory and voluntary sector. From 1991 to 1996 she was chief executive of the Family Welfare Association.

She was executive director of the charity commission from 1996 to 1999, when she joined the EOC.

She chaired the Joseph Rowntree Foundation's commission on standards and codes of Practice in the Voluntary Sector, which reported in 1997.

Health minister John Hutton said of Ms Berry: "Her time at the EOC, together with her deep knowledge of working in the social care sector, will provide crucial experience and breadth of perspective to the work of the GSCC."

The GSCC will replace the Central Council for Education and Training in Social Work in regulating the training of social workers.

fields.headline: Soundbite truths
fields.standfirst:
A fact watch to help expose election lies

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: If you are already confused by the claim and counter claim of competing political parties, worse is to come.
fields.body:
If you are already confused by the claim and counter claim of competing political parties, worse is to come. Bad and depressing as the distortions of policy are in the pre-election period, the election proper is always worse.

Yesterday, even before the official start of the campaign, provided as good an example as any. The two major party spokesmen met at the BBC Today programme studio and agreed on only one thing: three key issues would be education, health and crime, plus the tax needed to support the relevant services. Michael Ancram, Tory chairman, was asked to sum up his position on these complex and crucial services and provided, in what is admittedly an impossible task, the usual absurd and negative one-minute soundbite.

Surprise, surprise, there was nothing but failure that Mr Ancram could find: failure in education blighted by rising class sizes (wrong); failure on law and order because of rising crime (wrong); and failure on the health service with people "feeling let down" (which is a fair reflection of current polls). Labour's response was no better, pointing only to good news (7,000 more doctors, 10,000 more teachers, 17,000 more nurses) without any of the many and necessary qualifications. Here are three soundbite size sets of objective facts, which might act as a truth sieve for readers in the grim four weeks ahead of partisan avowal and assertion.

Education: Labour can take pride in the steep fall in infant class sizes (down from 485,000 or 29% of all 5- to 7-year-olds in classes of 30 or more to just 36,000 or 2% in January); the dramatic rise in literacy and numeracy standards by 11; the continued improvement in GCSE and A-level grades; and the 25% reduction in the proportion of pupils leaving school without qualifications. Labour should accept that secondary teacher-pupil ratios, now finally stabilised, have sunk to what they were over two decades ago; that education expenditure as a proportion of national income wavered between 4.5% and 4.8% in the last four years, levels which were exceeded by the Tories in five out of their last six years; and that ministers were late in producing relevant vocational courses for non academic children post 14.

Crime: Labour can take pride in recognising that reducing the causes of crime (through its policies on unemployment, truancy, drug abuse, homelessness and poor parenting) is far more effective in reducing crime over the longterm than more police officers; for providing a much more coherent youth justice system, with faster procedures and more reparation than the old £1bn system condemned by the Audit Commission; and for its expansion of intelligent preventive programmes such as more secure houses on poor and rundown estates. It should be condemned for bowing to the Mail by accepting Michael Howard's criminal justice acts that pushed up the prison population by 50%; producing a five-year plan in February that included 2,660 new prison places in a system with record numbers already; and failing to reform our 30-year-old drug misuse laws.

Health: belatedly it came good with the biggest increase in spending (a one third rise in real terms over 5 years) since the NHS was launched, plus last year's commendable 10-year plan to modernise the system. Yet even now, the five-year spending rise will still leaving spending below the European average by 2006 - a target which Tony Blair set himself last year. Similarly, his education target set this year (state and private schools enjoying equal facilities) would cost an extra £17bn. It is unachievable while Labour refuses to introduce higher taxes.

Education: Labour can take pride in the steep fall in infant class sizes (down from 485,000 or 29% of all 5- to 7-year-olds in classes of 30 or more to just 36,000 or 2% in January); the dramatic rise in literacy and numeracy standards by 11; the continued improvement in GCSE and A-level grades; and the 25% reduction in the proportion of pupils leaving school without qualifications. Labour should accept that secondary teacher-pupil ratios, now finally stabilised, have sunk to what they were over two decades ago; that education expenditure as a proportion of national income wavered between 4.5% and 4.8% in the last four years, levels which were exceeded by the Tories in five out of their last six years; and that ministers were late in producing relevant vocational courses for non academic children post 14. Crime: Labour can take pride in recognising that reducing the causes of crime (through its policies on unemployment, truancy, drug abuse, homelessness and poor parenting) is far more effective in reducing crime over the longterm than more police officers; for providing a much more coherent youth justice system, with faster procedures and more reparation than the old £1bn system condemned by the Audit Commission; and for its expansion of intelligent preventive programmes such as more secure houses on poor and rundown estates. It should be condemned for bowing to the Mail by accepting Michael Howard's criminal justice acts that pushed up the prison population by 50%; producing a five-year plan in February that included 2,660 new prison places in a system with record numbers already; and failing to reform our 30-year-old drug misuse laws. Health: belatedly it came good with the biggest increase in spending (a one third rise in real terms over 5 years) since the NHS was launched, plus last year's commendable 10-year plan to modernise the system. Yet even now, the five-year spending rise will still leaving spending below the European average by 2006 - a target which Tony Blair set himself last year. Similarly, his education target set this year (state and private schools enjoying equal facilities) would cost an extra £17bn. It is unachievable while Labour refuses to introduce higher taxes.

webTitle: Hague pledges hard line on unwed mothers and travellers

fields.headline: Hague pledges hard line on unwed mothers and travellers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Conservative party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday unveiled a series of hardline policies in an attempt to shore up the Tory vote in the local and general elections on June 7.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday unveiled a series of hardline policies in an attempt to shore up the Tory vote in the local and general elections on June 7.

At the launch of the Tory manifesto for the local elections, Mr Hague pledged to put pressure on councils to make unmarried young mothers live at home rather than take up precious public housing.

He also made clear that a Tory government would reject the "politically correct view" that minor crimes by travellers should be ignored.

The joint crackdown on young mothers and travellers was the most controversial aspect of the Tory manifesto for the local elections which will be held on the same day as the general election.

Mr Hague hopes to encourage a high turnout on June 7 by pledging to introduce a series of hardline measures that will appeal to traditional Tory supporters.

The pledges unveiled in the local election manifesto pro vided a taster of the rightwing policies which will form the centrepiece of the Tories' general election manifesto.

In a section in the local election manifesto, entitled Helping Teenage Mothers and Families, the Tories pledged to scrap Labour plans to house unmarried teenage mothers in special hostels.

"The first question when an unwed teenager is pregnant should not be whether there is council flat for her, but whether her parents can support her and her child when she finishes school or look for work," the manifesto said. "Councils and housing associations need to think very carefully about the signals they send out when they allocate social housing."

Threatening to remove the right of unmarried young mothers to a council flat will upset some Tories on the left of the party. They remember the embarrassment the party faced in the 1990s when the former social security secretary, Peter Lilley, launched his notorious "little list" crackdown on teenage mothers.

The Tory leadership under lined its determination to fight the elections from the right with a pledge to crack down on "troublesome travellers".

"Conservatives will introduce tough new measures to stop illegal camps of travellers blighting local communities," the manifesto said. "We reject the politically correct view that a blind eye should be turned to minor crimes by many travellers just because of their alternative lifestyle."

Mr Hague pledged to counter voter apathy in the local elections by promising populist measures to crack down on graffiti and to hand greater powers to local councils.

Under the Tory plans, well run local authorities will be classified as "free councils" and given greater powers to run their own affairs.

The Tory leader said: "Few things are more important to people than the state of their immediate neighbourhood, things like litter, graffiti, noisy neighbours, their local services and how much they cost. Labour want these to be the forgotten elections because they want people to forget their appalling record in local government."

The Tories launched their local election campaign with a brief video which highlighted the "incompetence, gross mismanagement and corruption" of local councils.

But there was embarrassment after a misspelt caption in the video talked of "town halls in Britian".

The Tories faced further embarassment last night after details leaked out of the party's election campaign timetable. A Labour party activist, who logged on to the website of the young Conservative Future group, was emailed a 21-day timetable showing where the party would concentrate its efforts throughout the campaign.

On the first day of the campaign, supporters were asked to flood into Norfolk where there are a series of key marginal seats.

But the Conservatives, who still call themselves the party of the union, asked supporters to go to Wales on only one day and to Scotland on only two days.

Tory plans for town halls

 End capping of council budgets

 Hand greater powers to well-run councils. "Free councils" will have fewer Whitehall inspections and more freedom to raise funds for capital investment

 End regional bureaucracy in England by abolishing regional chambers and development agencies

 Defend "metric martyrs" by allowing loose goods to be sold in pounds and ounces

 Tough measures to crack down on travellers

 Abolish national and regional house building targets

 Give residents more say in planning process by allowing right of counter appeal

 Crack down on litter and graffiti by allowing councils to keep revenues from fines

 Set up regeneration companies to help rejuvenate rundown areas

 Crack down on "neighbours from hell" by introducing fast track evictions

 Give greater powers to schools by handing head teachers and governors full control over budgets

 Allow councils to end "cabinet" system of government and return to old committee system

 Encourage teenage mothers to live with parents rather than "off the welfare state"

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Writing on the Labour Day bank holiday, the Diary sends fraternal greetings to the people of Cuba.
fields.body:
Writing on the Labour Day bank holiday, the Diary sends fraternal greetings to the people of Cuba, and wonders if they'd be interested by a detail concerning British sponsorship of the US's traditional anti-Cuba resolution at last month's UN human rights commission in Geneva.

It's a sign of American desperation that, with the vote desperately close, leaders of African countries were apparently woken the night before by a plaintive George Bush - but how far did Britain go to help secure a narrow 22-20 majority? No one can know for sure. Still, it is intriguing to note that a day before the vote, with Kenya pledging to vote against, Bomber Short's international development department dangled a $37m Aids care offer - although seemingly using a World Bank official as cover - to the Kenyans, who have 1.6m sufferers. And would you believe it, they changed their minds and abstained! Bomber's mob strongly deny the Cuban foreign minister's charge of bribery, insisting the package was decided on here months ago. They have yet, however, to deny the curious timing.

 Still on Cuba, we alluded recently to Maff's failure a month later to acknowledge the offer to send veterinary teams to fight foot and mouth in response to Nick Brown's appeal for help. The item appeared here on April 27. That day the agriculture minister Baroness Hayman sent the Cubans a message promising an immediate Maff response. Nearly a fortnight later, the Cuban embassy continues to wait. What an absolute shower they are at Maff.

 Turncoat contender Peter Hain's efforts to rebuild his reputation as a firebrand of the left fall tantalisingly short. Despite a "warning" to Mr Tony to be more radical in a major Times interview last week, Peter's most radical remark was, "I have the spirit of activism in me." Yes, ducky, but are you a socialist? Well, it seems so... but only for his adoring French audience. In Jean-Michel Carre's amusingly titled 1999 book Construction d'un Utopie, about a cooperative of laid-off miners taking over the Tower colliery in Wales in 1994, Peter is lyrical. "Tower is practical socialism, it's socialism in action," he cries. "It's a fantastic advertisement for socialist politics... " Wow. The old political acquaintance of his who sent the book insists Peter wouldn't dream of saying a word of it in English, but that seems harsh. So come on Peter, unleash the "s" word on your British fans too.

 Worrying news from Wyre Forest, where Stupidest MP 2001 front-runner David Lock, the justice minister who bullied a local free sheet over claims that he abandoned a campaign to save a hospital on becoming a justice minister, looks in trouble. Retired hospital consultant Richard Taylor is standing for the Health Concern party, and an on-line mini-poll has Health Concern on 68% to Labour's 25%. No doubt David would dismiss the poll as worthless, and perhaps so. Anyone interested will find it on David's own website, at www.davidlock.fsnet.co.uk

 Few have accused Gordon Brown of rampant self-effacement, but even that monomaniac was startled by the massive media presence to see him off when he arrived at RAF Northolt yesterday on the way to Brussels to handbag the European finance ministers over his spending plans. Still, we gather Gordon unpreened himself with decorum when it was gently explained that the scrum was not for him, in fact, but poor old Ronnie Biggs.

 Hats off to Sion Simon for his new column in Decanter magazine. This month Ali Campbell's best-loved press storm trooper muses on the 1999 Rhones, especially "Mr Rostaing's Cote Rotie... At little more than £20 a bottle," writes Labour's candidate for Birmingham Erdington, "I can't help but snaffle some up." Geoffrey Robinson would say you can't get a decent Rhone for under £300, but if Sion wants to pose as a true man of the people, that's fine by us.

fields.headline: Marketeers prepare for recession
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Advertising agencies will take a hit as marketeers reduce their advertising budgets, writes Julia Day.

17.04.01: Marketeers left behind on interactive TV
fields.body:
Marketeers are cutting back spending on all areas of their activity, apart from staffing levels, as the profession faces up to the possibility of recession.

This could be bad news for advertising agencies, which will take a hit as marketers reduce their advertising budgets.

This is one of the key revelations of the Chartered Institute of Marketing's spring 2001 trends survey, to be published on tomorrow.

Results of the survey suggest the decline in the US stock market and problems associated with foot and mouth disease have affected marketeers' outlook since the winter 2001 survey.

Although sales targets have been revised downwards, confidence among marketeers about achieving those targets is low.

The CIM Confidence Index has risen from 89.3% in the winter survey to 89.7%, presumably due to lower sales targets.

But even with this very small rise in confidence, the index remains at a historically low level.

Expenditure on all areas of marketing activity is suffering as a result and an increase of just 2.9% is planned for spending on total sales operations.

The overall staffing levels of marketing departments do not appear to be in decline, however, with 81% per cent of respondents reporting no changes will be made their staffing levels.

But because staffing levels are holding steady, in-house marketeers can be fairly confident although advertising agencies and outside suppliers should be less so.

When asked about their priorities for the coming year, two thirds of respondents said building their share of the UK market was a priority.

The results of the spring 2001 Marketing Trends Survey reflect a marketing profession exercising caution in the face of potential economic problems.

fields.headline: Good Evans
fields.standfirst: Chris and Billie spring surprise wedding
fields.trailText: Chris Evans and Billie Piper have shocked cynics by bringing their wedding forward to avoid publicity, writes Sophie Lomax.
fields.body:
For a man who revels in PR stunts involving serial dating of pop stars, news that Chris Evans has finally married one might come as a shock to cynics.

But ask Billie Piper, who secretly married Evans in a small and subdued Las Vegas wedding on Sunday night, why and she is likely to reply, "Because we want to."

That song launched her career and now the couple have proved wrong those who doubted their relationship was anything more than a PR stunt by bringing their marriage forward to avoid publicity.

The ceremony was brought forward by more than four months, with the couple tying the knot at the Little Church of the West on the Las Vegas strip at 6.25pm local time on Sunday.

They were attended by six friends, including best man Danny Baker, and the £200 service was conducted by a local minister, James Hamilton.

Church manager Greg Smith said the couple looked "ecstatic" as they exchanged vows.

Evans wore striped trousers and a green shirt, he said, while Billie looked "radiant" in a pink sarong and white cotton blouse.

DJ Nick Abbot broke the news last night on the station, Virgin Radio, on which Evans is himself a DJ.

The 35-year-old millionaire and media mogul met the 18-year-old Piper when she appeared on his TV show, TFI Friday.

She was in the process of splitting from her long-term fiance, Five's Richie Neville.

Evans, former chief of Virgin Radio and worth an estimated £80m, bought Piper a £105,000 rose-filled Ferrari just three days after they became an item, the only snag being that she had not passed her driving test.

The singer was involved in a court case in March, in which a woman, 32, was given an 18-month suspended prison sentence for threatening to decapitate Piper after she allegedly gave the woman a "sly" look during filming for a TV show.

fields.headline: Stars of 70s sitcoms return in surreal sketch show
fields.trailText: The BBC has raided the retirement homes of light entertainment's fading stars as TV producers go to lengths to get a laugh, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC has raided the retirement homes of light entertainment's fading stars as TV producers go to extreme lengths to get a laugh.

Anna Karen and Stephen Lewis (Olive and Blakey from On the Buses) join Lionel Blair, Mollie Sugden and Roy Barraclough in a "dark and surreal" new sketch show. Their traditional fans are likely to be shocked by the roles they play.

Blair is depicted as a life-sentence prisoner who indulges in self-abuse in his cell, Melvyn Hayes from It Ain't Half Hot Mum is a transvestite, while Sugden is presented in what the producers describe as "compromising situations".

"The central idea is that the comedy is by young innovative writers and has a modern and contemporary feel, dark and surreal," said the series producer, Gary Chippington. "It is a long way from the cosy comedy you associate with the core cast who are all stars in 1970s light entertainment."

Revolver is one of three BBC sketch shows being made in Scotland which producers hope will prove a hit across Britain. Velvet Soup is also described as "dark", while the more traditional Chewin' the Fat, which has spawned a new vocabulary of playground catchphrases in Scotland, is being recommissioned for network broadcast.

Mr Chippington, who is also producing Velvet Soup, rejected the charge that comedy was becoming increasingly inaccessible. "They both have mainstream appeal, they are very well made, slick programmes that are not designed to alienate anybody. We are not going for cult audiences."

He said viewers were becoming more demanding: "It's not good enough any more to put a few pot plants up against a flat backdrop and call it an office. The depth and quality of the performances are being taken far more seriously."

Revolver will start its run on the digital entertainment channel BBC Choice in the autumn.

Revolver

Carmen Silvera from Allo, Allo and Nicholas Smith (Mr Rumbold from Are You Being Served?) are among the 1970s light entertainment actors who appear in this bizarre new series. One sketch sure to raise the hackles of sensitive critics is the "coma ward", where Stephen Lewis, right, (Blakey from On the Buses) is shown as a coma victim pretending to be dead.

Velvet Soup

In the tradition of Absolutely and the League of Gentlemen, this sketch show is based on a cast of quirky characters. They include Hans and Horst - strongmen in love; Quigley Cox, the world's most tragic man, Rude Mum, the Arctic Scientists and Harry and his Performing Monkey.

Chewin' the Fat

Returns for a new series. This show has enjoyed growing appeal south of the border, but in Scotland its catchphrase "Gonnae no dae that!" ("Don't do that") is a favourite with pupils and students. It features Ford Kiernan and Greg Hemphill, rising stars of Scottish comedy.

fields.headline: PCC to investigate Sun's role in Biggs' return
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Sun has insisted there is a "massive public interest defence" in paying for Ronnie Biggs to return to the UK, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The Sun yesterday insisted that there was a "massive public interest defence" in paying for Ronnie Biggs to return from exile in Brazil to prison in Britain.

Pressure on the paper intensified when the press complaints commission (PCC) said it would investigate the issues raised by the affair: paying convicted criminals is a breach of the editor's code of conduct, unless a newspaper can demonstrate there was a significant public interest for doing so.

But the Sun said that it had considered the PCC code before it embarked upon the stunt, and pointed out that it had facilitated the return to prison of a convicted criminal at no cost to the British taxpayer.

It has been reported that the newspaper paid £44,000 to Biggs's family or associates. Some £20,000 is said to have gone to his son, Michael; Biggs's fellow train robber Bruce Reynolds and his son Nick, who travelled on the Sun's chartered plane to Rio, are said to have received £12,000 each.

Payments to criminals are covered by section 16 of the editor's code, which was tightened in the wake of the Fred and Rosemary West murders, when at least seven witnesses sold their stories to national newspapers for between £750 and £100,000.

Section 16.2 says: "Payment or offers of payment for stories, pictures or information, must not be made directly or through agents to convicted or confessed criminals or to their associates - who may in clude family, friends and colleagues - except where the material concerned ought to be published in the public interest and payment is necessary for this to be done."

webTitle: Blair and Brown direct election blockbuster

fields.headline: Blair and Brown direct election blockbuster
fields.standfirst: Theatre and farce - general election time shows all the facets of British politics. Benjamin Wegg-Prosser explains how the Labour party campaign will be managed
fields.trailText: Theatre and farce - general election time shows all the facets of British politics. Benjamin Wegg-Prosser explains how the Labour party campaign will be managed.
fields.body:
If "politics is showbiz for ugly people" as Jay Leno, the US chat show host once observed, then a general election is a Hollywood blockbuster: big budget, dozens of locations, tight schedule of events, badly paid and overworked staff, and a cast of prima donnas.

Labour's campaign in 1997 swept the Oscars. This time round the glitz of their finest hour may have worn off but their professionalism and efficiency will be as strong as ever.

For this election Tony Blair has cast himself as both director and the star performer. He will be touring the country in his battle bus and appearing in London every few days for the 8.30am press conference.

His visits will focus on the government's attempts to rebuild public services and their reputation for economic competence, Labour's two key political messages.

Gordon Brown will be the main supporting actor and producer. He will leave Whitehall this morning and take up residence in Millbank tower for three weeks. He's been given a discrete office in the corner of the 1st floor overlooking the River Thames.

Like all movie stars he will be joined by a collection of groupies - though from the Treasury, rather than Beverly Hills. Mr Brown will chair the crucial 7.00am planning meeting and prepare for the morning press conference, which he will lead in Mr Blair's absence. After which he will follow the news and constantly finesse Labour's campaign strategy.

Government ministers will be sent across Britain taking Labour's message to local TV studios and radio stations. Labour has built up an impressive network of regional offices led by experienced operators who cut their political teeth taking on Militants in the 1980s and the Tories in the 1990s. These unsung heroes will supply the script for ministers to deliver when the cameras start to roll.

A handful of the most photogenic cabinet members will be invited to appear at the national press conferences in London which Labour hope will set the agenda. This select group of star turns have undergone media training over the past two months to ensure their techniques are up to scratch.

All of this activity is dictated by a series of "grids" which party staff started working on last October after Labour's annual conference. These are diaries which set out in minute detail the events required to complement Labour's national political message.

Millbank is planning to launch the campaign with an emphasis on Labour's handling of the economy, starting with Mr Blair speaking to a business audience in the West Midlands on Thursday morning.

After the manifesto launch, about a week into the campaign, Labour's attention will move to health, education and crime. In the final seven days Labour will return to the economy, focussing on their strong reputation with the business community and the Tories' spending plans which, to Mr Brown's fury, the media still refuse to scrutinise.

This national activity will supplement a string of local initiatives led by constituency parties. For the past month these volunteers sat on their hands having prepared for a May election, the more hasty among them even had to pulp thousands of "Vote Labour on May 3rd" posters.

They have been set the task by Millbank of defending Labour's 418 seats. While party HQ will draw on the latest electoral special effects these loyal campaigners will rely on the more traditional methods of canvassing and envelope stuffing.

Brown will want senior backroom staff to keep him up to date with the work of these activists. This effort will be led by Margaret McDonagh, the party's general secretary.

Lance Price, the urbane communications director, will keep him posted on developments in the press, along with David Hill, the grandfather of spin doctors who is returning to Millbank for the campaign.

In addition to these campaigners Mr Brown will depend on Douglas Alexander, MP for Paisley South and his erstwhile researcher as a reliable source of advice.

To match Alexander, the prime minister appointed Pat McFadden, previously a member of the No 10 policy unit to act as his eyes and ears in HQ.

These key staffers will be joined by the mass ranks of No 10 advisers, with Alastair Campbell leading the charge, and more than 70 Whitehall special advisers playing other supporting roles.

This is the first election since 1950 which Labour does not need to gain any new seats to secure a working majority. With the Tories in freefall they have an historic opportunity to win another full term of office.

Labour's stars know that if they remember their lines there's a chance that they'll pull in as many punters as they did four years ago. That really would be a suitable sequel to their award winning performance in 1997.

fields.headline: Creditors chase PLO money man
fields.standfirst:
Arrest opens Palestinian can of worms


Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Palestinian multi-millionaire who ran the PLO's finances for 12 years is being pursued in Britain for debts left behind when he fled bankruptcy.
fields.body:
A Palestinian multi-millionaire who ran the PLO's finances for 12 years is being pursued in Britain for debts left behind when he fled bankruptcy.

Jaweed al-Ghussein, now under house arrest in Gaza, was forcibly removed from his refuge in Abu Dhabi and flown out on Yasser Arafat's personal aircraft. His extradition, or abduction, over what the Palestinian authorities say is a long-unpaid debt, has begun to shed unflattering light on the PLO's usually opaque management of its money.

His daughter, Mona Bauwens, and his son, Tawfiq, have been waging a fax and email campaign to secure his release and hinting that he knows enough to blow the lid off PLO corruption.

Ms Bauwens shot to fame a few years ago after David Mellor, the Tory minister, and his family accepted a holiday in Marbella at her expense.

The cause of the row, according to Palestinian sources, is an unpaid loan of $6.5m (£4.6m) which Mr Ghussein borrowed from the Palestinian National Fund in 1991 while he was the fund's chairman - in effect, the PLO's treasurer.

According to this version, Mr Ghussein insisted he was solvent but asked for a three-month loan to tide him over a financial difficulty, offering property worldwide as security.

The PLO leader, Yasser Arafat, personally approved the loan, these sources say.

In 1998, claiming non-payment of its loan, the PLO obtained a judgment against him in the High Court in London for the full amount plus interest, but then found it was unable to enforce the order.

Amjad Salfiti, the PLO's London solicitor, said: "We found that he had put away most of his properties into trusts. Then we learned that another creditor was filing for bankruptcy."

Mr Ghussein was formally declared bankrupt in the UK in 1999. The creditor which started the bankruptcy action was a South African company which claimed £334,000.

Mr Ghussein's trustee in bankruptcy, Lee Manning of Kroll Buchler Phillips, is still pursuing the money. "He has substantial assets in Abu Dhabi which are more than enough to meet his liabilities, but the law is complicated," Mr Manning said. "There have also been movements of assets within the UK which we are investigating."

Tawfiq Ghussein denies that his father owes the PLO money. He says the row is not about a loan but about an "unsuccessful investment" which was made by his father in 1991 with Mr Arafat's approval. "We have the original transfer papers signed by Arafat himself. It was done in England but is governed by Swiss law. We will release them when the time is right," he said.

According to Tawfiq, the matter was fully resolved in 1992 when his father, "through no legal or moral obligation" handed over 46 plots of land in Jordan to Mr Arafat's legal adviser, Zuhair al-Khatib.

He says the High Court order in London was granted in his father's absence. "They put documents through the letter box of my sister's flat. He wasn't aware of that. The claim was wrongly served and not defended."

Solicitors for the PLO did attempt to serve a writ at a flat in Mayfair which they believed to be Mr Ghussein's address. Ms Bauwens then engaged solicitors to inform them that the address was her home and that her father was no longer living in Britain.

Mr Salfiti insists that the writ was properly served. "It was served in line with the rules in the UK," he said. "Mr Ghussein had the opportunity to challenge service but he has not done so. Also, he has not appealed against the court order or applied to have it set aside."

In the meantime, Jaweed al-Ghussein had moved to Abu Dhabi, in the United Arab Emirates - where he has a company called Cordoba Development Corporation - and the PLO began to pursue him there.

According to his son, the PLO won its court action in the UAE but this was overturned by the supreme court on appeal.

Palestinian sources say the supreme court's ruling was conditional: it gave Mr Ghussein a month to produce documents and find someone to stand bail, but when the deadline expired he had not done so. Mr Arafat then sent one of his close associates, Mahmoud Abbas ("Abu Mazen"), to the Emirates with a letter for the president, Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan.

Shortly afterwards, Mr Ghussein, who is 71 and a diabetic, was arrested by UAE police at a late-night party and flown to Gaza. The legal basis of Mr Ghussein's enforced removal to Gaza is unclear. The Palestinian Authority has no extradition treaty with the UAE and Tawfiq says that in any case his father should have had the right to appeal against extradition.

fields.headline: Baby's killing fuels hatred
fields.standfirst:
Israel voices regret as shelling claims four-month-old victim

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli army tank shells that landed in Khan Yunis refugee camp set another grim record in a seven month catalogue of horrors, turning Iman Hijjo into the youngest victim of the Palestinian uprising and fuelling hatred of the Israelis.
fields.byline: Ghada Ageel  in Khan Yunis refugee camp and Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The neighbours tried desperately to hope for the best as they bundled the injured mother and her baby into taxis yesterday. "She is alive, yes, she is breathing," they said as the cars sped towards the hospital. But Suzan Hijjo, 19, did not need to look at her four-month-old daughter, Iman. "She is dead, I know it," she said.

The Israeli army tank shells that landed on the densely populated Khan Yunis refugee camp in the south of the Gaza Strip earlier in the morning set another grim record in a seven month catalogue of horrors, turning Iman Hijjo into the youngest victim of the Palestinian uprising and fuelling hatred of the Israelis.

The killing of the infant, who was hit by shrapnel from the shells, brought appeals for peace from the Pope, who is visiting Syria, and a rare apology from Israel's government.

In the Syrian ghost town of Quneitra, on the Golan Heights, the Pope said the violence in Gaza gave greater urgency to his prayers for peace in the region. "Mindful of the sad news of conflict and death which even today arrived from Gaza, our prayer becomes even more intense," he said.

In Jerusalem, the hardline Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said: "I am very sorry. I am sure we will make every effort to avoid tragic cases like this." He added: "Children and babies should not be involved in this terrible war that we would like one day to finish."

But Palestinian officials said the killing of Iman, and the wounding of more than 20 others - including 10 children in a primary school at the opposite end of the camp - was a grave escalation of violence.

"We have lived this tragedy since the beginning of the intifada, but today is the saddest day in my life," said Zuhria Abu Jayyab, a neighbour of the Hijjos. "Even if the baby was your enemy's child, you would cry for her. How do you expect us to feel if the baby is one of our neighbours?"

Iman was killed only a few steps from her grandmother's house, neighbours and relatives said. When the first shell punched through the asbestos roof of their shanty, three generations of the family fled into the road barefoot, plunging into a fog of smoke and dust.

Suzan was clutching Iman to her chest when a shell landed barely two metres away.

"We were sitting at home when the children started to count the shells flying overhead," said Shifa Maher Hijjo, a cousin who lives next door. "I heard Suzan and her mother screaming. When I reached the corner, I found Suzan on the ground and her mother next to her, the baby in pieces and blood everywhere."

Four members of the family were wounded by the shrapnel: Iman's grandmother, Samia, lost a chunk of her right leg; Suzan suffered a perforated lung, and her aunt and uncle, themselves small children, were also hit. Uncle Mahmoud, 21 months, was peppered by shrapnel and aunt Duniya, six, was hit in the hands and leg.

The Israeli army said the shelling of three different sections of Khan Yunis was in retaliation for mortar bombs fired earlier yesterday on the illegal Jewish settlements that cut the camp off from the sea. The attacks by Palestinian militias caused no injury.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has ordered his militias to stop the mortar fire, which has provoked the Israeli army to stage repeated invasions of Palestinian-ruled territory in Gaza.

Officials in Khan Yunis admitted that mortar attacks had been launched from the camp, but said they had not come from the area where the Hijjos lived. "Nothing from this area was shot towards the Israelis," said Fayez Abu Shammala, the deputy mayor.

However, Mr Sharon told the Israeli parliament that Palestinian officials were actively involved in attacks on Jewish settlements, including the firing of mortars. Despite his regret for the killing of Iman and the wounding of other children, he was adamant that he would not hold peace talks until the firing stops.

But that standoff leaves the Israelis and Palestinians with no exit from the violence that has claimed nearly 500 lives in seven months, most of them Palestinians, a report on the uprising warns.

"If they do not return to the negotiating table, they face the prospect of fighting it out for years on end, with many of their citizens leaving for distant shores to live their lives," said the report by the former US senator George Mitchell.

fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats declared last night that they were on the eve of a historic general election result amid signs that the Tories were heading for a "meltdown" throughout Britain.

Menzies Campbell MP, the Lib Dem foreign affairs spokesman, said that the recent Tory infighting would deal a huge blow to William Hague's electoral prospects - to the benefit of the Lib Dems.

"After weeks of infighting there is now every possibility of a Tory meltdown," Mr Campbell said. "The Tories are already fighting among themselves over the election of their new leader. People are disappointed with Labour and continue to distrust the Conservatives, so this election will provide an opportunity for real change in Britain."

His remarks came as the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy said he was raring to fight the election. "Every campaign is a test of every party leader's character and leadership, but I think we have got the most united party of the three," he said. "We are ready for the off now and I am looking forward to it."

Mr Kennedy was speaking at a church fete in Portsmouth south, a seat which the Lib Dems snatched from the Tories in 1997 when the party won 46 seats - the best result by a third party since 1929.

Mr Kennedy said he was convinced the Lib Dems would increase their number of seats as the party picks up votes from Tories who were dismayed by their party's lurch to the right and from Labour supporters who believe that the government has failed to deliver.

Mr Kennedy reaffirmed that the Lib Dems would increase the level of income tax for earners of more than £100,000 to 50% and 1p would be added to income tax across the board. "People are not daft in this country," he said. "They know you cannot get something for nothing. The billions of pounds generated can substantially increase pensions and pay for a lot more investment in education, get rid of student fees and provide more investment for the health service."

fields.headline: Hatfield faults 'known for two years'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: An official investigation into the Hatfield rail crash, in which four people died, has shown that Railtrack knew about problems with the track two years before the tragedy, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
An official investigation into the Hatfield rail crash, in which four people died, has shown that Railtrack knew about problems with the track two years before the tragedy, it emerged last night.

A draft report of the official industry investigation reveals that Railtrack was first aware of a problem with the Hatfield track in 1998. It had previously only admitted to finding the cracks in November 1999, a year before the disaster.

According to a report in today's Financial Times, the investigation cites a litany of management failure by rail chiefs and engineers in the lead-up to the crash.

It claims that despite the discovery of gauge corner cracking on the track, a series of mistakes, lack of knowledge and poor communications meant the repairs had not been carried out by the time of the crash in October last year.

Instructions were given to put the problem right within six months of discovering it, but these were not acted on.

Four people died when a GNER London to Leeds high-speed train was derailed at Hatfield after the track shattered into 300 pieces.

The train had been travelling at 115mph but 20mph speed restrictions were later imposed - something Railtrack admitted it should have done before the crash.

According to the Financial Times, the report says a track inspector employed by Balfour Beatty admitted he regularly walked in a ditch beside the Hatfield track, giving him an inadequate view of the the rail. Ultrasonic tests carried out by Balfour Beatty every three months gave results that should have indicated a serious problem, but they appear not to have been acted on.

The unpublished report claims there is a "strong probability" that the track was broken before the train passed over it.

The 113-page report, based on an inquiry by Railway Safety, the industry's safety body chaired by retired rail engineer John Mitchell, focused on the actions of employees at Railtrack and its maintenance contractor, Balfour Beatty Rail Maintenance Limited. Evidence was also taken from Jarvis, the company employed to carry out track replacements by Railtrack.

Mr Mitchell criticised the written evidence for being of "limited value", and Railtrack, British Transport police and the health and safety executive for holding back important documents.

"These decisions have undoubtedly lengthened the inquiry timescale, and have proved to be a serious handicap in establishing the facts," he said.

Police are still investigating the crash and manslaughter charges could be brought.

webTitle: March on parliament to demand cash

fields.headline: March on parliament to demand cash
fields.standfirst:
Rural firms say £24m aid package is a farce, as legal attempts to stop cull begin

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Rural businesses yesterday dismissed an extra £24m announced by the government to help firms affected by the foot and mouth crisis, and made plans to demonstrate outside parliament tomorrow.
fields.body:
Rural businesses yesterday dismissed an extra £24m announced by the government to help firms affected by the foot and mouth crisis, and made plans to demonstrate outside parliament tomorrow.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, announced the creation of a recovery fund to help small and medium-sized businesses in areas worst hit by closed footpaths and the absence of tourists.

Businesses would receive up to £15,000 in grants for marketing support, skills improvement and IT investment to help them adapt. There will also be grants to meet interest repayments on borrowings caused by the crisis, which is costing English tourism alone £140m a week.

Mr Meacher said: "Small tourism and other country businesses are essential to the health of the rural economy. We want to ensure that viable businesses can survive to help land recovery in these areas.

"This fund should provide direct help to up to 10,000 small and medium-sized businesses, and wider benefits to all rural businesses affected by foot and mouth."

The total offered to rural businesses since the crisis began is more than £250m.

But yesterday rural business owners said no money had reached them, and that the government's idea of skills seminars and so on was a farce; they wanted cash compensation and the opening of footpaths.

Deborah Cowin, a member of the self-styled Cumbria Crisis Alliance, is a gallery director and bespoke jeweller in Keswick; she had taken one order since March, she said.

"It is an insult to offer us seminars," she said. "We are all from thriving, growing businesses. We do not need special advice. We need cash aid. We need to retain staff.

"All we have seen so far is three months' hardship rate relief. The government is nibbling around the edge of the problem and we are becoming a forgotten strata of society. We are dispossessed."

Ms Cowin said rural proprietors from Cumbria, Devon and Wales would demonstrate at the lack of government support in London tomorrow.

Steve Binder, director of the Newlands adventure centre in Keswick, said he had taken taken £9.87 since March, compared with £25,000 last year. He said: "We just see money being poured into the wrong places. I have very little faith in the ability of the government to target money directly. We never see it."

Rosemary Keen, a guesthouse owner in Ambleside, said of the government's help so far: "This money they are talking about is fictitious. I haven't seen anybody who has got any of this money yet, apart from the rate relief."

Judy Carless said her restaurant in Exmoor national park had been closed since February: "This is an absolute waste of time. It is going to have to be cash aid. I don't see how else they can do it. We have been totally forgotten."

The extra funding came as an animal sanctuary owner in Dumfries and Galloway and a farmer on Exmoor launch court cases to stop their animals being culled.

Juanita Wilson of the Mossburn animal centre in Hightae, said she had put £10,000 of personal savings into a fight to prevent 14 goats and three sheep being culled by slaughtermen directed by the Scottish executive. A local vet had given animals the all clear, she said.

"I'm prepared to go to the court of session in Edinburgh. We will no doubt lose, but I have been assured by my QC that we can take our case to the Lords and the European court of human rights." Some 75 people have surrounded the centre to block entry.

Christopher Thomas-Everard, whose 980 cattle were due to be the first slaughtered on Exmoor, yesterday vowed to fight the Ministry of Agriculture in court.

The animals were ordered to be culled after a visit 12 days ago from a de-horning contractor from Wilvelscombe, which has several foot and mouth cases. Mr Thomas-Everard said his cattle had been declared healthy by vets.

webTitle: Bush resumes spy flights off China

fields.headline: Bush resumes spy flights off China
fields.standfirst:
Washington says it has a right to patrol coastline

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: China
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday resumed surveillance flights off the Chinese coast, in defiance of Beijing's demands for an end to the patrols after a collision between a US spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet in April strained relations between the two countries.
fields.body:
The United States yesterday resumed surveillance flights off the Chinese coast, in defiance of Beijing's demands for an end to the patrols after a collision between a US spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet in April strained relations between the two countries.

Pentagon officials said an unarmed RC-135 jet, loaded with electronic surveillance equipment, flew along the coastline of northern China in daylight and without a fighter escort. The officials said China did not launch fighter jets to intercept it and the US plane returned to Kadena air base on the Japanese island of Okinawa.

The Chinese foreign ministry gave no immediate response yesterday, but Beijing has repeatedly insisted that the flights, aimed at inspecting military activity and eavesdropping on military communications, be brought to an end.

Washington has insisted it has a right to conduct patrols in international airspace and has promised that flights would also resume off the more sensitive southern coast of China. The Pentagon has raised the possibility that future patrols might be given fighter escorts.

Yesterday's patrol was the first surveillance flight since April 1, when a US navy EP-3 spy plane collided with an F-8 Chinese fighter off southern China. The Chinese pilot died, but the 24-strong crew of the US plane managed an emergency landing on China's Hainan Island. Each side blamed the other for the incident.

The US crew were released only after Washington said it was "very sorry" for the death of the Chinese pilot and for the American plane's landing.

The EP-3 lost its nose-cone and damaged its propellers in the collision. The crew also destroyed as much of its sensitive eavesdropping equipment as they could before leaving the plane. Much of the rest was removed by Chinese military intelligence for analysis. The hollowed out plane is still on Hainan Island, but the Chinese military allowed a team of US engineers to inspect it for the first time last week.

The US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said on Sunday that he was confident the $80m (£57m) aircraft would be released.

"I would suspect we'll get it back," Mr Rumsfeld said. "They wouldn't have allowed an inspection team to go in there if they didn't plan to return the airplane."

He said that it would be "logical" to repair the plane and fly it off the island, but the Chinese military have in the past objected to suggestions that the plane be repaired on the island. An alternative would be to break the plane up and ship it out in pieces.

In his television appearance on Sunday, Mr Rumsfeld accepted responsibility for the diplomatic confusion triggered last week by a Pentagon statement which called for the suspension of US military contacts with China, in conflict with the Bush administration's current policy of maintaining links and playing down the seriousness of the rift over the EP-3. The Pentagon statement was withdrawn a few hours after its release, and the mistake was blamed on a member of Mr Rumsfeld's staff.

"There's no question that I made a mistake. A mistake was made," Mr Rumsfeld told the CBS programme Face the Nation. "To the extent there's any fault ... to be assigned, it's certainly as much mine as anybody else's, and I'm in charge."

webTitle: Gangs cash in as cigarette prices soar

fields.headline: Gangs cash in as cigarette prices soar
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Bootleg cigarettes have become a significant problem in Britain, with packs being sold not just in street markets, but at pubs, clubs and car boot sales.
fields.body:
Bootleg cigarettes have become a significant problem in Britain, with packs being sold not just in street markets, but at pubs and clubs, car boot sales and even from the front windows of some houses.

Gangs such as the Fosters, though, are small fish compared with the organised smuggling gangs whose numbers have grown along with the recent rises in cigarette tax - Britain has one of the highest cigarette prices in Europe. A recent UK threat assessment by the national criminal intelligence service said 19% of all identified crime groups were engaged in excise fraud and 21% of drug trafficking gangs also engaged in cigarette smuggling.

Last year the government lost approximately £3.8bn in revenue through smuggled tobacco. As of April this year, legitimate cigarettes were stamped with a duty paid label and, at the beginning of July, legislation comes into effect which makes it a criminal act to sell unmarked products; those caught can be fined up to £5,000 and shopkeepers can be banned from selling tobacco for six months.

The paymaster general, Dawn Primarolo, said yesterday: "We are determined to stamp out tobacco smuggling, which is why we have spent £209m on introducing a national network of x-ray scanners and recruiting extra frontline staff. With nearly 1,000 more customs officers now working on the ground, organised criminals are coming under increasing pressure and the introduction of duty paid marks on legal packs means that smuggled cigarettes are getting easier for everyone to spot."

The main method of smuggling into Britain is in sea containers which usually start their journey in the far east. As customs and excise clamp down on smuggling, the methods of hiding cigarettes become more imaginative. Recent shipments have been found inside laminate doors, in cases ostensibly containing micro-scooters and in catering size tins of mushrooms. Until now, customs believe they have seized no more than 10% of the total number of cigarettes coming in to Britain.

Favourite smuggled brands are Benson and Hedges, Embassy Regal, Sovereign and L&Ms. The profits on large-scale smuggling are enormous but, even on the smaller scale, cigarettes can be bought in the Canaries for around £7 for 200 while they would cost £40 for the same amount in Britain.

New scanners are now in operation across the country. At Southampton and Felixstowe docks, customs and excise officers have welcomed the £2.5m Heimann Cargo Scanner, a large lorry with an x-ray arm which can examine a sea container in a matter of minutes.

In the past year there were 282m cigarettes smuggled through Southampton docks with a revenue value of £45m to £50m, just a small proportion of the British total. Keith Nugus, anti-smuggling manager at Southampton docks, said the new scanner was a deterrent. "We are now only finding a couple a month," he said.

"Before Christmas it was two to three a week. We have found a many as 10.5m cigarettes in one container. When the opposition are going to the extent of especially fabricating door panels, it's quite an operation. There is usually around half a million pound profit to be made on a container load of cigarettes.

"At the lower end we are finding passengers on cruise liners bringing in suitcase loads of cigarettes which would make them enough money to pay for their cruise.

"On a couple of occasions in December we had families with kids coming through, with 40,000 to 50,000 cigarettes in their suitcases."

fields.headline: Retired mandarins round on 'myths'
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Twelve former senior civil servants will today reject Tory claims that continental leaders are determined to construct a European superstate and to build up an army to rival Nato.
fields.body:
Twelve former senior civil servants will today reject Tory claims that continental leaders are determined to construct a European superstate and to build up an army to rival Nato.

Lord Butler of Brockwell, the former cabinet secretary who served Margaret Thatcher and John Major, is scathing about the Tories' hardline stance on Europe. Lord Butler will warn of the dangers of facts about Europe being "grossly misrepresented".

Lord Butler, who retired in 1998, is a co-author of a pamphlet for the cross-party Britain in Europe group. The paper, the European Union Today which will be published today, shows that the EU allows member states to further their own interests in Brussels.

Sir Michael Butler, who was Britain's permanent representative to the EC between 1979-85, said: "The most widely spread myth of all is that the EU is about to become a superstate. Our considered view is that this will not happen."

His comments came as the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, reiterated his warning that the government is determined to take Britain into a European superstate. Speaking on Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Maude called for powers to be repatriated back to member states rather than pushing on with a "relentless one-way street towards the creating of a single European superstate".

Mr Maude has pledged that a Tory government would renegotiate Britain's entire relationship with Brussels by using next month's EU summit in Gothenburg to call for the renegotiation of last December's Nice treaty - which laid the basis for the enlargement of the EU as well as the common agricultural policy and the common fisheries policy.

Sir Michael, who drew up the agreement in the 1980s which gave Britain its rebate back from Europe under Lady Thatcher, dismissed Mr Maude's plans. "If we were to go to the European council after the election and say that we were not prepared to ratify the Nice treaty and renegotiate a whole lot of things we would find we could not succeed. If the more extreme version of Conservative policy were to be adopted it would be damaging to British interests."

fields.headline: Judge blocks Zimbabwe terror trial
fields.standfirst:
Court queries legality of act used to try Mugabe's rival
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, won an important first round victory against the government at his terrorism trial yesterday when the high court questioned the constitutionality of oppressive British colonial-era laws used to charge him.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and Chris McGreal
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, won an important first round victory against the government at his terrorism trial yesterday when the high court questioned the constitutionality of oppressive British colonial-era laws used to charge him.

The high court postponed the trial while the supreme court considers whether President Robert Mugabe can even use the notorious Law and Order (Maintenance) Act which has been wielded by every Zimbabwean government for four decades to oppress opponents.

If the supreme court strikes down either the entire act or the section dealing with terrorism, it will not only end Mr Tsvangirai's prosecution but possibly remove an important weapon from Mr Mugabe's arsenal in his battle with all manner of opponents. The act has been used to prevent anti-government demonstrations, to try to curb critical journalism and to justify violence against dissenters.

Judge Moses Chinhengo delivered his blow to the government's case on the first day of the trial: "It is common knowledge that the Law and Order (Maintenance) Act is a piece of colonial legislation that was introduced in 1960, before this country got a justiciable Bill of Rights in 1980," he said.

"That historical fact suggests that in the new order, the act will be sorely tested each time it is relied upon by the state to prosecute an individual."

No date was set for the supreme court hearing but if it upholds the law, the case will be referred back to the high court.

Mr Tsvangirai is on trial for terrorism, for a remark he made at a rally of his Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) party last September warning Mr Mugabe to resign after the opposition came close to winning parliamentary elections.

"We say to Robert Mugabe, if you don't want to go peacefully, we will remove you violently," he said.

The prosecutor, Nathaniel Sibanda, told the court yesterday that Mr Tsvangirai's words were an incitement to revolution. "The charges are directed at mischief of the highest order, which is calling for the violent removal of a lawfully elected president in a democratic state," he said.

But many Zimbabweans see the trial as an attempt to prevent Mr Tsvangirai running for president against Mr Mugabe. If the opposition leader is convicted and given more than six months in prison he would be barred from high office.

Yesterday, Mr Tsvangirai praised the independence of the judiciary despite attempts by the government to purge the courts of "disloyal" judges.

The supreme court is still considered independent with four of its five judges resisting pressure to resign. The fifth judge - Zimbabwe's new chief justice - was appointed in March after his white predecessor was threatened until he took early retirement.

Judge Chinhengo said the supreme court should decide whether the two sections of the Law and Order act under which Mr Tsvangirai is charged infringe the right to free speech and the right to be considered innocent until proved guilty. But the court could scrutinise the entire act if it chose.

It was introduced in 1960 by the British colonial authorities to curb the activities of African nationalists pressing for the then Southern Rhodesia to become independent. The law was made even tougher by Ian Smith's white minority regime after its unilateral declaration of independence as Rhodesia.

The white government used the act to jail Mr Mugabe for 10 years without a trial. Mr Tsvangirai's lawyer, Chris Andersen, was a minister of justice in the Smith government - although not the one who sent Mr Mugabe to prison. Yesterday he was challenging the constitutionality of a law he used repeatedly before independence.

Two sections of the act - forbidding public gatherings without a police order and barring journalists from publishing news that might cause "fear and despondency" - have already been struck down by the supreme court.

Mr Mugabe's information minister, Jonathan Moyo, said the government would respect the high court ruling.

"We respect the institution of an independent judiciary and we look forward to the outcome of the supreme court case," he said. "It is interesting that so many international journalists came here for this case. We do not want to see an international media kangaroo court saying there is no rule of law in Zimbabwe. We hope they do not try to politicise this case. It is not a politically motivated case, it is a criminal case."

But there are few in Zimbabwe who believe that.

webTitle: Bootlegging does pay - but is it worth it?

fields.headline: Bootlegging does pay - but is it worth it?
fields.standfirst:
Customs officers and the courts are clamping down on a trade that cost the government £3.8bn in lost revenue last year
Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Customs and excise officers estimate that from their regular buying trips to France the Fosters evaded paying £365,000 in duty. Neighbours, who saw the steady stream of people leaving the Fosters' house with cigarettes and alcohol, believe it was far more.
fields.body:
It takes at least eight hours to get to the duty free shops of Calais from Cullompton in Devon and a good bit longer to reach the cheap tobacco in Adinkerke in Belgium. But for the Foster family the journey was more than worth it.

Customs and excise officers estimate that from their regular buying trips the Fosters evaded paying £365,000 in duty. Neighbours, who saw the steady stream of people leaving the Fosters' house with cigarettes and alcohol, believe it was far more.

Last month, after a customs and excise surveillance operation, four members of the family were jailed when they pleaded guilty to conspiring to evade payment of duty on smuggled alcohol and tobacco.

Brian Foster, 51, got three years, his wife Brenda two, and his daughters, Tracy, 26, and Sonia, 28, 12 months - a lesser penalty because they both have children. The first half of their sentence is to be served in custody and the second half on suspension.

On the St Andrews estate on a hill at the back of Cullompton, people were stunned by the length of the sentences. To most it was just an "innocent" bit of bootlegging. Everyone in the town knew that if they went up to Brian's "castle" at the top of the hill they could get all the smuggled fags and booze they desired.

Surveillance photographs during Operation Sister showed people coming out laden from the Foster home, a former council house.

At Plymouth crown court Foster said that initially when he travelled to France with his racing pigeons, friends asked him to bring back duty free goods, and when the need to pay for his daughters' double wedding came up he got more and more involved.

Customs officers can only estimate how many trips the family made - 105 - but what they do know is that the Fosters made so many journeys that they earned Eurostar loyalty cards. Other friends and relatives were involved, and 10 passports were seized from the Foster home.

After warning the family four times and impounding their car (they organised a run to pay for a new one), customs officers decided that they were more than using what was a "generous concession" and put them under surveillance.

Tracy Foster was intercepted at Dover with 3,000 cigarettes and 30kg of hand-rolling tobacco. Eight people were initially arrested, including the next-door neighbour, John Pike, and his son, Andrew.

Mr Pike said he had made four trips in two months to France and Belgium, driving Sonia, who did not have driving licence. "We just brought back a couple of boxfuls of rolling tobacco and maybe just a few bottles of wine," he said.

No charges were pressed against him. "It would have been easy for me to become more involved," he said. "I am glad it didn't go any further. We are just glad it's all over.

"I wasn't too glad when I heard their sentence. I think they [the authorities] have done it just to show everybody an example, to try to stop it quick. It has certainly made me realise that it is illegal. It's tempting to pay cheap prices."

All the while Brian and Brenda Foster, who are unemployed and on benefit, were having their mortgage paid by social services. Both have criminal records.

Bob Gaiger, a spokesman for customs and excise, said: "It is important for people to realise they cannot only lose their smuggled goods but also their car, and face a jail sentence."

Last week customs officers at Dover said that every week they discovered at least 10 adults using children aged five to 11 to bring tobacco illegally into the country. Smugglers pretended that the children were on day trips to Calais. Tobacco was packed into their rucksacks to be brought back.

Nigel Knott, a customs spokesman for Dover, said a young woman had been caught with 5kg of hand-rolling tobacco worth £180 in a pram mattress after leaving a ferry. On another occasion the same woman was found with 900g of hand-rolling tobacco in her baby's jumpsuit and 5kg in the changing bag.

webTitle: Macedonia pulls back from brink of declaring war

fields.headline: Macedonia pulls back from brink of declaring war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Under pressure from senior Nato and EU officials, the Macedonian government yesterday put off plans to declare a state of war in the face of new fighting by ethnic Albanian guerrillas in villages close to Kosovo and southern Serbia.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood near Slupcane, Macedonia, and Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
Under pressure from senior Nato and EU officials, the Macedonian government yesterday put off plans to declare a state of war in the face of new fighting by ethnic Albanian guerrillas in villages close to Kosovo and southern Serbia.

Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary-general, and Javier Solana, the EU foreign policy chief, denounced the guerrillas but warned Macedonian officials that the emergency move could lead to the main Albanian political party's withdrawal from the government and a slide into civil war.

"The message today to the government and all the people of this country is they must go back from the brink before further disaster," Lord Robertson said. "The international community will not allow democratic institutions to be undermined by a bunch of murderers stuck in the mountains."

Developments in Skopje took place as Macedonian security forces launched one of their heaviest bombardments of ethnic Albanian rebel positions since fighting began last Thursday. However there was no sign of the National Liberation Army, the group behind the clashes, giving ground.

Helicopter gunships made repeated sorties firing into the villages of Vaksince and Slutcane. The helicopters were backed up by heavy calibre mortar and tank fire. Apart from the intermittent rattle of machine-guns there was little return fire from rebel positions.

Western military analysts said there was no sign of a quick end to the conflict "The shelling is not causing [the NLA] any real damage, and using troops would be very difficult," said one diplomat.

"This was always going to be for the long haul. Even if the army pushes them out of one area they'll pop up in another."

The prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, said at the weekend that he would demand that parliament declare a state of war. That would give President Boris Trajkovski the ability to rule by decree and appoint a government of his choosing. Borders could be sealed, a curfew imposed, and demonstrations banned.

After the first eruption of fighting by the NLA in ethnic Albanian villages north of the city of Tetovo in March, the government agreed to start urgent talks on reform. The guerrillas had retreated in the face of a heavy artillery barrage and an offensive by helicopter-borne troops and special police but warned they would return if the talks did not produce results.

While denouncing the gunmen, Macedonia's Albanian parties agreed with their demands. At the time, Nato and the EU also called for the government to move fast on reform and not give way to triumphalism or intransigence after the gunmen withdrew. Western military officials warned that the NLA had withdrawn in good order, saving its men and most of its weaponry.

The latest fighting opens a new front in largely Albanian villages just west of the town of Kumanovo.

The political dialogue between the government and ethnic Albanian leaders has not yet covered the Albanians' key demand for a change in the constitution to reflect the fact they form at least 30% of the population. Lord Robertson appealed to all leaders to continue the talks. "There must be a support for a grand coalition, a united front against violence," he stressed.
