webTitle: Japan told to prepare for pain

fields.headline: Japan told to prepare for pain
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The new Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi sketched out his plans for surgery on the world's second biggest economy yesterday in a parliamentary speech that warned the population to grit its teeth for agonising change.
fields.body:
The new Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi sketched out his plans for surgery on the world's second biggest economy yesterday in a parliamentary speech that warned the population to grit its teeth for agonising change.

Echoing the promises of reform that won him a surprise victory in last month's Liberal Democratic party leadership election, Mr Koizumi said Japan would have to slash banks' non-performing loans, trim government spending and wean the economy off of an addiction to public works projects.

"In the process of implementing structural reforms, there will be a shake-up of inefficient sectors and pain in society," a grim-faced Koizumi said in comparing himself to the Meiji-era revolutionaries who modernised Japan in the mid-19th century.

"Adopting a stance that does not fear pain, does not flinch at the barriers of vested interests, and is not shackled by the experience of the past, I want to establish an economic and social system suitable for the 21st century."

While short on specifics, the message is likely to go down well with voters and investors, who have welcomed Mr Koizumi's determination to confront powerful lobbies within his own party that have repeatedly blocked reforms.

A poll by public broadcaster NHK showed Mr Koizumi is the most popular prime minister in living memory with a support rating of 81%, against less than 10% for his predecessor Yoshiro Mori.

The moneymen have also indicated their approval of the new premier. Mr Koizumi's speech yesterday drove the main Nikkei-225 index above 14,500 points for the first time in nearly six months.

So far the change has been more one of style than substance. Most of the contents of the new administration's policy package were drawn up before Mr Koizumi took power.

Echoing his predecessor - but with considerably more conviction - the new prime minister said his government will clear up the problem of bad loans - estimated at between 30 trillion and 110 trillion yen (£171bn-£630bn) - in two to three years. Anticipating that this would drive many firms into bankruptcy, he also pledged to establish a stronger safety net for the unemployed.

In a short-term measure to lift stock prices, Mr Koizumi said a body would be established to buy up bank share holdings and tax relief would be introduced for profits made by individuals through equity deals.

He said he would establish advisory panels to consider the possible election of the prime minister through a popular vote and the privatisation of the postal savings system, which is now effectively the world's biggest bank. To boost competition, the administration will strengthen the powers of the fair trade commission and other regulators.

The biggest test for Mr Koizumi will be on fiscal policy, where the prime minister pledged to cap the issuance of government bonds to ¥30 trillion a year as a first step towards reining in a public debt.

fields.headline: Mayor's blueprint for London
fields.standfirst:
Livingstone blueprint to redevelop London

Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone will unveil the blueprint for a massive redevelopment of London today which is to allow the population to grow by nearly 10% to 8.1m.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone will unveil the blueprint for a massive redevelopment of London today which is to allow the population to grow by nearly 10% to 8.1m during the next 15 years without triggering social collapse or transport gridlock.

In the first strategic plan for the capital for a generation, the mayor will seek an alliance with property companies by offering them opportunities for profitable, high-density housing developments in return for a guarantee that at least 50% of the new homes will be rented at affordable prices.

The plan will reject policies for dispersing people to other parts of southern England. Mr Livingstone will say this would be an environmental disaster for the green belt and would ruin Britain's "world city", a linchpin of the global economy.

Instead, he plans to accommodate London's natural population growth and net inward migration which, if recent trends persist, would add 700,000 people - and 500,000 households - by 2016.

The projected need for more than 33,000 new homes every year for the next 15 years is much larger than the government's suggestion that the London plan should provide for an extra 23,000 households a year to 2006.

Under Mr Livingstone's plan, developers would be encouraged to provide offices and homes near big new transport intersections created by construction of cross-London rail lines. They would be told to restrict parking space to make residents rely on public transport.

The biggest developments will be on brownfield sites in the East End, around the interchange with the proposed Channel tunnel rail link at Stratford, and in corridors leading to Stansted, Gatwick and Heathrow airports.

The proposals are part of the first consultative version of a "spatial development strategy" that the mayor is required by law to produce. A more detailed formal document will be considered by a government-appointed panel next year.

The mayor's final plan, subject to direction by ministers, will set out the planning framework within which the London boroughs will have to work.

Mr Livingstone will say he is aiming for a consensus around plans for higher population densities. "People like living in urban areas, close to the facilities and services they need. That is one of the reasons why house prices in Knightsbridge and Islington - some of the densest urban areas in London - are so high.

"We must ensure that London exemplifies urban renaissance by developing at higher densities in more attractive urban environments, linked to public transport services," he will say.

Nicky Gavron, the deputy-mayor and one of the main architects of the plan, said it would not give developers a free hand to put up 40-storey skyscrapers. In return for profitable opportunities to build and sell swish penthouse flats, they would be required to provide social benefits, including affordable homes for the city's workers.

At least 35% of the units built should be available for social renting, and 15% for people on moderate incomes.

"This plan is the silver bullet that hits all the targets for accommodating population growth, rejuvenating local econmies and making the city environmentally and socially sustainable, and less dependent on the motor car," she said.

The plan says London ranks alongside New York and Tokyo as one of three genuine "world cities". London is "the UK's only opportunity to maintain a world city, and the success of the UK economy as a whole is dependent upon the success of London".

The city has to expand to the east and south, the report will claim.

New high-density housing would be "located in places with adequate public transport... This will allow car parking to be limited and will help ensure that the growth in journeys created by the growth in population is accommodated, as far as possible, within the public transport network.

"The layout of sites should be designed primarily for the needs of pedestrians, not cars."

The plan says half the new homes are likely to be in the central London riverside boroughs, Docklands and the Thames Gateway, the area around the river's eastern approaches to the city.

Areas identified as prime opportunities for development in central London included Paddington, King's Cross, South Bank and Elephant and Castle. In the longer term there would be development at transport intersections created by the Thameslink 2000, CrossRail and Hackney-South West rail lines.

Instead of suburban sprawl, there would be regeneration of 10 square kilometres of development land in the Thames gateway near some of London's greatest concentrations of deprivation. There would be an "arc of opportunity" in Newham to shift London's employment and residential focus towards the east.

Three regional development corridors would be created in the Lea valley leading out towards Stansted, the "western wedge" from Paddington towards Heathrow and the Wandle valley, including Croydon, and stretching towards Gatwick.

The plan is not costed at this stage, but it calls for London to retain a larger share of tax revenues to redress years of under investment.

It proposes socially balanced communities, built around more public buildings and shopping in local town centres.

The document includes plans to protect wildlife, relieve an acute shortage of cemeteries and recycle more of the 18m tonnes of waste produced by the capital each year. It also warns that London's flood defences are at risk from rising water levels caused by global warming.

Mr Livingstone will say this would be an environmental disaster for the green belt and would ruin Britain's "world city", a linchpin of the global economy. Instead, he plans to accommodate London's natural population growth and net inward migration which, if recent trends persist, would add 700,000 people - and 500,000 households - by 2016. The projected need for more than 33,000 new homes every year for the next 15 years is much larger than the government's suggestion that the London plan should provide for an extra 23,000 households a year to 2006. Under Mr Livingstone's plan, developers would be encouraged to provide offices and homes near big new transport intersections created by construction of cross-London rail lines. They would be told to restrict parking space to make residents rely on public transport. The biggest developments will be on brownfield sites in the East End, around the interchange with the proposed Channel tunnel rail link at Stratford, and in corridors leading to Stansted, Gatwick and Heathrow airports. The proposals are part of the first consultative version of a "spatial development strategy" that the mayor is required by law to produce. A more detailed formal document will be considered by a government-appointed panel next year. The mayor's final plan, subject to direction by ministers, will set out the planning framework within which the London boroughs will have to work. Mr Livingstone will say he is aiming for a consensus around plans for higher population densities. "People like living in urban areas, close to the facilities and services they need. That is one of the reasons why house prices in Knightsbridge and Islington - some of the densest urban areas in London - are so high. "We must ensure that London exemplifies urban renaissance by developing at higher densities in more attractive urban environments, linked to public transport services," he will say. Nicky Gavron, the deputy-mayor and one of the main architects of the plan, said it would not give developers a free hand to put up 40-storey skyscrapers. In return for profitable opportunities to build and sell swish penthouse flats, they would be required to provide social benefits, including affordable homes for the city's workers. At least 35% of the units built should be available for social renting, and 15% for people on moderate incomes. "This plan is the silver bullet that hits all the targets for accommodating population growth, rejuvenating local econmies and making the city environmentally and socially sustainable, and less dependent on the motor car," she said. The plan says London ranks alongside New York and Tokyo as one of three genuine "world cities". London is "the UK's only opportunity to maintain a world city, and the success of the UK economy as a whole is dependent upon the success of London". The city has to expand to the east and south, the report will claim. New high-density housing would be "located in places with adequate public transport... This will allow car parking to be limited and will help ensure that the growth in journeys created by the growth in population is accommodated, as far as possible, within the public transport network. "The layout of sites should be designed primarily for the needs of pedestrians, not cars." The plan says half the new homes are likely to be in the central London riverside boroughs, Docklands and the Thames Gateway, the area around the river's eastern approaches to the city. Areas identified as prime opportunities for development in central London included Paddington, King's Cross, South Bank and Elephant and Castle. In the longer term there would be development at transport intersections created by the Thameslink 2000, CrossRail and Hackney-South West rail lines. Instead of suburban sprawl, there would be regeneration of 10 square kilometres of development land in the Thames gateway near some of London's greatest concentrations of deprivation. There would be an "arc of opportunity" in Newham to shift London's employment and residential focus towards the east. Three regional development corridors would be created in the Lea valley leading out towards Stansted, the "western wedge" from Paddington towards Heathrow and the Wandle valley, including Croydon, and stretching towards Gatwick. The plan is not costed at this stage, but it calls for London to retain a larger share of tax revenues to redress years of under investment. It proposes socially balanced communities, built around more public buildings and shopping in local town centres. The document includes plans to protect wildlife, relieve an acute shortage of cemeteries and recycle more of the 18m tonnes of waste produced by the capital each year. It also warns that London's flood defences are at risk from rising water levels caused by global warming.

webTitle: Railtrack faces fines over delays in repairs

fields.headline: Railtrack faces fines over delays in repairs
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack will fail to meet targets set by the regulator to restore the network to normal by May 21, raising the issue of fines against the company, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack will fail to meet targets set by the regulator to restore the network to normal by May 21, raising the issue of fines against the company, industry sources said last night.

Seven months after the Hatfield rail crash, the company is struggling to complete renovation work on parts of the 11,000-mile network, particularly the east and west coast main lines. It was hoping to finish a large part of the work over the holiday weekend.

The regulator, Tom Winsor, will have to decide what action to take against the company for failing to meet the May 21 target, when the summer timetable is due to be introduced. Industry sources said that, given the failure of Railtrack to keep to its promises, Mr Winsor could not just sit back and set a new target for the company.

The regulator's clash with Railtrack will coincide with the publication of Railtrack's annual report and accounts which will show losses of more than £300m, the first since privatisation five years ago.

The sources said that Mr Winsor will have to consider issuing an enforcement order against the company, a move which would raise the question of fines through the courts, or he could condemn the company for its failure to meet the May 21 target, inviting third party action against Railtrack by the train operating companies for recompense for lost business.

Ministers have constantly stressed that the company will not be re-nationalised. But the next few weeks will bring pressure on Labour to reappraise its attitude towards the company if it is re-elected.

Government sources said yesterday that it could not continue handing over money to Railtrack without expecting to see some benefit. The company has been given £2bn over the past few months, but Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, says it will not be enough.

webTitle: 'Health risks' in new police radio system

fields.headline: 'Health risks' in new police radio system
fields.trailText: The Home Office is facing intense pressure to delay the introduction of a £2.5bn police communications system amid warnings it may expose users to health risks on a par with asbestos.
fields.body:
The Home Office is facing intense pressure to delay the introduction of a £2.5bn police communications system amid warnings it may expose users to health risks on a par with asbestos.

Two independent experts on the biological effects of electromagnetic radiation have accused ministers of using the police as guinea pigs by pressing on with the launch of the BT Airwave system in the absence of detailed research into potential health risks.

The advanced digital system, which is being piloted by Lancashire police before being given to every force in the country by 2005, has been welcomed as a technological leap forward.

Using the Terrestrial Trunk Radio System (Tetra), the new European standard for emergency service communications, Airwave offers guaranteed national coverage, vastly improved sound quality, better security through encryption and features such as data transfer and emergency buttons on officers' handsets.

Forces have been complaining for years that the current analogue radio system is woefully inadequate as it does not cover some locations, is prone to break down at crucial times and fails to provide essential security. So confident was the government of the benefits of Tetra that it sold off the existing police frequencies as part of the £20bn auction of licences for the next generation of mobile phones.

But concern is growing that electromagnetic radiation emissions from the handsets may pose a direct health risk for the users.

The fear centres on the operating frequency of 17.6Hz assigned to Tetra when the system was being established. This means that it emits radiation in pulses occurring 17.6 times a second, a level some scientists believe can penetrate deep into the brain, damaging cell communication.

Roger Coghill, an independent research scientist and a member of the Department of Health's UK mobile telecommunications health research programme, said: "A criminal could not have come up with a better system. They couldn't have chosen a better frequency with which to disarm and debilitate the very forces that are trying to secure their arrest."

Alasdair Philips, an expert on the biological effects of electromagnetic radiation and director of the campaign group Powerwatch, said Tetra had the potential to become the "next asbestos".

"It is beyond belief that any one could be contemplating the rollout of a system like Tetra because of the evidence about the dangers of pulsed frequencies," he said. "To design a communications system based on these principles is mind numbing. The effects we may see could well be on a par with Gulf war syndrome."

Last year, Sir William Stewart's report on mobile phone safety concluded that systems modulating at frequencies around 16Hz should be "avoided if possible in future developments of signal coding".

Since then the Home Office has ordered reviews of existing research on Tetra while insisting that rollout of the new system goes ahead as planned.

But the scientists say existing research is inadequate because the tests have only been carried out on animals and human tissue but not on humans.

"I'm currently involved in some research but all this should have been done years ago," Mr Philips said. "The net result is that the police are guinea pigs."

Low-frequency electromagnetic radiation was identified as far back as the 1960s as a potential anti-personnel weapon when the superpowers began conducting experiments into non-lethal "mind control" devices.

fields.body:
 In our leader, May 4, about the planned return to Britain of the criminal Ronnie Biggs, we said that Jack Mills, the train driver, "died later from wounds inflicted during the [great train] robbery." Although the contributory causes of his death, several years after the robbery, during which he was hit on the head with a metal bar, remain controversial, it is stretching a point to say he died of "wounds".

 In a report headed Hague may be on way out..., page 11, May 3, we said Tom King won Bridgwater with a majority of 15,248. In fact, the majority was a marginal 1,796. The larger figure is the Labour majority in Bridgend.

webTitle: Letters: Grisly work on the farm

fields.headline: Grisly work on the farm
fields.trailText: While I am delighted that the foot and mouth crisis is now manageable (Foot and mouth setback over Exmoor cull plan, May 7), countless people who have been directly affected have received little recognition.
fields.body:
While I am delighted that the foot and mouth crisis is now manageable (Foot and mouth setback over Exmoor cull plan, May 7), countless people who have been directly affected have received little recognition. Since early March my husband has been seconded to Maff as an animal health officer (AHO). Since then our lives have been on hold.

For more than eight weeks he has worked, on average, a 14-hour day, six days a week. He is mentally and physically exhausted. But he is one of the lucky ones, he manages to get home on Sundays; a colleague hasn't seen his wife for nine weeks because they live on a farm. He hasn't had a day off in that time.

In Dumfries and Galloway the army is loading animals on to trucks for disposal elsewhere: an unpleasant job but not the worst. The AHOs are dealing with carcasses of animals that have been sick. They build the pyres then load and fire them. Afterwards they clean and disinfect the farms. During the outcry about dioxins, no thought has been given to those closest to the scene.

My husband has had distraught farmers crying on his shoulder. He says this is the most difficult part of the job. He can harden himself to the mountains of dead animals that he sees day after day, but has received no training for the counselling that he has to do.

So, in the run up to the general election, when Tony Blair and his Labour colleagues, senior Maff officials and army generals all pat each other on the back for doing such a great job, how about some proper public recognition for the people who have put their lives on hold and done the most hideous job imaginable? They are the ones who have really got the job done.
Alison Caw
Edinburgh

webTitle: Letters: Two tales of human rights

fields.headline: Two tales of human rights
fields.trailText: A number of reasons have been offered for the removal of the United States from the UN human rights commission (US shocked by loss of key UN seat, May 4).
fields.body:
A number of reasons have been offered for the removal of the United States from the UN human rights commission (US shocked by loss of key UN seat, May 4). No mention, however, has been made in the press of two of the most significant examples of human rights abuses committed by the United States: the use of torture weapons in American prisons and the sale of these weapons worldwide.

Restraint chairs, pepper spray, stun guns and stun belts are employed routinely throughout the American penal system. And in its latest report on the subject, Stopping the Torture Trade, Amnesty International states that the US is by far the largest exporter of leg irons, shackles and electroshock stun devices in the world.

I imagine these factors were part of the deliberations of the UN human rights commission.
Harold Pinter
London
llen@dialstart.net

 Michael Ellison states that America received fewer votes than, among others, Bahrain in the ballot for a seat on the UN human rights commission.

Bahrain has set an example in the promotion of human rights. In February 2001 Bahrain released every political prisoner, invited all exiles to return home, scrapped security legislation and held a referendum on the introduction of democracy. Bahrainis are now setting up a bicameral parliament with full legislative powers whose members will be elected by both men and women.

Amnesty International described these events as "extraordinary developments", and said that its delegates witnessed "a truly historic period for human rights" when they visited the country earlier this year. Bahrain's election to the UN human rights commission is deserved recognition of the country's achievements.
Hugh Canavan
Gulf Centre for Strategic Studies, London

webTitle: Letters: Politicians should accept they can't run a railway

fields.headline: Politicians should accept they can't run a railway
fields.trailText: It is difficult to see how Tony Grayling can support his argument that the railways are a natural monopoly (Trains and shares and planes, May 4) when the data he uses show rail has only an 8% share of the UK travel market.
fields.body:
It is difficult to see how Tony Grayling can support his argument that the railways are a natural monopoly (Trains and shares and planes, May 4) when the data he uses show rail has only an 8% share of the UK travel market. The Office of Fair Trading requires at least a 25% market share before an investigation. Nor can he argue that rail is like water, when there is no practical alternative to water while, for most people, rail is not even an everyday method of travel.

To argue that political control is needed for the railways because they receive large sums of public money is not logical, since other private-sector industries also receive large sums of public money. Nor can the record of custodianship when the railways were in public ownership from 1948 to 1996 raise confidence. During that time the railways were reorganised on average every five years and their freight market share shrank from 42% to 7%, and passenger share from 35% to 7%.

In 1968 the Select Committee on Nationalised (transport) Industries reported that, while ministers were supposed to lay down broad policy guidelines, they rarely did but were "closely involved in many aspects of management". No wonder the railway industry shrivelled, with its roots constantly being dug up by politicians for checking.

What the railways need is a long period of consolidation without constant political interference, so that managers can manage the network back to being an important method of transport in the UK. It was good to hear Lord Macdonald announce last week that the railways would not be renationalised.
Prof Lewis Lesley Liverpool JM University
transport-science@rapid.co.uk

 On Saturday I went to watch my son's last rugby match for York University. I decided to leave my car at home in west London and let the train take the strain. Alas, the journey did not go as planned. The Southwest train into Waterloo was delayed so I missed my connection at King's Cross. I boarded the next LNER intercity train but it developed a fault so, after half an hour, we were herded to a replacement train on another platform.

When I eventually arrived in York I had missed the start of the match. Returning to York station after the game, my connection was running an hour late. An earlier train was running even later so I caught that instead. It got to King's Cross two hours late. The final leg of my journey from Waterloo was capped by a 30-minute delay looking for a driver.

The only part of the trip that worked effectively was the tube connection between Waterloo and King's Cross. This government is now hell bent on destroying the underground in the same way as the Conservatives decimated British Rail. One can only deduce that no one in government uses the railway. Perhaps if they did they would think again about their idiotic dogma and the damage it will do to London.
Michael Crosby
Staines, Middlesex

fields.headline: After Orwell
fields.trailText: "The world of Nineteen Eighty-Four ended in 1989," asserts Timothy Garton Ash (Orwell for our time, Saturday review, May 5). With the deaths of Orwell's "three dragons" (imperialism, fascism and communism), "Orwell had won." But he hadn't. He had lost.
fields.body:
"The world of Nineteen Eighty-Four ended in 1989," asserts Timothy Garton Ash (Orwell for our time, Saturday review, May 5). With the deaths of Orwell's "three dragons" (imperialism, fascism and communism), "Orwell had won." But he hadn't. He had lost. Where was socialism? Nowhere. In making his assertion, Ash is forced to make a distinction that shouldn't need making: "... communism, not to be confused with the socialism in which Orwell himself believed..." It was this very confusion that Orwell fought against. "Nothing," he said, "has contributed so much to the corruption of the idea of socialism as the belief that Russia is a socialist country."

In our time this myth (that what western socialists wanted was what the Soviet Union had) was put about so successfully by the Conservative press that, when the Soviet Union fell, the socialist movement collapsed as a serious force in the west. And we are now left with a concoction of liberalism and Thatcherism which has been labelled by its creator "New Labour".
Michael McEvoy
Hanworth, Middlesex michaelmcevoy@onetel.net.uk

 Timothy Garton Ash makes a good case for his claim that George Orwell was the most influential writer of the 20th century. But in dismissing as "striking misjudgment" Orwell's claim that "fascism and capitalism are at bottom the same thing", he fails to acknowledge the emerging new dragon of nation states in hock to capital. And in reminding us that Orwell's real name was Eric Blair, Garton Ash fails to make the connection with Tony Blair, whose New Labour drives forward the agenda of making society and people subservient to capital. Never were we more in need of a George Orwell.
Daniel Vulliamy
Hull D.L.Vulliamy@cll.hull.ac.uk

And in reminding us that Orwell's real name was Eric Blair, Garton Ash fails to make the connection with Tony Blair, whose New Labour drives forward the agenda of making society and people subservient to capital. Never were we more in need of a George Orwell. Daniel Vulliamy Hull D.L.Vulliamy@cll.hull.ac.uk

fields.headline: The left gathers steam
fields.trailText: According to Roy Hattersley (It's still my party right or wrong, May 7), the success of Labour in a forthcoming election is ineluctable whereas the Conservative party is unelectable.
fields.body:
According to Roy Hattersley (It's still my party right or wrong, May 7), the success of Labour in a forthcoming election is ineluctable whereas the Conservative party is unelectable. He nevertheless urges disillusioned Labour voters to register a vote for New Labour, in spite of Jack Straw replicating Michael Howard's "reforms" and David Blunkett breaking his promise to extend comprehensive education.

To those I would add: failure to establish local democracy by restoring greater powers to local government; obsession with privatisation of London Underground in spite of horrendous results from British Rail; support for GM crop experiments even when sites are close to organic farms; and tacit support for "Son of Star Wars", which would re-establish an arms race.

Like Hattersley, I did not leave the Labour party with the Gang of Four. But he is wrong if he thinks that his staying had any effect on the direction of the party. I suggest the opposite happened. New Labour is a direct result of the Gang of Four's defection, in the same way as Thatcherism pushed the Labour party to the right.

Unlike Hattersley, the ordinary voter has no regular public platform on which to express his discontent. I hope that Tony Blair will recognise from a diminished vote that some of us have had enough of his rightwing policies.
Daphne Partridge
Southwick, West Sussex partridge@unisonfree.net

 You quote Roy Hattersley's warning (Blair fears stayaway voters, May 7) of the "near extinction of Her Majesty's opposition" if there were another Labour landslide. To my mind it would be the single best thing for the country if the Tory party was so comprehensively rejected that it split into two: a Europhile party and a Little Englander party. This would leave the Liberal Democrats as the official opposition and social democracy the undisputed basis of British politics. The Tories have ruined this country since the second world war - let us be shot of them once and for all.
RL Symonds
Mereworth, Kent r.symonds@virgin.net

 Roy Hattersley reminds me of Samuel Beckett, who was obsessed with death but graciously agreed ("I can't go on, I'll go on") to live. Hattersley clearly prefers his own deathly tenure of office in the Labour party to its current bouncy vitality. The comedy of Beckett's negation was illustrated by his wife's reaction on hearing he'd won the Nobel prize (" Quelle catastrophe!") which Sam nevertheless accepted. Posturing the negative is an absurdist position in the theatre, a sad thing in politics.
Gil Elliot
London

 Roy Hattersley is likely to be disappointed in his irrational and forlorn hope that some day his party will return to its social democratic past. The long line of New Labour managerial politicians who have discarded their previous political convictions and are willing to step into Blair's shoes should he fall on his sword is demonstrated by your piece on Alan Milburn (How firebrand Milburn became a model manager, May 7). A growing number of socialists are not prepared to wait with Roy Hattersley. Labour will be facing its largest ever challenge from the left in the general election, with over 300 socialist candidates.
Nick Long
Independent Labour/ Green Socialist PPC Lewisham west

 How totally refreshing Roy Hattersley is. Is there no chance that he can renounce his peerage and stand as a socialist next month?
Micael McKiernan
Lichfield, Staffs
mmckiernan@ireland.com

webTitle: Comment:  Wembley fiasco is indictment of greedy elite

fields.headline: Kick out the money
fields.standfirst:
The Wembley fiasco is an indictment of the greedy elite which has stolen the game

Special report: the future of Wembley
Guardian football site
fields.trailText: The Wembley fiasco is an indictment of the greedy elite which has stolen the game.
fields.body:
It was only a matter of time before Wembley stadium sought to change its strip. When the banks blew the whistle on the rebuilding programme and the government refused to move the goalposts, the project was left with nothing to sell but its name. The stadium's identity, it seems, is worth some £120m. Though this represents just one-fifth of the cost of the reconstruction, the company which bought it would, in effect, acquire cultural ownership of our most famous arena. The Sunday Telegraph helpfully suggested that it might be called the "Coca-Cola National Stadium".

This would not be the first such deal. Drive past the Bolton Wanderers stadium at night, and all you'll see is a gigantic Reebok logo. The Wanderers' own badge is attached to the wall, but it isn't illuminated. "Football," the club's website boasts, "has become the ideal medium in which to project your company image to the mass market. A captive audience of thousands come to the Reebok stadium every match day."

It has taken centuries to reduce football, and its audience, to captivity. As the anarchist journal Do or Die records, the authorities first sought to restrain the game in 1314. Edward II's court complained of "a great noise in the city caused by hustling over large balls, from which many evils may arise". It forbade football on pain of imprisonment. But no one seemed to take much notice. In those days football was played by hundreds of men, striving to propel the ball from parish to parish by almost any means possible. Anyone who sought to stop them would have been kicked into touch.

In the 17th and 18th centuries, vast numbers of men would come together on newly enclosed land to play political football. Soon after kick-off, the ball would be abandoned, and the players would start ripping up the dykes and hedges erected by the landlords. Unsurprisingly, the game was condemned in 1796 as "disgraceful to humanity and civilisation, subversive of good order and government and destructive of the morals, properties and very lives of our inhabitants".

But as the great open spaces the traditional game required were fenced off and privatised, the sport of the peasantry and proletariat became ripe for acquisition. In 1848, the year of revolution, football succumbed to the forces of reaction: a group of undergraduates drew up the "Cambridge rules", forbidding the riotous assembly which was, for many players, the entire purpose of the game. The rowdy carnival moved to the terraces: between 1894 and 1914, Do or Die notes, there were 4,000 recorded instances of football "hooliganism".

But even the polite and formal 11-a-side game has proved too sprawling and too free for modern proprietorship. Soon after it took office, the Thatcher government changed the law to allow schools and local authorities to sell their assets. Playing fields were seized by developers to build superstores and executive estates. This government promised to bring these sales to an end: in 1998 it granted special powers to the Department of Education to defend school grounds. But in the two years following their introduction, the secretary of state approved 115 applications to destroy school playing fields, and rejected just four.

Fans as well as players have now been shut out of the game. Until 1981, the Football Association sought to ensure that the clubs belonged in spirit to their supporters, not their proprietors. Then, however, in the name of stimulating investment, it relaxed the rule which forbade the owners from issuing a dividend greater than 5% of the nominal value of the shares. From that point on, as the football writer David Conn has documented, the game was offered for sale to the highest bidder.

Martin Edwards spent £600,000 building up his stake in Manchester United, then sold most of it a few years later for some £100m. John Hall bought Newcastle for £3m, later selling just 10% of the club for £16m. Ken Bates bought Chelsea in 1982 for £1. The 18% he retains is now worth some £10m.

As football began to be kicked around between its proprietors, the turnstiles gave way to television as its principle source of income. At first the money from the broadcasting rights was distributed evenly between all the clubs in the football league. But in 1991, with the Football Association's backing, the most lucrative teams broke away to form the FA Carling Premiership, whose principal purpose was to capture almost all the broadcast fees. The league sold exclusive rights, now worth £1.1bn, to Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB. The top clubs and their owners were massively enriched. The rest were left with sweet FA.

Ninety per cent of the clubs outside the premiership are now losing money. School leagues are collapsing, semi-professional teams are going bust. The premiership has picked up the ball and walked off the pitch.

While the fans remain loyal to the corporations which have usurped their clubs, the new owners appear to believe that they have no obligation to reciprocate. The average cost of a ticket to a premiership football match is now 10% higher than the average cost of a ticket to the Royal Opera House. Two hundred years ago, anyone could play football. Twenty years ago anyone could turn up and cheer. Today even watching their team on television is beyond the means of some fans.

A full team strip, which some of the clubs contrive to change every few months in order to wring more money from their supporters, now costs up to £100. And the strips are, of course, little more than mobile hoardings. Anyone can see that Michael Owen represents Carlsberg and Reebok. But you'd need binoculars to notice that he also plays for Liverpool.

If the Wembley stadium is to become just another corporate acquisition from which all but corporate VIPs are excluded, then it makes no difference to most of us whether it is rebuilt or not. Indeed, a new national stadium in London would merely consolidate the enclosure of the game, sustaining the capital's cultural and economic sovereignty.

So what's to be done? I suspect that Do or Die's prescription of three-sided psycho-geographic football will be slow to catch on. But it seems to me that the undying loyalty which makes the big clubs' fans so vulnerable to exploitation is now gravely misplaced. Perhaps we need to abandon the existing clubs and form new teams (drawing their players only from the places they are supposed to represent) and a new football association, controlled and financed entirely by the fans and ploughing any money it makes back into community sports.

It's time we kicked the money out of football. Let's leave the proprietors to play economic handball in front of the hospitality boxes, and reclaim the game in the streets and fields in which it first arose.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Russian forces unleashed a fierce assault on the Chechen town of Argun yesterday, shortly before an EU human rights mission flew into the region.
fields.body:
Russians pound Chechen town

Russian forces unleashed a fierce assault on the Chechen town of Argun yesterday, shortly before an EU human rights mission flew into the region.

A rebel spokesman said fighting was raging in "every street" after the Russians swooped to arrest suspected guerrillas. Reuters, Moscow

Police blamed for Iran deaths

Iranian football fans who illegally sat on a stadium's fibreglass roof caused it to collapse on Sunday, killing at least two supporters and injuring hundreds, the deputy sports director of of Mazandaran province said.

Asghar Samarbakhsh blamed police for allowing 25,000 people into the Sari stadium, meant to accommodate 15,000. "All those on the roof were without tickets," he said. AP, Sari

Liberians angry at UN sanctions

Thousands of Liberians took to the streets of Monrovia again yesterday in protest at UN sanctions imposed on the country for fuelling war in west Africa.

The ban on Liberia's diamond exports and on travel by its top officials began yesterday, two months after the security council gave Liberia a period of grace to prove it had cut its links with Sierra Leone's rebels. President Charles Taylor is accused of supply ing the rebels in return for diamonds. Reuters, Monrovia

Princess is pregnant

Crown Prince Philippe of Belgium and his wife, Mathilde, are expecting their first child in November. Philippe, 41, heir to King Albert II, has enjoyed a popularity boost since the marriage 18 months ago.

The princess, 28, is the daughter of a Flemish aristocrat, but was brought up in the French-speaking south. Reuters, Brussels

Stockholm wolf eludes police

Police chased a wolf in central Stockholm yesterday but gave up after it disappeared into a forest. It is believed to be one of about 120 wild wolves in south Scandinavia. Reuters, Stockholm

webTitle: Australia opens first heroin injecting room

fields.headline: Australia opens first heroin injecting room
fields.trailText: Australia's first legal heroin injecting room, the largest "shooting gallery" in the world, has opened its doors to drug users in Sydney's red-light district, despite opposition.
fields.body:
Australia's first legal heroin injecting room, the largest "shooting gallery" in the world, has opened its doors to drug users in Sydney's red-light district despite opposition from Aborigines and local business people.

The 18-month trial in Kings Cross, an inner city area notorious for prostitution and drug dealing, will aim to cut the country's drug overdose deaths, which have soared from six in 1964 to 958 in 1999.

Since it was proposed two years ago, the injecting room has attracted criticism from local people, the Australian prime minister and the Pope, who sent a letter forbidding the Sisters of Charity order to run the centre, where nurses provide supervision and sterile equipment for addicts to inject drugs.

An Aboriginal elder lodged a complaint with the Land Titles Office last Friday, claiming that the $A500,000 (£185,000) injecting room was close to an indigenous burial ground. Uniting Care, the charity running the centre, has 21 days to respond.

The controversial trial was originally intended to involve several other shooting galleries, but two court challenges and divided public opinion led New South Wales's Labor government to support a single centre.

The NSW premier, Bob Carr, whose brother died from a drug overdose, and the police have backed the project, which is funded by money confiscated from convicted drug dealers.

The local chamber of commerce, which lost a Supreme Court challenge to the injecting room last month, claimed the centre was already exacerbating drug use in Kings Cross. "As of the last 24 hours there's been an enormous increase in the number of drug addicts and dealers in this area," its spokesman Paul Haege said.

Local drug users last night welcomed the shooting gallery, which can offer 200 injections daily, but many said they had been scared off by media attention. Just eight users stepped past waiting camera crews to enter the centre on its first day.

"I think it's a good thing, otherwise there are people shooting up in the gutters," said Helen. "But I wouldn't use it after last night when I saw all my friends walking in there on TV."

She said she regularly witnessed about five overdoses a night in Kings Cross and believed that the injecting room would definitely help cut drug-related deaths. One in five drug overdoses in New South Wales occur in the district.

Critics of the injecting room pointed out that it failed to stop ambulances being called out to three overdoses in Kings Cross on its first night, but the centre's staff appealed for time and space for the trial, the first in an English-speaking country, to work properly.

fields.headline: Red ink on the Thames
fields.standfirst: Millennium projects need fresh appraisal
fields.trailText: The failure of the Millennium Dome at Greenwich has become a symbol of public sector inadequacy and an ongoing warning that prestigious projects like this are best left to the private sector.
fields.body:
The failure of the Millennium Dome at Greenwich has become a symbol of public sector inadequacy and an ongoing warning that prestigious projects like this are best left to the private sector.

The brief but loss-making history of the dome is regularly contrasted with its private sector rival up river, the London Eye, or millennium wheel. While the dome failed, dismally, to attract the number of people it projected, the eye received 3.5m visitors in its first year, 60% more than expected. It still revolves proudly every day taking visitors into its slow-moving pods without bothering even to stop. It looks to outsiders like a revolving cash generating machine, proving to the backers of the dome and others how a prestigious project should be executed.

Except for one thing. The London Eye Company has just released its first accounts. They show that instead of making a fat profit it actually lost £8m in its first year, despite having attracted 1.8m more visitors than forecast. A spokesman for British Airways, the main owner, said it aimed to break even "in the medium term", a phrase so vague that not even lossmaking dot.com companies use it. The company is reported to have dropped plans to float the company on the stock markets and approaches to build similar eyes abroad do not seem to have made much progress. Unless the company is indulging in sophisticated accounting methods to benefit the company's main debtors (BA and Tussauds Attractions), then maybe there is something about these projects that makes it difficult to make an early return whether they are in the public or private sectors.

Neither project, however, gets the gain on its balance sheet of external benefits that arise. The sight of the eye has given great - if unquantifiable - joy to passers by even if they don't indulge themselves. It is one of the reasons why visitors come to London (even during this depressed year) and they also spend lots of money on other things, thereby stimulating the local economy. A cost-benefit analysis of the dome would almost certainly find that as a result of its construction and the associated infrastructure (including the extension to the Jubilee Line) land values all around had gone up significantly. The brief but loss-making history of the dome is regularly contrasted with its private sector rival up river, the London Eye, or millennium wheel. While the dome failed, dismally, to attract the number of people it projected, the eye received 3.5m visitors in its first year, 60% more than expected. It still revolves proudly every day taking visitors into its slow-moving pods without bothering even to stop. The London Eye Company has just released its first accounts. They show that instead of making a fat profit it actually lost £8m in its first year, despite having attracted 1.8m more visitors than forecast. A spokesman for British Airways, the main owner, said it aimed to break even "in the medium term", a phrase so vague that not even lossmaking dot.com companies use it. The company is reported to have dropped plans to float the company on the stock markets and approaches to build similar eyes abroad do not seem to have made much progress. fields.headline: Greece's negligence
fields.standfirst: It must do more to combat terrorism
fields.trailText: Heather Saunders, the widow of the British military attaché, Stephen Saunders, murdered by terrorists in Athens last June, says she has not given up hope of seeing her husband's killers brought to justice.
fields.body:
Heather Saunders, the widow of the British military attaché, Stephen Saunders, murdered by terrorists in Athens last June, says she has not given up hope of seeing her husband's killers brought to justice. But her happiness and that of her children had been ruined, she told the Wiltshire coroner last month. "My life has been blown from under me."

The Greek government should be in no doubt that many other people in Britain, and elsewhere, are also hoping that the members of the 17 November anti-capitalist, anti-Nato terror gang responsible for this odious crime will soon be arrested. Greece has long had a reputation for being less than totally robust in its approach to combating terrorism.

This perception (which Greeks protest is unfair) has been reinforced by the failure to apprehend any member of 17 November, in the Saunders case or otherwise, despite its admitted involvement in over 100 incidents since 1975 and the deaths of 22 other people, some of them also diplo mats. Greece has been urged, most recently by George Tenet, the CIA director, to get a grip. But the impact of such admonitions is diluted by often repeated, disturbing suggestions, which by their nature cannot be verified, that the left-wing terrorists are to some extent protected by sympathetic, influential political or enforcement figures.

Greece has a bigger than usual incentive to dispel such worries: the 2004 Olympic Games, which it is due to host. Controversy already surrounds construction projects, many of which are behind schedule and over cost - and in the case of a planned sailing centre at Marathon, culturally and environmentally intrusive. Greece has been warned by the International Olympic Committee that it could lose the games if matters do not improve rapidly. But this concern must encompass the paramount need to ensure security for athletes and spectators. The terrorist massacre at the 1972 Munich Olympics is not forgotten.

fields.headline: Freeways swallow drivers' free time
fields.trailText: Congestion on US highways is now so bad that the average American spends 36 hours a year sitting in traffic, a report published yesterday reveals.
fields.body:
Congestion on US highways is now so bad that the average American spends 36 hours a year sitting in traffic, a report published yesterday reveals.

Two years earlier, the average American spent 34 hours in traffic annually, compared with 11 hours per year in 1982, according to the Texas Transportation Institute at Texas A&M University, which studied congestion in 68 urban areas. The data was compiled by 11 state highway departments.

Congestion costs an estimated $78bn (£55bn) a year in wasted time and petrol, the institute said.

The most congested highways in the country were found in Los Angeles, California, where residents in 1999 averaged 56 hours a year - more than a working week's worth of time - in bumper-to-bumper traffic.

The study's co-author Tim Lomax, a research engineer, said that the building of transport infrastructure, including roads and bus and rail systems are not keeping pace with the construction of new housing and businesses across the country.

"It's a whole lot easier to start a manufacturing company or a software firm or build new housing than it is to put in a new highway or new street or even a new bus route," he said.

A research group funded by the building industry warned that growing congestion on US highways could hurt the economy and jeopardise quality of life.

"Increasing traffic congestion nationwide threatens to put the brakes on the nation's economic growth," William Wilkins, executive director of the Road Information Programme, said.

fields.headline: Mandela to write second memoir
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela is to write a second, and potentially more controversial, autobiography covering the years since his release from prison in 1990.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela is to write a second, and potentially more controversial, autobiography covering the years since his release from prison in 1990.

The book will pick up where his successful first autobiography, Long Walk to Freedom, left off. But whereas that book was principally a tale of struggle and heroism, the second will have to delve in to the murky world of wielding power if it is to achieve anything like the same success.

The new book can be expected to deal with Mr Mandela's fractious relationship with the man who set him free, former president FW de Klerk.

Mutual respect between the two Nobel peace prize winners quickly diminished, not least because Mr Mandela came to believe that the white regime was perpetuating violence in black townships as part of its negotiating strategy.

Through all of this, Mr Mandela's marriage was falling apart as not only were Winnie's misdeeds laid bare but she refused to drop her boyfriend.

The book will also be a defence of Mr Mandela's presidency which some in the ANC say was too strong on reconciliation and weak on reform.

Critics say President Thabo Mbeki believes the Mandela government was one of missed opportunities, particularly to undertake a greater redistribution of wealth in the early days of the new South Africa.

Among the most timely insights Mr Mandela can offer - if he chooses - will be about Mr Mbeki. The former president secretly favoured another candidate to be his deputy and anointed Cyril Ramaphosa.

Mr Mbeki won the day with the party. The government recently named Mr Ramaphosa as one of three anti-apartheid politicians under investigation for an apparently non-existent plot to oust Mr Mbeki.

fields.headline: Charles Johnson
fields.trailText: As president of the International Flat Earth Society, Charles Johnson who has died aged 76, maintained that our planet was a disc of unknown dimensions, with the North Pole in the middle.
fields.body:
When Charles Johnson looked out of his window, the view of California's Mojave desert stretching to the horizon neatly confirmed his beliefs as president of the International Flat Earth Society. But what of the frequent arrivals of Nasa space shuttles at the nearby Edwards air force base, and the photographs of earth as a globe that astonauts brought back?

Johnson, who has died aged 76, scoffed. "It's just a stupid old airplane carried piggy-back and dropped over Lancaster [the town where he lived]. It hasn't orbited earth, that we know."

The congruence of these two - America's pioneers into the cosmos, and the white-bearded Johnson with his crackpot theories - were further proof, if any is needed, that California rivals England as the home of eccentrics. Through his quarterly Flat Earth News, which once had 3,500 subscribers, Johnson maintained that our planet was a disc of unknown dimensions, with the North Pole in the middle.

For him, the sun and moon, each 32 miles in diameter, circled the disc at a constant height of 3,000 miles. So-called sunsets, which he liked to watch from his porch as he smoked a cigar, were optical illusions. And the 1969 televised moon landing was really filmed in Arizona with a script by science-fiction writer Arthur C Clarke.

Before chuckling at Johnson's wrongheadedness, it should be noted that his society was an English invention. He took over in 1972 from the late Samuel Shenton of Dover, and the society traced its origins to the Universal Zetetic [investigating] Society, founded in England in 1832 by Sir Birley Rowbotham, who wrote a tract called Earth Not A Globe.

In 1888, the even more gloriously named Sir Walter de Sodington Blount conducted a series of experiments on the Old Bedford Level canal, proving, he said, that the earth did not curve.

This, at least, was Johnson's account of his society's origins. He and his late Australian wife, Marjory, measured the surface of Lake Tahoe, in northern California, to arrive at the same conclusion. Furthermore, Johnson insisted, his wife did not hang by her feet when she was young in a place that should never be called Down Under.

Johnson was only eight, and living in Texas, when he became committed to flat earthism. He recalled spinning a globe in class, listening incredulously to his teacher talking about gravity, and then looking out of the window at a lake, where he observed no curvature. He was an articulate defender of his beliefs and, although not highly educated, was a forceful and fluent writer.

He always insisted that the globe theory was invented by scientists - "the same old gang of witch doctors, sorcerers, tellers of tales, and priest entertainers" - attempting to obliterate Christian beliefs. Johnson was convinced that Jesus believed in a flat earth because he "ascended" into heaven, and "if earth were a ball, there would be no up or down."

Born in San Angelo, Texas, Johnson graduated from the local high school, and moved to San Francisco, where he was an airplane mechanic for 25 years. He began corresponding with Shenton, who specified before his death that Johnson should replace him at the society's head, and, by the mid-1990s, its membership had grown to nearly 4,000.

Members paid $25 a year and were given a map of the flat world. This was also, Johnson pointed out, the insignia of the United Nations, demonstrating that its founders were, at heart, flat earthers.

His last years were marrred by a near-fatal mishap, when his house burned down in 1995. He managed to rescue Marjory, who was, by then, in a wheel chair and needed oxygen to breathe. All his records were burned, and Marjory died the following year.

Johnson moved into a caravan next to the ruin of his home, but local authority officials evicted him because it did not have the required wooden foundations. He moved in with his brother, his only survivor, on the outskirts of Lancaster, and began to rebuild the society. It now has about 100 members.

fields.headline: Boozoo Chavis
fields.standfirst: Accordionist behind America's zydeco renaissance
fields.trailText: Accordionist behind America's zydeco renaissance.
fields.body:
Of all the strange music to issue from the United States during the birth pangs of rock 'n' roll in the mid-1950s, there was no record more bizarre than Paper In My Shoe, by the Louisiana singer and accordionist "Boozoo" Chavis, who has died aged 70.

The lurching, droning two-step, played on saxophone and button accordion, was, for many listeners, their first contact with zydeco, the vernacular music of African-American Louisiana, linked to the white Cajun tradition.

That the record became a minor hit in 1954, however, was probably due less to ethnomusicological curiosity than to the spectacular ruggedness of the performance - not only are the musicians out of tune with each other, but the accordion is out of tune with itself - and its enigmatic subject-matter.

"I got a paper in my shoe . . . well, your mama don't 'low," seemed to be about the extent of the lyric, sung in both English and French. Close listening suggests that Chavis was actually describing a pebble in his shoe, in which case the song was not some slice of southwestern folklore but a cover of a late-1930s recording by Ella Fitzgerald.

Imperfect though the finished product was, it was lucky to have been made at all. At the time, Chavis, whose reputation as a musician hardly extended beyond the black community of Dog Hill, in Lake Charles, Louisiana, was accustomed to playing solo, keeping time by stamping his feet on a Coca-Cola crate.

In the studio, he was teamed with a local band, Classie Ballou's Tempo Kings, but, as the recording director, Eddie Shuler, remembered: "Classie had no idea what Boozoo was trying to do. Finally, I spent $1.25 on a half-pint of Seagram's 7, hoping the whiskey would loosen everybody up." Chavis is said to have become so loose that towards the end of the recording he fell off his chair, an incident Shuler concealed with a tactful fadeout.

Subsequent records were less successful, and, after a dispute about royalties, Chavis concentrated on breeding and training racehorses. Some 25 years would pass before he hitched on his accordion again. With his sons, Charles and Rellis, and a couple of other young musicians, he formed the Magic Sounds, and began playing regularly at Richard's Club in Lawtell.

Alongside fellow accordionists Stanley "Buckwheat Zydeco" Dural, John Delafose, Rockin' Dopsie (Obituary, October 4 1993) and younger players like Nathan Williams, Chavis led a local renaissance of zydeco music in the mid-1980s that defied the recent death of the idiom's most famous practitioner, Clifton Chenier.

As a senior figure, Chavis saw his role clearly. "They got all these guys out here sayin' 'zydeco zydeco', and them jokers ain't no more playin' zydeco than I'm jumpin' out the window. I want to show the world what zydeco is."

He made a series of albums for both local and national labels, marketed a line of souvenir underwear, and was featured in Robert Mugge's film The Kingdom Of Zydeco, where he conducted a musical battle with his younger rival Beau Jocque.

Within a decade, as his producer Scott Billington noted, "It was Boozoo's sound, not that of Clifton Chenier, which had become the dominant model for zydeco - the loud push-and-pull of the diatonic accordion, the pumped-up low end, and songs that sacrificed everything else for groove."

Meanwhile, Boozoo played every weekend at dancehalls on the Gulf Coast circuit. "After a few songs," said records journalist Ben Sandmel, "Boozoo's invariably dripping with sweat. To protect his accordion from perspiration, he wears an apron, which, in combination with his ubiquitous Stetson, creates the surrealistic image of Lawrence Welk transformed into a cowboy short-order cook who sings in Creole French."

Boozoo is survived by his wife Leona, three sons and three daughters.

fields.headline: John Kashdan
fields.standfirst: Artist whose monotypes filled a missing link in printmaking
fields.trailText: Artist whose monotypes filled a missing link in printmaking.
fields.body:
The works of the painter and printmaker John Kashdan, who has died aged 84, were exhibited in Britain and the United States until he withdrew them from the gallery scene after 1950. But following a distinguished teaching career, he began to exhibit again after almost 40 years, and the British Museum, in particular, recognised the innovative quality of his monotype prints.

Born in London of a Russian father and English mother, Kashdan grew up in straitened circumstances. At the age of 12, he decided to become an artist, but then had to leave school at 14. Attending evening classes at a working men's institute led to the suggestion that he apply to the Royal Academy schools.

In 1935, he visited Paris and painted in northern France. A compensation payment from an accident enabled him, at last, to start at the Royal Academy schools in 1936. As a first-year student, he won the RA gold medal and travelling scholarship, which he used to spend the summers from 1936-39 in the south of France.

The works he painted after moving to Cambridge in 1943 showed the influence of Picasso and Bracque, as well as that of Juan Gris, whose work he had seen in the collection of his friend Gustav Kahnweiler. Kashdan painted mainly still lifes, demonstrating his interest in design and colour construction, while his Artist And Model series of paintings were more exuberant, with flamboyant colour and bold use of line. Kahnweiler's encouragement resulted in him getting his first exhibition, at the Redfern gallery, London, in 1945.

He had many literary friends, and an interest in theatre led to puppet theatre becoming a subject of some paintings and prints, and, later, to the use of dramatic improvisation as a vehicle for teaching in art schools.

Kashdan used to visit Henry Moore's studio regularly. He was impressed by the simple abstract shapes of Moore's early sculpture, and by his Shelter Sketchbooks, published during the war. Moore brought Kashdan's work to the attention of James J Sweeney, of the Museum of Modern Art, New York.

Another artist friend was Richard Ziegler, a German refugee also living in Cambridge. Ziegler, who had known Paul Klee in Germany, had developed his own print-making process using transfer drawing and duplicator paper to make editions of his prints. The freedom of expression he achieved impressed Kashdan, who evolved his own techniques to make monotypes, or unique impressions on paper.

Kashdan produced a great variety of monotype prints in the 1940s and 1950s, often combining the classic monotype technique of Dégas with a form of offset drawing similar to that pioneered by Klee and Ziegler. He also experimented with a method of etching on acetate and a simple form of screenprinting.

Klee's work was a strong influence, and Kashdan met Jankel Adler, a close associate of Klee. In 1946, he was invited to send about 50 monotypes for exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, and showed this portfolio to Adler before the prints were dispatched to New York. Adler was impressed, and introduced Kashdan to Robert Colquhoun, Robert MacBryde and John Minton. Kashdan's monotypes, and the techniques he had developed, had a strong effect on Colquhoun and MacBryde, who began to make their own monotypes.

Adler's main pursuit was what Michael Middleton has called the quest "to bring the human figure within a post-Cubist, post-Expressionist framework". Like Adler, Kashdan used archetypal, and even grotesque, figures and faces to represent universal images of the suffering of the war years.

He had also encountered the work of the Mexican popular artist Posada, whose tendency towards caricature and whose bizarre visions of grinning skeletons bedecked with striking hats and clothes were echoed in Kashdan's monotype series of Nocturnal Heads and Insect Women, in which he portrayed sinister figures of the night derived from Kafka's Metamorphosis, and savagely caricatured society women as beetles with glittering shells.

Postwar relief was tempered by pessimism - there was shock at the revelations of wartime atrocities, and anxiety about the atom bomb. Kashdan felt progressively less interested in being part of what he called "the gallery scene". His mood and work had become dark, intense and brooding, highly charged with grief and drama.

His monotypes and drawings were exhibited in 1947 at the Art Institute of Chicago and, in 1948, at the Philadelphia Art Alliance. From 1948 to 1950, he continued to exhibit in mixed exhibitions in London and Cambridge. But he then decided to withdraw from public exhibitions, and concentrate on teaching.

Kashdan had moved to Devon in 1946 to take up a teaching post and launch an art department at the Royal Naval College, Dartmouth. An articulate and inspiring teacher, he moved to the Guildford School of Art in 1951, and to Epsom School of Art in 1972, remaining there until retirement in 1982.

In 1989, his first one-man exhibition for almost 40 years - a retrospective of paintings and monotypes from 1940 -55 - was held at the England & co gallery, in London. The British Museum's department of prints and drawings recognised the significance of this missing link in the history of British printmaking, and acquired a substantial collection of his work.

Some were later included in the major exhibition (and book of the same title), Avant-Garde British Printmaking 1914-60, at the British Museum in 1990. In 1991, Kashdan held a second exhibition at England & co of monotypes from 1941-91.

He leaves his second wife, Marthe, and three sons and daughter from his first marriage.

Attending evening classes at a working men's institute led to the suggestion that he apply to the Royal Academy schools. In 1935, he visited Paris and painted in northern France. A compensation payment from an accident enabled him, at last, to start at the Royal Academy schools in 1936. As a first-year student, he won the RA gold medal and travelling scholarship, which he used to spend the summers from 1936-39 in the south of France. The works he painted after moving to Cambridge in 1943 showed the influence of Picasso and Bracque, as well as that of Juan Gris, whose work he had seen in the collection of his friend Gustav Kahnweiler. Kashdan painted mainly still lifes, demonstrating his interest in design and colour construction, while his Artist And Model series of paintings were more exuberant, with flamboyant colour and bold use of line. Kahnweiler's encouragement resulted in him getting his first exhibition, at the Redfern gallery, London, in 1945. He had many literary friends, and an interest in theatre led to puppet theatre becoming a subject of some paintings and prints, and, later, to the use of dramatic improvisation as a vehicle for teaching in art schools. Kashdan used to visit Henry Moore's studio regularly. He was impressed by the simple abstract shapes of Moore's early sculpture, and by his Shelter Sketchbooks, published during the war. Moore brought Kashdan's work to the attention of James J Sweeney, of the Museum of Modern Art, New York. Another artist friend was Richard Ziegler, a German refugee also living in Cambridge. Ziegler, who had known Paul Klee in Germany, had developed his own print-making process using transfer drawing and duplicator paper to make editions of his prints. The freedom of expression he achieved impressed Kashdan, who evolved his own techniques to make monotypes, or unique impressions on paper. fields.headline: Lord Farnham
fields.trailText: The 12th Baron Farnham, Barry Maxwell, who has died aged 69, was a top City banker and an Irish peer, who laboured mightily to improve the image of the freemasons.
fields.body:
The 12th Baron Farnham, Barry Maxwell, who has died aged 69, was a top City banker and an Irish peer, who laboured mightily to improve the image of the freemasons.

Although he originally joined the order in his native County Cavan, he rose within the English hierarchy to become, in 1991, pro-grand master of the 275-year-old United Grand Lodge of Ancient, Free and Accepted Masons of England.

He presided over the 25th anniversary celebrations of the installation of the Duke of Kent as its grand master, which attracted to Earls Court, London, more than 12,000 freemasons in full kit and was open to the press for the first time.

Farnham's rise was accomplished as much by his attractive personality as by his campaign to shed the freemasons' aura of secrecy, an aspiration which, in a hierarchical organisation, required considerable personal skills.

He had learned these mainly at the old City merchant bank of Brown Shipley, of which he was a director (1959-91), chairman (1984-91), and chairman of its holding company (1976-91). In 1990, just before his retirement, he also took over as chief executive, when the bank went into the red and before it fell prey to a takeover. By then, Farnham had also become chairman of Avon Rubber, chairman of Provident Life Assurance and a director of General Accident Life Assurance.

He was the son of Lieut Col Arthur Maxwell, the pre-war MP for Kings Lynn, who died in 1942 from wounds received at El Alamein. Originally from Lanarkshire, the family had settled in County Cavan in the 16th century. The title was created in 1756 for John Maxwell, the county's MP.

The 11th baron's grandfather sat in the House of Lords as an Irish representative peer. But, in 1922, Irish independence ended the speaking and voting rights of Irish peers, leaving them only with the right to listen from the steps of the throne. Farnham's attempts to restore his full access to the house were finally rejected in 1995.

He was educated at Eton and Harvard, before doing national service in the Royal Horse Guards. In 1958, his name was linked to Princess Alexandra, but the following year he married Diana Gunnis, who survives him, as do two adopted daughters.

 Barry Owen Somerset Maxwell, 12th Baron Farnham, banker, company chairman and freemason, born July 7 1931; died March 22 2001

fields.headline: The Tudor massive
fields.trailText: TV review: Henry VIII | Coronation Street
fields.body:
So it wasn't a traumatic childhood that turned Henry VIII into a blobby murderous monster, "a spot of blood and grease on the history of England". According to David Starkey's Henry VIII (Channel 4) - revised and updated for 2001 - li'l Hal led a rather charmed life in the royal nursery with his sisters.

There were weeping willows, fields of wild flowers and ye olde games with pieces of string. Verily, Henry, Mary and Margaret wore floppy hats and skipped merrily, if the ghostly reconstructions are to be believed. And since a lady-in-waiting was in charge of the nursery, it was clear that Henry's mum, Elizabeth of York, was in charge of their upbringing, even if she actually lived miles away in another palace. And you thought you-can-have-it-all superwomen were a 20th-century thing.

Even when Henry started his schooling, he enjoyed himself studying English, French, Astronomy, Latin, Arithmetic (which would come in handy later for counting wives) and History. He was the last lad you would expect to turn into a power-mad, priapic egomaniac. These are, as always, famous last words, since it's the quiet, seemingly jolly ones you have to watch. Apparently, Stalin was a teddy bear of a boy.

So Starkey escorted us on a (quite long) wander down the twisty-turny road of history to explain Henry's transformation and that of the England which he managed, and what a jolly informative scamper it was, charting the marriages, the divorces, the deaths, the wars, the politicking and the tumultuous rollercoaster of his reign. It was most exhausting just hearing about Henry's ups and downs, so no wonder the man took to comfort eating.

That parallels were drawn with more recent history - the death of Diana, the 1997 Labour landslide, the ructions in the House of Windsor - seemed initially naff, but since Starkey himself noted that the England of today is still Henry's, it was inspired stuff. Even if viewers in Scotland may have felt a bit left out.

All pursed lips and wide eyes, Starkey looks rather like a startled lemur, and he does dress like a character from The Fast Show, but still, he is rather captivating. It is not just his knowledge of and his passion for the subject, but also his many ingenious accessories. There was cheese to illustrate the differences between France (a moon of brie) and England (a lump of rubber cheddar), shears with which to lop the head off a thistle, to symbolise James IV of Scotland's defeat at Flodden, and many glasses of wine with no discernible purpose other than to whet Starkey's whistle. History is, it seems, thirsty work.

Once married to Weatherfield's own Henry VIII, Mike Baldwin, Alma had a lucky escape when she got a divorce (as opposed to a beheading). But now it seems the Grim Reaper has caught up with her, and she won't even get to see the rolling fields of Shropshire afore she goes.

In Coronation Street (ITV), her manfriend Frank made it clear he was as supportive and steadfast as the gusset in a pair of Underworld knickers when she told him of her cancer. If people could do that thing that cartoon characters do when they start running (you know, that mid-air revolving legs thing just before they zoom off), Frank would have done that last night. At least now Alma has justification for her look of permanent surprise.

(Were you of the conspiratorial bent, you might surmise that Alma and David Starkey are brother and sister who, when their parents' plane went down in the jungle of Madagascar, were raised by lemurs. These lemurs taught the pair not just their permashocked facial expressions but also how to peel bananas with their feet, which tree grubs are the tastiest and how to climb on sharp rocks without cutting themselves. Rescued some years later, the pair went their separate ways and forgot all about their banana and grub proclivities. Now, only their faces hold some reminder of their early years in the rainforest - and you might not even notice that if you weren't flicking between the two programmes. Jon Ronson, take a seat.)

So for whom will Alma turn to for support now? The self-centred Audrey? Ken in his crotch-hugging Jeremy Bowen trousers? Gail? Or old Leatherface himself, Mike? Hobson has taken his choice and left Alma with the rest. It's enough to make you turn to drink. Or history.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio: Between Ourselves | Evening Concert | Night Waves
fields.body:
Vicky Worner was married with three children when she decided to join a closed convent. As she explains in Between Ourselves (9.0am, Radio 4), it was something of a shock all round. Her children were naturally stunned, and the contemplative order which agreed to accept her, the Carmelites, had hastily to adjust many of its ideas. Though she burns for God, she remains unsure if she will stay.

It's a mite startling to stumble on a musical setting of Friedrich Nietzsche, whose ideas underpinned much of Hitler's appalling philosophy. In fairness, Nazism was not even a blip on the horizon when Delius completed his Mass of Life in 1908, and Nietzsche's concept of the Superman had not acquired its later baggage. The Mass takes up the whole of the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM).

The personal life of another German philosopher, Immanuel Kant, was as far from Nietzsche's man of action as one can get. His neurotically ordered routine enabled his neighbours to set their watches by his daily constitutional. Not surprisingly, the author of The Critique of Pure Reason has come down to us as a bodiless shadow who passed his entire life in contemplation. However, Richard Coles discovers in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) that Manfred Kuehn's new biography paints a very different picture, filling out the human detail that is absent from most history books.
