fields.headline: Tech deal maker turns manager
fields.trailText: Frank Quattrone, an investment banking specialist in the hi-tech sector, is discussing a change of role at Credit Suisse First Boston which would mean a shift of focus to private equity investing.
fields.body:
Frank Quattrone, an investment banking specialist in the hi-tech sector, is discussing a change of role at Credit Suisse First Boston which would mean a shift of focus to private equity investing.

CSFB stressed yesterday that Mr Quattrone, one of Silicon Valley's biggest deal makers, would remain as head of its technology group. However, any new fund would mean a shift in Mr Quattrone's activities from raising capital and takeovers to investing in companies themselves.

The talks, which are unlikely to result in a new fund until next year at the earliest, reflect the changed nature of the hi-tech sector after a year of falling share prices.

CSFB's fees from initial public offerings, once a staple of the group's profits, have plunged 97% so far this year, compared with the same period in 2000.

The bank has joined several others in announcing plans to sack investment bankers in recent weeks. Less than 20% of those are to come from Mr Quattrone's 400-member team.

One CSFB executive said the bank and its head of technology had been talking about a $1bn fund for some time. The talks with Mr Quattrone moved up a gear because of difficult market conditions.

"Now is an attractive time to buy some assets," he said.

The talks also come as Mr Quattrone's group is one of several targeted by a securites and exchange commission inquiry into the way technology bankers awarded the shares of the most popular IPOs during last year's "gold-rush" period.

A technology group spokeswoman said the talks had been predicated on Mr Quattrone's continued leadership.

webTitle: Satellite, cable & digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable & digital: The Adventures Of Robin Hood | Eyes Wide Shut | Vincent And Theo | La Belle Noiseuse | Hooked
fields.body:
Films

The Adventures Of Robin Hood (William Keighley, Michael Curtiz, 1938) 9pm, TCM
More than 60 years old, but still the best Robin Hood in the wood. It's played with enormous brio, Errol Flynn at his devil-may-care best as the hero, Olivia de Havilland his haughty but melting Maid Marian; and Basil Rathbone and Claude Rains make a fine dastardly duo as Guy of Gisbourne and Prince John. The non-stop, high-spirited action (Keighley was replaced by the more dynamic Curtiz), builds to a classic final duel between Robin and Guy ("You've come to Nottingham once too often..."); and all superbly photographed in the new, lustrous Technicolor.

Eyes Wide Shut (Stanley Kubrick, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
The subject is sex, so it's all the stranger that Kubrick concluded his brilliant career with a whisper rather than a bang. It's the story of a Manhattan doctor driven by fantasies of his wife's infidelity to take a sexual twirl on a sultry night, encountering temptation wherever he roams. As the couple, Tom Cruise seems out of his depth, Nicole Kidman more attuned to sexual danger; but at least as interesting as the on-screen action is what the performances said about the actors' own soon-to-end marriage. The film looks richly seductive and is entirely watchable, but, based on Arthur Schnitzler's Traumnovelle, set in Vienna nearly a century ago, it feels like a period piece.

Vincent And Theo (Robert Altman, 1990) 10pm, FilmFour
This haunting study of the relationship between Vincent Van Gogh and his art-dealer brother Theo is the first half of an excellent artistic double bill on FilmFour. Altman's film is also about the relationship between art and money, the painter grappling as much with day-to-day survival as his work. It's a compelling portrait, beautifully photographed by Jean Lepine and powered by superb performances from the art school graduate Tim Roth as Vincent and Paul Rhys as Theo.

La Belle Noiseuse (Jacques Rivette, 1991) 12.30am, FilmFour
The four-hour version, rather than the two-hour Divertimento, and worth every minute. It's a portrait of an artist (Michel Piccoli) and the very physical, emotionally draining nature of his art. Suffering for years from "painter's block" he rediscovers his muse in the shape of friend's lover Emmanuelle Béart; the friend, David Bursztein, and the painter's wife, Jane Birkin, grow increasingly jealous and suspicious: a richly absorbing picture, full of fine detail.
Paul Howlett

Documentary

Hooked 9pm, History Channel
Despite the perennial hysteria over drug abuse, it's become almost impossible to obtain reasoned information on the drugs themselves. Far from being some arcane branch of "alternative culture", this four-part series demonstrates just how central these drugs have been to modern life, and what a fascinating history they have. First up is cocaine,which was once endorsed by everyone from Sigmund Freud to baseball players to the Pope, was thought to cure everything from dandruff to alcoholism, and was outlawed because of racist paranoia rather than health concerns. Steve Rose

Eyes Wide Shut (Stanley Kubrick, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier The subject is sex, so it's all the stranger that Kubrick concluded his brilliant career with a whisper rather than a bang. It's the story of a Manhattan doctor driven by fantasies of his wife's infidelity to take a sexual twirl on a sultry night, encountering temptation wherever he roams. As the couple, Tom Cruise seems out of his depth, Nicole Kidman more attuned to sexual danger; but at least as interesting as the on-screen action is what the performances said about the actors' own soon-to-end marriage. The film looks richly seductive and is entirely watchable, but, based on Arthur Schnitzler's Traumnovelle, set in Vienna nearly a century ago, it feels like a period piece. Vincent And Theo (Robert Altman, 1990) 10pm, FilmFour This haunting study of the relationship between Vincent Van Gogh and his art-dealer brother Theo is the first half of an excellent artistic double bill on FilmFour. Altman's film is also about the relationship between art and money, the painter grappling as much with day-to-day survival as his work. It's a compelling portrait, beautifully photographed by Jean Lepine and powered by superb performances from the art school graduate Tim Roth as Vincent and Paul Rhys as Theo. La Belle Noiseuse (Jacques Rivette, 1991) 12.30am, FilmFour The four-hour version, rather than the two-hour Divertimento, and worth every minute. It's a portrait of an artist (Michel Piccoli) and the very physical, emotionally draining nature of his art. Suffering for years from "painter's block" he rediscovers his muse in the shape of friend's lover Emmanuelle Béart; the friend, David Bursztein, and the painter's wife, Jane Birkin, grow increasingly jealous and suspicious: a richly absorbing picture, full of fine detail. Paul Howlett Documentary Hooked 9pm, History Channel Despite the perennial hysteria over drug abuse, it's become almost impossible to obtain reasoned information on the drugs themselves. Far from being some arcane branch of "alternative culture", this four-part series demonstrates just how central these drugs have been to modern life, and what a fascinating history they have. First up is cocaine,which was once endorsed by everyone from Sigmund Freud to baseball players to the Pope, was thought to cure everything from dandruff to alcoholism, and was outlawed because of racist paranoia rather than health concerns. fields.headline: A May Day stroll
fields.trailText: Country diary: Cheshire
fields.body: With the sun shining out of a clear blue sky, my May Day walk took me again through the winding lanes that stretch out from the village. The hedgerows were now bright and green with the fresh leaves of the thorn bushes, and a closer look revealed the tiny clusters of tightly wrapped buds that would burst into flower in the next fortnight. In the meantime it was the blackthorns that were providing the colour, with dark and leafless stems and branches crowded with small, pure white flowers. The roadside verges were home to the dandelions, and their yellow carpet stretched as far as the eye could see, but it was here that the late emerging spring butterflies could be found feeding on the abundance of nectar. On one 100-yard stretch of embankment I recorded five species - comma, small tortoiseshell and peacock, with two male orange tips patrolling their respective territories over several small patches of hedge garlic, and a butter yellow brimstone, which soon flew off to continue the search for its offsprings' food plant, the alder buckthorn. Overhead, swallow numbers were building up, and I could see across the fields that most of the farms now had their summer pairs in residence; the birds were taking advantage of the puddles left by the previous night's rain to collect mud and small grit for their new nests. I found another example of the ongoing spring migration at the local riding stables, where five wheatears were enjoying a steady supply of flying insects over a field liberally covered with horse droppings. They would each choose their own small mound on which to stand, upright like toy soldiers, before darting away to left or right for their next meal.

webTitle: Cargo ship leak danger to Mull

fields.headline: Cargo ship leak danger to Mull
fields.trailText: Pollution experts were last night assessing the damage to a Swedish-registered cargo ship which ran aground off the island of Mull and began leaking diesel.
fields.body:
Pollution experts were last night assessing the damage to a Swedish-registered cargo ship which ran aground off the island of Mull and began leaking diesel.

The 3,000-tonne Lysfoss, which had been carrying paper and timber with a consignment of hazardous chemicals, issued a mayday call yesterday morning after striking rocks on the northern peninsula of the island.

Six of the crew were rescued unhurt but there were concerns about fuel leaking from the damaged hull. The vessel's port side was badly holed and began taking in water.

It was initially thought that up to 20 tonnes of fuel might have escaped. But Bill Spiers, district controller of Clyde coastguards, said the crew had managed to move fuel from a ruptured fuel tank into another tank and the spillage was smaller than feared. The ship had been carrying 30 tonnes of diesel oil and 180 of intermediate fuel oil, as well unidentified hazardous chemicals.

Mr Spiers said: "Now it is just a question of trying to salvage the vessel and get it off the rocks but we will be keeping a close eye on the pollution risk." He confirmed that the chemicals that had been on board were hazardous but said they were not thought to be posing any risk.

Later, coastguard officials said an initial salvage study of the ship suggested that it was unlikely to break in two.

The Lysfoss had been en route from Sweden to Belfast. The ship's master and engineer stayed on board the vessel as it was drained. Later, the six who were taken off returned to assist with the salvage.

A pollution control team from London was due to arrive at the scene, off the coast of Drimnin, by early evening. Islanders said any major spillage would be a disaster in an area known for its pristine coastline and rich fishing.

A Northern constabulary spokesman said measures were in place to protect fish farms from possible pollution.

fields.headline: The politics of lawyer-bashing
fields.standfirst: Lawyer-bashing is based on false assumptions. But that doesn't stop Tony Blair doing it
fields.trailText: Lawyer-bashing is based on false assumptions. But that doesn't stop Tony Blair doing it.
fields.body:
 If all the media stories predicting what the Labour government would do if it won the election were true, it would, I've calculated, need a legislative programme 17 years long. One of the more persistent, though always nebulous, stories around is that the prime minister intends "waging war" (almost always the phrase used) against fat-cat lawyers. But let's look a little deeper into that. The really fat cats do not trouble the public purse. We don't know exactly, because they don't reveal their tax returns to the media, but there's general agreement that there are around 20 barristers, perhaps a few more, who earn more than a million pounds a year. A few dozen more may be in the half-million-plus range. Almost without exception, they operate in the areas of law to do with commerce, finance, tax and the like. Their clients tend to be large corporations or other wealthy enterprises, and, occasionally, rich individuals. Their fees are high because their clients can afford them. Very rarely are they paid with taxpayers' money. I can't believe that it's the government's intention to interfere with agreements reached in the free market not involving public funds. There are, it's true, some QCs who earn a lot from legal aid, usually because they've been involved in one or two very long and complex criminal or family cases. The lord chancellor has already taken steps both to reduce their exaggerated fees and to restrict their presence in cases in which they're not necessary. It's possible that the government plans to open up the bar to more competition, as outlined by a recent Office of Fair Trading report; but that would hit ordinary, thin barristers far more than it would touch the incomes of the stout. The fact is that the fat cats against whom Blair Wars is allegedly going to be waged are few in number; any new initiative will make only a very small difference to the national bill for legal services. But it is good for a government to be seen to be bashing lawyers, even if the grounds for it are flimsy.

 There was a lot of lawyer-bashing, too, last week, following the May Day demonstrations. A couple of newspapers took exception to the probability that the police will be facing many claims for compensation over their tactics and conduct during the final, Oxford Circus phase of the demos. The Daily Mail also focused on the fact that a number of solicitors' firms were standing by to give legal advice and handing round their business cards. But what is wrong with that, provided, of course, the potential client is not taken for a financial ride by the lawyers and gets competent help and advice? Now Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has jumped on to the band-wagon, objecting to adverts by solicitors' firms in hospitals alerting patients to the possibility that they may have a legal claim. Again, I ask, what is the harm done? To whom? Lots of people land up in hospital because someone has committed a wrong against them, for instance, injured them by negligent driving. Many others are victims of clinical negligence by doctors or the hospitals themselves. I cannot see the objection to telling injured patients that they may have a legal right to compensation, and informing them of a law firm that might help. I will return to the subject soon, with particular reference to the misuse of the description "ambulance chasers".

 It's sad that I was a little surprised at Jack Straw doing the right thing in the criminal justice world. I was not alone in fearing that, when Sir David Ramsbotham's lively stint as chief inspector of prisons came to an end, he would be replaced by someone likely to be, shall we say, a little less forthrightly critical of the state of our prisons. The appointment of Sir David himself in 1995 was viewed suspiciously as an attempt to put in place someone more amenable to Home Office policy and the prison service than Sir Stephen Tumim had been. It didn't take long for Ramsbotham to prove his doubters wrong. He was fearless, robust and plain-speaking, often making prison officialdom and personnel very cross. So we were kind of expecting his successor to be a more shadowy, more establishment, less challenging figure. Not a bit of it. Anne Owers, currently director of Justice, is an inspired choice. She will be as firm and courageous as her predecessors - and as fair, paying tribute where due. Jack Straw could presumably have blocked her appointment in favour of someone more timid. He didn't, which is to his credit.

webTitle: Bosses' pay rises at triple inflation

fields.headline: Bosses' pay rises at triple inflation
fields.trailText: Directors of British companies received basic salary increases averaging 8% last year - double that of their employees and more than three times the annual inflation rate, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Directors of British companies received basic salary increases averaging 8% last year - double that of their employees and more than three times the annual inflation rate, according to a report published today.

A survey from Executive Remuneration Review found the rewards for chief executives running companies ranked in the FTSE 100's top 30 were worth a basic of just over £600,000, at the median, rising to £800,000-plus when bonuses were included.

Median basic pay overall was £394,400 for those running parent companies, against £150,000 for those in charge of subsidiaries, but the survey showed that directors continued to top up their salaries with packages including bonuses, share options, pensions and company cars.

Almost all the 95 companies responding to the survey said annual bonuses had been awarded, with the median level worth 24% of salary - similar to the previous year.

Some 58% of firms granted share options, representing 81% of basic salary. About 76% of executives either received a company car or the increasingly popular cash alternative, with the latter worth £47,500 for chief executives.

The report found the pay gap between men and women as pronounced in the boardroom as on the shopfloor. Only 10% of the 1,457 bosses covered by the survey were women, and their average salary was £145,000 compared with £181,300 for male counterparts.

Executives in the south of England receive higher salaries than those in other regions. The median basic salary in the south was £137,000, against £100,000 in the north and £97,000 in the Midlands.

fields.headline: Dirty tricks
fields.standfirst: When an Essex policeman tried to sue the NHS, claiming a knee operation had been botched, he was hoping for £300,000 for loss of earnings. In the end, a judge awarded him a fraction of that.  Esther Addley  reports on the rocketing trend in personal injury fraud - and the beginnings of a backlash
fields.trailText: When an Essex policeman tried to sue the NHS, claiming a knee operation had been botched, he was hoping for £300,000 for loss of earnings. In the end, a judge awarded him a fraction of that.  Esther Addley  reports on the rocketing trend in personal injury fraud - and the beginnings of a backlash.
fields.body:
It has not been a happy few years for Martin Cottrell, but last month things got very much worse. A former Metropolitan police officer from Chingford in Essex, Mr Cottrell was a keen footballer until he injured his right knee in 1994. An operation failed to fix the problem, and more than three years later he was still receiving treatment. Arguing that the operation had been botched and that he was barely able to work at the family cleaning firm, Mr Cottrell sued the NHS for a total of £300,000, as compensation for pain and loss of earnings.

Last month, a judge at the high court referred Mr Cottrell's case to the DPP, urging that he face a criminal prosecution for conspiring to defraud the NHS. While Redbridge NHS Trust had admitted that his operation was carried out negligently, the judge ruled that Mr Cottrell had colluded with his parents, wife and daughter to exaggerate the extent of his injury and wheedle as much money out of the trust as possible.

In part, he was trapped by technology. The NHS lawyers had become suspicious, and put Mr Cottrell under covert surveillance. Despite his complaint that he was still in considerable pain, a video taken last August showed him limping only very slightly. The judge awarded him £64,000 for the genuine injury, but concluded that his loss of earnings claim was "wholly bogus". Since Mr Cottrell had already turned down an out-of-court settlement, most of the award is likely to disappear in costs.

It is a sobering tale, but Martin Cottrell's story is unusual only in that he was caught. According to industry insiders, insurance fraud, particularly in the highly lucrative area of personal injury, is on the increase, costing insurance companies millions per year and pushing premiums skywards. Figures published by the National Audit Office last week showed that the NHS is facing claims for clinical negligence totalling a quite staggering £4bn, compared to only £50m in 1997-8. Extrapolating patterns from the insurance industry, it is likely that a significant chunk of these claims will be fraudulent.

While it is impossible, by definition, to measure how many bogus claims are paid out, fraud is certainly nothing new to insurers. But what is unprecedented, they claim, is the rise in claims specifically for personal injury. In part, this is due to a change in the law. Legal aid for personal injury was abolished in April last year; to compensate, the government lifted certain restrictions to the "no win, no fee" system, first introduced in 1995. Claims management companies now advertise widely on TV, arguing "where there is blame, there is a claim". The problem for insurers, and by extension for policyholders, is that claims are being brought where there was never any injury in the first place.

"We are concerned that the overall level of insurance fraud is increasing," says Suzanne Moore of the Association of British Insurers. "We are becoming a more litigious society, so it is likely that fraudulent personal injury claims are also on the up. Ultimately it's not free money, it's paid by policyholders." The ABI estimates that more than £700m a year is paid out on fraudulent claims, adding some 3-4% to insurance premiums. Others in the industry put the figure at anything up to 10%.

Bob Barnett, managing director of specialist fraud investigators Ravenstone UK, is one of the pessimists. "At one time, fraudulent claims didn't go on so much, but it's turned into a massive problem. People at one time wouldn't have dreamed of making a claim unless they were injured, but now it's at epidemic proportions."

The particular appeal of personal injury fraud is that it can be so lucrative. "If you look at the number of claims that are coming in, say for road traffic accidents, they are remaining fairly static," says Dominic Burch of insurers Direct Line, "but each one of those claims may now have a number of elements to it. If you have a personal injury claim in there, the cost shoots up. If you get whiplash and have to retire from work you're talking £20,000 to £100,000."

Injuries can also be reasonably easy to fake, or at least exaggerate. Whiplash injuries in particular are extremely difficult to disprove; some claimants may even be coached in how to complain of a particular soft tissue injury. "It's much easier to ignore the doubt, which many experts will do," says one investigator. "Unless there is very good evidence to counteract that, their claims will stand. Getting evidence that someone is lying is not very easy."

Personal injury fraud falls into two areas. The first is the opportunistic, small-scale cheat, who has had a genuine bump on the head or botched medical procedure, but is tempted to exaggerate the extent to which they have been incapacitated. They may also have had a bad back from twisting awkwardly in bed, which they decide they might as well attribute to the accident. Most frauds are opportunistic claims and most, therefore, are notoriously difficult to disprove.

The second type of scam is considerably more audacious. Two years ago a family from Preston were jailed for a total of 21 years for a clutch of bogus claims totalling £3m. According to claims brought against several different insurers, in the space of four months in 1990, Mohammed Sharif accidentally drove his car into his son Arif, his daughters Parveen (twice), Yasmin (twice) and Razia, and his son-in-law Abdul Raschid. Another son, Zulfiqar, even pretended to be incontinent, paralysed and a deaf mute for 15 years after a street attack. He was caught out when investigators filmed him working out in a gym.

Insurers are very reluctant to divulge the criteria that might bring a suspect claim to their attention, and sketchy in the details about how they try to trap them. Barnett admits to relying on a network of informants, as well as on whistleblowing from aggrieved or jealous friends. Suspect claims often cluster geographically, perhaps around a bent firm of solicitors or a doctor prepared to turn a blind eye. "We are looking for things that are interesting, suspicious or high risk," says Bill Trueman, head of fraud at Direct Line.

The other significant weapon available to insurers is surveillance, although not everyone is convinced of its legitimacy. Frances McCarthy, president of the Association of Personal Injury Lawyers, says: "Surveillance can be very upsetting. I had a case where a woman knocked on my client's front door saying, 'We are giving out free boxes of vegetables, but you'll need to carry it from the car because I am a woman.' He carried the box and he was filmed doing it, but it was obvious that the way he was carrying it was consistent with someone with a bad back." Solicitors working for the NHS will also admit privately that using public money to spy on injured people is a sensitive issue.

McCarthy argues that the use of surveillance and the publicity given to a few high-profile cases has created a culture of suspicion around all personal injury claims, concealing the fact that the vast majority are almost certainly genuine. "These are very serious happenings in people's lives and have very long-term consequences. People don't always realise the consequences of a major injury.

"Traditionally, people have been very slow to complain or take advice about pursuing a claim, but we see very strongly that health and safety becomes an issue only when claims are made. Sometimes litigation is the only way to prevent accidents. I find it surprising that there is an attempt to blame people who have been injured and suggest that they are in the wrong."

They may also have had a bad back from twisting awkwardly in bed, which they decide they might as well attribute to the accident. Most frauds are opportunistic claims and most, therefore, are notoriously difficult to disprove. The second type of scam is considerably more audacious. Two years ago a family from Preston were jailed for a total of 21 years for a clutch of bogus claims totalling £3m. According to claims brought against several different insurers, in the space of four months in 1990, Mohammed Sharif accidentally drove his car into his son Arif, his daughters Parveen (twice), Yasmin (twice) and Razia, and his son-in-law Abdul Raschid. Another son, Zulfiqar, even pretended to be incontinent, paralysed and a deaf mute for 15 years after a street attack. He was caught out when investigators filmed him working out in a gym. Insurers are very reluctant to divulge the criteria that might bring a suspect claim to their attention, and sketchy in the details about how they try to trap them. Barnett admits to relying on a network of informants, as well as on whistleblowing from aggrieved or jealous friends. Suspect claims often cluster geographically, perhaps around a bent firm of solicitors or a doctor prepared to turn a blind eye. "We are looking for things that are interesting, suspicious or high risk," says Bill Trueman, head of fraud at Direct Line. The other significant weapon available to insurers is surveillance, although not everyone is convinced of its legitimacy. Frances McCarthy, president of the Association of Personal Injury Lawyers, says: "Surveillance can be very upsetting. I had a case where a woman knocked on my client's front door saying, 'We are giving out free boxes of vegetables, but you'll need to carry it from the car because I am a woman.' He carried the box and he was filmed doing it, but it was obvious that the way he was carrying it was consistent with someone with a bad back." Solicitors working for the NHS will also admit privately that using public money to spy on injured people is a sensitive issue. McCarthy argues that the use of surveillance and the publicity given to a few high-profile cases has created a culture of suspicion around all personal injury claims, concealing the fact that the vast majority are almost certainly genuine. "These are very serious happenings in people's lives and have very long-term consequences. People don't always realise the consequences of a major injury. "Traditionally, people have been very slow to complain or take advice about pursuing a claim, but we see very strongly that health and safety becomes an issue only when claims are made. Sometimes litigation is the only way to prevent accidents. I find it surprising that there is an attempt to blame people who have been injured and suggest that they are in the wrong."

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Sidelines must protest at the recent glut of couples who feel that it is the world's duty to sit meekly and observe while they trumpet "We love each other THIS MUCH!" at varying pitches of hysteria.
fields.body:
Sidelines must protest at the recent glut of couples who feel that it is the world's duty to sit meekly and observe while they trumpet "We love each other THIS MUCH!" at varying pitches of hysteria. First was that pair who took the unnecessary step (geddit?) of getting married during the London Marathon, as though clogging up the streets with a margarine brand on your chest were something to be proud of - and not only that, but sexually aroused by to boot (geddit again?). Now we're presented with Fiona and Mike Thornewill, who at the weekend became the first married couple to walk to both Poles. Oh super. Love is a limitless journey of self-discovery and mutual exploration, of course, it goes without saying, but haven't these people heard of intercourse? Or going to the cinema in the afternoon, then getting drunk until it's time to go home? There is something unnerving about such eagerness to Do Stuff Together. And it reminds Sidelines of the word "wholesome", never a happy event.

Flowers, on the other hand, are so happy, they're delirious. According to research undertaken by the University of New Jersey, receiving flowers as a gift is most likely to have a long-term positive effect on mood. The study examined the responses of women aged 22 to 90 to receiving gifts, one of which was a bouquet. But note, if you will, the other items that were delivered to participants: a scented candle and a basket of fruit. No wonder blooms came up trumps. The candle assumes that you're the kind of woman who genuinely desires to spend hours in the bath, festering in your own dirty water, with one painted toenail up the tap, secretly fretting about the cotton content of your bed linen. The bowl of fruit will sit gathering dust until all the pears get ripe and go off at once, in the space of an hour (which may pass while you are asleep). I'd rather take the cash.

Finally, I am most distressed that nobody has expressed any interest in witnessing the execution of this column. Sidelines wrote to a selection of global media outlets, offering them the once-in-a-lifetime chance to watch me sitting in my chair, but nobody responded. Apparently, they'd all gone to the circus.

fields.headline: House of horror
fields.standfirst: Stuart Jeffries  is thrilled by a shocking addition to the Delacroix museum in Paris
fields.trailText: Stuart Jeffries is thrilled by a shocking addition to the Delacroix museum in Paris.
fields.body:
Just around the corner from the Saint-Germain cafes where Sartre and De Beauvoir used to hold court is the lovely little Place Furstenberg. Here the romantic painter Eugène Delacroix lived in a house that has since been converted into a museum. It's a lovely spot to visit in the Parisian spring, with a quiet blossoming garden and a delightful atelier. Admittedly the painting we've come to see concerns a mother about to stab her children to death in order to enrage her husband, but it's still a pleasant outing.

The exhibition Médée Furieuse (Furious Medea) brings Delacroix's still shocking painting of the murderous demi-god of a sorceress to Paris for the first time in ages. It's been moved from Lille to the Musée National Eugène Delacroix in Paris to be hung in his atelier in a fine historical exhibition that displays studies for and later versions of the work.

The exhibition is well timed. Paris has been awash in Medea studies since Isabelle Huppert brought her Avignon festival production of Euripides' play to the French capital recently. There's even a Medea musical.

The 1838 canvas, which outraged and entranced the salon of the same year, is the centrepiece of this exhibition. It's flanked by two versions Delacroix painted for rich people shortly before his death in 1863.

Delacroix had a thing about breasts. You can see that in the proud bosom of Liberty Leading the People (at the Louvre), or in the remarkable embonpoint of one woman in The Death of Sardanapalus (Louvre also). But Médée Furieuse, while maintaining the breast fixation, is less vividly coloured and less deliriously composed than such works. For his first mythological subject Delacroix became restrained, classical and reminiscent of the other leading French painter of his day, Ingres. Intriguingly, in the preparatory drawings for Médée Furieuse, the heads of her two children cover her breasts as though they were taking a suck for one last time before she dispatches them. In the final painting, however, the children's heads slump below her bosoms and are half throttled by their mother's arm. We catch the terrified eye of one child looking directly at us. While Medea's right arm holds the pair tight, the left hand clutches a dagger.

It's a wonderful gesture - at once maternally protective and unnaturally brutal. We see Medea's profile as she looks out of her cave in panic; she might almost be a protective mother holing up from some unseen threat. But in fact she is the threat - the wild animal - and her panic surely concerns what she is about to do.

Better yet, the sun is penetrating the cave, leaving only the top of Medea's head in shade. In Delacroix's painting, the line between dark and light races diagonally from an inch up her noble nose to the tip of her ear, making her look like a helmeted warrior - a female Achilles overwhelmed by ruthless rage. A fantastic painting.

 Médée Furieuse is at the Musée National Eugène Delacroix in Paris (01 44 41 86 50) until July 30.

fields.headline: Novartis buys 20% of Roche
fields.trailText: Novartis, Europe's third largest drugs group, yesterday appeared to open the door to further consolidation in the sector by snapping up a 20% stake in arch-rival Roche for about £1.95bn.
fields.body:
Novartis, Europe's third largest drugs group, yesterday appeared to open the door to further consolidation in the sector by snapping up a 20% stake in arch-rival Roche for about £1.95bn.

Analysts immediately suggested that the move was a prelude for a full merger of the two Swiss firms - despite the best efforts of both to dampen the speculation.

"At the moment it is a long-term financial investment, but obviously it opens up all the possibilities," said Novartis's chief financial officer, Raymund Breu, referring to his company's move.

Roche chairman Franz B Humer insisted: "We have a change here in one of the shareholders. Apart from that, nothing changes for us."

Novartis, which manufactures a wide range of prescription drugs, baby foods and health products, is buying the stake from billionaire Swiss financier Martin Ebner's BZ Gruppe Holdings.

Mr Ebner is throwing in the towel after a long-running campaign to modernise the shareholding structure and corporate governance practices at Roche - which many outsiders view as archaic.

The heirs to the holdings of Roche's founding families - the Hoffmans and Oeris- retain a majority control of the company, despite only owning 10% of the shares.

Roche - which is perhaps best known for antacid therapy Rennie - has struggled to increase earnings in recent months. Sales of its anti-obesity drug, Xenical, have failed to live up to expectations and several patents have expired.

Last month the Basle-based firm said it would review its operations and make significant job cuts. Novartis, on the other hand, has performed strongly, successfully launching a series of new drugs and growing business in the important American market.

It has thrown off the traditional cloak of corporate secrecy in Switzerland by listing its shares in New York, making its accounting more transparent and bringing in executives with international experience in the industry.

A combination of the two firms would create one of the three largest drugs companies in the world - roughly equal in size to Pfizer and GlaxoSmithKline. The latter two have pulled off major mergers of their own in the past 12 months, seeking ways of keeping annual earnings growth at 10% or more.

Analysts have speculated that a merged Novartis-Roche could look to do a deal with a big US healthcare firms such as American Home Products or Schering-Plough.

However, before anything can happen, Novartis would have to persuade the two families that control most of the votes at Roche that times have changed and that the company has to modernise if it is to remain a global player.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cancer 'error' man dies
fields.body:
Cancer 'error' man dies

A father of three whose throat cancer was missed by 11 different doctors has died in hospital in Sheffield. Steven Harley, 42, of Barnsley, had part of his tongue, his voice box and part of his jaw removed in November after he was told the surgery was his only chance of survival.

Briton held at US test site

Mike Townsley, 37, from Edinburgh, was arrested with an activist from Denmark after they gained access to a US army missile testing range on Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific Marshall Islands, Greenpeace said yesterday.

School beat for police

Police officers are to be stationed at secondary schools in Southwark, south-east London, Scotland Yard said yesterday. They hope to deter crime in schools and make it easier for young victims to report offences.

Protest against GM crops

Around 100 people took part in a protest yesterday at a proposed trial site for genetically modified crops in Mathry, Pembrokeshire. The land is owned by the former Conservative MP Tony Marlow.

Drug case five to learn fate

Five Britons charged with drug-related offences in the United Arab Emirates will be told of the court's judgment at the end of next week, the Foreign Office said yesterday. The five protested their innocence when the case was adjourned last month.

Student's ecstasy death

Lorna Spinks, 19, a student, died in hospital yesterday after collapsing at a Cambridge club early on Sunday. She had taken high strength ecstasy, police said. Two 19-year-old men have been arrested in connection with the supply of controlled drugs.

Girl, 5, killed in car crash

A five-year-old girl, believed to be from Warwickshire, died after her parents' car was in a head-on collision on the A52 in Lincolnshire, police said yesterday. A 25-year-old man was arrested in Grantham.

Laying it on with a towel

While 16% of people on weekend breaks pinch hotel towels, the figure for guests from the midlands is as high as 36%, according to an internet survey. It also claimed midlanders were three times more likely to be caught in lovemaking by chambermaids than visitors from elsewhere.

webTitle: Campaign tune echoes Elgar on a bad day

fields.headline: Campaign tune echoes Elgar on a bad day
fields.trailText: There is something very revealing about the choice of composer for the Conservative election theme - Mike Batt, the man who gave us Bright Eyes and the Wombles song, inflicted the wet T-shirt violinist Vanessa Mae on an unsuspecting public, and is behind the all-girl string quartet Bond, whose current promotional campaign drapes them around their instruments in Page 3 poses. Is the Tory party really so short of ideas that it cannot come up with something classier than that?
fields.body:
There is something very revealing about the choice of composer for the Conservative election theme - Mike Batt, the man who gave us Bright Eyes and the Wombles song, inflicted the wet T-shirt violinist Vanessa Mae on an unsuspecting public, and is behind the all-girl string quartet Bond, whose current promotional campaign drapes them around their instruments in Page 3 poses. Is the Tory party really so short of ideas that it cannot come up with something classier than that?

Batt has produced a piece of total vacuity. According to central office's press release, this theme tune, Heartlands, "embodies the music traditions of our United Kingdom, and conveys a very Conservative sense of pride in our country".

It works on the principle that if you repeat even the tritest melody often enough, people will eventually be conned into thinking that it is a real tune.

In fact this is at best half of a tune, a vaguely yearning horn phrase that does not go anywhere but just comes back again and again, louder and louder, until it reaches its final peroration, and we are released from our torment.

What starts off as Vangelis ends up as bad Elgar, with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra (who seem to be prepared to do anything as long as it is work these days) bolstering up the tawdry theme with suitably soupy orchestration.

There is an "upbeat" version too, "for use on the campaign trail" which is much the same only faster, complete with a vaguely dance track backing, and is just as awful. "I wanted the music to have gravitas", says Batt, "to have compassion and warmth of spirit, but at the same time, strength of purpose".

I am sure the whole Conservative party would like to have that too; perhaps Heartlands has got it right after all.

The writer is classical music critic of the Guardian

webTitle: MPC should elect to ignore politics

fields.headline: MPC should elect to ignore politics
fields.standfirst: Dilemma for the rate setters
fields.trailText: Dilemma for the rate setters
fields.body:
In one respect at least, the nine members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee are very much like the rest of us: they would like to put all thoughts of a general election out of their heads and get on with life as normal. The MPC starts its two-day meeting to decide the level of interest rates tomorrow and the City is increasingly of the belief that the outcome will be another reduction in borrowing costs. Some brave souls are even speculating that the Bank might opt for 50 basis points this time, bringing rates down to 5%.

However, the MPC's decision is due within 48 hours - and perhaps only 24 hours - of the prime minister firing the starting pistol for the election campaign. Would it not look a bit odd to be responsible for knocking a few pounds off the cost of 11m mortgages just as the phoney war ends and the real battle begins?

Surely it would be better for the Bank to sit on its hands for a month rather than presenting the government with a propaganda coup?

No doubt there will be a few rumblings if the MPC does cut rates, particularly since its four outside members are all hand-picked by the chancellor of the exchequer.

But the Bank's job is clear: it is obliged to hit the government's 2.5% inflation target and, within that remit, to be supportive of growth and employment. In its four-year life, the MPC has weighed up the pros and cons and made a judgment on economic factors alone. Stripping out the politics, evidence from both services and manufacturing last week suggested that the economy is slowing, and this may push inflation even further below its target.

In those circumstances, the Bank should not hesitate in lowering rates. To do nothing when it believes that something ought to be done would not just be bad for the economy, but bad for the Bank's reputation for independence as well.

Strategic stake

Novartis's decision to snap up BZ Gruppe Holding's 20% voting stake in fellow Swiss pharmaceutical group Roche has certainly intrigued investors.

The initial reaction is that Novartis - itself the result of a merger of Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy - must be looking for another leg up in the size stakes. A combination of Novartis and Roche would have annual pharmaceutical sales of $20bn (£14bn) - not too far behind the likes of GlaxoSmithKline and Pfizer.

Novartis argues it has three reasons for the deal. Roche is a good investment, the purchase opens up a number of strategic possibilities and it preferred to buy the shares itself rather than see the stake go elsewhere. Novartis might reckon Roche a good investment but the view is scarcely universal. Roche shares have underperformed the Dow Jones Stoxx healthcare index by 14% this year.

The strategic options will depend on the families which control Roche. Martin Ebner at BZ Gruppe Holdings is no slouch when it comes to pressing conservative boards into accepting reform but even he has grown weary of trying to make headway at Roche. It is, after all, his stake which Novartis has bought. The clincher for Novartis is surely the third of its stated reasons. Novartis may or may not be able to open up new strategic fronts at Roche but it will certainly have a big say over anything anybody else might be planning.

Snail wail

Last night the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, acknowledged that the process of international monetary and financial cooperation could often seem to be progressing at a snail's pace.

Sir Eddie had been doing a little research. Provided they keep going, snails can cover a fair amount of ground he told an audience in Zurich. The world's fastest snail has, he said, been clocked at 16cms a minute. Or, looked at another way, it could cover the journey from Zurich to Basle - home of the central bankers' talking shop, the Bank for International Settlements - in something under a year.

The trick of course, is to keep going. That, however, is not always easy. The European commission, for example, would like to fast track - among other legislation - EU financial services laws. Proposals to speed up the process which were drawn up by a committee headed by former central banker Alexandre Lamfalussy have already been endorsed by EU leaders. But the European parliament, not unnaturally, is worried that the process could undermine its powers of scrutiny. The end result is that the 2005 deadline for the liberalisation of EU financial services is loooking tricky.

Then there is the EU takeover directive. It has taken years to negotiate but just when it seemed to have cleared the last hurdle, the Germans have voiced reservations about a key area.

Could Sir Eddie's comparison have been a little unfair to snails?

A combination of Novartis and Roche would have annual pharmaceutical sales of $20bn (£14bn) - not too far behind the likes of GlaxoSmithKline and Pfizer. Novartis argues it has three reasons for the deal. Roche is a good investment, the purchase opens up a number of strategic possibilities and it preferred to buy the shares itself rather than see the stake go elsewhere. Novartis might reckon Roche a good investment but the view is scarcely universal. Roche shares have underperformed the Dow Jones Stoxx healthcare index by 14% this year. The strategic options will depend on the families which control Roche. Martin Ebner at BZ Gruppe Holdings is no slouch when it comes to pressing conservative boards into accepting reform but even he has grown weary of trying to make headway at Roche. It is, after all, his stake which Novartis has bought. The clincher for Novartis is surely the third of its stated reasons. Novartis may or may not be able to open up new strategic fronts at Roche but it will certainly have a big say over anything anybody else might be planning. Snail wail Last night the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, acknowledged that the process of international monetary and financial cooperation could often seem to be progressing at a snail's pace. Sir Eddie had been doing a little research. Provided they keep going, snails can cover a fair amount of ground he told an audience in Zurich. The world's fastest snail has, he said, been clocked at 16cms a minute. Or, looked at another way, it could cover the journey from Zurich to Basle - home of the central bankers' talking shop, the Bank for International Settlements - in something under a year. The trick of course, is to keep going. That, however, is not always easy. The European commission, for example, would like to fast track - among other legislation - EU financial services laws. Proposals to speed up the process which were drawn up by a committee headed by former central banker Alexandre Lamfalussy have already been endorsed by EU leaders. But the European parliament, not unnaturally, is worried that the process could undermine its powers of scrutiny. The end result is that the 2005 deadline for the liberalisation of EU financial services is loooking tricky. Then there is the EU takeover directive. It has taken years to negotiate but just when it seemed to have cleared the last hurdle, the Germans have voiced reservations about a key area. Could Sir Eddie's comparison have been a little unfair to snails?

webTitle: Tim Parks on Verona playing away to Lazio

fields.headline: The sweetness of defeat
fields.standfirst: Half of their supporters have been barred from the ground, they've had a player sent off and they never stood a chance of winning. But there is some joy when Verona play away to Lazio
fields.trailText: Half of their supporters have been barred from the ground, they've had a player sent off and they never stood a chance of winning. But there is some joy when Verona play away to Lazio.
fields.body:
Could there be anything better than opening your wallet and finding between the banknotes a ticket for a big match: "Lazio v Verona, Stadio Olimpico Roma. Settore ospiti"? And can there be any finer feeling than that moment, walking north along the Tiber, when casual Sunday passers-by are all at once transformed into a purposeful crowd? People were headed for the stadium. Only an hour and a half to kick-off.

Beer and sandwich beside me, I sat on the parapet of the Ponte Duca D'Aosta to soak up the scene and see what the local paper had to say about the game. After yet another defeat, the Hellas boys were in disarray. Their big Danish central defender Martin Laursen had accused his team-mates of not trying. Perhaps the team was about to go to pieces.

But Il Messaggero had nothing to say about the explosive situation in Verona's dressing room. Instead the paper was concentrating all its attention on another dysfunctional family: in the small northern town of Novi Ligure, a 16-year-old girl and her boyfriend had stabbed to death the girl's mother and younger brother. "She was a completely normal and very charming girl," said the next-door neighbour.

Perversely, even this horrendous story did not dissolve my dreamy pre-match state of mind. If these kids, I told myself facetiously, had gone to a few away games, screamed a few insults, spat from the windows of the supporters' bus, perhaps none of this would have happened.

Then a voice said: "Alè!"

I looked up from my paper. The fans of Verona and Lazio have what the Italians call a gemellaggio, a friendship arrangement. Could this be because both groups are considered racist? As a result, I was fearlessly wearing my yellow-blue scarf and Hellas hat, something that would have been madness were we playing AS Roma, whose more politically correct hooligans are famous for their knife attacks on the buttocks of opposing supporters. Now someone was asking me: "Do you know where our section is?" He too had a blue and yellow scarf, but he seemed morose, in need somehow. We set off together. Who would have thought that this glum man was about to confirm my dumb reflection that football might be a solution to all kinds of family crises?

"Bound to lose today," I tried. "So hardly worth worrying about it."

"Oh, it's not that."

"Best we can hope for is that Brescia and Vicenza lose too."

"Right."

We crossed the Lungotevere to the huge monolith raised to Mussolini Dux. Rome is the one town in Italy where you feel the arrogance of power weighing down on you. Everything is on a grander scale. No chance for Hellas, I repeated to myself.

At the end of the first half it was 2-0. Need I say to Lazio? Marco, my new acquaintance, had hung on beside me but said very little. There was a fierce tension about the man. He was well dressed, in his early 30s, had a pleasant, open face, but seemed angry. We were all angry, of course. With Perotti, our coach, and with the players. But he seemed angry with himself. He wasn't shouting.

Despite inevitable defeat, the spirit of the fans had been festive at first. We were enjoying being in this fantastically dramatic stadium, enjoying the warm welcome of the Lazio fans who roared out, "Vi salverete" - you won't go down - to console us after they scored. Some of them even had Hellas flags. Then news came through that the bulk of our supporters, in a couple of coaches, had been turned back by the police because they were drunk. To protest at this needless piece of cruelty - after all, there was absolutely no danger of violence at today's game - the chant leaders insisted that we all sit down and stop singing.

"Merda, merda, merda," Marco said.

As soon as we sat down, the team started performing. Only moments into the second half, our tiny Argentinian, Camoranesi, scored with a stunning volley from the edge of the box. Immediately Lazio got another. But amazingly Verona seemed to have taken over the game. They were doing all the attacking. The referee was the notorious Pierluigi Collina, the shaven-headed emblem of total authority. To be true to his iron-grip image, something he clearly works hard at, he suddenly and quite unexpectedly sent off the mild-mannered Martino Melis, Verona's left half. Melis had been given a yellow card in the first half for a foul from behind. Now Lazio had a free kick in midfield. Melis was about five yards off the ball and walking away. Collina blew his whistle. Melis half turned. The ball struck him. Collina immediately showed him a second yellow card and sent him off.

That did it. Marco suddenly snapped out of his gloom. His whole attitude changed. He was on his feet, kicking the steps, yelling abuse. "They're scared of us!" An improbable scenario. All the same, down to 10 men, Verona scored at once. Three-two.

The fans were now torn between the need to protest about police harassment and the desire to support the team. People kept jumping up and sitting down. Lazio scored another. Apparently it was over. But Perotti brought on the huge striker Michele Cossato, a man who hardly ever gets a game, and 10 minutes later he scored his first goal in Serie A. Four-three. Five minutes from time, Lazio keeper Marchigiani just touched a free kick round the post. Oh, we were so close to equalising! In the final seconds Lazio got a lucky fifth. Game over.

Throughout all this excitement Marco had been quite wild, and now, when the police prevented us from leaving, he grew even wilder. What possible reason could there be for keeping us, he demanded? We were twinned with Lazio. But the police were adamant. They kept us there an hour. When finally we got to the gates we were met by a mob of cheering Lazio boys eager only to swap scarves. "I've missed my fucking train," Marco groaned.

I too had time to kill, so we sat in a bar and he told me his story. Married with two children, he had planned to use the excuse of the away game in Rome to start an affair. He had met a woman at a conference recently. In any event, he had booked into a hotel last night and asked her out to dinner. She had a boyfriend but had sold the man some excuse. They had had a very intimate meal, then walked for a bit around the Piazza di Spagna. "But when it was time to invite her up to the hotel room, I didn't somehow."

Marco had then spent half the night and all of this morning eating his heart out over the wonderful sex he had passed up. He was convinced she was on for it. He couldn't understand why he hadn't been more decisive. "When I saw you on the bridge I was feeling like a complete fool."

But now he felt great.

"Why?"

"Don't know. It was the game. All that excitement. I thought we played pretty well, actually. I mean, you can't expect to win at the Olimpico. Che bastardo, Collina! But just being there, it's incredible. What a stadium. When the game ended, I just wanted to get home as soon as possible. That's why I was so furious with the police. Feel really glad now that I didn't do anything. You know the mess you get into if you start something with a woman."

"Nothing like" - I shook my head - "the mess Hellas are in."

His face clouded over. "What chance next week against Atalanta?"

Already we were wiring ourselves up, two family men on our second beer.

fields.headline: Brothers sought on woman's murder
fields.trailText: Police launched a hunt for two brothers yesterday after a young mother was murdered and her friend seriously injured.
fields.body:
Police launched a hunt for two brothers yesterday after a young mother was murdered and her friend seriously injured.

Elizabeth Hartley, 22, was stabbed to death at the home of her friend Kevin York, 34, who suffered chest wounds in the attack on Sunday night. Mr York staggered out into the street in Trowbridge, Wiltshire, to alert a passerby.

Police said the brothers, Jason and Timothy Seviour, who knew the murdered woman and her friend, were being sought in connection with the attack.

Detective Chief Inspector Norman McKeaveny issued a warning that the brothers were violent and should not be approached by the public. "Their behaviour is unpredictable, and they are urged to come and talk to us," he said.

"It is believed the two suspects were friends with the victims. At this stage we don't know what the reason for this attack was."

Police said there had been no signs of a forced entry into Mr York's house and no obvious signs of a struggle.

Forty police officers were carrying out a fingertip search for the murder weapon and conducting house to house inquiries.

Ms Hartley was pronounced dead at the scene. Mr York was taken to Royal United hospital in Bath, where he was in a "comfortable" condition last night.

At a press conference at Trowbridge police station, Mr York's mother, Christine, said her son and Ms Hartley "were just good friends" and had lived in the same street all their lives.

They had come back from a drink in town and had gone for a Chinese takeaway, then got a taxi home.

"My son was nearly killed. Our families have been close friends for years. Liz was part of me," Mrs York said.

"I got a phone call saying my son had been rushed to hospital and that I should get there as soon as possible. I don't know why anyone would want to attack them."

Ms Hartley, who leaves two young children, is understood to have been estranged from her husband and is better known locally as Lizzie Cooper.

Her sister, Teresa Cooper, sobbed at the press conference, saying: "She was only 22."

A neighbour, Janet Shergold, said: "I have known the Coopers during the 20 years they had lived in the same street. We have always got on well with the Coopers and the Yorks. They are both decent families."

Police urged anyone spotting the brothers, who are also from Trowbridge, to dial 999 or call the Wiltshire force on 01380 722341.

Jason Seviour, 22, was described as white, 5ft 6in, of medium build, clean shaven with short fair hair and scarring to the right side of his face. He was wearing a dark baseball jacket.

Timothy, 20, was described as white, 6ft 1in, of medium build, with short fair hair and blue eyes and wearing similar clothing.

Neither brother can drive, so they were expected to have used a taxi or other means of transport to leave the area.

webTitle: From the bars of Rio to the bars of Belmarsh

fields.headline: From the bars of Rio to the bars of Belmarsh
fields.standfirst: Fugitive faces British justice - and a chance to enjoy healthcare he could not afford in Brazil
fields.trailText: Many things have changed in the 35 years since Ronnie Biggs last set foot in the UK, but the process of being fingerprinted and photographed on his return to a British prison yesterday was at least vaguely familiar to the train robber.
fields.body:
Many things have changed in the 35 years since Ronnie Biggs last set foot in the UK, but the process of being fingerprinted and photographed on his return to a British prison yesterday was at least vaguely familiar to the train robber.

Since news of his imminent return from Brazil emerged last week, the Home Office has insisted that Biggs would not receive special treatment, and that despite his failing health he would be dealt with like any other escapee. So yesterday, after a 13-hour flight from Rio, an eight-minute hearing at West London magistrates court and a 70-minute drive across the capital to Belmarsh high security jail in Woolwich, south-east London, Biggs went through the formal prison reception procedure.

On arrival he would have been signed over to prison officers by Securicor escort guards and watched as his belongings were logged and packed into clear plastic bags. He would then have been taken for a reception interview with a senior officer. His details will have been placed on a computer and he will have been issued with a prison number, different to the one he left behind when he scaled the walls of Wandsworth prison in 1966.

Biggs will then have been searched before being offered the option of keeping the beige trousers, yellow shirt and blue pullover in which he arrived in the UK, or trading them for the standard Belmarsh uniform of blue jeans, a blue shirt and a tracksuit. His prints and portrait will then have been taken for the prison files.

Next, Biggs will have been examined by a prison nurse during which the question of suicide risk would have been ad dressed. In view of his frail condition - he has had three strokes in two years and cannot speak - he is then likely to have been assigned a bed on Belmarsh's three-storey hospital wing, either on a general ward or in one of the individual cells with its own toilet and sink, usually reserved for those who pose a danger to themselves or other inmates. There, Biggs will get what he came for: healthcare of a standard he could not afford in Brazil.

By the standards of British prisons, Belmarsh offers excellent healthcare, with in and outpatients facilities, primary care, therapeutic and psychiatric units, an intensive care suite and observation rooms. As a new inmate Biggs will also be entitled to a well man clinic in which inmates are advised on a healthy lifestyle. Oxleas NHS healthcare trust works closely with the prison and, should Biggs require treatment outside Belmarsh's walls, he will most likely receive it at the nearby Queen Elizabeth hospital in Woolwich.

High security

While Biggs yesterday cut a pitiful figure in contrast to the playboy rogue of tabloid myth, his new home is at least appropriate for a man with a notorious criminal reputation. Belmarsh is part of the prison service's high security estate and houses around 800 remand and convicted prisoners, among them some of the most dangerous men in Britain. It has an internal "citadel" and a tunnel to the cells at Woolwich crown court.

According to the Home Office, Biggs will remain there for at least a fortnight before being assigned to another jail. In normal circumstances inmates are watched over a period of weeks by officers and probation staff to assess what risk they pose. "Most people you have to keep in for several weeks to see if they have any deviant tendencies," said a spokeswoman for the prison service.

While he waits for a decision on his permanent home, Biggs will be subject to the same regime as other Belmarsh inmates. He will take his first prison breakfast at 8.40am today and, if fit, would work or take classes until 11.30am when inmates return to cells and eat lunch. Between 2.15pm and 5pm inmates return to work or education, before evening lock-up. On alternate nights prisoners have around two hours of association, before lock-up at 8.30pm. As a convicted prisoner, he will be allowed one visitor a week in addition to legal visits, which are likely to be frequent in the coming days.

The police have indicated that Biggs will not be charged with the offence of escaping and yesterday is likely to be the last time he appears in court, barring incident. Even so, Biggs's legal team has much to ponder as they seek to persuade the Home Office that their client is eligible for early release despite having served just 15 months of a 30-year sentence.

His solicitor, Jane Wearing, said yesterday that she would be seeking a hearing before the court of appeal "in respect of his outstanding sentence". In the event of the court agreeing to hear an appeal against the sentence 35 years after it was passed, it is unlikely to do Biggs any good. While some observers at the time of the original trial felt 30 years excessive for armed robbery, even a reduced sentence would be likely to see Biggs facing 15 to 20 years. Only a reduction to two years or less would see him with any prospect of immediate release.

His best chance, and the most likely avenue for his advisors, is to seek release on compassionate grounds. Under the 1991 Criminal Justice Act the home secretary has the power to release prisoners on licence in exceptional circumstances. Reggie Kray was released from jail last year while suffering from terminal cancer, although unlike Biggs Kray had been eligible for parole for some years.

Applications for compassionate release are made in the first instance through the prison governor, who will take advice from medical and probation staff. If the prisoner has a very short time to live, poses no risk to the public, or has suffered a tragic bereavement, then the home secretary may order their release, but being an ill old man is not enough. Ironically for Biggs, his best chance of tasting freedom, and the pint he has been dreaming of, lies in having weeks rather than months to live.

As a convicted prisoner, he will be allowed one visitor a week in addition to legal visits, which are likely to be frequent in the coming days. The police have indicated that Biggs will not be charged with the offence of escaping and yesterday is likely to be the last time he appears in court, barring incident. Even so, Biggs's legal team has much to ponder as they seek to persuade the Home Office that their client is eligible for early release despite having served just 15 months of a 30-year sentence. His solicitor, Jane Wearing, said yesterday that she would be seeking a hearing before the court of appeal "in respect of his outstanding sentence". In the event of the court agreeing to hear an appeal against the sentence 35 years after it was passed, it is unlikely to do Biggs any good. While some observers at the time of the original trial felt 30 years excessive for armed robbery, even a reduced sentence would be likely to see Biggs facing 15 to 20 years. Only a reduction to two years or less would see him with any prospect of immediate release. His best chance, and the most likely avenue for his advisors, is to seek release on compassionate grounds. Under the 1991 Criminal Justice Act the home secretary has the power to release prisoners on licence in exceptional circumstances. Reggie Kray was released from jail last year while suffering from terminal cancer, although unlike Biggs Kray had been eligible for parole for some years. Applications for compassionate release are made in the first instance through the prison governor, who will take advice from medical and probation staff. If the prisoner has a very short time to live, poses no risk to the public, or has suffered a tragic bereavement, then the home secretary may order their release, but being an ill old man is not enough. Ironically for Biggs, his best chance of tasting freedom, and the pint he has been dreaming of, lies in having weeks rather than months to live. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: • Hundreds of UK jobs could be under threat after US computer networking firm 3Com announced plans yesterday to axe 30% of its worldwide staff.
fields.body:
 Hundreds of UK jobs could be under threat after US computer networking firm 3Com announced plans yesterday to axe 30% of its worldwide staff.

Some 3,000 jobs are being cut by the Californian group in a bid to slash annual costs by $1bn(£700 million) and move back into profit.

The group employes 800 people in the UK, across its European head office in Winnersh, Berkshire, a research facility in Hemel Hempstead, Herts, and a development site in Edinburgh.

A spokeswoman for 3Com said the UK would be hit by the cuts but the exact number of job losses would not be known for about six weeks.

She said: "We have to go through a consultation period in the UK and then we will know what the final outcome will be."

The heads of each business unit would be working out their own business plans to determine where jobs may be lost, she added.

3Com's chief executive Bruce Claflin announced the cuts in the US before stock markets on Wall Street opened for trading.

He said the company had been hit by softer demand and lower prices over the second half of the year. The cuts were a necessary step "in our plan to restore profitability", he added.

 Eight European countries, including Britain, will today (tuesday) defend aviation pacts they have struck with the United States, denying accusations from the the European Commission that they are breaking EU law.

The court case will have a major impact on future liberalisation of air traffic between the European Union and the United States and so-called "open skies" arrangements which give foreign airlines free access to other countries airports.

The Commission, the 15-nation bloc's executive, has for years been pressing to negotiate such a deal with the United States on behalf of all 15 EU countries.

But national governments snubbed the request, many of them preferring to sign individual U.S. deals during the 1990s, much to the annoyance of Commission officals who say these agreements distort what should be a single EU market.

The eight countries concerned - Britain, Germany, Sweden, Denmark, Belgium, Austria, Finland and Luxembourg - will appear in the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg to defend their deals. The court is not expected to give a ruling for several months, officials said.

 IXEurope, the internet hosting company that was forced last year to pull a £300m flotation, has closed a new funding round that it claims will give it enough cash to reach profitability.

Existing investors European Acquisition Capital, Bank of America Equity Partners and JP Morgan Partners have agreed to put up €19.5m (£12m) of new money, which IXEurope says will enable it to become cash flow positive in the first half of next year.

IXEurope specialises in managing customers computer and server requirements from state of the art buildings equipped with high-speed telecommunications links.

The company was planning to float until November last year when deteriorating stock market conditions and the poor performance of rival TeleCity forced it to pull the issue.

The funding market for internet hosting firms remains tight but is showing signs of recovery. In March Cityreach raised €40m of new cash to add to a total of €260m raised since it was set up at the end of 1999.

However, industry projections that the internet hosting market will eventually be worth £5bn are being questioned by some analysts because many of the centres still have tens of thousands of square feet of unleased space on their hands.

IXEurope has now raised a total of €104m. It has eight operational data centres across Europe with two in London and others in Dusseldorf, Frankfurt, Milan, Nice, Paris and Zurich.

Its customers included Hewlett Packard, NTT, Cable & Wireless, Enron, Nikon and Attenda.

 Shares in top German power utility E.ON fell yesterday after two large shareholders, insurer Allianz and the state of Bavaria, said they had begun talks to cut their stakes to help the group win U.S. approval for the purchase of Britain's Powergen.

Last month, UK utility Powergen agreed a €8.2bn takeover bid from E.ON but Powergen owns a utility in the United States - LG&E - where regulations require any non-utility shareholdings in E.ON to be cut to below five percent.

 Retail therapy is losing its allure as shoppers opt to spend more on trips abroad or eating out, according to a report released today (tues).

Average income is on the up but little of this extra cash is being spent on clothing or furniture as people become bored with going to the shops.

Retail consultancy Verdict said many high-street chains now face a challenging future unless they can inspire customers to come to their local store.

Just below one-third - 32.9% - of all consumers' spending goes on the retail sector today, compared to 47% in 1980.

Verdict chairman Richard Hyman said: "There are now lots of other things we can spend our money on now compared to ten to 15 years ago and retail is losing out as a result of that.

"Retail sales are not diminishing, they are not going backwards, but they are growing very slowly, more slowly than its costing these companies to stay open."

webTitle: Regulators pass Reed's takeover of Harcourt

fields.headline: Regulators pass Reed's takeover of Harcourt
fields.trailText: Reed Elsevier's plans to establish itself as one of the world's largest players in the education publishing business received a huge boost last night after US regulatory authorities cleared its proposed £3.1bn acquisition of American group Harcourt General.
fields.body:
Reed Elsevier's plans to establish itself as one of the world's largest players in the education publishing business received a huge boost last night after US regulatory authorities cleared its proposed £3.1bn acquisition of American group Harcourt General.

Analysts had feared that the market power of the combined group might force Reed to dispose of some publications to get the deal approved by the US Justice Department but instead it waved the deal through.

Part of the Harcourt business is expected to be sold to Thomson, the Canadian business information company, for £1.4bn subject to government approval.

Shares in Reed, which have this month fallen by around 20p to trade at 663p amid growing concerns that the inquiry may have unearthed some problems, are expected to bounce back when markets reopen this morning.

Competition authorities in Germany, Austria and Ireland have also cleared the deal.

The last remaining hurdle to the completion of the acquisition is an ongoing inquiry by the UK competition commission into the effect that the merged company would have in the market for scientific, technical and medical journals.

The Government surprised the stock market and Reed by announcing in February that it would probe the deal on competition grounds even though official data showed the market share in Britain would be no higher than 15%.

Less than 1% of Harcourt's total group revenues come from the disputed markets in the UK.

On Friday Reed asked for the offer period for the deal first announced in October to be extended until June 4 to take account of ongoing regulatory issues.

webTitle: DiData takes on Compaq in bidding war

fields.headline: DiData takes on Compaq in bidding war
fields.trailText: IT services firm Dimension Data yesterday underlined its determination to grow in the US by launching a bid for an internet consulting firm that has already agreed a takeover with the giant Compaq Computer Corporation.
fields.body:
IT services firm Dimension Data yesterday underlined its determination to grow in the US by launching a bid for an internet consulting firm that has already agreed a takeover with the giant Compaq Computer Corporation.

DiData, as the South African based but London listed company is known, is attempting to gate-crash an agreed takeover of the New York based Proxicom by offering 30% more than the $266m (£185m) that Compaq has tabled.

The $7.50-per-share cash counter-offer values Proxicom at $448m, or $376m when the cash on its balance sheet is taken into consideration. At the height of the dot.com boom Proxicom shares traded as high as $50, valuing the firm at almost $3bn.

However, Proxicom said it had not modified an earlier recommendation to shareholders that they approve the Compaq deal and the proposed counter-offer remains on a knife edge. Compaq has three days to decide whether it wishes to match the DiData offer.

DiData's group strategy director, Richard Came, said he saw Proxicom as "an ideal fit" to enhance its e-business integration business, which helps integrate network infrastructure and application software.

Awareness of the DiData brand in the US would also be boosted, he said.

The Johannesburg headquartered firm made US expansion a priority after trans ferring its main listing to London last summer. It raised £1.5bn to go on an acquisition spree and has since bought up several small US firms.

A takeover of Proxicom and its 1,000 staff would be DiData's s biggest US deal to date and give it access to customers like America Online, General Electric, General Motors and Merrill Lynch.

DiData is due to report first quarter results next week. They will be closely watched by analysts after the profit warnings from Cisco.
