webTitle: After 35 years, Biggs is back in jail

fields.headline: After 35 years, Biggs is back in jail
fields.trailText: The moment Ronnie Biggs has spent most of the last 35 years trying to avoid came just after 9am yesterday. Minutes after the private jet that had flown the last fugitive of the great train robbery from voluntary exile in Brazil touched down at RAF Northolt, Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles boarded the aircraft.
fields.body:
The moment Ronnie Biggs has spent most of the last 35 years trying to avoid came just after 9am yesterday. Minutes after the private jet that had flown the last fugitive of the great train robbery from voluntary exile in Brazil touched down at RAF Northolt, Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles boarded the aircraft.

"Are you Ronald Arthur Biggs?" he asked the frail, sunken-eyed figure. The Scotland Yard detective produced a warrant for being unlawfully at large and with the words "I am now going to formally arrest you" brought to an end the 13,068 days Biggs had spent on the run.

Within hours, the man who was for years Britain's most wanted criminal was back behind bars more than three decades after he escaped from Wandsworth jail where he had served 15 months of a 30-year sentence for his part in the heist of the century.

From Northolt, Biggs, 71, and debilitated by three strokes, was taken to Chiswick police station where a doctor declared him fit to appear before a district judge at West London magistrates court. After an eight-minute hearing, the fugitive was sent to the high-security confines of Bel marsh prison in south-east London, to resume his sentence.

The shuffling figure clutching a walking stick who made his way into the silent courtroom under the stare of the massed ranks of the press and court staff appeared a shadow of the man who had thumbed his nose at British justice as he lived out a playboy lifestyle on the beaches of Rio de Janeiro.

The gaunt figure was only able to respond to questions from the clerk of the court with a grunt and a police doctor repeatedly passed him handkerchiefs so that he could wipe away the saliva dribbling down his chin. Biggs confirmed his name and date of birth before summoning enough energy to puff out his chest when asked if he was the man sentenced at Buckingham assizes on April 16 1964 to 25 years imprisonment for conspiracy to stop mail and to 30 years for robbery with aggravation.

"I'm satisfied that you are the person named in the warrant and have been unlawfully at large," district judge Tim Workman said. "The law requires me to return you to prison, which I will now do."

With that, Biggs, his white hair combed loosely over his head, shuffled from the dock to be led down the stairs and through a back entrance of the court where he was put into a waiting Securicor prison van and driven away.

His legal team immediately announced that he would be seeking a hearing before the court of appeal against his outstanding sentence.

"All he seeks is a fair and balanced hearing at which all relevant issues can be addressed," said Jane Wearing, of Leftley Mallett solicitors.

"Mr Biggs is not in good health. The authorities responsible for his welfare are aware of this and he will receive proper medical attention as soon as possible."

Biggs spent the last of his £147,000 share of the 1963 train robbery long ago and it was his failing health that led him to turn to the Sun to orchestrate his journey home.

The exercise has been a massive coup for the paper, although the press complaints commission yesterday said that it will conduct an investigation into the affair which it claimed raised a number of issues under the newspaper code of practice relating to payments to convicted criminals. Biggs's son Michael is reported to have received £20,000 in "expenses" with the mastermind of the great train robbery, Bruce Reynolds, and his son, Nick, getting £12,000 each.

A spokesman for the Sun said the PCC code was taken fully into account before it decided to fly Biggs home "at no cost to the British taxpayer".

webTitle: Warnings of safety problems in water industy

fields.headline: Warnings of safety problems in water industy
fields.trailText: The government needs to take urgent action to review the water industry, otherwise the safety problems that have arisen in rail and gas will hit another essential public service, the Consumers' Association will warn this week.
fields.body:
The government needs to take urgent action to review the water industry, otherwise there is a significant risk that the safety problems that have arisen in rail and gas will hit another essential public service, the Consumers' Association will warn this week.

"This is the most crucial time for water since privatisation, with fundamental changes proposed," said the association's policy adviser on utilities, Caspar Henderson.

"If competition is not properly managed, there is a risk that substandard water will get into the water system, that further competition will force prices up for some users and that consumers will be exposed to liabilities when companies fail. But the government has been dragging its feet."

The association's fears echo those put by the Public Utilities Reform Group and the main water union, Unison, to the environment select committee this year. The reform group said it was concerned the trend towards using specialist contractors could lead to another Railtrack.

Unison also questioned the benefits of the proposed changes: "We have serious concerns that they are based on the interest of bonds markets and owners, rather than a rational appraisal of the benefits to customers. The concept of these new ownership structures contracting out their operations to five or six main contractors and many more subcontractors might make the safety issues of Railtrack problems look small."

In its draft water bill, the government proposes to introduce more competition into the industry. There are 10 monopoly network operators in England and Wales which supply water and run the sewage systems in the areas they serve.

Under new plans, companies will be able to compete both to supply a "common carriage" network of pipes and to retail water to customers, while existing water companies remain monopoly network operators.

The CA says the draft water bill has flaws. It is sceptical that the benefits of introducing common carriage competition will outweigh the costs of implementing it.

Consumers in rural areas and those on low incomes could be hit with higher prices - some bills could rise by more than half - as companies cherry-pick the most lucrative customers, the CA warns. Cross-subsidies, which ensure everyone pays the same for their basic water needs, could unravel.

The water industry was privatised in 1989, and since then around £34bn of capital investment has been spent on services and environmental improvements. But the improvements have been paid for by consumers.

According to the environmental audit committee, consumers' water bills have risen on average 36%, and sewage bills have risen 42% in real terms, in the 10 years since privatisation. The cost of capital is the single biggest cost and accounts for about one-third of consumers' water bills.

As privatised monopolies, the water companies are regulated by Ofwat, which decides how much companies need to spend on the network and then how much they can charge. In the first price review, the water companies put in what are now regarded as hugely inflated estimates of what they needed to spend to deliver services. They significantly underspent and tended to delay investment until the end of the price period.

Private company profits rose 147% in the seven years after privatisation. Accusations of excessive profits and fatcat salaries coincided with droughts and water rationing in the 1990s. The regulator responded by imposing substantial price cuts in his 1999 price review, about 12.5% on average.

Now the companies are facing lower financial returns and shares have been trading at about 25% less than the value of assets as assessed by the regulator. The system of 26 integrated water companies is unravelling with corporate changes and proposed restructuring.

They significantly underspent and tended to delay investment until the end of the price period. Private company profits rose 147% in the seven years after privatisation. Accusations of excessive profits and fatcat salaries coincided with droughts and water rationing in the 1990s. The regulator responded by imposing substantial price cuts in his 1999 price review, about 12.5% on average. Now the companies are facing lower financial returns and shares have been trading at about 25% less than the value of assets as assessed by the regulator. The system of 26 integrated water companies is unravelling with corporate changes and proposed restructuring.

fields.headline: Transco loses gas leak records
fields.trailText: Transco, the privatised monopoly that operates Britain's gas pipe network, has admitted that it has lost its regional records of the number of gas leaks left for repair.
fields.body:
Transco, the privatised monopoly that operates Britain's gas pipe network, has admitted that it has lost its regional records of the number of gas leaks left for repair.

Industry sources told the Guardian that the number of gas leaks yet to be fixed had doubled in London and Scotland in the past two years.

But Transco's director of regulation, Chris Bolt, who was formerly the acting rail regulator, said last week that he did "not recognise these figures" and the company put out a statement saying that the number of such leaks had been reduced by 50% nationally in the last year.

But the company's external affairs manager, Graham Frankland, has admitted that Transco can neither confirm nor deny the figures for London and Scotland. "Prior to 1999, the figures were kept locally. When we went out into the regions we found that the data was not being retained," he said. Data is available for 2000, when "we saw there was a need to retain the information centrally", he added.

In 2000, 9,500 leaks were left to be repaired later in north London, and 8,400 were rescheduled in Scotland. Union sources said these figures were double what they were two years previously.

According to the south-east regional organiser for the GMB union, Ed Blisset, lost records were a serious problem. "Constant managerial changes have led to the loss of records and confusion. My engineers are being asked to work on pipes they can't find and they don't know what type of pipes they are."

The health and safety executive is investigating Transco's records.

Mr Blisset said the crisis of staffing - Transco has admitted it needs to recruit 1,000 engineers across the country this year alone - and the state of the pipework and records meant gas was "a disaster waiting to happen in conurbations".

The former gas regulator, Clare Spottiswoode, said that during her tenure "Transco quite often didn't have the data we thought it should". She also said she had had discussions with the HSE and Transco about how many engineers they should have to maintain safety.

She said: "We knew engineers would be needed in all the companies after deregulation and that British Gas had taken the lead in training in the past, so we put a lot of effort into it in the early days.

"That was Transco's responsibility and we had to make sure they had money for it. Once I had done that I had no further role to play. The HSE should have been monitoring it." Transco claims it has met all its safety observations.

fields.headline: Life and crimes of a train robber
fields.trailText: August 1963 On his 34th birthday, Biggs is a member of a 15-man gang that holds up a London to Glasgow mail train, stealing £2.6m (around £50m today). The train driver, Jack Mills, is beaten round the head and never works again
fields.body:
August 1963 On his 34th birthday, Biggs is a member of a 15-man gang that holds up a London to Glasgow mail train, stealing £2.6m (around £50m today). The train driver, Jack Mills, is beaten round the head and never works again

1964 Biggs is tried separately to the rest of the gang after the jury accidentally hears he has served time in prison. Sentenced to 30 years

1966 After 15 months in Wandsworth prison, Biggs escapes, scaling a 25ft wall with a rope ladder and jumping on to an open-top furniture van with a mattress inside to break his fall

1966-70 Biggs moves from London to Paris to Australia

1970 After being recognised, he flees Australia, boarding a boat to Panama, then flying to Brazil on false passport

1974 Daily Express tracks him down in Rio and he indicates he is ready to come home. But the paper tips off Scotland Yard and Det Chief Supt Jack Slipper flies to Brazil to arrest him. From a cell, Biggs discovers his girlfriend, Raimunda de Castro, is pregnant, and as the father of a Brazilian national he is immune from extradition

1975 Michael is born

1979 Appears alongside Sex Pistols in film The Great Rock'n'Roll Swindle. Later fell out with their manager, Malcolm McLaren, over royalties.

1981 Kidnapped by mercenaries who take him to the Caribbean and plan to sell him to the highest bidder. Authorities in Barbados refuse them entry and Biggs returns to Brazil

1981-2001 Increasingly short of money, Biggs is forced to trade on his infamy, charging tourists £70 a head (including signed T-shirt) to attend barbecues at his home

May 2001 Is imprisoned in a London jail after surrendering to British police from Brazil

Jan 2002 Loses an appeal to have his 30-year sentence reduced

July 2002 Marries his former Brazilian lover, Raimunda Rothen, in a ceremony at Belmarsh high security prison

Jan 2004 Is admitted into hospital several times for chest infections

Oct 2005 Told that health is not bad enough to be released

July 2007 Is moved from Belmarsh prison to Norwich prison on "compassionate grounds"

Dec 2007 Biggs issues a further appeal asking to be released from jail to die with his family

fields.headline: Mayor's blueprint for London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone will unveil the blueprint for a massive redevelopment of London today which is to allow the population to grow by nearly 10% to 8.1m.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone will unveil the blueprint for a massive redevelopment of London today which is to allow the population to grow by nearly 10% to 8.1m during the next 15 years without triggering social collapse or transport gridlock.

In the first strategic plan for the capital for a generation, the mayor will seek an alliance with property companies by offering them opportunities for profitable, high-density housing developments in return for a guarantee that at least 50% of the new homes will be rented at affordable prices.

The plan will reject policies for dispersing people to other parts of southern England. Mr Livingstone will say this would be an environmental disaster for the green belt and would ruin Britain's "world city", a linchpin of the global economy.

Instead, he plans to accommodate London's natural population growth and net inward migration which, if recent trends persist, would add 700,000 people - and 500,000 households - by 2016.

The projected need for more than 33,000 new homes every year for the next 15 years is much larger than the government's suggestion that the London plan should provide for an extra 23,000 households a year to 2006.

Under Mr Livingstone's plan, developers would be encouraged to provide offices and homes near big new transport intersections created by construction of cross-London rail lines. They would be told to restrict parking space to make residents rely on public transport.

The biggest developments will be on brownfield sites in the East End, around the interchange with the proposed Channel tunnel rail link at Stratford, and in corridors leading to Stansted, Gatwick and Heathrow airports.

The proposals are part of the first consultative version of a "spatial development strategy" that the mayor is required by law to produce. A more detailed formal document will be considered by a government-appointed panel next year.

The mayor's final plan, subject to direction by ministers, will set out the planning framework within which the London boroughs will have to work.

Mr Livingstone will say he is aiming for a consensus around plans for higher population densities. "People like living in urban areas, close to the facilities and services they need. That is one of the reasons why house prices in Knightsbridge and Islington - some of the densest urban areas in London - are so high.

"We must ensure that London exemplifies urban renaissance by developing at higher densities in more attractive urban environments, linked to public transport services," he will say.

Nicky Gavron, the deputy-mayor and one of the main architects of the plan, said it would not give developers a free hand to put up 40-storey skyscrapers. In return for profitable opportunities to build and sell swish penthouse flats, they would be required to provide social benefits, including affordable homes for the city's workers.

At least 35% of the units built should be available for social renting, and 15% for people on moderate incomes.

"This plan is the silver bullet that hits all the targets for accommodating population growth, rejuvenating local econmies and making the city environmentally and socially sustainable, and less dependent on the motor car," she said.

The plan says London ranks alongside New York and Tokyo as one of three genuine "world cities". London is "the UK's only opportunity to maintain a world city, and the success of the UK economy as a whole is dependent upon the success of London".

The city has to expand to the east and south, the report will claim.

New high-density housing would be "located in places with adequate public transport... This will allow car parking to be limited and will help ensure that the growth in journeys created by the growth in population is accommodated, as far as possible, within the public transport network.

"The layout of sites should be designed primarily for the needs of pedestrians, not cars."

The plan says half the new homes are likely to be in the central London riverside boroughs, Docklands and the Thames Gateway, the area around the river's eastern approaches to the city.

Areas identified as prime opportunities for development in central London included Paddington, King's Cross, South Bank and Elephant and Castle. In the longer term there would be development at transport intersections created by the Thameslink 2000, CrossRail and Hackney-South West rail lines.

Instead of suburban sprawl, there would be regeneration of 10 square kilometres of development land in the Thames gateway near some of London's greatest concentrations of deprivation. There would be an "arc of opportunity" in Newham to shift London's employment and residential focus towards the east.

Three regional development corridors would be created in the Lea valley leading out towards Stansted, the "western wedge" from Paddington towards Heathrow and the Wandle valley, including Croydon, and stretching towards Gatwick.

The plan is not costed at this stage, but it calls for London to retain a larger share of tax revenues to redress years of under investment.

It proposes socially balanced communities, built around more public buildings and shopping in local town centres.

The document includes plans to protect wildlife, relieve an acute shortage of cemeteries and recycle more of the 18m tonnes of waste produced by the capital each year. It also warns that London's flood defences are at risk from rising water levels caused by global warming.

fields.body:
Nick Denton, 35

www.moreover.com

What does it do? Aggregates news sources from 1,500 company websites.

How it's gone: Has secured the backing of Reuters, admits times are tougher, but claims Moreover has enough cash to see it through to profitability. Pocketed a few hundred thousand pounds from the sale last summer of network ing club, First Tuesday.

Valuation: Paper fortune of around £10m, up from £3m, but not yet turned into cash.

fields.headline: James Corsellis
fields.trailText: Icollector
fields.body:
James Corsellis, 30

Icollector

What does it do? Online auction service.

How it's gone: Corsellis moved from CEO to become deputy chairman in January 2001. Icollector entered into joint deals with CNN and the FT. In September sold their web consultancy business, CM Interactive, which raised capital to be invested back into the business. Launched joint site with ebay, which brought in 29 million customers. They now represent 100 auction houses and recently had 1,200 people bidding online.

Valuation: "The value of the share price has dropped by about 90% plus, and I don't even bother to look any more."

fields.headline: Robert Bonnier
fields.trailText: www.Scoot.com
fields.body:
Robert Bonnier, 30

www.Scoot.com

What does it do? Online equivalent to Yellow Pages.

How it's gone: The Dutch-born entrepreneur looked to have pulled off a coup when the online directory service won the backing of media giant Vivendi Universal last year. Scoot shares soared, valuing the firm at more than £2bn, and Bonnier at £140m, but have fallen sharply since then and the company is now thought to be looking for a buyer.

Valuation: £4m.

Mark Bernstein, 40

Gameplay

What does it do? Online games portal.

Valuation: Down from £7m to £1.5m.

www.Jungle.com

Still working for Jungle but has other ideas up his sleave. Working on Globalshed.com, a DIY portal, with friend and former Big Breakfast presenter, Johnny Vaughan.

fields.headline: Paul Barry-Walsh
fields.trailText: Netstore
fields.body:
Paul Barry-Walsh, 44

Netstore

What does it do? Data warehousing via the internet.

How it's gone: Floated on the stock market in April 2000, reported a loss of £1.1m and is valued at £27m. Barry-Walsh also sold his computer disaster recovery firm, SafetyNet, last June, pocketing £70m, and used the proceeds to set up a charitable foundation called Fredericks. Invested in 10 companies, hoping the money raised will fund the foundation.

Valuation: Around £87.5m last time, now nearer £70m.

fields.headline: If you ask me..
fields.standfirst: I have a son who is in his last year of A-levels. He has now realised that he needs to put more effort into his studying but still does not accept advice readily. He is studying physics, maths and chemistry and is predicted B, B, C or higher. He is currently achieving beneath this. The school takes the view that the students should not be monitored and have to work things out themselves. Do you have any ideas for revising?
fields.trailText: I have a son who is in his last year of A-levels. He has now realised that he needs to put more effort into his studying but still does not accept advice readily. He is studying physics, maths and chemistry and is predicted B, B, C or higher. He is currently achieving beneath this. The school takes the view that the students should not be monitored and have to work things out themselves. Do you have any ideas for revising?
fields.body:
The most useful revision anyone can do is based on past exam papers, which you can get from the exam board or buy from the publishing houses. Most pupils get hold of the papers and try to do them, which is no good because they don't get marked. The way to use them is to go through the paper and identify the elements that are being tested: is the question asking you to use Pythagoras's theorem or repeated integration, for example. Look at the papers to analyse which topics are being tested and which come up the most.

Also, look at the size of each topic. If there is one that invariably comes up, but that doesn't involve retaining a huge amount of information, revision pays off. Some topics, like heat transfer, are enormous but there is usually only one question on them in the exam paper. Looking at the size of each bit of the syllabus and the number of times it crops up is a sensible way to work out how to use your time wisely.

One general piece of exam advice that can't be repeated often enough is never to leave a question blank on a multiple choice paper. A blank is automatically wrong; but a guess has a one in four chance of being right.

Jean Gemmell
Acting general secretary, Professional Association of Teachers

This boy is probably feeling vulnerable, miserable and worried, but there is plenty he can do. He may not want to take advice from his parents but there are plenty of other alternatives. There is a website at bbc.co.uk/radio1/essentials where 17- and 18-year-olds have a message board for people struggling with all kinds of revision - some of it is chit-chat but there is some good solid content, people asking for help and getting it. It's important to know that everybody goes through this, however confident they may seem.

It's also important for this father to accept that his son's revision isn't his responsibility. It's horrible for parents, but there is very little they can do in these situations. Yes, they can be supportive, but ultimately it's the child's own responsibility. It's good preparation for life: whether you go on to university or a job, you will be judged on your motivation, and the way you work is a key skill for success.

Parents need to convey that they are not nagging or getting angry, but that they care - which is easier said than done with a teenager. They can suggest dividing revision into manageable sessions, perhaps two hours a day, half an hour at a time, so it doesn't seem such a huge mountain. And they can help by providing a nice place to work, and offering anything the student needs, from bacon butties to box files. But the most important thing for parents is to be patient and stay calm.

Karen Johnson
Executive editor, BBC Education

This is a demanding trio of subjects and revision does need careful planning. Perhaps this boy's peer group would be the best place to start looking for help. He could work with his friends, see what they're doing, and they would be able to help each other. But I would have thought the school would have some kind of revision programme: after all, it's as much in the interests of the school as the pupil to get good exam results, though it's true that at A-level you do need to take some responsibility yourself.

In the first instance I would get the son to approach his teachers again and ask for specific advice on the best way to tackle his revision. If a fairly negative attitude comes back I see no reason why the parent shouldn't go into the school and ask the same questions. After all, the teachers will know better than anyone which text book chapters or notes will reinforce his weak areas. The school should also be able to point to appropriate revision areas on the web.

Arthur De Caux
Education officer, National Association of Head Teachers

Coming next

My daughter has failed her 11-plus and is devastated. Today we found out that she failed her first appeal. The only way I can justify her marks is that she just had a bad day. Is it worth pursuing?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020-7239 9933 or email to: education.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: The school that opted out of Northern Ireland's state system

fields.headline: By the book
fields.standfirst: When denomination means more than securing a good school for your child, it matters that the education minister is an ex-IRA man. Especially to Ian Paisley's schools. By Rosie Cowan
fields.trailText: When denomination means more than securing a good school for your child, it matters that the education minister is an ex-IRA man. Especially to Ian Paisley's schools. By Rosie Cowan
fields.body:
The little ones gather round to hear the young woman teacher telling, in a lively, straightforward way, the story of Naaman the Leper. It's as if the trials of the ancient Syrian army captain happened just yesterday.

Even the youngest in the small class of eight primary 1-4 pupils enthusiastically joins in as they complete their worksheets, quickly grasping the meaning of the tale - that he was cured of his disease when he did God's bidding with childlike faith and obedience.

It's a fitting moral for the independent Christian school, which has just 22 pupils (eight of them post-primary) and four teachers in a small, one-storey building in Ballymoney, County Antrim. The school is one of seven, spread throughout Northern Ireland and run by Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterian Protestant church, which have opted out of the state system in order to give children the strong religious grounding they feel is missing in mainstream education. Sinn Fein education minister Martin McGuinness, who last week admitted being an IRA leader in Derry on Bloody Sunday, would most definitely not be a welcome visitor.

At first glance, Ballymoney's three classrooms are much like any other school, the walls packed with brightly coloured drawings, books, charts and other learning aids.

But the world map with photographs of local missionaries, the prominent display of bible quotations, and the names of the pupil houses - Luther and Calvin - give some clues to its crucial core values.

Bible study and prayer are a major part of the curriculum and fundamentalist values pervade every subject. The children don't play team sport on a regular basis, nor do they have any formal contact with state schools. Sex education is banned, and, while pupils learn about evolution and the Big Bang, they are taught these are false theories; the creation story as recounted in Genesis is the only truth.

Pupils do not have to be Free Presbyterians. The organisers say Roman Catholics are welcome, as well as other Protestant denominations. But all parents have to be Christians who accept the school's ethos of strict discipline and corporal punishment.

"Many state schools are a nightmare, with whimpering, nerve-wracked teachers at the mercy of an unruly mob," argues the plain-speaking Rev Ivan Foster, convenor of the Free Presbyterian church's all-male education committee (women are barred from being ministers or elders). Foster's wife, Ann, started the first independent school in Kilskeery, County Fermanagh, in 1979. His six children all attended the school, and his eldest daughter is now head of the independent school in Newtownabbey, County Antrim.

"We believe in putting God first and this requires discipline," he says. "We see our schools as an extension of the Christian family, where a homely atmosphere is maintained and the teacher takes on the role of a strict but loving parent."

Most of the schools opened in the 1980s and pupil numbers have stayed fairly static since then; a total of 350 pupils, aged four to 18, attend. They receive no state money and each is run separately by its local church congregation, with parents, teachers and other church members involved in ongoing fundraising.

Parents pay a small annual fee: £275 for the first child, and lesser amounts for siblings attending the same school. Foster admits parents are required to devote time and effort to the school, but claims they are rewarded with the knowledge that their children are well looked after and not falling under harmful influences.

"Sending your child to one of our schools requires sacrifice. Not huge financial sacrifice, but parents have to be prepared to belong to that school - fundraising, taking part in activities, for maybe 10, 12 years - and many people are not prepared to make that sacrifice." He bluntly dismisses as psychological goobledegook any suggestion that pupils' education or social skills could suffer due to isolation from the modern world.

"The world was built on small schools," he says. "I was educated in an 11-pupil school in the mountains of Fermanagh. We don't want our children mixing with others who blaspheme and sin. That is the point of taking them out of the system."

Ironically, he is in agreement with McGuinness on one point - that children should not be streamed or sent to different schools at the age of 11. The education minister is currently conducting a wide-ranging review into the controversial selection procedure in the state system. Those at the independent schools, however, do not sit the 11-plus; pupils continue at the same school for their post-primary years.

"We feel the 11-plus is a contradiction and there is no point in preparing our children for the state system if they are staying with us," explains Foster. "We take every child we can and take them as far as we can, making full use of their talents, whatever their abilities. Our standards are excellent. A poor year for us is when only 75% of pupils get five GCSE grade A-C passes."

The Ballymoney pupils' day opens with 15 minutes of hymn singing and prayers. There is a 15-minute prayer for missionaries and the sick after break, and another 15 minutes of Bible study after lunch.

"Morality is dealt with in every sphere," says Foster. "We don't teach children about sex because sex education today is about contraception and abortion, how to sin without paying the penalty."

Ballymoney principal Jemise McIlhagga, a friendly, energetic woman in her early 30s, agrees that there can be no middle ground over moral issues.

"Sex before marriage, abortion, homosexuality, these are not matters for debate," she says. "God has told us what is right and we must abide by his rules."

The children have two classes of bible study a week, and one scripture recitation, from the King James authorised version-"not some watered down kiddies edition," stresses McIlhagga. Grace is said before lunch and even before the children eat their break-time crisps and chocolate bars. "If we can bring God into a lesson, we will," she explains. "For instance, having so many of our missionaries all over the world makes a useful introduction to other countries in geography, and a reminder that God made heaven and earth."

McIlhagga, who became a Christian at the age of six, was deeply unhappy in her previous job, teaching chemistry at a state secondary school for 10 years, but now feels she has found her professional haven.

"There was no place for God at that school," she explains. "Even amongst the other staff, there was bad language and immorality. The concept of putting God first was completely alien." Teachers' wages in the Free Presbyterian schools are about £250 a week, much lower than the state norm, but for committed church members who see their jobs as religious vocations, it is a labour of love.

"When I heard the principal of this school was going to Kenya to become a missionary, I prayed about coming here and God told me to come. This job is a vocation and you are called to it as to a ministry," she says.

"There is an appalling lack of discipline in some schools. If the pupils rule the teachers then they can't teach. Christians are meant to examine their own behaviour and correct it. But our system works well and I personally have never had to smack a child."

The small classes and the homely atmosphere, with families heavily involved in the day-to-day running of the school, can, she says, work wonders.

"I love this school. I have more work than I ever had, and our salaries are nowhere near the state wages, but it is not a drudge. You don't have to drag yourself in to face cheeky children."

The small classes and the homely atmosphere, with families heavily involved in the day-to-day running of the school, can, she says, work wonders. "I love this school. I have more work than I ever had, and our salaries are nowhere near the state wages, but it is not a drudge. You don't have to drag yourself in to face cheeky children."

fields.headline: Age and innocence
fields.standfirst: Academics nearing retirement are just as vulnerable to prejudice as other older people
fields.trailText: Lynne Segal
fields.body:
"Never in human history has a population so wilfully defied nature as has the present generation." With this bold statement, gerontologist Tom Kirkwood kickstarted this year's Reith lectures. The series has generated far less controversy than usual. Ageing remains the depressing turn-off, the great taboo, the feared and yet, inevitably, necessary political topic we cannot completely ignore.

So let me try to turn your thoughts to ageing and its vicissitudes in the contemporary academy. I'm not sure which generation Kirkwood has in mind, but for a while my own one, graduating into careers at the end of the Sixties, had a mellow ride in the academy.

Indeed, in the 1980s, it seemed we were almost all over 40; the barriers for young people trying to join us grew higher, with little expansion, few new jobs. Exploding student numbers with new criteria for government funding at the close of the decade turned our world upside-down, and there has been little wilful defiance of anything at all since: administrative or natural.

The fickle trajectory of this generation in higher education is instructive. The older we get, the harder we work. That in itself may be no bad thing. Regular mental exercise "preserves patterns of neuronal interconnection that might otherwise atrophy from disuse," Kirkwood broadcasts. The twist is this. The harder we work, the less we feel valued in the current purely fiscal accounting of all things. Approaching retirement age, some colleagues are producing what will be their best work and remain the most confidently inspiring teachers, yet they can feel like the living-dead, knowing forced retirement will mean they have no place in the next-but-one Research Assessment Exercise.

Meanwhile, the ambitious young academics now being eagerly hired to work more cheaply alongside us are discouraged in a different way. Forced into immediate over-drive in the hope of promotion which often does not come, too poor for pleasing accommodation, too busy for parenting, many cannot live the lives they would choose.

The defiance Kirkwood refers to, of course, is the "longevity revolution", our lengthening life-span and the material possibilities for staying healthy in old age. This immediately suggests we might consider raising, or abandoning, the compulsory retirement age. But then we confront more hurdles.

The first is the increasing cultural horror of ageing. The older the population grows, the more we value youth. This is especially true of attitudes to women, who have only just entered the academy in large numbers. It is we who will live longest, but who are soonest placed on the futile treadmill to stay forever young, who must battle hard to avoid social invisibility and condescension.

Economics lecturer John Lloyd recently wrote he feared he might become yesterday's man when he was no longer "a key team member". But yesterday's man generally receives much more attention than his female colleagues. His decreasing workloads sometimes even allow him to spend more time with those children he may have in his second family, with a much younger woman, as yesterday's man becomes tomorrow's dad.

However, he may be as alarmed as his mid-life female colleagues by the second hurdle. It comes from the imposition of a type of enterprise culture which values speed of output over the accretion of insight and scholarly pedagogy: with online learning systems, for example, pretending they can (in the words of the chief executive of Unipart) help staff learn and function "at the speed of light".

At the least one might hope the serious money now designated for lifelong learning has been inspired by and will benefit the troops who constitute the longevity revolution. But even this is not quite as one might wish, causing Martin Shreeve (director of Better Government for Old People) to point out at the Reith lectures that opportunities for older people to benefit from university education are meagre.

Further education does attract a wide age range, but new schemes are largely targeted at the young or those in work. It has lost much of the community orientation which once attracted older people and others outside the workplace to Workers Educational Association classes.

These would have been just the people most concerned about issues like globalisation and a more equitable sharing of the world's resources. If they do still want to join the debate on why their own life expectancy is double that of their sisters and brothers in many parts of Africa they will have little choice now but to expose their own infantile dementia, accompanying those wild-eyed youths in Oxford Circus next May Day.

Lynne Segal is Anniversary Professor of Psychology and Gender Studies at Birkbeck College, London University.

webTitle: Jewish charity gets nod to run national adoption register

fields.headline: Jewish charity gets nod to run national adoption register
fields.trailText: A leading Jewish charity has emerged as the government's surprise choice to run the national adoption register for England and Wales, due to be launched in July.
fields.body:
A leading Jewish charity has emerged as the government's surprise choice to run the national adoption register for England and Wales, due to be launched in July.

Norwood Ravenswood has been announced as "preferred bidder" for the contract to operate the register, which is seen as key to improving the adoption system. The central database will hold details of children awaiting adoption and of families approved to adopt, with local authorities able easily to look further afield if adoption cannot be arranged locally.

Although Norwood Ravenswood is an established child and family services charity, and itself operates a voluntary adoption agency, eyebrows will be raised that the register contract is not to go to British Agencies for Adoption and Foster ing (BAAF). When ministers last year embarked on adoption reforms, BAAF was chosen to coordinate a working group to produce a set of national standards. The umbrella organisation also runs its own, embryonic register and publishes a monthly magazine, Be My Parent, which profiles children seeking adoption.

It is thought that BAAF was among some half-a-dozen organisations which bid for the register contract, but that their tender prices varied widely.

John Hutton, social care minister, believes the register will be crucial in achieving the government's target of a 40% increase in adoptions from local authority care. "The bid Norwood Ravenswood submitted was particularly strong and met all the necessary specifications," Hutton says. "I very much look forward to working with their team and hope we will be able to award them the contract to run the new register shortly."

The charity was formed in 1997 by the merger of Norwood Child Care and the Ravenswood Foundation, which worked with children and adults with learning disabilities. Ruth Fasht, for the charity, says the register is "an exciting project which has the potential to help link up hundreds of looked-after children with suitable prospective adoptive parents".

Felicity Collier, BAAF chief executive, says: "The register provides a really important opportunity to connect more children with more families. We are pleased that a decision has been made and look forward to working alongside Norwood Ravenswood to help ensure this potential is realised."

fields.headline: Job Channel launches text message service
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A digital TV-based recruitment outfit is launching the 'first' SMS text messaging jobs service. By Ashley Davies.
Useful link: jobchannel.tv
fields.body:
A digital TV-based recruitment outfit is launching what it claims is the first SMS text messaging jobs service.

The Job Channel, an online jobs database operating on interactive digital TV platforms, kicks off the new service today.

Initially users must log onto the digital channel to register for a position in order to have their search results or new job alerts sent to their mobile phones.

In two weeks time, users will be able to input their information via a website if they do not have interactive TV.

Most of the channel's suppliers are recruitment agencies, spanning a number of sectors.

Simon Parker, marketing manager of Multimedia Television, which owns the Job Channel and MMTV, said he had bought 100,000 messages which he expected to use in the next couple of months.

"I don't know why no-one else is doing this. It's simple and easy and not that expensive to buy the messages," he said.

fields.headline: Desmond set to sell porn portfolio
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Richard Desmond is close to selling his troublesome portfolio of top-shelf magazines, writes Dan Milmo.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express newspapers owner Richard Desmond is close to selling his troublesome portfolio of top-shelf magazines, but will hang onto his X-rated Fantasy Channel station.

His Northern & Shell company has found three buyers for the magazines, which include adult titles such as Asian Babes and Forum, and a sale should go through within three months.

The news is a public relations coup for the publishing tycoon, who is desperate to shake off his "porn baron" reputation and put the titles on the block at the beginning of the year.

A spokeswoman for Northern & Shell confirmed the imminent sale, but declined to name the buyers or reveal a price for the deal.

"Three companies have been short-listed, and are being subjected to due diligence procedures. Northern & Shell are at the stage where they are simply choosing the buyer," said a spokeswoman for Northern & Shell.

It is understood that Mr Desmond has offered the stable of magazines to several overseas businesses.

The magazines are owned by Mr Desmond's Portland Investments and Fantasy Publications companies, but his money-spinning adult Fantasy Channel will not be included in the sale.

The continued presence of the Fantasy Channel in the Northern & Shell group could scupper Mr Desmond's plans to float his publishing empire, which is valued at £500m.

City advisers will think twice about associating themselves with a company which still has links with the porn business.

Mr Desmond has also been forced into a sale for financial reasons, with Portland's latest accounts showing that the magazines lost £870,000 in 1999, and Fantasy Publications lost £815,000 in the same year.

Analysts have suggested the titles may fetch up to £20m.

Last year's £125m acquisition of the Daily Express, the Sunday Express and the Daily Star from United Business Media was financed by a £97m loan from Commerzbank, sparking a cost-cutting spree at Northern & Shell.

The publisher of OK! magazine is following the lead of porn tycoon David Sullivan, who recently gave away his adult titles after complaining that the porn publishing business was past its sell-by-date.

fields.headline: UK music site fails to launch
fields.trailText: 8.30am: US music giant Launch Media has shelved plans for a British version of its website, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
US music giant Launch Media has shelved plans to launch a British version of its website.

Launch.co.uk had already recruited staff and was looking for a European partner to inject cash into the venture.

But sources say the UK launch has now been postponed indefinitely due to market conditions and the eight staff will lose their jobs.

They include chief executive Dominic Hardisty, who was previously operations director at the Financial Times, and two senior editors, Jim Irvin and Jenny Bulley, who were poached from Emap's Mojo last year.

It has been suggested the Nasdaq-listed Launch Media might have another crack at Europe should conditions improve.

But the company is now concentrating its energies on reigniting investor confidence in its flagship site, Launch.com, after shares sunk below the $1 mark last month.

At its peak two years ago, Launch Media's shares were priced at $25.

The news will add to the woes of the already depressed internet music business, which has found it difficult to make users pay for services and downloads.

United Business Media has been looking for a buyer for its internet music operation, dotmusic since November last year.
